column2: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said he would consult William J. Bratton, a former police commissioner in New York, and consider deploying the army to curb violence.
Markets continued this week’s pattern of wild swings between gains and losses, as earnings and jobless data got investors hunting for bargains.
A show at Asia Society is devoted to the splendors of the ancient Buddhist civilization of Gandhara, which flourished in northern Pakistan.
A Greek salad on a bun makes a satisfying meal.

The Monkees abruptly cancelled the last nine dates on their reunion tour Friday, including several concerts in New England, the BBC reported. Three of the original members of the made-for-TV band - Micky Dolenz, Davy Jones and Peter Tork - went back on the road earlier this year after a decade without performing. All three released statements Friday, saying the tour marking the band's 45th anniversary could not continue, without specifying the reasons.

CAREY--Hugh. My deepest condolences to Hugh Carey's family. I thank them for sharing him with the residents of New York State. He had the keen ability of knowing what had to be done to right the course of New York State, and the determination to see that we stayed the course to emerge a better, stronger and healthier New York. I thank Governor Carey for broadening my horizons beyond Wall Street, and entrusting me with the responsibility of being Superintendent of Banking for New York State. Hugh cared about the people of New York, and the people cared about Hugh. Thank you for being you. Muriel Siebert

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Charles MacKay, the general director of the Santa Fe Opera, announced on Wednesday that at a time of economic hardship and cutbacks among many arts institutions, his company would present a new opera in three consecutive seasons, starting in the summer of 2013. These include the first commissioned works of Mr. MacKay's tenure, which began in 2008. The first will be ''Oscar,'' based on the life of Oscar Wilde, composed by Theodore Morrison, a professor emeritus at the University of Michigan, with a libretto by the director John Cox, who has staged six productions for Santa Fe. Drawing heavily on Wilde's descriptions of his ordeals during two years of imprisonment, as well as his letters and documents from his contemporaries, ''Oscar'' will star the countertenor David Daniels in the title role. Mr. Daniels is currently singing the role of Roberto in the Santa Fe Opera's production of Vivaldi's ''Griselda.'' Mr. Cox and Kevin Newbury will direct.

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. - Ryo Ishikawa made quite a splash Thursday at the P.G.A. Championship. In fact, he made a half-dozen of them. Ishikawa, a 19-year-old from Japan, took to the seemingly ubiquitous water at Atlanta Athletic Club like a duck - and left like a wounded one. Six shots found their resting place at the bottom of ponds, inflating his score to 85.
HABER--Ruth S. November 14, 1916 - August 8, 2011. Beloved widow of William B. Haber. Loving mother of Lady Donna Haber Kornberg (Sir Hans Kornberg), Robert Haber. Hillside Mortuary (800) 576-1994.

Aretha Franklin will be honored at a gala concert in Washington to mark the 25th anniversary of the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, the institute announced Thursday. The concert will be held Sept. 12 at the Kennedy Center. Past winners of the prestigious Founder's Award will perform at the concert, along with the jazz greats Herbie Hancock and Wayne Shorter and the singers Dianne Reeves and Dee Dee Bridgewater. The program, of course, will be a tribute to the life and music of Thelonious Monk, the seminal jazz pianist and composer.

KAUFMAN--Morris, 89. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Toby and Alan, Sheila and Sheldon, Robert and Ronnie, Amy and Robert; seven grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. WWII veteran, businessman, Renaissance man. Donations to mjhsfoundation.org
Corporations are people, my friend. MITT ROMNEY, responding to hecklers in Iowa who want higher corporate taxes. [A16]

GREGORY--Jane Ball Lockhart, 90, of Charlottesville, died Tuesday, August 9, 2011 at her home at University Village. She was born August 27, 1920 in Glen Allen, Virginia, the daughter of the late George Bartley Lockhart and Al-Willie Ward Lockhart. Mrs. Gregory was pre-deceased in 1969 by her husband, Philip H. Gregory, of Lyndonville, Vermont, to whom she was married on January 19, 1943. Survivors include her three daughters, Jane Lockhart Gregory Rubin of New York City, Susan Ayers Gregory Gibbs of Stanardsville, Virginia, and Nancy Ross Gregory Smith of Indian Harbor Beach, Florida. Mrs. Gregory also leaves six grandchildren: Lara Ross Constable of Seattle, Washington; Maia A. Rubin of New York City; Peter L. Rubin of Washington, D.C; Joshua Philip Gibbs of Essex Junction, Vermont; Christopher Scott Gibbs of Asheville, North Carolina; Jennie Howard King of Hardwick, Vermont and seven great-children. A memorial service will be held at the chapel at St. Paul's Memorial Chapel, 1700 University Avenue, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903 at 10:30am. Saturday, August 13, 2011 with The Rev. Dr. Ann Bagley Willms presiding. The service will be followed by a luncheon reception in the dining room at University Village, 500 Crestwood Drive, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903 at 12:30pm. Inurnment and memorial service will be held in the fall in Essex, Junction, VT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Mrs. Gregory's name to WVPT-Virginia's Public Television Station, 298 Port Republic Road, Harrisonburg, VA 22901-3063. Friends may sign the guest register at teaguefuneralhome.com.

Funds of hedge funds are changing their ways. For decades, the money managers, which invest across a number of hedge funds, lured big institutions with the promise of diversification. They justified the extra fees by saying their extensive due diligence would help protect investors from major blowups.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about Yankees closer Mariano Rivera's history against the Red Sox erroneously described a play by Boston's Marco Scutaro in the ninth inning of Sunday night's game. He was rounding first base on a leadoff double off Rivera; he was not heading home (although he scored later in the inning on a sacrifice fly to tie the score).

MARBURGER--John H. The Staller Family is saddened by the passing of Dr. John Marburger, and they would like to extend their deepest sympathies to his wife, Carol and the family. Dr. Marburger was instrumental in making the Staller Center for the Arts at Stony Brook University possible, in addition to many other campus improvements. Erwin P. Staller

YAFFE--Sumner, MD, passed away at his home in Westwood, CA on August 10, 2011. Born in Boston, MA and educated at the Boston Latin School, Harvard College and University of Vermont School of Medicine. He served as Director of the Center for Mothers and Children at the National Institutes of Health for several decades. An internationally recognized researcher and advocate, he is considered the Father of Pediatric Pharmacology. He is survived by his beloved wife, Susanne H. Goldstein, and children, Steven, Kristine, Jason, Noah, Ian and Zachary, and five grandchildren. Tributes to the Sumner J. Yaffe Scholarship at the University of Vermont School of Medicine.

AMES, Iowa -- A withering critique of President Obama's handling of the economy was overshadowed by a burst of incivility among the Republican presidential candidates who gathered here for a debate on Thursday night and fought to stay alive in the party's increasingly fractious nominating race. The simmering animosity that has been building among some contenders broke into full view during the two-hour debate, with Representative Michele Bachmann defending her legislative accomplishments, her economic ideas and her experience to serve as president. She batted away the criticism, smiling at times and swinging at others, trying to prove she could take the heat.

CLAREMON--Ruth. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our friend Ruth Claremon. Ruth and her beloved husband Irving have been generous supporters of the College of Medicine. Ruth was a member of our National Women's Division. Irving is a member of our Society of Founders and was an early member of our Men's Division. To Irving and the entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Richard M. Joel, President Yeshiva University

CARBONITE I.P.O. Carbonite, an online data storage company, made its stock market debut on Thursday, rising 23.5 percent from its initial public offering price of $10 to close at $12.35. ''We went public in the worst possible public market,'' David Friend, Carbonite's chief executive, above, said. ''But our business model is very predictable, investors are very scared, and Carbonite provides that predictability.''

BRENNAN--William, 94, of Westport, CT on August 10th. Beloved husband of the late Jean and father of Jude, Colleen, Bill, daughter-in-law Pam, and grandfather of Nicole, Mackenzie and Katie. He was much loved and will be missed by his family and many close friends. Funeral services at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, CT on Sunday, August 14th at noon.

Francesco Quinn, a television and film actor who appeared in Oliver Stone's searing 1986 Vietnam War film, ''Platoon,'', died on Friday in Malibu, Calif. The son of the actor Anthony Quinn, he was 48. Mr. Quinn collapsed on a street near his home, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said. His agent, Arlene Thornton, said the cause was believed to be a heart attack.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. -- It was the home where Franklin D. Roosevelt, ravaged by polio, learned to walk with a cane and leg braces. It was where he was persuaded by Democratic leaders to run for president in 1932. And it is where, whenever his health deteriorated, the future president would wade into the calm streams nearby or read books on the front porch.

LOS ANGELES - In a courtroom here, Jeffrey E. Gundlach, one of the most prominent bond managers in the country, on Thursday defended himself against claims that he had planned to sabotage his former employer, Trust Company of the West, by using stolen data and client information to start a competing firm. ''I took my responsibility at TCW very seriously, '' he testified. ''I loved TCW.''

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. - Ken Mangum, the metaphorically inclined director of the golf courses at the Atlanta Athletic Club, compared the odd damaging of two greens to ''cutting yourself with a razor on your wedding day.'' An apparent malfunction of lawn mower brushes tore up patches of the 14th and 17th greens Wednesday night at the club's Highlands course, site of the P.G.A. Championship.

11:13 p.m. | Updated As they tried to blame President Obama for the nation's lowered credit rating, the Republican presidential candidates who squared off Thursday night in Iowa made several misleading, incomplete or simply false claims. ''I was fortunate enough to be a governor that got an increase in the credit rating of my state at the same time we got a president who got a decrease in the credit rating of our nation,'' Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, said. ''And that's because our president simply doesn't understand how to lead and how to grow an economy.''

WEISSMAN--Ira J.,of Northvale, NJ passed away on Sunday, July 10, 2011 at the Rockleigh Jewish Home. He was born on January 5, 1931 in Yonkers, NY. Ira received his BBA from the City College of New York and his MBA from the University of Wisconsin. After graduate school, Ira worked for Hart, Schaffner and Marx in Chicago, IL, before returning to New York City where he joined Imperia Foods, Inc. While learning the cheese processing business, he became an importer of hard cheeses eventually rising to President of Imperia Foods. Additionally, Ira served on the Board of Directors of the Cheese Importers Association of America for several years. He was elected President of the CIAA in 1995 and 1996. Active in many community organizations, he was chosen to be a member of the first Community Board in the Tribeca area of New York. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Plaza Cooperative in Fort Lee, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Dr. Myrna Schear, his sons, Miles and Marlowe, his brother Clark Weissman and his sister, Frances Doughty.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about a new wariness of venture funds among institutional investors reversed the identifications of two investment executives who commented on the issue. Chris Douvos, co-head of private equity at the Investment Fund for Foundations is at the left and Jordan Silber, a partner in the venture capital group at the law firm Cooley, is at the right.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has officially canceled plans to loan works by the fashion designer Paul Poiret to Moscow's Kremlin Museum, as part of the ongoing fallout from a legal dispute that has halted all loans from Russian to American museums. ''It's really a matter of fairness and equity,'' the Met's spokesman, Harold Holzer, said. As long as Russia's ''loan embargo is in place,'' Mr. Holzer said, ''this museum believes it can no longer lend to Russian museums.'' The Met was to lend 35 Poiret works to the show, which is scheduled to open at the Moscow museum on September 6. The cancellation of the loans was first reported by the New York Observer. The Russian embargo stems from a dispute in which the Brooklyn-based Chabad-Lubavitch organization is seeking the return from Russia of a large collection of books and religious documents. Assembled over two centuries by Chabad leaders, the collection was looted by the Nazis and later seized by the Russians. On July 30, 2010, a federal judge ruled in the dispute in favor of Chabad, ordering Russia to turn over the collection. But Russia has so far refused to comply. In the meantime, Russian officials have warned museums there that any art they lend to the United States could be seized as potential leverage. American diplomats and museum officials have tried to reassure Russian museums that works on loan are immune from seizure, but so far their assurances have not been enough to satisfy the Russians. Several Met shows have been affected, including ''Cezanne's Card Players'' and ''Rooms with a View.'' ''Everyone here is saddened'' that the long tradition of mutual loans has been affected, Mr. Holzer said, adding that ''as a gesture of goodwill and friendship,'' the Met would be sending something to the Moscow museum: namely, some of the scenic backdrops from its own Poiret exhibition, in 2007. ''We feel we can't send over the actual art,'' he said, but ''we're sending over the backdrop material.''

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. - As a teenager, Phil Mickelson nurtured his golf game on the public Torrey Pines South course in San Diego, and he considered the design inviolate, down to the slope of the greens. But when the noted course toughener Rees Jones completed a configuration in 2001, Mickelson was no fan of the finished product. He seems to have never forgiven Jones, later disapproving of a makeover at another cherished greensward, Cog Hill's Drubsdread in suburban Chicago. So it was hardly a surprise to hear Mickelson find fault Thursday with Jones's latest high-profile handiwork, the renovated Highlands course at Atlanta Athletic Club.

An article on Thursday about France's fears for its AAA credit rating erroneously attributed a distinction to its budget deficit of 5.7 percent of gross domestic product. That is the second-highest in Europe, after Britain, among AAA-rated nations -- not the second-highest in Europe over all.

A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about the actor John Wood referred incorrectly to Mr. Wood's nomination for a Tony for ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.'' As the obituary correctly noted, he was nominated for the original 1967 Broadway production -- not for his performance in the 1987 revival, depicted in the photograph.

A picture caption on Thursday with a music review of a Mostly Mozart Festival concert by the Budapest Festival Orchestra misidentified the site of the performance. It was Avery Fisher Hall -- not the Rose Theater, where the orchestra played last week. Schedule information with the review misstated the date of a concert featuring Matthias Pintscher conducting the International Contemporary Ensemble as part of the Mozart festival. It was Thursday, not next Tuesday.

LEVY--Ellen. A gifted interior designer with an extraordinary sense of color and beauty, she was also a wise and caring friend. The loves of her life were her family and her art. Her presence is everywhere in our home. We will miss her wisdom, her talents and her. Jackie and Chuck Warren.

On the first episode of ''Russian Dolls,'' Eva Levitis sits at the head of a table, prepping her pancake makeup for a beauty pageant. The pageant, for grandmothers only, is one she'll handily win - no one else tries for a belly dance routine that includes an eggplant-colored brassiere, dripping with beads. But that hasn't happened yet. She's still at home, her hair a nest of blond curls, speaking longingly into a make-up mirror: ''I always dreamed to be onstage. And people was looking at me.'' Her English is stilted, charming. Don't blame her.

An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday, comparing e-readers, misstated one capability of the Amazon Kindle. Kindles have some Internet functions, including a limited Web browser; it is not the case that ''you can't hop off to the Web to look up facts.''

Christopher Sieber will play Albin (a k a the drag queen Zaza) in the national tour of ''La Cage aux Folles,'' the show's producers announced on Thursday. Mr. Sieber (''Shrek the Musical'') will play opposite George Hamilton, who was previously announced to portray Georges, Albin's partner. The tour begins in October in Des Moines. In a twist, Mr. Sieber played the role of Georges, with Harvey Fierstein as Albin, in the 2010 Broadway revival of the show, which won the Tony Award for best revival of a musical. The production, which originally co-starred Kelsey Grammer as Georges and Douglas Hodge as Albin, closed in May.

FISCHER--Norman, passed August 8, 2011, age 98. Former member of American Stock Exchange. Dear father of Dale Fertig and Robert Fischer. Beloved grandfather of Evan, Alex, Jeffrey, Michelle and Jody. Also survived by four great-grandchildren and brother Harold.

An exhibition that explored the history of graffiti and street art brought record-setting crowds into the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the museum said. The show, ''Art in the Streets,'' drew 201,352 visitors from April 17 through Aug. 8, the highest exhibition attendance in the museum's history. The previous attendance record was set with the museum's Andy Warhol retrospective, which drew 195,000 visitors in 2002. Because of ''Art in the Streets,'' the museum expects to double its total annual attendance this year to 400,000. The exhibition was open for 81 days with a daily average attendance of nearly 2,500, which broke previous daily attendance records. The show's final week also set a record with 32,278 visitors.
International NIGERIANS GET FIRST PAYMENT

EMERSON--Jane. The Board of Directors, Advisory Board, Leaders Council and staff of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourn the death of our beloved friend and colleague, Jane Emerson. We send heartfelt condolences to her devoted husband, Bob, and family. Evelyn H. Lauder, Founder and Chairman Myra Biblowit, President

8 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS: THE BATTLE UNFOLDS This overview of the Sea Shepherd's last four Antarctic campaigns chronicles the encounters leading up to the season finale at 9, in which Capt. Paul Watson, founder of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, finds his life's work paying off with what he calls the ultimate victory. In ''Whale Wars: War Stories,'' at 10, the journalist Lisa Ling sits down with, above from left, Captain Watson, Matthew Smith, Fiona McCuaig and other crew members to review the actions that led Japan's whaling fleet to end its season early. 10 A.M. (HBO) THE LOVELY BONES (2009) Mark Wahlberg and Rachel Weisz play the grieving parents of Susie Salmon (Saoirse Ronan), a 14-year-old who has gone missing in 1970s suburbia in this adaptation from Peter Jackson of the best seller by Alice Sebold. Stanley Tucci is the neighbor who knows what happened. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said: ''As a pictorial artifact 'The Lovely Bones' is gorgeous. It pulses and blooms and swells with bright hues and strange vistas.'' But in the end the film, which focuses on Susie as she hovers in the ''in-between'' and tries to bring her killer to justice, ''shows less audacity'' than the novel ''and too much art.''

BROWN--Morris. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our long time Member and dear friend, Moe Brown. A world class CPA, well respected in his profession, he was at EBC just recently for lunch and it is hard to believe both he and Sylvia are now gone. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Our sincere condolences to his sons and the rest of the Brown family. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary
NORKIN--Sam. The nieces and nephews of Sam Norkin mourn the passing of their beloved uncle.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that he planned to play receiver Plaxico Burress for a few snaps in Monday's preseason opener against the Houston Texans, even though Burress continues to be limited in practice because of an ankle injury. Burress wore a full set of pads for the Jets' two-and-a-half-hour afternoon practice Thursday but participated only in individual drills. Burress, who hurt his ankle last week, took no repetitions Tuesday during team periods. The Jets were off Wednesday.

An article on Wednesday about the ties that many of News Corporation's independent directors have to the company and its chairman, Rupert Murdoch, misstated the role of John L. Thornton, a former president of Goldman Sachs, in News Corporation's purchase of Star TV. Mr. Thornton represented the owner of Star TV in the deal, not News Corporation.

HOUSTON -- For weeks this blazingly hot summer, the sanctuary inside Evangelist Temple Church of God in Christ here has been uncomfortably stuffy -- too warm for Sunday services, and seemingly hotter, one recent 94-degree evening, than that place where Bishop Rufus Kyles seeks to prevent his congregation from spending eternity. Nine 5-ton, 8-ton and 10-ton air-conditioning units usually keep the church cool, but this indoor heat was not a matter for an air-conditioning specialist.
TRANTEL--James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James Trantel, associated with The New York Times from October 1, 1974 until retiring on January 1, 2005.

It was to have been the summit of a spectacularly ambitious and rapid ascent in finance: turning what began as a $4.6 million hedge fund into an investment bank that could rival Goldman Sachs. But three years and millions of dollars later, Kenneth C. Griffin is abandoning his quest. The founder of the investment powerhouse Citadel is now trying to sell Citadel's investment bank to focus on electronic trading in his securities division, a person close to the firm said.

CALZOLAIO--Ida. Cherished wife of Giancarlo, adored mother of Aurora, Donald (Kathy), John Carlo (Karen Salamon), beloved grandmother of Lauren, Michael, James, Mia, loving sister, sister-in-law, aunt and friend to many. Contact Farenga Funeral Home 718-726-6060 for arrangements.

-Here's a rare literary phenomenon: Americans are rushing to read poetry. One day after Philip Levine was named the next poet laureate, his books have quickly sold out in bookstores and online retailers, making it nearly impossible to immediately acquire copies of some collections of his poems. On the Amazon.com ''Movers and Shakers'' list, which tracks books that are growing the most quickly in popularity, two by Mr. Levine were at the top of the list: ''What Work Is,'' a collection of poems that won a National Book Award, and ''The Simple Truth,'' a collection that won a Pulitzer Prize. Both books are backordered and not available to ship for at least six days. Other books are backordered for at least one to three weeks.

MARCUS--Elliott M.,M.D., 78, of Boston, MA and Key Biscayne, FL on July 25. Emeritus Professor of Neurology at UMass Medical School and former Tufts Medical School Professor. Co-authored four neuroscience textbooks. Founding President, Mass. Neurologic Association. Neurology Chair at St. Vincent's Hospital/Fallon Clinic. Epilepsy researcher, educator. Husband of Dr. R. Nuran Turksoy-Marcus. Father of Dr. Erin N. Marcus. Life Celebration at Tufts Goddard Chapel, Noon, September 17. Donations to: UMass Elliott Marcus Lecture Fund, 508-856-6515.

It looks like September will be Roman Polanski month. First the New York Film Festival announced its opening-night selection, on Sept. 30, would be the director's latest project, ''Carnage,'' based on the play ''God of Carnage.'' Now comes news that the Museum of Modern Art is mounting what it is billing as ''a complete retrospective'' of the director's work. Running Sept. 7 to 30, the series will range from Mr. Polanski's student shorts of the late 1950s to his first feature, ''Knife in the Water'' (1962), and his 2010 film, ''The Ghost Writer,'' starring Ewan McGregor and Pierce Brosnan.

An article on Tuesday about the San Diego Chargers' possible relocation to Los Angeles misstated the name of the section of Interstate 5 that runs between San Diego and Los Angeles. Going north from San Diego, the section is known as the San Diego Freeway, and becomes the Santa Ana Freeway in Orange County; it is not the Golden State Freeway, which begins in Los Angeles.

Life, liberty and the pursuit of ... mappiness? That is the humorous rubric for a new series of digital maps created by the Scholars' Lab, an office and Web site run by the University of Virginia Library about developments in the digital humanities. Kelly Johnston, a geographic information systems specialist at the lab who created the maps, explained that he tried to convert the qualities of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness into quantities that could be visualized in a map. It's the kind of pursuit explored in a recent New York Times article.
Silicon Valley is booming even as the rest of the economy is facing increasing uncertainty.. But the memories of the dot-com bust are rustling in the background.
The day in sports, including images from the third round of the P.G.A. Championship and the World Badminton Championships in London.

This morning I introduced a formula that projects a candidate’s vote total in the Iowa caucuses based on their finish in the Ames Straw poll as well a couple of other factors. The straw poll historically does have some predictive power, particularly if you look at the share of the vote that each candidate finished with rather than simply who won and who lost.

As the manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Mike Scioscia is obviously biased toward his ace, Jered Weaver, as a contender for the American League Cy Young Award. But Scioscia made an interesting point last week about the stress of Weaver’s innings.
JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Nobody scored better Saturday at the P.G.A. Championship than David Ben Toms-Crane.
Forget “America the Beautiful.” It has been America the ordinary, bordering on the ugly, at recent Grand Slam events, with Europeans and South Africans hogging the last half-dozen.
A four-over 74 freshly in the books, Rory McIlroy clickety-clacked past his manager, Chubby Chandler, en route to the scorer’s shed.
In the late 1990s, the Auburn University golfer Jason Dufner and his buddies, fueled by beer, would fetch a few irons from their bags and hit balls late at night — from their front porch.
The weeklong oppressive weather at the Atlanta Athletic Club has kept the onsite medical team busy.
Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Michele Bachmann’s win in the important Iowa Straw Poll this weekend.
Aug. 13, 2011 - Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Representative Michele Bachmann's win in the important Iowa straw poll this weekend.

GREENLAND, N.H. — Introduced as “the next president of the United States,” Gov. Rick Perry of Texas allowed himself a smile, stepping to a podium assembled hours earlier in a Greenland, N.H., backyard.

MONTREAL — Earlier Saturday, in response to a question about Mardy Fish, the American ranked eighth over all who advanced to the Rogers Cup final, the analyst and former player Darren Cahill turned his attention instead to Andy Roddick. Or, more specifically, he gave an impassioned defense of Roddick, who had not been mentioned at that point.

One of baseball’s most enthusiastic bloggers and Tweeters is a 55-year-old grandfather with eight children who last worked for a major league team in 1993. He is Dale Murphy, a two-time most valuable player who starred for the Atlanta Braves in the 1980s and is now, officially, technologically advanced.
After Zhao Liang pulled a film of his from the 2009 Melbourne Film Festival, Ai Weiwei, another Chinese director, confronted him to ask about his motives.

At Representative Charles B. Rangel’s birthday party at the Plaza Hotel on Wednesday night, guests like Edward I. Koch, the former mayor, and Scott M. Stringer, a mayoral hopeful and Manhattan borough president, responded to a recent article in The New York Times detailing Alec Baldwin’s political aspirations.
Zhao Liang's films, which explore the relationship between the Chinese government and its citizens, have received critical acclaim abroad but are not screened in China.

AMES, Iowa — Michele Bachmann‘s high-intensity, Tea Party-inspired critique of President Obama propelled her to a first-place finish in the straw poll here Saturday, giving her presidential campaign a boost even as the field of rivals expanded to include Texas governor Rick Perry.
Roller Hockey has long been a staple of growing up in Rockaway, Queens. A league that plays next to Rockaway Beach, on the Atlantic Ocean, has seen a resurgence.
After the votes have been tallied at Saturday’s straw poll in Iowa, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota will make the rounds on the Sunday shows, appearing on six different channels.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s how to tell whether you are a total crossword geek: you get to a clue like 110 Down (“It has a period of 2[pi]”), despair because your brain shuts down like the jaws of a bear trap when it is confronted by math, and then sigh in relief because the crossing that enables you to solve it is ANSAE, an obscure example of crosswordese that is actually a part of another example of crosswordese, the infamous EWER. It’s a peculiar form of relief, but it works for me.
Iowa Republicans mingled with presidential hopefuls as they began voting in the first test of how the candidates trying to unseat President Obama are faring with their base.
In this edition: debt ceiling deals, debt downgrades and recall elections.

One of the odder sideshows of the Lesser Depression has been the ongoing crusade of Chicago’s Casey Mulligan, who has repeatedly tried to convince everyone via his blog that contrary to all appearances, we are not suffering from an overall lack of demand. One of his arguments was that since employment of teenagers continues to expand in the summer, when those teenagers are in fact able to work, supply must be the constraining factor. Another was that the growth in Texas employment similarly shows that demand can’t be the factor limiting national employment. The latter argument, of course, has new relevance now that Rick Perry is going to run on his alleged economic miracle.
The Times’s Michael D. Shear leads a walking tour of the Iowa straw poll, where G.O.P. candidates jockeyed for attention.
The Times's Michael D. Shear leads a walking tour of the Iowa straw poll, where G.O.P. candidates jockeyed for attention.
Hiram, Ohio, Aug. 14, 1861
The Yankees held a small but elegant ceremony to honor Derek Jeter for reaching 3,000 hits before Saturday’s game against the Tampa Bay Rays.

The Quad Blog is zeroing in on what’s being served before kickoff on Saturdays and Sundays and asking readers to submit their recipes and favorite tailgate dishes. Use this form to send us your recipes, and please send a picture of your fare and perhaps an interesting back story. We’ll share selected submissions over the course of the season.
AMES, Iowa — On the heels of his official presidential announcement, Rick Perry has unveiled a new, two-minute campaign video.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — On optics alone, a New England coastal hub might seem like hostile territory for a Texas governor. Street musicians lug their instruments across the main drag downtown. Sedans funnel toward the water’s edge, with kayaks strapped to their roofs. And, most conspicuously, the city square teems with blue-state transplants from Boston and New York.
The search for a missing New York City police officer who disappeared during a father-and-son kayaking trip on Friday ended a day later with the recovery of the officer’s body, the authorities said.

Gee calls himself the master of the one-liner, but he admitted in a recent interview that it is one of his great strengths and one of his great weaknesses. In fact, Gee makes enough of what he called “dumb statements” in public that he keeps a list of them. Gee declined to show the list in its entirety, but acknowledged that some of the following statements made the cut.

While living in Rio de Janeiro in 1999, I saw something that caught my attention: a television broadcast of a Carnival parade that paid homage to a plastic surgeon, Dr. Ivo Pitanguy. The president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, appeared on state television this week looking healthy and walking confidently in the first such footage of the wounded leader since an early July speech in which he appeared dazed and disfigured. In a video posted Thursday, Mr. Saleh appears wearing a white robe, black blazer and cream-colored gloves, striding through the halls of a hospital in Saudi Arabia and sitting with several of his ministers who were hurt in a bomb attack on his presidential palace more than two months ago. Mr. Saleh, who was also wounded in that attack, left the hospital on Sunday and is currently recuperating in a Saudi royal residence.

Sam - the piano player who stirred up painful memories by singing ''As Time Goes By'' in ''Casablanca'' - might disagree. But in the theater, as in life, a kiss is hardly just a kiss. Whether bestowed on the lips, the cheek, the hand or any other part of the anatomy, the simple application of the lips to someone else's body can illuminate all sorts of different, and often contradictory, feelings. I was recently reminded of the theatrical power of the kiss when I saw the Sydney Theater Company's superb visiting production of ''Uncle Vanya'' at the Kennedy Center in Washington. Directed with genius by Tamas Ascher, this inventively visceral interpretation is filled with instances of physical contact in which affection and anger, attraction and repulsion seem to exist in uneasy simultaneity. This is the world of Chekhov, after all, where emotions are paralyzingly ambivalent.

FRONT PAGE An article on June 2 about the unemployment rate's effect on President Obama's prospects for re-election misstated the number of presidents who have run for re-election since Franklin Delano Roosevelt. It is seven, not ten. (Presidents Truman, Johnson and Ford came to the presidency by succession, not election, so their candidacies as incumbents are not considered re-election campaigns.) This correction was delayed because an e-mail from a reader pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

(HBO) LIFE AS WE KNOW IT (2010) Holly Berenson (Katherine Heigl) runs a swanky food shop in Atlanta; Eric Messer (Josh Duhamel, above with Ms. Heigl) is a womanizing jock who directs live sports events on television. Their mutual best friends (Hayes MacArthur and Christina Hendricks) think they'd be great together, leading to one of the worst blind dates of all time after it becomes clear that he has already lined up a late-night tryst. Then their friends die in a car crash, leaving behind their baby girl, and Holly and Eric as her guardians. Voilà! Instant family, full of love (for the child) and mutual loathing (for each other). Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called this romantic comedy from Greg Berlanti bland, with ''not a single deviation from formula.'' Still, the movie received an A-minus score from audiences in exit polls and came in second to ''The Social Network'' in its opening weekend at the box office. 5 P.M. NEWMAN--Charles. The Jack Martin Fund records with profound sorrow the passing of Charles Newman. Charlie was the last living founding member of the fund. He was an inspiration to all who knew him. Our heartfelt condolences to Gert, Bruce, Jay and his entire family. The Board of Directors

BEER--Dr. Morton A.,died peacefully at his home in Morristown, NJ on August 12, 2011. He is survived by his beloved wife of 68 years, Norma. He was born on July 24, 1920. He received his BA in 1941 and his MD in 1944, both from Cornell University. He served during WWII as a Captain in the US Army Medical Corps. He was a Fellow of both the American College of Surgeons and the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology. He served as Chairman of the Department of Ob-Gyn at Morristown Memorial Hospital, where he delivered over 6,000 babies. He was a member of the Morris Township Planning Board and served as Chairman. He volunteered his services and established a gynecology section at the Dover Community Clinic. He had an agile and quick mind, a terrific sense of humor, a love of golf, the New York Giants, great food, and most of all he loved spending time with his family, who will miss him terribly. He leaves two daughters and a son-in-law, Barbara McGee and Patricia and Lawrence Kotler; three grandsons, Andrew McGee, Michael Kotler, and Jonathan Kotler; and his brother, Earl Beer.

KLETT--John Cleveland, Jr. New York City attorney, born November 9, 1926, died at home after a short illness on August 10 at the age of 84. Mr. Klett was a member of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore from December 1952 until April 1960. Thereafter, he served as tax counsel for Hertz Corporation from April 1960 until August 1962; he joined Pepsi-Cola in 1962 in the Law Department; in 1964 served as president and chief executive officer of Empire State Sugar Company, Inc., a subsidiary of PepsiCo, Inc.; and in 1966 he was appointed Vice President, Administration, Pepsi-Cola Co. In 1969 he left Pepsi-Cola to start his own practice which he maintained until June 2011. Mr. Klett received his LLB from Fordham in 1949, where he was on the Dean's List. Over his career he has written extensively and been a lecturer on Federal taxation. He served in the U.S. Naval Reserve during World War II from 1943-1946; and served in Korea from 1950 to 1952 as Lt. j.g. in various positions on the USS Gull and the USS Scout; for which service he received the Bronze star and other Presidential and United Nations citations. He is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Larsen; three daughters: Kathleen M. Garrett; Margaret M. Barsalou; and Carolyn M. Klett; 13 grandchildren; and brother, Joseph Klett. Two sons, Jack Cleveland Klett, II and George B. Klett., predeceased him. Visiting at Charles Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY, Monday, August 15 from 6-8pm. A Requiem Mass will be held on Tuesday, August 16 at 10am at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Church of St. Thomas More in his memory.

The recent market decline, and the media (over)reaction that followed, reminded me that we still have not learned a very simple lesson: the time to prepare for a ''crisis'' is long before you find yourself in one. It's not a good idea to figure out how a parachute works after you jump out of the plane. The stock market is doing what stock markets do. Yet we run around like it's such a shock. We don't know when it will happen, and often it's hard to tell why, but the fact that the market went down shouldn't have surprised anyone.

Steve Reich, the eclectic composer, has dropped plans to use a photograph of the burning World Trade Center with a hijacked plane about to hit it on the cover of his new album. The move came after some critics called his use of the photo insensitive. The album is called ''WTC 9/11'' and includes an unsettling 15-minute piece inspired by the attacks and their aftermath. It is due out on Sept. 20 on Nonesuch Records. Mr. Reich lives near Ground Zero and has said the attack ''was not a media event'' for himself and his family. But some critics hammered him, saying that using the image for commercial purposes was inappropriate.

Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, reported net assets of between $85 and $264 million in financial disclosure papers filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday. Most of that money is invested in a blind trust, the campaign said, with holdings in dozens of different investments across a range of industries, both in the United States and internationally. So far, Mr. Romney has chosen not to tap into his personal wealth to finance his campaign, as he did in 2007, when he lent himself millions of dollars to run for president.

For more than 40 years, a pair of famous friends have shared a home, a bedroom and even bath time - as well as proximity to a certain rubber duck. And for almost as many years, questions have swirled around like draining bathwater: Are these two men gay? Well, they're puppets, actually, the producers of ''Sesame Street'' said in a statement on Thursday, so Bert and Ernie do not have a sexual orientation.

Christina Aguilera and Smokey Robinson will be among the musicians performing at a concert in Britain on Oct. 8 to pay respects to Michael Jackson, the organizers have announced. -Several of Mr. Jackson's brothers are also slated to perform at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff, Wales, as well as some of his nephews who are in the British boyband 3T. The singer Cee Lo Green has also committed to performing, along with Leona Lewis, Craig David and Alien Ant Farm, which did a rock version of Jackson's ''Smooth Criminal'' in 2001.

FIRTH--Harriette Campbell, whose love of family and friends led her to travel the world, died peacefully in her sleep, August 8th, 2011, at her home at Sunrise Assisted Living in Burlington, Mass after a brief illness. She was born September 23, 1923 in Pelham Manor, New York, the only daughter of Clarence George Campbell and Florence Lawrence Campbell. The youngest of four, she attended Pelham High School and Mary Washington Secretarial College. A lifelong member of Trinity Church Roslyn, NY, she was a devoted Sunday School teacher and supported her husband on the vestry. She is survived by her daughters Letitia Firth Andrewartha and Daphne Firth.; a son, Lawrence Gerald Firth and five grandchildren, Jennifer Laine Gabrielski, Christopher David Andrewartha, Lindsey Anne Gabrielski, Elizabeth Clare Andrewartha and Lauren Nicole Firth. A memorial service will be held later this fall at Trinity Episcopal Church, Roslyn, NY. Donations can be made in her honor to Childfund International, 2821 Emerywood Parkway, Richmond, VA 23294.

This year's Summer Shorts series at the 59E59 Theaters includes new works by playwrights ranging from established talents (Christopher Durang and Tina Howe) to an incoming freshman at Yale (Ruby Rae Spiegel). Running in the program's Series B is a new drama by Will Scheffer, a creator of the acclaimed television series ''Big Love,'' which came to its conclusion this year. JOHNS CREEK, Ga. -- Brandt Snedeker mixed up his designated tee time Friday, believing it was 8:20 a.m. instead of 8:10. He discovered the misunderstanding while on the practice putting green and sprinted to the tee, arriving two minutes late. The P.G.A., sticklers for punctuality, slapped him with a two-shot penalty. ''That's the first time that's happened in my career, and I guarantee it will be the last,'' he said after a round of 73 for an aggregate of seven-over-par 147.

The Children's Museum of Manhattan has received a $40,000 planning grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to develop a major exhibition on Muslim culture, the museum said on Wednesday. The exhibition, planned for 2014, will be called ''Muslim Worlds'' and will emphasize the diversity of Muslim culture. In a recent interview, the museum's executive director, Andrew Ackerman, said the idea was to educate children and families about the Islamic world and, by ''putting it in a larger context, to remove many of the stereotypes.'' The museum said it would be the first exhibition of its kind intended for a family audience in the United States. In planning the exhibition, it said it would engage an advisory committee of educators, scholars and community leaders to explore exhibition ideas, review research, and make recommendations.

MOSCOW -- Poland's prime minister was forced to hastily apologize on Friday after it emerged that his government had apparently unwittingly aided in the arrest of a prominent human rights activist in Belarus by supplying banking information to officials there. The Polish prosecutor's office confirmed that it had sent details from the Polish bank account of the activist, Ales Belyatsky, as part of a routine information request, despite warnings from the Foreign Ministry to treat such requests with caution.
KHATAMI--Marie Hoguet. Dear Mommy, we miss you everyday. You have been watching over us. We love you. Daddy, Mariechi, Renee, Jessie, Jimmy and your loving grandchildren.

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. -- Larry Nelson appreciates the no-expiration-date exemption for past P.G.A. Championship winners. He prefers its policy to the more restrictive United States Open, which cuts off former champions from automatic entry 10 years after they earned their titles - though, with life expectancy surpassing 80 in most developed nations, who can blame the Open? Yet Friday, Nelson, 63, emphasized within minutes after putting out on the 18th hole that this was his final rodeo at a major.

Everyone knows that Los Angeles is a rough place to be a writer. Rarely, however, does getting a movie script rejected involve an explosion. But it did on Thursday in Beverly Hills. An aspiring writer desperate to get his script read received a loud rejection when the police blew up a briefcase that contained the screenplay after a literary agent refused to read it.

When ensembles that play mostly standard repertory take on contemporary works, they think of it as stretching, a broadening of their horizons. Perhaps it's the same for a group like the International Contemporary Ensemble when it turns its attention to Mozart and, in the context of its usual wet-ink repertory, Schoenberg, as it did in a Mostly Mozart concert on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Or maybe not: however these players spend their time now, they lived and breathed the standard repertory during their student years, which were not long ago. Still, it seemed strange to hear this superb new-music group navigating Mozart's ''Gran Partita'' (K. 361) in the second installment of its Mostly Mozart residency. It was assuring, too: listeners who dislike new music (or early music on period instruments, for that matter) insist that musicians who specialize in these repertories do so because they are weak in the ''real'' stuff. But the ensemble's fresh, vital performance vanquished that argument, as did its taut, essentially Romantic rendering of Schoenberg's Chamber Symphony No. 1.

Though the Union army was still getting its war footing, by August 1861 the Northern blockade of Southern ports and waterways was almost complete. That month federal ships closed the Mississippi River to commerce between loyal and secessionist states, while naval squadrons were in place off the coast of most Southern cities, from south Texas to the Chesapeake. President Lincoln had approved the blockade, known as the “Anaconda Plan,” in April. At first it was widely derided in the North and dismissed in the South—the American navy, people said, was in no shape to clamp down on thousands and thousands of miles of coastline. Nevertheless, this massive operation had an immediate impact on the Confederate economy and, as it tightened its grip on the Southern coastline, began to choke the South into submission.

Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn’t resist. DEBT spirals: the term sounds ominous. As it should — these market vortexes are posing grave dangers to the global economy right now. A national debt crisis is a bank run writ large, says Kenneth Rogoff, an economics professor at Harvard and co-author with Carmen M. Reinhart of “This Time Is Different,” a history of financial crises. When a country like Greece goes deep into debt, bond investors start to worry they won’t get their money back. What can happen next is a debt spiral, a vicious circle of sinking confidence, rising borrowing costs and, ultimately, rising debt burdens. As investors lose confidence in a country, its bond prices drop, its bond yields rise and its government must pay higher interest rates to borrow. That, in turn, deepens the debt problem — and the whole thing starts over again. Debt spirals are dangerous, but they aren’t inevitable. “Country debt crises are essentially political,” Mr. Rogoff says. Governments can often stem the crisis by reducing spending, raising taxes or both. But such steps are particularly difficult — and politically unappetizing — when growth is slack, as it is now in much of the world. Tightening the belt slows growth even more, eroding tax revenue and — you guessed it — increasing the debt burden, at least in the short term. Of course, the best way to avoid a debt spiral is to avoid running up a lot of debt in the first place — when the economy is doing well. “If you walk outside without a raincoat and the sun is shining, you are fine,” Mr. Rogoff says. “But if it starts pouring, you are going to get wet.” — DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

EMERSON--Jane Grumbach, 64, died on August 10 in New York City. For most of her life, she worked as an event planner for cultural and charitable organizations, including the New York City Ballet, the American Ballet Theater, God's Love We Deliver, and the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. She is survived by her husband, Robert; her mother, Doris Grumbach; her sisters, Barbara Wheeler, Elizabeth Cale, and Kathryn Grumbach; and nieces and nephews. A memorial event will be held in the fall. Memorial gifts may be made to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation www.bcrfcure.org.

PETERSON--Ralph, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Ralph Peterson, professor emeritus of medicine and chief of the Division of Endocrinology of the former New York HospitalCornell Medical Center from 1958 to 1983. A gifted endocrinologist, scientist and teacher, Dr. Peterson provided leadership and inspiration that built the reputation of the Division and launched numerous young physicians on a career in academic medicine. An accomplished biochemist, he was one of the very first to use isotopes in metabolic investigations in human disease, advancing our understanding of steroid hormones, metabolism and inherited diseases. As a basic science researcher, he was part of the team that described 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, leading to the development of an inhibitor for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia and male pattern baldness. A brilliant and kind man, he will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the entire Peterson family. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Andrew I. Schafer, M.D. Chairman, Dept of Medicine Julianne Imperato-McGinley, M.D., Chief, Div of Endocrinology Weill Cornell Medical College

In a scene that will have played out 77 times in recent weeks, mourners stood on a grassy hill outside Oslo and watched a hearse slowly drive down a winding road leading away from a church after a funeral. Soft rain, gentle sobs and the sound of an organ delicately punctuated the silence. Most of the candles, letters and flowers that created memorials to the victims of the July 22 bombings in the capital and the attack at a youth leadership camp have been cleared away by city workers. The National Archives will preserve some of the letters and gifts at Oslo Cathedral that were sent from around the world.Playing dead to escape death and witnessing their friends being killed has weighed heavily on the teenagers who survived. The tight-knit group of young political activists who attended the summer camp on Utoya Island say they have grown even tighter through adversity. More pictures are at nytimes.com/world.

THIS is turning into the summer when New York's flirtation with cold-brew coffee became an impossible romance. Coffee made by letting grounds and cool water steep overnight was nearly impossible to find in the city as recently as 2008; now it's everywhere, plied at a pushcart on the High Line and swigged from Stumptown's stubbies outside the Ace Hotel. Kickstand, the coffee cart on a bike that pedals around Brooklyn, is getting into the act, delivering cold brew to neighborhoods in the borough and parts of Manhattan. And while most of the other coffee comes ready to drink, Kickstand's is a 16-ounce concentrate that you dilute to taste. This means you can also mix it with a simple syrup and freeze it. Top with whipped heavy cream, and you have a delicious granité, Rome in a frosted cup. Place your order ($11 for a 16-ounce bottle, plus deposit and delivery fee) or find retail locations at kickstandbrooklyn.com. OLIVER STRAND

A picture caption on July 31 with an article about Eindhoven, the Netherlands, a factory town turned design center, misidentified an oval structure. It is the entrance to an underground bicycle parking garage, not the Blob, a new glass and steel dome that has become a popular meeting place. The article also misstated the acreage for the development site of a complex called Strijp-S and referred incompletely to the ownership of the site. It is 66 acres, not 70,000. And while the development company Trudo owns the largest share in Strijp-S, it is working with two partners -- the construction company VolkerWessels and the municipality of Eindhoven. Trudo is not the sole owner.

The San Diego Padres signaled a new direction last off-season when they traded their signature star, Adrian Gonzalez, to the Boston Red Sox for three prospects. The Padres have not won much this season, but they still have a strong bullpen, even if it looks a lot different from what most people expected. Heath Bell, their three-time All-Star closer, survived the July 31 nonwaiver trading deadline when the Padres found they could get more for their cheaper setup man, Mike Adams, who went to the Texas Rangers for two Class AA starters.

An article on July 31 about BMW's plans for battery-powered cars referred incorrectly to the price of another electric model, the Nissan Leaf. It sells for $36,050 in the United States -- not $42,600, which is the price in Britain converted to dollars.

BELKIND--Shirley, 95, on August 11, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Ralph, Linda, Stacy and Anne. Loving grandmother of David, Ian, Andrew, Michael, Lauren, Tamara and Saskia. Adored great-grandmother of Jackson. Dear mother-in-law of George, Florence and Frank.

As the manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Mike Scioscia is obviously biased toward his ace, Jered Weaver, as a contender for the American League Cy Young Award. But Scioscia made an interesting point last week about the stress of Weaver's innings. ''One thing about Jered is he's pitched with his back against the wall almost every game because he hasn't had a lot of run support,'' Scioscia said. ''Very rarely have we given him that early run support to allow him to really challenge guys.''

SINCE their debut record, ''North Hills,'' came out two years ago, the folk-rock band Dawes has been eliciting comparisons to some illustrious names: Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young; the Eagles; the Band. Partly this has to do with the mythology surrounding their first album: they recorded it at the producer Jonathan Wilson's studio in Laurel Canyon after playing a run of small hootenannies there. But mostly it has to do with their sound, which has a warm, stripped-down Americana feel frequently described as vintage. Recently, the group got about as big a nod as four guys playing folk rock could hope for: Robbie Robertson, the somewhat reclusive songwriter from the Band, asked them to back him in a series of rare performances. Dawes is now on tour to promote its follow-up record, ''Nothing Is Wrong,'' which was recorded on a setup of entirely analog gear that included a timeworn Studer tape machine owned by Jackson Browne. ABBY AGUIRRE

He was 71. The cause was complications of lung cancer, his wife, Barbara, said.

CALZOLAIO--Ida. Cherished wife of Giancarlo, adored mother of Aurora, Donald (Kathy), John Carlo (Karen Salamon), beloved grandmother of Lauren, Michael, James, Mia, loving sister, sister-in-law, aunt and friend to many. Contact Farenga Funeral Home 718-726-6060 for arrangements.

MAZEL--Alan J. Alan J. Mazel, beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away after a long illness with wife Vicki and family at his side. A noted Orthodontist with offices on Madison Avenue and Great Neck, Dr. Mazel's practice included many luminaries of television, stage, movies, music and international figures. Dr. Mazel served as a Captain in the US Air Force with distinction. Using a mobile dental van, he visited isolated radar sites providing dental care to servicemen. A world traveler, Dr. Mazel and his wife Vicki visited many corners of the globe. An avid baseball fan, Brooklyn born Mazel loved the Dodgers as a youth and the Mets for his adult life. His last public appearance was July 21 for a Mets baseball game. Dr. Mazel's retirement years were spent with his family where he was a central and adored figure. He leaves a legacy of love and loyalty. Remembering him always are his wife of 53 years, Vicki Mazel, sons Joseph, Geoffrey and daughter Ila, in-laws Lisa, Sue and Matt as well as grandchildren Max, Brian, Mandy, Benny, Eliza, and Jenna. And many other beloved family and friends. His warmth, strength and guidance will be sorely missed.

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. - Nobody scored better Saturday at the P.G.A. Championship than David Ben Toms-Crane. O.K., these are two different players. But David Toms and Ben Crane, teeing off together among the early twosomes since each had flubbed their way to three over par at the midpoint, seemed interchangeable as they conducted their own intramural competition and moved to the fringe of contention.

HEAVY-DUTY pickup trucks are the supercars of the truck world. They have more power than drivers are likely ever to exploit, and bragging rights depend on statistics that are, in practical terms, theoretical. Like a Lamborghini Aventador's top speed, a GMC Sierra HD's maximum tow rating (21,700 pounds) is more of a chest-thumping point than a practical consideration. In some versions of the Sierra 2500, you could theoretically carry a Corvette Z06 (3,175 pounds) in the bed.

Several years ago, I began anthropological fieldwork among a ''tribe'' of Cariocas (residents of Rio de Janeiro): socialites and their maids, divorced housewives, unemployed secretaries, aspiring celebrities, transvestite prostitutes and other patients who were making Brazil the ''empire of the scalpel.'' I first met Éster through her former employer, a successful plastic surgeon, for whom she'd worked as his personal cook. Éster lived nearby in Vidigal, a favela near the brilliant white sand beach of Leblon. One day after she'd prepared dinner for his family she shyly told him in private, ''Doutor, I want to put in silicone.'' After reading up on prosthetic materials in an Internet café, she'd settled on a midcost model of breast implant (about $900) and convinced the doctor that she was a good candidate. Hesitant to perform the surgery on his domestic employee, he referred her to a young resident in the clinic of Dr. Ivo Pitanguy, Brazil's most influential plastic surgeon.

WASHINGTON -- As the economy worsens, President Obama and his senior aides are considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on economic issues, seeking to highlight substantive differences with Republicans in Congress and on the campaign trail rather than continuing to pursue elusive compromises, advisers to the president say. Mr. Obama's senior adviser, David Plouffe, and his chief of staff, William M. Daley, want him to maintain a pragmatic strategy of appealing to independent voters by advocating ideas that can pass Congress, even if they may not have much economic impact. These include free trade agreements and improved patent protections for inventors.

Here's a letter from the composer STEPHEN SONDHEIM, responding to Patrick Healy's article about a new version of ''Porgy and Bess'' being staged by American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. The article by Mr. Healy about the coming revival of ''Porgy and Bess'' is dismaying on many levels. To begin with, the title of the show is now ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess.'' I assume that's in case anyone was worried it was the Rodgers and Hart ''Porgy and Bess'' that was coming to town. But what happened to DuBose Heyward? Most of the lyrics (and all of the good ones) are his alone (''Summertime,'' ''My Man's Gone Now'' ) or co-written with Ira Gershwin (''Bess, You Is My Woman Now''). If this billing is at the insistence of the Gershwin estate, they should be ashamed of themselves. If it's the producers' idea, it's just dumb.

GREGORY--Jane Ball Lockhart. 90, of Charlottesville, died Tuesday, August 9, 2011 at her home at University Village. She was born August 27, 1920 in Glen Allen, Virginia, the daughter of the late George Bartley Lockhart and Al-Willie Ward Lockhart. Mrs. Gregory was pre-deceased in 1969 by her husband, Philip H. Gregory, of Lyndonville, Vermont, to whom she was married on January 19, 1943. Survivors include her three daughters, Jane Lockhart Gregory Rubin of New York City, Susan Ayers Gregory Gibbs of Stanardsville, Virginia, and Nancy Ross Gregory Smith of Indian Harbor Beach, Florida. Mrs. Gregory also leaves six grandchildren: Lara Ross Constable of Seattle, Washington; Maia A. Rubin of New York City; Peter L. Rubin of Washington, D.C; Joshua Philip Gibbs of Essex Junction, Vermont; Christopher Scott Gibbs of Asheville, North Carolina; Jennie Howard King of Hardwick, Vermont and seven great-children. A memorial service will be held at the chapel at St. Paul's Memorial Chapel, 1700 University Avenue, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903 at 10:30am. Saturday, August 13, 2011 with The Rev. Dr. Ann Bagley Willms presiding. The service will be followed by a luncheon reception in the dining room at University Village, 500 Crestwood Drive, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903 at 12:30pm. Inurnment and memorial service will be held in the fall in Essex, Junction, VT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Mrs. Gregory's name to WVPT-Virginia's Public Television Station, 298 Port Republic Road, Harrisonburg, VA 22901-3063. Friends may sign the guest register at teaguefuneralhome.com.

From ''Bartleby, the Scrivener'' to ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club aims to generate lively online discussion of those books classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non in which the city features centrally. On Tuesday, Sept. 6, from 1 to 4 p.m., join the new Big City columnist, Ginia Bellafante, for a live discussion of the first club selection, Colum McCann's award-winning novel ''Let the Great World Spin,'' which revolves around Philippe Petit's high-wire walk across the World Trade Center towers in 1974.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Coronation for Basketball's Clown Prince,'' Aug. 7: Although many consider Michael Jordan the best basketball player ever, I believe that ranking should go to Oscar Robertson because he was the best team player.

With used-car prices at historic highs, customers hoping for those prices to decline may have to wait years for a reprieve. Prices for used cars are likely to stay high for the next two to three years, according to a report released Thursday by Kelley Blue Book, which tracks new- and used-car prices.

The preseason games may have started, but N.F.L. coaches are in midseason form in reciting cliches. They hoped to see some specific generalities from their squads in the opening games. ''I want to see execution of the offense, good decisions and support,'' Detroit Coach Jim Schwartz said.

A report last Sunday about the wedding of Adiya Dixon and Erin Wiggins misidentified the area of study in which the bridegroom earned a master's degree from Case Western Reserve University. His degree is in bioethics, not biology.

A four-over 74 freshly in the books, Rory McIlroy clickety-clacked past his manager, Chubby Chandler, en route to the scorer's shed. ''How is it?'' Chandler asked, alluding to the injured right wrist that has plagued McIlroy for all but two of his 54 holes in the P.G.A. Championship.

A consummate scrabbler and crossword puzzler, she loved life, fishing, the beach, the Mets, her longtime friends and her family. She is survived by her husband of 59 years Richard, her daughters Anne Maltz and Sara Maltz-Foell, her son-in-law Helmut Foell and her grandhildren Daniel, Julia, Alexandra and Michael. AMES, Iowa -- The race for the Republican presidential nomination came into sharper focus on Saturday as Gov. Rick Perry of Texas declared his candidacy in South Carolina and Michele Bachmann won a closely watched poll of voters in Iowa. With Republican enthusiasm swelling over the prospect of defeating President Obama next year, thousands of party activists converged here for the Iowa straw poll. The outcome, combined with the entrance of Mr. Perry, could help reorder the top tier of contenders, with Mrs. Bachmann and Mr. Perry positioned to challenge the perceived front runner, Mitt Romney, and each other.

HARRIS--George ("Bud"). Died July 26, 2011, at age 100. Served in China in the US Army during WWII, then as cultural attache with US Embassy in Nanjing 1947-49 and head of the Fulbright Scholars Program in China. Subsequently chief of the China desk in US State Dept. Bureau of Far Eastern Affairs and then professor at the School of International Service (SIS) at American University in Washington D.C., retiring in 1981. Approaching 100, he published a book of poetry, "Flotsam and Jetsam", a spirited reflection on aging. Predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Elaine A. Harris. Survived by goddaughters Ann Spence and Jean Bennett and Elaine's niece Valerie Read.

ROSEN--Harold J.,a New York City-born specification writer, died on Tuesday, July 19 at his home in Chevy Chase, Maryland. In 2000, he became a Fellow of the Construction Specifications Institute and was awarded a gold medal. Mr. Rosen was the author of The Principles of Specification Writing (1967), which was renamed Construction Specification Writing: Principles & Procedures and is currently in its sixth revised edition. His second book, Architectural Materials for Construction (1995), remains in print. He was also a regular contributor to Progressive Architecture magazine, writing the Specifications Clinic column that ran from 1956-1975. Mr. Rosen, who received a Bachelor of Chemical Engineering degree from the City College of New York in 1938, began his career as Civil Specifications Engineer with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers from 1941-46. From 1964-73, Mr. Rosen was the Chief of Specifications for the New York office of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, and worked on the Hirschhorn Museum and the Lyndon B. Johnson Library. In 1973, he went into private practice and worked on the Jacob K. Javits Center. He taught at the Pratt Institute, the University of Wisconsin, and Rennselaer Polytechnic Institute. He was also a member of the Committee of Examination for the National Council of Architectural Registration Boards. The son of Russian Jewish immigrants, Mr. Rosen was born on February 2, 1915. In 1929, the family moved to Mountaindale, NY. There, they ran a grocery store, above which was a hotel that they operated during tourist season. Though he only lived there a few years, he always had fond memories of Mountaindale. His sister Zelda was born there in 1931. Mr. Rosen wed Rose Lillian Barenberg in 1939. Rose died in 1992. Mr. Rosen is survived by his sister Zelda Tenenbaum; three sons: Dr. Jeffrey Rosen, a professor of psychology at the City College of New York; Mark Rosen, a labor arbitrator in Washington, D.C.; Peter Rosen, Director of Real Estate at George Mason University, Virginia; and five grandchildren.

The dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial on the National Mall in Washington will be held on Aug. 28, the 48th anniversary of Dr. King's March on Washington and his ''I Have a Dream'' speech. The dedication, which is to include remarks by President Obama, is free and open to the public; tickets for the reserved viewing areas are sold out. Destination DC, a marketing organization for the city, has teamed with hotels to offer a limited number of ticket packages for the reserved areas, which are standing room only. The packages offer tickets to the ceremony with a minimum purchase of two nights in one of 16 hotels. The number of tickets you receive corresponds to the number of occupants in your room.

Many readers had strong reactions to last week's Metropolitan cover article by Peter Applebome, ''Williamsburg on the Hudson.'' The article ran online with a different headline, ''Hipsters on the Hudson,'' and for many commenters that word was a lightning rod. Additionally, they took issue with the comparisons drawn between various Hudson Valley towns and New York City neighborhoods. Readers also responded to Robin Finn's article about urban garden theft, ''Pilfered Peppers in City Gardens; Tomatoes, Too.'' Below, excerpts from the comments on both stories, drawn from NYTimes.com. For what it's worth, I would argue that Rhinebeck is the Upper West Side, and Millbrook is the Upper East Side. John C.,

PAEZ--George Dr.,passed away on July 29th. A graduate of Columbia University and the University of Chicago, he served during WWII and received the Purple Heart. His diverse career included work in nuclear physics, financial and business management. He is survived by his wife Antoinette Molodowitz Paez. A private celebration of life will be held in September.

An opinion essay on Aug. 7 about the benefits of boredom gave the wrong word for what David Foster Wallace's posthumous novel, ''The Pale King,'' calls low-level Internal Revenue Service employees who review tax returns. It is wigglers, not wrigglers.

KLASS--Blossom Marcus, passed away on August 5, 2011. She was to be 83 on August 20. Blossom was the devoted wife of Lionel Klass, who died on February 25, 2000. She was a gifted teacher, a world traveler, a lover of the arts, and especially of gardens. A long time resident of Midwood, Brooklyn, Blossom was an avid community activist, holding executive positions in the Nottingham Association, New York Community Hospital Advisory Board, and the 70 Precinct Community Council. She deeply understood the role of the citizen in city affairs and was committed to improving and unifying her community. Blossom prided herself on bringing together disparate elements in the neighborhood, and enjoyed a wide circle of diverse friends, who will miss her.

DEBT spirals: the term sounds ominous. As it should -- these market vortexes are posing grave dangers to the global economy right now.A national debt crisis is a bank run writ large, says Kenneth Rogoff, an economics professor at Harvard and co-author with Carmen M. Reinhart of ''This Time Is Different,'' a history of financial crises. When a country like Greece goes deep into debt, bond investors start to worry they won't get their money back. What can happen next is a debt spiral, a vicious circle of sinking confidence, rising borrowing costs and, ultimately, rising debt burdens. As investors lose confidence in a country, its bond prices drop, its bond yields rise and its government must pay higher interest rates to borrow. That, in turn, deepens the debt problem -- and the whole thing starts over again. Debt spirals are dangerous, but they aren't inevitable. ''Country debt crises are essentially political,'' Mr. Rogoff says. Governments can often stem the crisis by reducing spending, raising taxes or both. But such steps are particularly difficult-- and politically unappetizing -- when growth is slack, as it is now in much of the world. Tightening the belt slows growth even more, eroding tax revenue and -- you guessed it -- increasing the debt burden, at least in the short term.Of course, the best way to avoid a debt spiral is to avoid running up a lot of debt in the first place -- when the economy is doing well. ''If you walk outside without a raincoat and the sun is shining, you are fine,'' Mr. Rogoff says. ''But if it starts pouring, you are going to get wet.''
Television Ginia Bellafante
