SCHNEIDER--Graham Mark. The Bugler called for Graham Mark Schneider at the age of 84 on August 11, 2011. He was born into a loving home filled with music, letters, and books. Committed to helping others, he was an Eagle Scout, a WWII Veteran, a Trial Attorney for 50 years, the founder and first President of the Auxiliary Police Benevolent Association. His desire to ensure the dignity of others, involved his support of Native Americans, history of the Jewish people and Democratic Politics. His wife of 57 years Lois, children Karen and Jonathan, grandchildren Melissa and Alexis, sons-in-law Peter and James, family and friends have all been enriched by his teachings. We salute him.

Vincent van Gogh's fascination with sunflowers is reflected in the many shades of yellow setting off summer tans, including a luncheon dress, the foil for a beehive hat and bag. Other eye-catchers: Alexander McQueen's moth-pattern evening dress and baroque sandals, a bicycle in taxicab camouflage and fields of sunflowers and black-eyed Susans in city markets. And if sunflowers are not your style, what about the banana-print shirt below?

I remember quite clearly one of my middle-school teachers telling me that I was a stone with sharp, jagged edges, but that I would turn into a smooth river stone as I grew older. During the years while I was making this film, I felt like I was getting sharper and sharper instead. ZHAO LIANG, a filmmaker, on ''Petition,'' a documentary that angered the Chinese government. [12]

HILTON--Alice Mary, Ph.D.,died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Wednesday, August 10, 2011, aged 92, with her two beloved daughters by her side. Scholar, author, and lecturer, Dr. Hilton read the classics and mathematics at the University of Oxford. She continued her studies in mathematics and electrical engineering at the University of California and Caltech and art history at Columbia University. Over the course of her career, Dr. Hilton published three books including Logic, Computing Machines, and Automation, as well as hundreds of monographs, essays, and articles related to the roots and development of Western Civilization. Among her professional accomplishments, she was President of the Society for Social Responsibility in Science and Founder and President of The Institute for Cybercultural Research and the Arts-in-Context Education Foundation. Dr. Hilton explored the arts in the context of historical events and scientific milestones and, for close to four decades, offered related lectures and seminars at The Metropolitan Museum of Art and at many other national and international venues. She is survived by her daughters, Barbara Mary Hilton Hayward and Kathryn Anne Hilton-Hayward, and her granddaughter, Saskia Ama Sams-Yeboah. A private funeral service and interment will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue, New York. A celebration of Alice Mary Hilton's life will be held in New York in the autumn. Donations in her memory may be made to her favorite charities, Amnesty International or Habitat for Humanity, or to another charitable organization.

ONE of the most harrowing stretches in Wall Street history began with the loss of the AAA credit rating of the United States and ended with fears of a new recession. In between, the wild swings in the financial markets captivated the nation, and the world. Even financial professionals were grasping for answers. Many were selling -- and many were buying as fast as they could. Each was making a bet on whether last week was a hiccup, or the start of something worse.

DEBT spirals: the term sounds ominous. As it should -- these market vortexes are posing grave dangers to the global economy right now.A national debt crisis is a bank run writ large, says Kenneth Rogoff, an economics professor at Harvard and co-author with Carmen M. Reinhart of ''This Time Is Different,'' a history of financial crises. When a country like Greece goes deep into debt, bond investors start to worry they won't get their money back. What can happen next is a debt spiral, a vicious circle of sinking confidence, rising borrowing costs and, ultimately, rising debt burdens. As investors lose confidence in a country, its bond prices drop, its bond yields rise and its government must pay higher interest rates to borrow. That, in turn, deepens the debt problem -- and the whole thing starts over again. Debt spirals are dangerous, but they aren't inevitable. ''Country debt crises are essentially political,'' Mr. Rogoff says. Governments can often stem the crisis by reducing spending, raising taxes or both. But such steps are particularly difficult-- and politically unappetizing -- when growth is slack, as it is now in much of the world. Tightening the belt slows growth even more, eroding tax revenue and -- you guessed it -- increasing the debt burden, at least in the short term.Of course, the best way to avoid a debt spiral is to avoid running up a lot of debt in the first place -- when the economy is doing well. ''If you walk outside without a raincoat and the sun is shining, you are fine,'' Mr. Rogoff says. ''But if it starts pouring, you are going to get wet.''
Subject: Hillary Buckholtz, 31, a publicist in Washington, D.C. Previous Potter Exposure: Nephew once had a Harry Potter-themed birthday party.

MAZEL--Dr. Alan J. Died on August 12, 2011. Loving husband of Vicki. Devoted father of Joseph Mazel, Geoffrey Mazel and Ila Scheckner. Adored grandfather of Max, Brian, Mandy, Benny, Eliza and Jenna. Brother of Barbara Solan. Beloved father-in- law, uncle and cousin. Services 11:30am on Monday August 15, 2011, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

One of baseball's most enthusiastic bloggers and Tweeters is a 55-year-old grandfather with eight children who last worked for a major league team in 1993. He is Dale Murphy, a two-time most valuable player who starred for the Atlanta Braves in the 1980s and is now, officially, technologically advanced. Murphy was easily the best player on many hopeless Braves teams that found a national following through TBS. Among his many fans was Alex Rodriguez, who grew up in Miami and once wore No. 3 in Murphy's honor. Murphy includes that number in the name he uses on Twitter, @dalemurphy3, and he blogs at murphtalks.blogspot.com.

In the late 1990s, the Auburn University golfer Jason Dufner and his buddies, fueled by beer, would fetch a few irons from their bags and hit balls late at night - from their front porch. They aimed at lampposts along the street, which happened to include a campus engineering building.

I'M the youngest of five brothers. I learned strategy early; if I couldn't figure out where they all were and avoid them, one would always give me a job. My nickname was Remote Control because they would always make me get up to change the TV channel. My father worked for Coca-Cola, so I grew up with a very famous brand. He was vice president for prestige accounts, with clients like the United States Olympic Committee and Disney.

COLE--Robert Vail Jr.,49, of New York City died August 3, 2011 after a valiant battle with cancer. He was an accomplished architect specializing in the preservation of historic structures. As a Principal of the New York firm Swanke Hayden Connell Architects, Rob oversaw restoration works that included New York City's Hall of Records and Criminal Courts, New York City Public School 157, the Federal Triangle IRS Headquarters Building in Washington DC, and the West Virginia State Capitol. He was the primary author of Historic Preservation - Project Planning and Estimating, the first comprehensive guide on planning and cost estimating for historic preservation. Prior to joining SHCA in 1998, Rob was Corporate Officer with the firm of Carey & Co., serving as project manager for award-winning projects including the seismic upgrade and rehabilitation of San Francisco's City Hall, War Memorial Opera House, and Spreckels Temple of Music. Graduate of the University of Oregon School of Architecture and Allied Arts. Born in Hudson, Ohio. Son of the late Robert Cole and survived by his mother Dolores Cole, sisters Sandra Brown, Patricia Gralow, Priscilla Murray, Wendy Aguilar, and nine nieces and nephews. Rob touched the lives of countless people with his intellect, humor, passion, and warmth. Donations may be sent in memory of Rob to the Greenwich Village Society of Historic Preservation, 232 East 11th Street New York, NY 10003 or www.gvhsp.org. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

DVORAK--Stephen Charles, of Westfield, NJ passed away peacefully at his home on Monday, June 27, 2011. He was 89 years old. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Phillips Dvorak, and nieces and nephews (Caroline Yates of Rochester, NY, Robert Dvorak of Babylon, NY and Barbara Kothe, of Waxhaw, NC). He is pre-deceased by his first wife, Florine O. Dvorak in 1985. Stephen Dvorak was born on January 15, 1922 in the Bronx, NY and attended Townsend Harris High School (class of 1939). Stephen graduated from Webb Institute of Naval Architecture in 1950 with a degree in Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering. During World War II Stephen was the first student at Webb to leave for service in the US Army, serving as a technician from 1942-1946. He received a Masters Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Columbia University in 1956. Throughout his career in marine engineering, Stephen worked for NY Shipbuilding Corp., Designers and Planners, JJ Henry Co, the Hoboken Shipyard and Coastal Drydock and Repair. He also established an independent broker/dealer, Stephen Dvorak and Co., and concluded his working years at the Internal Revenue Service. In addition to his career, Stephen had a life-long love of ships, trains and trolley cars. Until recently, he travelled extensively throughout the US and Europe exploring those passions and supporting numerous not-for-profit organizations dedicated to preserving vintage methods of transportation. He was also a devoted alumnus of Webb Institute and kept in close touch with his fellow graduates and the Institute throughout the years. Stephen was a member of the Westfield Presbyterian Church and a Free Mason. A memorial service will be held on August 20 at 11 o'clock am at the Westfield Presbyterian Church, Westfield NJ and there will be a family visiting hour immediately preceding the service at 10am. Donations may be made in Stephen's memory to the Westfield Presbyterian Church, 140 Mountain Avenue, Westfield, NJ 07090. Services by Gray Funeral Home, Westfield, NJ
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Klinsmann Will Find There Are No Points for Style,'' Aug. 7: The United States is not the only country with a multicultural men's national soccer team.

THE Argentine stylist Marina Muñoz is well versed in cuff links, oxford flats, Panama hats and all manners of tomboy dressing. So when the idea to swap our girly satchels for a no-fuss briefcase struck, T: The New York Times Style Magazine knew exactly whom to take to the men's department. At Brooks Brothers, where doctor's bags and sharp-edged boxy cases were displayed handsomely throughout the sales floor, it was a cognac-colored alligator attaché that caught Ms. Munoz's eye. ''This is exquisite,'' she said holding it at her hip. ''I would wear it with a pair of A.P.C. jeans, a cashmere sweater and Belgian loafers.'' Alligator billfold briefcase, $6,500. Go to brooksbrothers.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

An answer last Sunday in the Q&A column about touring Rome on spring break misstated the price for a tour offered by Agnes Crawford, of Understanding Rome Tours. Like all of Ms. Crawford's tours, the ''Heart of Ancient Rome'' tour costs around 180 euros ($250), depending on the size of your group and length of the tour. It is not 12 euros.

SPERRY--Theodore, died peacefully at age 96, in Sarasota on August 6th with Herta (nee Ungar), his devoted wife of 62 years, by his side. A native of Vienna, Theo lived for 60 years in the New York area. He served proudly with the 2nd New Zealand Expeditionary Force in World War II in Egypt, Greece, and Italy. A graduate of NYU, Ted worked with brokerage firm Fahnestock and co-founded electronics company Fifth Dimension in Princeton. Ted was junior tennis champion and ranked number one in men's doubles in Austria, a ranked Eastern senior player, and a senior doubles competitor at Wimbledon. A USTA volunteer official for over 25 years, Theo was rep to the ITF for senior tennis. Ted was an Emeritus Director of the International Tennis Club of the USA. He was predeceased by daughter Claudia (Michael Kalafer) and granddaughter Nikole and is survived also by daughter Diana (the late William Temple), son Tom, sister Ina Ginsburg, grandchildren Scott, Liz, Justin, and Luisa, four great-grandchildren, and nieces and nephews.

Because of an editing error, the Keeping Score column last Sunday, about the role that luck has played in the hitting streak of Atlanta Braves second baseman Dan Uggla, misstated, in some copies, his career batting average and season batting average after he extended the streak to 27 games on Aug. 6. Uggla was a .258 career hitter, not a .257 one, and his batting average was .220, not .217. An accompanying chart also included incorrect statistics in some copies for Uggla's number of home runs, his batting average during the hitting streak, where his average ranked among hitting streaks of 25 games or more since 1919, and how much his overall batting average increased during the hitting streak. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/sports.

An article last Sunday about the play ''Clybourne Park,'' an examination of race, gentrification and real estate, misstated part of the name of the San Francisco theater where it had its West Coast premiere in January. It is the American Conservatory Theater, not the American Repertory Theater.
FISCAL calamity? Deceased former governor? Middling Jay-Z album? New Yorkers had a rough week. On Twitter, thankfully, no wound is too fresh to poke at in 140 characters.

An opinion essay on Aug. 7 about President Obama's leadership and principles referred incorrectly to the number of deportations under his presidency. More than 700,000 immigrants were deported during Mr. Obama's first two years in office; it is not the case that a million immigrants were deported in 2010, the year Mr. Obama gave a speech on immigration reform. Also, a larger number of deportations occurred over the two terms of George W. Bush, Mr. Obama's predecessor; Mr. Obama has not overseen more deportations than any other president.

A credit accompanying the Windows on the World illustration on Aug. 7, showing the view from the writer Elmore Leonard's window, gave an outdated reference to his latest novel. It is ''Djibouti,'' not ''Road Dogs.''

Ernie Johnson Sr., a beloved former Braves player in Milwaukee and Braves announcer in Atlanta, died Friday night after an extended illness at 87. Filling in on TNT's golf coverage this weekend for his son, the announcer Ernie Johnson Jr., is Verne Lundquist.

LYNCH--Dr. Richard B.,Jr, of Philadelphia on July 31. Son, RB is a respected Jazz composer and former New York Times reporter. See www.ediekins.org on Internet Explorer/ Cobi Narita/ Ran Blake Newsletter.

A report in the Extra Bases baseball notebook last Sunday about pitcher Cliff Lee's fifth shutout of the season for the Philadelphia Phillies misidentified the last pitcher who had more than five shutouts in a season. It was Randy Johnson, who had six shutouts in 1998 (two for the Seattle Mariners and four for the Houston Astros) -- not Tim Belcher, who had eight for the Dodgers in 1989.

These privately owned dogs were mobilized, with their owners, to search for victims of the 9/11 attacks. They are now retired. MOXIE, Age 13, Winthrop, Mass. She arrived at the World Trade Center site on Sept.11 and began working the next morning. Though she is trained to find survivors, she identified six bodies and many body parts during the eight days she worked there. Since her owner retired her at age 7, she has hunted and spent time on the waterfront.

For those who want to become fully immersed in a place without stepping onto an airplane, there's a digital magazine that aims to bring travel to you. TRVL, a free interactive app for the iPhone and iPad, is not a traditional glossy magazine, or even a digital alternative to one. Each issue is a self-contained feature article.

TWO years ago everybody seemed to be making a movie about the fashion world. Now they're writing a book. Three biographies of Coco Chanel are coming out, in case you've never heard of the lady from the Rue Cambon. There are also a number of designer monographs, quirky memoirs and elegant surveys from magazine archives. It's a huge season for fashion books -- huge, as Diana Vreeland would have insisted, herself the subject of a new work. In fact, I am most curious about ''Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel'' (Abrams), by Lisa Immordino Vreeland, who is married to a grandson of the legendary editor. Though D.V.'s own accounts remain in print, I expect ''The Eye Has to Travel'' to offer insights as well as a fresh supply of photos.

BRUNO--Iris, 88, of Greenwich Village died on August 8th, 2011. Born in New York City on June 4th 1923 to Donato and Serafina DiNapoli, Miss Bruno lived in the village her entire life. She had an extensive career employed as a travel agent with Liberty Travel. Iris was predeceased by her parents and brother Arthur. She is survived by her cousins and their families. Funeral services will be held at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker Street, New York, NY on Monday August 15 from 2:00 to 5:00pm and 7:00 to 9:00pm. WEISSMAN--Ira J.,of Northvale, NJ passed away on Sunday, July 10, 2011 at the Rockleigh Jewish Home. He was born on January 5, 1931 in Yonkers, NY. Ira received his BBA from the City College of New York and his MBA from the University of Wisconsin. After graduate school, Ira worked for Hart, Schaffner and Marx in Chicago, IL, before returning to New York City where he joined Imperia Foods, Inc. While learning the cheese processing business, he became an importer of hard cheeses eventually rising to President of Imperia Foods. Additionally, Ira served on the Board of Directors of the Cheese Importers Association of America for several years. He was elected President of the CIAA in 1995 and 1996. Active in many community organizations, he was chosen to be a member of the first Community Board in the Tribeca area of New York. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Plaza Cooperative in Fort Lee, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Dr. Myrna Schear, his sons, Miles and Marlowe, his brother Clark Weissman and his sister, Frances Doughty.

BOSWORTH--Stanley A. The entire Saint Ann's community mourns the loss of our founding headmaster. Stanley gave our school his life, his spirit, and his extraordinary vision. Thousands of students, past and present, are the beneficiaries of his intelligence, passion, and commitment. All of us who are members of the community he created mourn his passing, express our gratitude for what he created, and extend our sympathies to his family and many friends. A memorial will be held at St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Church at 2pm on October 15. In lieu of flowers, the Bosworth family has created the Stanley A. Bosworth Memorial Fund at Saint Ann's School.

SOMETIMES inspiration arrives when you least expect it. That's certainly true for ''Stone Walls: Personal Boundaries,'' the latest book by the photographer Mariana Cook. For eight years Ms. Cook took her two medium-format cameras and a tripod to places as far afield as Malta, Peru and the Aran Islands, searching for dry stone walls built without mortar but with plenty of patience and ingenuity. (An interactive feature on five photographs from the book is here.) ''It was their beauty that kept me going,'' Ms. Cook said. ''You've got to be a little nuts to go all over the world, tromping around fields looking for walls.''

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Woodshed Collective's production of the play ''The Tenant'' reversed the names of the two women shown with three other collective members. Emily Fishbaine is third from the left, and Jocelyn Kuritsky is fourth. And the article misstated the collective's real estate relationship with the West-Park Presbyterian Church, which it is using as the setting for ''The Tenant.'' Woodshed is renting the space, it was not donated by the church.

Several years ago, I began anthropological fieldwork among a ''tribe'' of Cariocas (residents of Rio de Janeiro): socialites and their maids, divorced housewives, unemployed secretaries, aspiring celebrities, transvestite prostitutes and other patients who were making Brazil the ''empire of the scalpel.'' I first met Éster through her former employer, a successful plastic surgeon, for whom she'd worked as his personal cook. Éster lived nearby in Vidigal, a favela near the brilliant white sand beach of Leblon. One day after she'd prepared dinner for his family she shyly told him in private, ''Doutor, I want to put in silicone.'' After reading up on prosthetic materials in an Internet café, she'd settled on a midcost model of breast implant (about $900) and convinced the doctor that she was a good candidate. Hesitant to perform the surgery on his domestic employee, he referred her to a young resident in the clinic of Dr. Ivo Pitanguy, Brazil's most influential plastic surgeon.

An article last Sunday about atomic bomb survivors in Japan who have turned against nuclear power in the wake of the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi plant misstated the number of bomb survivors represented by a group called Hidankyo, which has appealed for the first time for Japan to eliminate civilian nuclear power. The group says it represents roughly 50,000 survivors of the United States bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki -- not 10,000, which is the approximate number of survivors represented by the group in Nagasaki alone.

WHAT'S most remarkable about the faces in these turn-of-the-20th-century New York police photographs is that many -- with the simple addition of a baseball cap or the mere adjustment of a hairstyle -- would not look out of place on the city's streets today. Unquestionably antique yet eerily familiar, the likenesses suggest that certain urban faces occur and reoccur, reborn, perhaps, in new bodies across the span of time. Take, for instance, Henry Freymuller, a laborer arrested on a burglary charge in November 1911. Put him in a Jeter jersey with a Heineken in his hand and Mr. Freymuller could have been spotted at Tuesday night's Yankees game.
Art Carol Vogel
Classical Allan Kozinn

HEALY--Bernadine. Hunter College High School Alumnae/i Association is deeply saddened by the passing of one of its brightest stars, Dr. Bernadine Healy. Graduating at the top of her class in 1962, Dr. Healy went on to an exceptional career in medicine and public health. In light of her significant achievements, Dr. Healy was awarded Hunter College High School's highest honor, being named a Distinguished Alumna in 1991. She was honored again in 2009 by the HCHSAA at its Annual Spring Gala. Our deepest condolences to her family.

SUZUKI--Dr. Yasunosuke of Scarsdale NY, Professor Emeritus of Pathology and Community Medicine at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine died on August 9th, 2011. He was born in Shimoda, Japan in 1929 and graduated from Keio Medical School. Dr. Suzuki was a preeminent pathologist in asbestos related diseases. His research led to a global re-examination of asbestos use, and to massive class action suits by workers who had died from cancer. Suzuki received the Ramazzini Award and the Selikoff Lifetime Achievement Award. He is survived by his wife Mieko, and three children: Hiroko, Motoyuki, and Takaaki; and four grandchildren: Katherine, Theo, Thomas, and Miyo. Memorial Service: Saturday, August 20th, 11:30am, Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, Department of Preventative Medicine Scholarship Fund.

Motorists who never experienced the delights of central tire inflation afforded by the Hummer H1, Arnold Schwarzenegger's favorite S.U.V., may yet have their opportunity. Goodyear announced Thursday that it was developing technology that would keep a passenger car or commercial truck's tires rolling at optimum levels of pressure, eliminating the need for handheld gauges or stops at air pumps. The feature, called Air Maintenance Technology, would be contained within the tire and would require no external monitoring systems.

He is survived by his beloved wife Robyn Glaser, loving sister Diane Sugal, nieces Bonnie and Cheri Sugal and grandniece Katie Shane, his brother and sisters-in-law Gary and Thea Glaser and Arlene Goldman and their children. Arnie will be terribly missed by his family and the countless people whose lives he helped to better.

FOR years, the 18th-century barrio now known as TriBall (short for Triángulo de Ballesta, an imagined triangle bordered by Ballesta, one of the area's cross streets) was long associated with drugs and prostitutes, and therefore was duly ignored by much of the city. A cleanup began in earnest three years ago when a handful of Madrileño entrepreneurs and local merchants noticed that the bones of these ancient byways, which are located between Madrid's Malasaña neighborhood and Gran Vía boulevard, were charming. Anchored by 400-year-old churches and a crumbling but magnificent 19th-century theater, properties in the area were soon bought up and rehabbed in a focused effort to woo artists, boutique owners and chefs into what were once brothels and sex shops. The result has been a flowering of commerce, and a flurry of new restaurants, shops and watering holes. Though some prostitution lingers, the popular press has taken to calling the area Madrid's ''new Soho.''SARAH WILDMAN

Hong Kong, June 4, 2011 My husband and I are eight months into a three-year trip, and are blogging about our experiences at livingif.com. This photo was taken during the candlelight vigil held in Victoria Park in Hong Kong for victims of the Tiananmen Square protests. Thousands of people crowded the park. It was a moving experience even though we didn't understand anything that the speakers were saying because of the language barrier. ERICA CHUA, Minneapolis

Pet Airways has been named the most pet-friendly airline in North America by Petfinder.com, an organization that provides an online database of animals who need homes. In its annual review, Petfinder considered Pet Airways, which transports only animals in the main cabin of its twin turbo-prop planes, to be the most pet-friendly airline over all, as well as the best for large animals.

KLETT--John Cleveland, Jr. New York City attorney, born November 9, 1926, died at home after a short illness on August 10 at the age of 84. Mr. Klett was a member of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore from December 1952 until April 1960. Thereafter, he served as tax counsel for Hertz Corporation from April 1960 until August 1962; he joined Pepsi-Cola in 1962 in the Law Department; in 1964 served as president and chief executive officer of Empire State Sugar Company, Inc., a subsidiary of PepsiCo, Inc.; and in 1966 he was appointed Vice President, Administration, Pepsi-Cola Co. In 1969 he left Pepsi-Cola to start his own practice which he maintained until June 2011. Mr. Klett received his LLB from Fordham in 1949, where he was on the Dean's List. Over his career he has written extensively and been a lecturer on Federal taxation. He served in the U.S. Naval Reserve during World War II from 1943-1946; and served in Korea from 1950 to 1952 as Lt. j.g. in various positions on the USS Gull and the USS Scout; for which service he received the Bronze star and other Presidential and United Nations citations. He is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Larsen; three daughters: Kathleen M. Garrett; Margaret M. Barsalou; and Carolyn M. Klett; 13 grandchildren; and brother, Joseph Klett. Two sons, Jack Cleveland Klett, II and George B. Klett., predeceased him. Visiting at Charles Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY, Monday, August 15 from 6-8pm. A Requiem Mass will be held on Tuesday, August 16 at 10am at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Church of St. Thomas More in his memory.

An article last Sunday about an Anglican church in Tripoli, Libya, where congregants spoke about the mood of the capital during the war, quoted incorrectly from comments by an anonymous parishioner who said that some rebel sympathizers act in public as though they support Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The parishioner said, ''When NATO bombs at night, I hear my neighbors clap and cheer 'bravo,' and in the morning they are with the leader.'' He did not say ''in the morning they are with the rebels.''

ON his first trip out West, Bob Kolbrener went to Yosemite National Park, wandered into Best's Studio, the gallery of Ansel Adams and, in his words, ''was overcome by the classical music playing, the incense burning and the most fantastic photography on the wall.'' Then, in 1968, Mr. Kolbrener returned to Yosemite to take part in a workshop led by Adams, who taught the young photographer how to capture nature's most fleeting and dramatic moments. ''Great landscape photographs are very short-lived, weather-related events,'' said the now-renowned Mr. Kolbrener, who makes his first trip to Long Island on Aug. 20 for the opening of an exhibition of 25 of his best-known images. Pamela Lerner Antiques, 145 South Country Road, Bellport, N.Y.; (631) 776-2183. BRUCE PASK

One of the most important questions for small businesses hovering through all of the tumult of the last three years is whether they’ve been able to get the credit they need. The question has been hotly debated — even becoming a partisan issue last year, when Congress wrestled with the small-business lending fund that ultimately became law in the small-business jobs act. Banks tell anyone who will listen that they are eager to lend to any creditworthy business they can find. Republicans tend to put it slightly differently: small businesses that deserve credit can get it, but many are too cautious to make investments right now. Many Democrats and some small-business advocates say a good loan is hard to find.

CUT BANK, Mont. — The most direct path through Glacier National Park is called, famously and aptly, Going-to-the-Sun Road. About 51 miles long, it begins in the town of West Glacier, proceeds pleasantly along the wooded southeastern shore of Lake McDonald, providing intermittent glimpses of soaring peaks, and then, as if a giant had stepped on the end of the road, mistaking it for a seesaw, begins ruthlessly, gorgeously climbing. It goes northeast for three miles or so, then makes a hairpin turn and heads southeast along a mountain precipice and up, up, up — endlessly up if you’re on a bicycle. From the turn it’s eight miles to Logan Pass. There, at 6,646 feet, the road crosses the Continental Divide.

The Metropolitan Opera does not have a lock on outdoor, large-screen, high-definition opera transmissions. A popular summertime opera and classical music film festival has been operating for two decades in Vienna’s City Hall Square. Now a one-evening version, called the Vienna Music Film Festival NY, is heading to Brooklyn Bridge Park on Aug. 29 and will feature filmed excerpts of European opera productions. Austrian tourism and cultural authorities, along with the Vienna-based International Music + Media Center — a nonprofit association founded under the aegis of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization — and Czekaj Artistic Productions, are backing the show. The Met will present H.D. performances at Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5.

The picture of the Japanese woman among the ruins of Natori appeared on the front page of this newspaper and in newspapers around the world after the earthquake and tsunami. She sits on a concrete foundation, sobbing, her red boots lined up neatly to her right. She wasn’t identified in the photo, but some information about Akane Ito, which turns out to be her name, later surfaced. The most complete version of her touching story is in this article in The Daily Mail from April. When the picture was taken, Ito later told the newspaper, she thought all 13 of her dogs had been lost. The Daily Mail update shows her reunited with two of them. (Sadly, since the article appeared, none of her remaining dogs have been found, according to news reports.)

In an article in Friday’s paper, I described how some companies that operate dirty coal-fired power plants are playing chicken as they face a decision on whether to retire them or install expensive scrubbers and filters. Patti Smith is variously known as a musician, poet, artist and memoirist. Now add feature film writer to that list. She confirmed Friday that she will be collaborating with the playwright and screenwriter John Logan on an adaptation of her best-selling book “Just Kids,” which chronicled her early years in New York, focusing on her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. She said that she and Mr. Logan were friends and that she had particularly admired his script for “Coriolanus,” the coming film adaptation directed by a mutual friend of theirs, Ralph Fiennes. She also cited Mr. Logan’s Tony-winning play about Mark Rothko, “Red.” “It was a beautiful script and he’s very knowledgeable about art,” Ms. Smith said, speaking by phone, adding later, “He’s very knowledgeable about Robert and his work too.” There’s no director or financing set, though Ms. Smith’s literary agent, Betsy Lerner, said several producers and especially actresses have expressed interest since “Just Kids” was published last year.

SCHWIMMER--Ruth, 85, died in Boca Raton, FL on August 10. Beloved wife of Leonard for 58 years and mother of Danae, Allyson, Claudia and loving grandmother of Zoe, Rachel, Dara, and Logan. A longtime resident of Lake Success, she possessed a natural grace and talent in everything she touched, whether it was art, fashion, decorating, music, literature but especially in tennis, where her form and skills were superb. PARIS -- One source of last week's market panic could have been set off by a simple work of fiction. A series of articles in Le Monde, ''End of the Line for the Euro,'' looked at how a collapse of the currency might hypothetically play out, particularly against the backdrop of French presidential elections next year.

GEWIRTZ--Morty. Beloved husband of Karin, loving father of Margo, adoring Papa of Avery and Spencer, devoted brother of George. We will miss your loving and caring presence forever. Funeral services will be held Tuesday 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81St.).

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. - The banner for foreign-born players at the P.G.A. Championship ended up in the slender hands of Anders Hansen on Sunday. He tied for the day's best round by shooting a four-under 66, but finished one stroke out of a playoff as the players ahead of him silenced questions about why Americans have been unable to win a major in recent years. Hansen birdied one-third of the back nine. A bogey at No. 16, a par-4 tailored to power hitters, kept him from joining Jason Dufner and Keegan Bradley in their playoff for the title.

In the annals of the sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church, most of the cases that have come to light happened years before to children and teenagers who have long since grown into adults. But a painfully fresh case is devastating Catholics in Kansas City, Mo., where a priest, who was arrested in May, has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of taking indecent photographs of young girls, most recently during an Easter egg hunt just four months ago.

Father-in-law of John Sicher. Step-grandfather of Carolyn Sicher Woolf. Grandfather of Sierra Fromberg and Lucas Steinberg. Father of Marlene Steinberg. He achieved great success as a respected business leader as vice president of his former employer Lightolier. Services will be at the Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel at 1pm, Sunday, August 21, 2011, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, NY.

CANNON FALLS, Minn. - House Speaker John A. Boehner once explained conservatives' hard line on the debt limit this way: ''A lot of them,'' he told a radio host, believe ''enough chaos'' would make opponents yield. Chaos arrived in financial markets last week after Standard & Poor's, citing Washington gridlock, stripped the United States of its AAA credit rating.

RAUCH--Rose Golub, 96, on August 10th. Beloved mother of Erika Rauch-McQuillan and Margaret Rauch; grandmother of Andrei and Lisa McQuillan; adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by husband Solomon Rauch, M.D., sisters May Lew and Aimee Golub and brother Sidney Golub. Contribution may be made to Doctors without Borders.

Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn't resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss -- the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City -- and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you try convincing your girlfriend that your studio -- which already looks like the Flintstones' prop room -- just needs one more boulder. ''I was like, 'The whole point about me growing as an artist is I have to grow in all of these different directions,' '' Mr. Distenfeld recalled saying.

Investors woke on Aug. 8 to a still-weak economy, market reaction to the downgrade of Treasury securities by Standard & Poor's the previous Friday, and volatile world markets. The Dow eventually dropped 634 points that day, to be followed by a week of ups and downs. The volume of traffic to business information sites on Aug. 8 increased 40 percent over Aug. 1. Most search terms that led to business sites included variations on the Dow, crude oil prices, NYSE and Nasdaq. But, ''Nicole Kidman,'' who will be on ''Sesame Street'' this fall, came up as search No. 28. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Amazon makes it extremely easy to take a bunch of words and publish them as a book for the Kindle e-reader. And longtime professional writers like Edward Jay Epstein, the author of books on Hollywood, diamonds and the assassination of John F. Kennedy, are refashioning their collected works into electronic format. ''The numbers are not great - last weekend I sold only 165 e-books - but they grow, like compound interest, with each new title,'' he wrote recently at theatlanticwire.com.

Disney's high-profile remake of ''The Lone Ranger'' has ridden into the sunset, at least in its current configuration. That long-gestating movie project -- starring Johnny Depp as Tonto, produced by Jerry Bruckheimer and directed by Gore Verbinski -- was expected to start shooting in October in New Mexico. But Walt Disney Studios pulled the plug late Friday after reaching an impasse with the filmmakers over costs, according to an industry official briefed on the matter who asked for anonymity because the details of the shutdown were considered private. A Disney spokesman declined to comment. Disney, according to the official, was willing to spend $200 million -- still an enormous amount of money for a western, which is perhaps Hollywood's riskiest genre -- but Mr. Bruckheimer and his team had sought a budget closer to $250 million. Hi-yo Silver and a-waaay with the entire project?

ATLANTA -- As she does every evening, Kelly Callahan walked her dogs through her East Atlanta neighborhood. As in many communities in a city with the 16th-highest foreclosure rate in the nation, there were plenty of empty, bank-owned properties for sale. She noticed something else. Those forlorn yards were peppered with overgrown gardens and big fruit trees, all bulging with the kind of bounty that comes from the high heat and afternoon thunderstorms that have defined Atlanta's summer.

The Yankees concluded a stretch of eight games in nine days against some of the American League's top teams Sunday by hanging around the clubhouse and packing for this week's seven-game trip after their meeting with the Tampa Bay Rays was postponed. On a day when the rain never let up, the Yankees received a respite after the challenging stretch. Manager Joe Girardi and his players reflected on the team's recent play, while Freddy Garcia showed off the cut on his right index finger to reporters.

The producer who is mounting a revival of ''Death of a Salesman'' on Broadway next year has tapped Andrew Garfield to play Biff, the wayward son of Willy Loman, a spokesman for the production said on Friday. Mr. Garfield, 28, who played a Facebook founder in ''The Social Network'' and just finished filming the title role in ''The Amazing Spider-Man,'' will join a heavyweight theater cast assembled by producer Scott Rudin, under the direction of Mike Nichols (''Spamalot,'' ''The Real Thing''). Philip Seymour Hoffman, an Oscar winner for ''Capote,'' will play Willy Loman, while Linda Emond (''Homebody/Kabul'') has been cast as his wife, Linda.

Curtis Martin is closely associated with football American-style, but these days, he appears to be taking a crash course in soccer. It is too early to say whether Martin may someday seek to become a team owner in Major League Soccer, but his interest in the sport is clearly growing. On Aug. 5, Martin took a seat in the director's box at Old Trafford in Manchester, England, where an impromptu version of the Cosmos, the legendary soccer team that had not played a real game in more than 25 years, took the field in a match against Manchester United. Martin was also in London in May, watching as Barcelona beat Manchester United to capture the UEFA Champions League title.

A growing number of nonprofit groups in California are being denied exemption from property taxes because the state's chief tax collector and assessors contend they do not do enough to benefit state residents, according to lawyers representing the groups. ''I have a client who applied for the exemption recently and has been denied on the basis that it would not be doing enough to benefit the citizens of California,'' said Ofer Lion, a lawyer. Mr. Lion would not name his client, but said it was new charity with ''a global outlook in its mission.''

LOS ANGELES - When last seen in these pages, in late 2009, the Hollywood power agent Tom Strickler had forsaken fame, fortune and his position as a partner in the Endeavor talent agency - which was then merging with the William Morris Agency - to climb peaks in Peru's Cordillera Huayhuash, and to start what he vaguely described as ''a nonprofit organization in the field of education.'' The education part of his adventure is now at hand: On Sept. 6, according to Mr. Strickler, the first campus of his newly established Extera Public Schools will open its doors to 264 students, in kindergarten through the third grade, in the largely Hispanic Boyle Heights section of Los Angeles.

9 P.M. (HBO) GLORIA: IN HER OWN WORDS After making headlines as a journalist in the 1960s in New York City with an exposé on the working conditions of Playboy Bunnies, Gloria Steinem, above, felt her political ideals expanding when she covered an abortion hearing for New York magazine in 1969 and learned of the horrifying experiences women had endured while trying to exercise reproductive rights. (Ms. Steinem kept secret the abortion she'd had at the age of 22.) On Aug. 26, 1970, she helped lead the Women's Strike for Equality on the 50th anniversary of the enactment of women's suffrage. By 1972 she had co-founded Ms. Magazine, beginning her ascent as the public face of feminism. This documentary from Peter Kunhardt chronicles Ms. Steinem's life through interviews and archival footage. Topics include her childhood in Toledo, Ohio; the inspiration for her work; her battle with breast cancer; and her late-in-life marriage and subsequent widowhood. Barbara Walters, Helen Gurley Brown, Phil Donahue and Larry King weigh in. 8 P.M. (ABC) BACHELOR PAD Jake Pavelka continues to be the focus of his former fiancée, Vienna Girardi, and her latest beau, Kasey Kahl, this time in a challenge in which players answer questions by throwing paint-soaked balls at bull's-eyes on one another's backs. Points are allotted for each body hit, with the winners treated to dates in a haunted hospital or a night on a private yacht.
Daniel D. McCracken, the first best-selling author of books that taught people how to use computers, died on July 30 in New York. He was 81. The cause was cancer, his wife, Helen Blumenthal, said.

If the first fear is global recession, the second is that central banks have run out of fixes. They do have means to respond, but only with radical and possibly dangerous policies whose efficacy is dubious. These nuclear monetary weapons might be better kept locked away. Printing money -- or quantitative easing -- has always been seen as the last resort. Now, it seems to be the only option. It has various manifestations, and recent weeks have shown some of its limitations.

James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks and the lead singer of the blues band the Straight Shot, took the stage at Williamsburg's Brooklyn Bowl on Sunday night. Unlike most events there, this concert was free - interesting, because revenue sharing will affect the N.B.A.'s next collective bargaining agreement. The sight of a league owner strutting on a stage during what could be a long labor struggle was one to behold. The correlation between the current financial squabbling between players and owners and much of Dolan's spending over the past decade rendered the reality of a free concert all the more fascinating.

LIPSEY--Robert Edward, 84, of New York and Lake Peekskill, NY, beloved husband of Sally Irene for 62 years, died Thursday. Devoted father of Marion Greenlee and her husband William, of Teaneck, NJ, Carol Hersh and her husband William of Great Neck, NY, and Eleanor Lipsey and her husband William Ho of London, England, he was also the proud and loving grandfather of Sarah, Michael, Julie, Kevin, Jennifer, Anna, Amanda and Lisa. At the National Bureau of Economic Research in New York from 1945 until his death, he published widely on the topics of international trade and direct investment, international comparisons of prices and output, and multinationals, and also served as director of the NBER's New York office. As Professor of Economics, Emeritus, at Queens College and The Graduate Center, CUNY, he continued to mentor graduate students until his death. At his request, no funeral will be held. Donations in his memory may be made to The Bronx High School of Science Alumni Association and Endowment Fund.

Patti Smith, below, is variously known as a musician, a poet, an artist and a memoirist. Now add feature-film writer to that list. She confirmed on Friday that she would collaborate with the playwright and screenwriter John Logan on an adaptation of her best-selling book ''Just Kids,'' which chronicled her early years in New York, focusing on her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. She said that she and Mr. Logan were friends and that she had particularly admired his script for ''Coriolanus,'' the coming film adaptation directed by a mutual friend of theirs, Ralph Fiennes. She also cited Mr. Logan's Tony-winning play about Mark Rothko, ''Red.'' ''It was a beautiful script, and he's very knowledgeable about art,'' Ms. Smith said by phone. ''He's very knowledgeable about Robert and his work too.'' There's no word on a director or financing, though Ms. Smith's literary agent, Betsy Lerner, said several producers and actors had expressed interest since ''Just Kids'' was published last year.

Listeners to 101.9 FM in New York, until recently a struggling alternative rock station, got a taste over the weekend of what its new owners hoped would be a successful new format: FM news. As on most news and talk stations, which are more common on the AM band, short news reports cycled around the clock, interspersed with traffic updates.

There is a reason that women go shopping in groups -- they like to ask their stylish friend, mother or the store's dressing room attendant whether something looks good. Go Try It On, a start-up that runs a Web site and mobile app for getting real-time feedback on outfits, believes that with computers and cellphones, fashion consultations should be possible even when people aren't together.
SCHNEIDER--Graham Mark. Adored uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle will hear the bagpipes play forever. Our love, your nieces and nephews

A lavish marketing campaign and positive reviews powered ''The Help'' to better-than-expected results at the weekend box office, but moviegoers ignored a ''Glee'' concert movie, a troubling sign for that TV musical's hopes of continued cultural dominance. The No. 1 movie in North American theaters was a holdover: ''Rise of the Planet of the Apes'' (20th Century Fox) sold an estimated $27.5 million in tickets for a stellar two-week total of $105 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. ''The Help'' (DreamWorks Studios/Disney) was second with about $25.5 million for a total of $35.4 million since opening on Wednesday; a notably large African-American audience turned out for this film, an adaptation of Kathryn Stockett's best-selling novel about black maids working for white women in the 1960s. ''Final Destination 5'' (Warner Brothers) was a soft third, taking in about $18.4 million, while ''The Smurfs'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) chugged away in fourth place, with an estimated $13.5 million in sales for a three-week total of $101.5 million. The comedy ''30 Minutes or Less'' (Sony/Media Rights Capital) sputtered in fifth place with $13 million in ticket sales. ''Glee 3-D'' (Fox), took in $5.7 million, an 11th-place result.

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. -- It looked like a typographical error. The yardage sheet for the final round of the P.G.A. Championship listed the par-four sixth hole at a length of 289 yards, shortened substantially from the 431, 417 and 432 yards it played over the first three days. A few veteran PGA Tour players could not remember a more dramatic crunching of distance in the middle of a major.

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. -- An even-par P.G.A. Championship left Phil Mickelson even-tempered after a disquieting week at the Atlanta Athletic Club. ''I played O.K.,'' he said calmly after another middle-of-the-road round, a 70 that was preceded by a 71, a 70 and a 69. ''I had a lot of good signs this week. I felt very close all week. It just never really clicked.''

Harry H. Wellington, whose half-century of studying and teaching law included a decade as dean of Yale Law School and eight years as dean of New York Law School, died last Monday at his home in New York. He was 84. The cause was a brain tumor, his wife, Sheila W. Wellington, said.

In his most recent thriller, ''The Devil's Light,'' Richard North Patterson wrote a detailed plot in which Osama bin Laden tries to drop a nuclear bomb on the United States to coincide with the 10th anniversary of 9/11. Two days before the book's publication date in May, Mr. Patterson watched on television as President Obama announced the news that Bin Laden, who was alive in Mr. Patterson's book, had been cornered and killed.

HILTON--Alice Mary, Ph.D.,died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Wednesday, August 10, 2011, aged 92, with her two beloved daughters by her side. Scholar, author, and lecturer, Dr. Hilton read the classics and mathematics at the University of Oxford. She continued her studies in mathematics and electrical engineering at the University of California and Caltech and art history at Columbia University. Over the course of her career, Dr. Hilton published three books including Logic, Computing Machines, and Automation, as well as hundreds of monographs, essays, and articles related to the roots and development of Western Civilization. Among her professional accomplishments, she was President of the Society for Social Responsibility in Science and Founder and President of The Institute for Cybercultural Research and the Arts-in-Context Education Foundation. Dr. Hilton explored the arts in the context of historical events and scientific milestones and, for close to four decades, offered related lectures and seminars at The Metropolitan Museum of Art and at many other national and international venues. She is survived by her daughters, Barbara Mary Hilton Hayward and Kathryn Anne Hilton-Hayward, and her granddaughter, Saskia Ama Sams-Yeboah. A private funeral service and interment will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue, New York. A celebration of Alice Mary Hilton's life will be held in New York in the autumn. Donations in her memory may be made to her favorite charities, Amnesty International or Habitat for Humanity, or to another charitable organization.

WALLEN--Sylvia, 92, August 8, on the 25 anniversary of her beloved Saul's passing. Loving mother to Robert, Jonathan, Judith, Marilyn, Judie, Jeffrey and Janice. Devoted grandmother to Marc, Jill, Stephen, Julie and Zachary. Great Grand Nan to Josh and Daniel. She will be greatly missed by family and friends and forever in our hearts.

Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday, 9:30 am St. Peter's Catholic Church. Interment at Mount Olivet Cemetery, Red Bank, NJ. Memorials Preferred to Pediatric Epilepsy Fund at Beth Israel Medical Center, c/o Walter Molofsky, MD 10 Union Square East Room 5G New York, NY 10003.

WILSKER--Howard (Butzy). August 4, 2011, age 84 of Lake Worth, FL. Grew up in Arverne, NY and then resided in Far Rockaway and Woodmere, NY. Adored husband for 60 beautiful years of Marjorie (Grant). Cherished father of Susan (Richard) Brownstein and Michael (Wendy) Wilsker. Proud grandfather of Ross, Gabriella and Gavin. Dearest brother of Paul (Judy) and the late Dr. Jerry (Thelma). Loving brother-in-law of Herbert (Joan Grant), devoted uncle and great-uncle. Three letter man at Far Rockaway High School. WWII United States Marines Corp. Vet, college at University of Miami, owner of Howard Fabrics, golfer, gin rummy player and good friend. Endearing and caring, he was an irresistible charmer.

The entrance of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas into the Republican presidential race may be bad news for Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann, but so far it seems to be good news for the book business. On Tuesday, two publishers announced forthcoming books on Mr. Perry, The Associated Press reported. Metropolitan Books will publish a work, with an unprintable title, by James C. Moore, the co-author of “Bush’s Brain,” and the Texas political consultant Jason Stanford in early 2012. The book, to be subtitled “Why Rick Perry Will Make America Miss George W. Bush,” will describe Mr. Perry as an “ideologue with scant interest or success in governing,” according to the publisher’s announcement. Crown, meanwhile, said it would publish “Rick Perry and his Eggheads,” by Sasha Issenberg, as an e-book next week. The e-book, about Mr. Perry’s successful 2006 re-election campaign, is based on Mr. Issenberg’s larger work, “The Victory Lab,” which is expected in the fall of 2012 and is to explore how social science and statistical analysis are changing political campaigning.

After rapidly building its brand of original programming around prestigious and much-lauded series like “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad,” AMC has been roiled by behind-the-scenes disputes and controversies at every one of its signature shows – even the ones it hasn’t started broadcasting yet. Bank of America took steps on Monday to exit the international credit card business, agreeing to sell its $8.6 billion Canadian card venture to the TD Bank Group for an undisclosed amount and putting its remaining European card portfolio on the block. With the announcements, Bank of America continued the push to overhaul its credit card business as the bank reels from hefty losses in its troubled mortgage division. While dumping the international card business, Bank of America has largely retained its card loans in the United States, among other core assets. The bank said it hoped the deals would shore up its capital ratios.

The Metropolitan Opera does not have a lock on outdoor, large-screen, high-definition opera transmissions. A popular summertime opera and classical music film festival has been operating for two decades in Vienna's City Hall Square. Now a one-evening version, called the Vienna Music Film Festival NY, is heading to Brooklyn Bridge Park on Aug. 29 and will feature filmed excerpts of European opera productions. Austrian tourism and cultural authorities, along with the Vienna-based International Music + Media Center - a nonprofit association founded under the aegis of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization - and Czekaj Artistic Productions, are backing the show. The Met will present H.D. performances at Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Sunday about economic policy discussions within the Obama administration omitted, in some copies, the word ''only'' from a quotation by Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director. In noting that the administration does not see deficits and jobs as an either-or choice, Mr. Pfeiffer said that ''it would be political folly to make the argument that only government spending equals jobs.''

An article on Saturday about France's stagnating economic growth erroneously attributed a distinction to its budget deficit among European countries with AAA credit ratings. France's budget deficit is second to Britain's; it is not the highest. (France's national debt is the highest among AAA-rated European nations.) And an accompanying picture caption referred incompletely to the role of an official, identified by title only, shown with François Baroin, the French finance minister. While the official, Valérie Pécresse, is the government spokeswoman, she is also the French budget minister.

The Interpublic Group of Companies, which has owned a tiny stake in Facebook since the days the social networking Web site was just for college students, is selling half its holdings for a hefty profit. Interpublic, which owns advertising and communications agencies like Deutsch, Initiative, McCann Erickson, Mullen and R/GA, acquired its ownership interest in Facebook in 2006.

Google made a $12.5 billion bet on Monday that its future - and the future of big Internet companies - lies in mobile computing, and moved aggressively to take on its arch rival Apple in the mobile market. The Silicon Valley giant, known for its search engine and Android phone software, rattled the tech world with its announcement that it would acquire Motorola Mobility Holdings, allowing it to get into the business of making cellphones and tablets.

The Federal Trade Commission on Monday announced a $50,000 settlement with a developer of mobile applications for children. The developer had been charged with violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act by collecting information from children who used the apps without their parent's permission. The case was the commission's first to involve mobile applications, or apps. The charges included collecting and storing children's e-mail addresses and allowing children to post personal information on public message boards.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with a review of ''The Help,'' a movie based on Kathryn Stockett's novel of the same title, misidentified the actor whose character employs the maid played by Viola Davis, who was shown in uniform serving women. She is Ahna O'Reilly -- not Bryce Dallas Howard, who was also pictured.

Time Warner Cable announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy Insight Communications, a large Midwestern cable television operator, for about $3 billion in cash. ''We believe in our business and its long-term prospects and have long thought that Insight's well-run, technologically advanced systems would fit well with our Midwest operations,'' Glenn Britt, chief executive of Time Warner Cable, said in a statement.

An article on Monday in some editions about two construction workers on Staten Island who were rescued from an elevator that was filling with water gave an incorrect name from the Fire Department for one worker. He is Wendell Amaker, not Windell Admaker.

An article on Sunday about the race for the Republican presidential nomination referred incorrectly to the employment history of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who announced his candidacy on Saturday. Mr. Perry served in the United States Air Force and worked in farming before entering politics at age 34. He has not held elective office ''his entire adult life.''

11:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE DOOR IN THE FLOOR (2004) In this adaptation of ''A Widow for One Year,'' by John Irving, Jeff Bridges and Kim Basinger, above, play Ted and Marion Cole, a long-married couple still reeling from the deaths of their two teenage sons in a car accident some years earlier. Elle Fanning is Ruth, their 4-year-old daughter, whose arrival was meant to help alleviate their grief. And Jon Foster is Eddie O'Hare, a boarding school student who has come to the family's Hamptons home to spend a summer working as an assistant to Ted, a famous author and illustrator of children's books, but ends up sleeping with his mentor's wife instead. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this drama from Tod Williams was ''surely the best movie yet made from Mr. Irving's fiction. It may even belong in the rarefied company of movies that are better than the books on which they are based. And above all, Jeff Bridges offers perhaps the wittiest and richest piece of screen acting by an American man so far this year.'' 8 P.M. STEVENS--Peter D.,MD. The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the passing of our dear friend and past President, Pete Stevens. Pete's warmth and exuberance permeated the relationships he forged with countless patients and many colleagues around New York City and throughout the country with whom he shared his expertise, his passion for teaching and his love for innovation in gastrointestinal endoscopy. He was much loved and will be sorely missed.

If elected president, Michele Bachmann said over the weekend, she would favor reinstating the ban on openly gay or lesbian people serving in the military, a policy known as ''don't ask, don't tell.'' Former Senator Rick Santorum has said similar things in the past. Turns out that it wouldn't be hard to do, legal experts say.

Eating red meat, and in particular processed red meat like bacon and hot dogs, raises the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But replacing just one serving a day with nuts or low-fat dairy can lower the risk, according to a study by Harvard researchers. Many other investigators have explored the link between diabetes and meat consumption, but this study is the largest and most comprehensive on the subject to date, following hundreds of thousands of people over the course of several decades. It is also the first to look not only at whether red meat consumption heightened the risk, but also at whether replacing meat with dairy or plant-based proteins like nuts and whole grains could make a difference.

An article on Monday about the Mets' loss on Sunday to Arizona described Chris Capuano, the Mets' starting pitcher, incorrectly. As an accompanying picture showed, he is a left-hander, not a right-hander. The article also described incorrectly the scene in the fourth inning after Diamondbacks pitcher Jason Marquis, who later learned he had fractured his fibula, hit Josh Thole with a pitch. Marquis and Thole crumpled to the ground about 60 feet apart, not 90.

An article on Saturday about an apology by Poland for apparently unwittingly aiding in the arrest of a human rights activist in Belarus by supplying banking information to officials there misstated the title of Radoslaw Sikorski, who issued the apology. He is Poland's foreign minister, not its prime minister.

Cargill, the American agricultural giant, said Monday that it planned to buy a Dutch animal nutrition company, Provimi, for $2.1 billion from the private equity firm Permira. One of the largest privately held companies in the world, Cargill said it made a binding offer for Provimi, which specializes in nutrition and supplements for farm animals, for 1.5 billion euros. The deal will help Cargill add vitamin mixtures and additives to its animal nutrition business and expand in Latin America, Russia and Asia, where Provimi operates.

I REMEMBER the first time I walked into a boxing ring: Tokyo, July 2009. The only thing I could hear was my heartbeat, blood being pumped to my brain. That, and the roaring of the crowd. The crowd actually might have been more intimidating than my opponent: me, a single boxer, against a mass of people. Boxing is a sport I cherish, roaring crowds and all. It is, of course, not a modern sport. But although I knew the sport had been covered many times, I realized that it had always been about the training and the fighting. The fans had largely been ignored. So I started taking pictures of boxing fans in all kind of venues in and around New York. At first, the feeling of facing these people to take their picture was pretty similar to that first fight of mine in 2009. I expected to encounter intense emotions. Still, the strength of them surprised me. My work as a photographer, then, was about recreating this strange mix of expected and unexpected.

An unconventional writing course taught by Alan Rickman in the coming Broadway comedy ''Seminar'' has snared its first two victims - er, students. Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater have joined the production of this Theresa Rebeck dark comedy, it was announced on Monday, playing aspiring novelists who pay $5,000 each for the privilege of working with Leonard, the internationally renowned literary figure played by Mr. Rickman. Ms. Rabe, a Tony Award nominee for last season's Broadway revival of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' will portray Kate, a character described by a production press representative as ''salty and headstrong'' and ''a girl from a wealthy family hosting the weekly seminar in her apartment.''

Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobility's management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the company's roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional 7,500 patents that are under government review. That intellectual property portfolio is a treasure trove for Google because the battle in wireless is one that is increasingly being fought in court.

Can good news ever occur in the life of Walter White without something equally devastating to even it out? On Sunday night, AMC clarified the uncertain future of ''Breaking Bad,'' its hit drama about that meth-cooking chemistry teacher, announcing that it has picked up the series for 16 additional episodes and that those segments will be the last installments of the series. ''It's a funny irony,'' Vince Gilligan, the ''Breaking Bad'' creator, said in a statement. ''I'd hate to know the date of my own last day on earth, but I'm delighted to know what Walter White's will be (episodically speaking). This is a great gift to me and to my wonderful writers. It's knowledge which will allow us to properly build our story to a satisfying conclusion. Now, if we don't manage to pull that off, we've got no one to blame but ourselves.''

STEVENS--Dr. Peter. The members of the Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology at Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the untimely passing of our friend, colleague and collaborator Dr. Peter Stevens, Director of Endoscopy at our sister Division at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Pete was a gifted, innovative gastroenterologist and endoscopist, a wonderful and caring clinician, and beloved mentor to a generation of physicians he trained. He had boundless integrity, kindness, and a gentle spirit. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences go out to his wife, Dr. Amy Stevens; son, Sam; daughter, Christina; and the entire Stevens family. Ira M. Jacobson, MD, Chief Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology, Weill Cornell Medical College

FRIED--Seymour, M.D.,87, beloved husband of Sylvia Fried, M.D., loving father of Ruthellen Fried, M.D., Kenny Fried, M.D., Lisa Fried-Kornbluth and father-in-law to Larry Boxt, M.D., Sharon Fried, M.D. and Asher Kornbluth, M.D. Dear grandfather of Kirin, Elliot, Ariel, Ilana, Jesse, Adina, Benji, Nessa, Saundra, Max and great-grandfather of Kevin and Charlotte. Transocean, one of the world's largest offshore drilling contractors, said on Monday that it had bid $1.43 billion for Aker Drilling of Norway to expand its fleet by adding rigs and ships. Transocean, which owned the rig lost in the oil spill disaster last year in the Gulf of Mexico, said it agreed to pay 26.5 Norwegian kroner ($4.80) in cash for each Aker share. The offer price is 62 percent higher than Aker's average share price over 30 days before the offer, Transocean said in a statement. Transocean will also assume $800 million of Aker's debt.

For women hoping to combat the symptoms of menopause with nonprescription alternatives like soy and flaxseed supplements, recent studies have held one disappointment after another. That followed a similar finding about hot flashes from a clinical trial of flaxseed.

Sleep-disordered breathing, or sleep apnea, is a common condition characterized by repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night. People with the disorder often snore and gasp during sleep, and it has been associated with hypertension, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Now a new study suggests it may also be associated with mental decline and dementia. The study, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, is not the first to find a connection between sleep apnea and dementia, but it is the first to use an objective measure of sleep-disordered breathing -- actually counting the number of disordered breathing events during a night of sleep using EEGs and other equipment. It is also the first to study the matter prospectively, first finding the disordered sleeping pattern in healthy people without dementia, and then checking, years later, to see if they were more likely than regular sleepers to deteriorate mentally.

Loving aunt of Roz and Marvin, Helen and Bennett, Arthur and Jane, Arlene and David, Toni and Walter. Loved by her extended family, late sisters and brothers in-law, and eclectic circle of friends. May her memory be for a blessing.

DES MOINES -- Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia has been named chairman of the Republican Governors Association, succeeding Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who stepped down to run for president. BROWNER--Kevin A. Beloved son of Elaine and the late Kenneth, beloved brother to Cliford, loving brother-in-law to Eileen, and Uncle "Nubie" to Cayla and Jessy. Rest in the Peace you so deserve, forever in our hearts.

Spandorf--Leo, 91, of Roslyn Heights, NY passed away on August 14, 2011. Survived by his best friend and beloved wife of 62 years, Bernice; his children, Rochelle Spandorf Buchsbaum, Alan Spandorf, and Barbara Spandorf Breed; sons-in-law Edward Buchsbaum and Craig Breed; and cherished grandchildren Jill and Jordan Buchsbaum and Jessica Buchsbaum Chaintreuil and John Chaintreuil. Proud graduate of Townsend Harris & Baruch College. Founding partner of Kohleriter & Spandorf, a highly regarded CPA firm, later Touche Ross, and a leader in the accounting profession. Leo graduated from Hofstra Law School in 1982 and began his second career as a tax attorney, from which he never quite retired. Intelligent, witty, generous and kind, a consummate professional who exemplified great ethics and integrity. He will be missed forever. Donations in Leo's memory may be made to Baruch College, Crohn's & Colitis Foundation or NARSAD.

Jeffrey Gundlach, the prominent bond fund manager, testified Monday that he began making backup plans in case he was fired by his employer, Trust Company of the West. In a civil trial pitting Mr. Gundlach against TCW, as Trust Company of the West is better known, Mr. Gundlach testified that he had been in talks to move part of TCW's fixed-income division to the Western Asset Management Company, also known as Wamco, before he was fired by TCW in December 2009. The discussions about hiring Mr. Gundlach were known as ''Project Artwork'' within Wamco, and Mr. Gundlach's team was known as ''Gallery,'' a nod to his appreciation for fine art.

In ''Bring It On,'' the 2000 movie starring Kirsten Dunst, two cheerleading squads faced off amid accusations of stolen routines. Now that animosity has carried over to a new musical based on the movie. In a complaint filed last week, the Writers Guild of America accused the producers of the movie of exploiting the screenwriter's rights by producing a new musical based on the story. The complaint claims that the guild's contract with producers says that two years after a movie's general release the right to adapt it into a stage play reverts to the screenwriter. According to The Hollywood Reporter, which first reported the claim, the screenwriter, Jessica Bendinger, had been trying to develop her own stage adaptation of ''Bring It On'' when she learned that the film's producer, Beacon Communications, was doing so as well. Beacon's version, which is directed and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler (''In the Heights''), with a book by Jeff Whitty (''Avenue Q''), and music and lyrics by Lin-Manuel Miranda (''In the Heights''), Tom Kitt (''Next To Normal''), and Amanda Green (''High Fidelity''), had a run earlier this year in Atlanta and is set to begin a 10-city national tour in Los Angeles on Oct. 30.

THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - Have you ever calculated your Six Degrees of Separation from someone else? How about from Kevin Bacon? The Six Degrees of Separation is an unproven theory (originated by Hungarian author Frigyes Karinthy and later popularized in a play by John Guare) that says that all people on Earth are no more than six connections away from each other. These "chains" of connections were meant to show that the world, while growing in population, was actually smaller than ever.

I moved from Chicago to Brooklyn in July of 2004, just in time to watch my mother die. That wasn't why I moved back. She was supposed to be getting better; the chemo was working. I came because I'd rented an apartment with Jay, this cute guy I'd started dating, who was originally from New York too. But a week after pulling up in a U-Haul, I found myself cleaning out my childhood home with my siblings. Our parents were both gone now; anything that we couldn't take with us had to fit in a 20-cubic-yard Dumpster.

Not long after setting sail from Massachusetts, the Cuba-bound merchant schooner Enchantress spied a square-rigged brig approaching, painted black, with dark sails and black mastheads and yards. As the vessel drew near the merchantman, a voice ordered the Enchantress to heave to. Shortly, a boat containing an officer and six men rowed alongside. Upon climbing over the gangway, the officer confronted the merchantman's captain, demanding immediate surrender of his vessel. Facing the muzzles of the raider's cannon, and with only a single musket on board, the schooner's captain had no alternative but to submit. It was piracy, plain and simple - but piracy condoned and supported by the Confederacy.

Researchers at the Lafayette campus of the University of Louisiana are looking for green substitutes for diesel fuel. The prime one now in use is soybeans, which are used to make biodiesel oil. But soybeans are also needed for human consumption and animal feed. The United States uses 45 billion gallons of diesel a year; making just one billion gallons from soybeans would use up 21 percent of the American crop, the scientists point out.

StumbleUpon has long been one of the most powerful tools for those who revel in the Web's randomness. A user chooses a few things he's interested in -- say, writing, American football and science -- and the service pulls up a new Web site of interest every time he presses "Stumble!" So, perhaps, that user would find a site with a list of "30 Books to Read Before You're 30," followed by one with "10 Quirky Science Tricks for Parties," followed by a page containing just a map of the United States made out of the football helmets of the local N.F.L. teams.

It can be tough to stand out among the almost 200 shows in this year's New York International Fringe Festival, which runs through Aug. 28. (Ending the title of your show with the words "The Musical!" is so 10 years ago.) One way to stop passers-by in their tracks is to design eye-catching artwork -- to be used online and in print -- that says "Look at me. Come see the show. If it's not good, keep me as a bookmark."

When it came to creative ice cream options, there was a time when Germans might have had to settle for spaghetti-eis, thin strands of vanilla ice cream smothered in a (supposedly) fruit-based syrup. For the traveler, this means that Berlin now offers some great new ways to cool off with cone or cup.

For a study published this year, researchers at Indiana State University had a group of healthy, young adults squat, lunge, twist, crunch and hold a rigid plank position to measure the hardiness of their back, abdominal and side muscles, the area generally known as the core. The same volunteers then completed a battery of physical performance tests, including leaping off the ground while tossing a medicine ball backward over the head and sprinting through a short obstacle course.
