The On Education column on Monday, about research fellows selected to advise the education commissioner and the state Board of Regents, gave an incorrect name from the New York State Department of Education for the group that contributed $50,000 to support the fellows. It is the National Association of Charter School Authorizers, not the National Association of Charter School Administrators.

The entrance of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas into the Republican presidential race may be bad news for Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann, but so far it seems to be good news for the book business. On Tuesday, two publishers announced forthcoming books on Mr. Perry, The Associated Press reported. Metropolitan Books will publish a work, with an unprintable title, by James C. Moore, the co-author of ''Bush's Brain,'' and the Texas political consultant Jason Stanford in early 2012. The book, to be subtitled ''Why Rick Perry Will Make America Miss George W. Bush,'' will describe Mr. Perry as an ''ideologue with scant interest or success in governing,'' according to the publisher's announcement. Crown, meanwhile, said it would publish ''Rick Perry and his Eggheads,'' by Sasha Issenberg, as an e-book next week. The e-book, about Mr. Perry's successful 2006 re-election campaign, is based on Mr. Issenberg's larger work, ''The Victory Lab,'' which is expected in the fall of 2012 and is to explore how social science and statistical analysis are changing political campaigning. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WITKOFF--Andrew Scott, 22, suddenly on August 14, 2011. Beloved son of Lauren and Steven, deeply loved brother of Alex and Zachary, cherished grandson of Lois and the late Martin Witkoff, and Marcella and Bob Rappoport, and adored nephew. Our hearts are broken, we are numbed with grief. Andrew loved life and lived every moment with great joy and spirit. He shall live forever in our hearts and souls. We will always wake with the vision of his smile. Rest in eternal peace, our dear Andrew. Services will be held on Wednesday August 17, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St.
FLESCHER--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Flescher, associated with The New York Times from November 1, 1963 until retiring on March 1, 1987.

GILL--John Lee, of New York died August 10, 2011, at Chester River Manor. He was 88. He was born in Chestertown, Maryland, the son of the late Charles Lee Gill, Jr. and Mable Coppage Gill. Mr. Gill was preceded in death by his wife, T. Smyth Gill, and his brother, William Thomas Hepburn Gill. Survivors include his sister, Jean Gill Smith of Centreville, MD and several nieces and nephews. John was a Veteran of World War II, serving as a Naval Aviator in the Western Pacific, mainly on the USS Santee CVE 29. After the war he returned to Chestertown and completed Washington College and then served as a Special Agent, Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1951 to 1977, assigned to offices in the Midwest, West and New York City. He was an active volunteer with the New York City Fire Department, being honored as an Honorary Deputy Chief, Fire Department, New York and the USS Intrepid CV 19 Aircraft Carrier Museum where he was presented with a Seat of Honor aboard the Intrepid on Memorial Day 2011. Also, John was a member of The Fire Bell Club of New York, Entrepid Museum Volunteers, U.S. Naval Institute, Society of Former Special Agents of the FBI, Inc. and the Escort Carrier Sailors and Airmen Association. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm, on September 24, 2011 at the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue (Corner of Madison and 35th Sts), New York, NY 10016 (Inquiries at 212-689-6350). In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made in memory of John to the New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, New York, NY 10475 (718-379-1900).

VIA--Marie Berry Matheke, 72, in Norfolk, with her family at her side died of heart failure on Monday, August 15, 2011 in Norfolk, Virginia. Born June 22, 1939 in Newark, NJ, she was the daughter of Lucy Van Swearingen Reinhart Matheke and George A. Matheke, M.D. Mrs. Via graduated from Mount Holyoke College and received an M.A. from the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia. She was a dedicated educator, teaching for nearly twenty years at Norfolk Academy in Norfolk, Virginia, having begun her career at the Venable School in Charlottesville, Virginia. An active member of First Presbyterian Church, Norfolk, Virginia, Mrs. Via served the church community as a Sunday school teacher, a member of the board of the First Presbyterian Preschool, and in many other capacities. She also served on the Centennial Committee for the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia. She is survived by her husband of fifty years, James Dillard Via, M.D. of Norfolk, Virginia and her two children, Anne Van Swearingen Via McCollough and her husband David Scott McCollough of New York City, and George Via of Norfolk, Virginia; her only grandson, James Andrew Scott McCollough of New York City; and her sister, Susan Quigley Matheke and her husband William Philip Feuer of Block Island, Rhode Island and their son Lewis George Feuer, who is relocating from Portland, Oregon to Boston, Massachusetts. Her parents and her brother, Michael John Matheke, predeceased her. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at 2pm. Sunday, August 28th at First Presbyterian Church, Norfolk, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia, P.O. Box 400276, Charlottesville, Virginia 22904 or First Presbyterian Church, 820 Colonial Avenue, Norfolk, Virginia 23507. H. D. Oliver Funeral Apts., Norfolk Chapel is handling arrangements. Online condolences may be made to www.hdoliver.com.

Steve Ross says he was happy to take his bialys out of New York. But no one was taking the New York out of his bialys. In 2001, Mr. Ross, the owner of Coney Island Bialys and Bagels, received an invitation to demonstrate authentic city baking at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival in Washington. Organizers supplied the mixer and an oven. Mr. Ross insisted on only one ingredient: New York City water.

Apple has a cash problem. It's not just that Apple has too much cash, $76 billion as of June 30. It's rather that the bulk of that pile, estimated at $41 billion, is held abroad. Apple does not want to bring it back to the United States for several reasons, primarily because of the tax consequences, but also because of its own growing foreign presence. Apple is not alone - this problem is an increasing one in corporate America. And the answer may not be more big, all-cash acquisitions, like Google's $12.5 billion offer for Motorola Mobility.

NATIONAL An article on Monday about Robert Finn, the bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph in Missouri, who waited months to report evidence of abuse by a priest, misstated one part of a three-year-old agreement to settle lawsuits in previous sex abuse cases. The settlement, for $10 million, included a list of 19 -- not 90 -- preventive measures, including immediately reporting possible abuse to the police.

The playwright Paula Vogel is leaving and staying. Ms. Vogel, the chairwoman of the playwriting department at the Yale School of Drama, has decided to step down at the end of the 2011-12 academic year, a year before her five-year term was scheduled to conclude. But she will remain a member of the faculty, which she joined in 2008, and will continue teaching at the school as she works on two projects. The first, ''One Hundred Years of Vengeance,'' is a co-commission from Yale Repertory Theater and the Oregon Shakespeare Festival that she plans to workshop next year with the director Rebecca Taichman. She is also involved with the first New York revival of her Pulitzer Prize-winning play, ''How I Learned to Drive,'' at Second Stage Theater.

CUMMINS--Douglas Tate, passed away Sunday, August 14th after a courageous battle against multiple myeloma under the loving care of the Haven Hospice Center of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. He was born 17 June, 1961 in Iowa City, Iowa, the son of Dr. Phillip D. Cummins, PhD, the deceased Jerri Ann Cummins, and step mother Karin Cummins. He graduated from the University of Iowa in 1985. His career included ten years as a representative of Union Pacific Railroad, transportation analyst at Nat West, and trader specializing in arbitrage at Wachovia and A.E. Englander. He is survived by his beloved daughter Victoria, her sister Caroline, his brother Daniel (Laurie) Cummins, his sister Thyra Cummins (Ronald) Cox, his loving niece and nephews and former wife Elizabeth Hamilton Sans, and Mrs. Richard B. Smith.

REMEMBERING TO SHARE Q.At restaurants casual and high end, my family, friends and I enjoy tasting one another's dishes. We even make a point of ordering different things to make the most of our shared dining experience. This was the target of rude snubs in France. Last week, I dined with my cousin, her French husband and their friends. My cousin and I ate half our dishes, then swiftly and silently exchanged plates, exercising extra discretion in this company. One of my cousin's friends called us out on it, even making a remark about our Chinese heritage. (We consider ourselves international and primarily speak English.) I was totally offended and bewildered. What's the etiquette on food-sharing at Western restaurants, where everyone chooses their own main courses, unlike at the Chinese table? And isn't it antisocial to guard your chosen dish, without offering to share the delights of the dinner table?

BOYLAND--Sean Denis. A fixture of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and New York's East Village, admired for his eccentric humor, immaculate handlebar mustache, and fierce loyalty, died on August 15, 2011, in the company of loving friends and family on the Upper East Side, New York. He was 31.

10:45 A.M. (IFC) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) In 1995 Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French fashion magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke that left him with a condition called locked-in syndrome, in which he retained vision, hearing and a perfectly functioning mind, but his body was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking his eye. In this third feature film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric (above, with Anne Consigny); Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is the speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. ''The phrase 'triumph of the human spirit' hovers over 'The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,' along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind'' -- among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration -- Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) ''Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual,'' which Mr. Schnabel demonstrates with ''imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.'' 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: HUMPHREY BOGART ''Bogart: The Untold Story'' (1996), Chris Hunt's documentary, narrated by Stephen Bogart, the son of Bogart and Lauren Bacall, introduces this 13-film tribute to an actor whose gangster persona cloaked an adolescence of privilege in New York City and at Phillips Academy in Massachusetts. Highlights include ''To Have and Have Not'' (1944), in which Ms. Bacall made her film debut (above, with Bogart) in Howard Hawk's adaptation of the Hemingway novel, at 11; ''The Maltese Falcon'' (1941), John Huston's take on Dashiell Hammett's novel, and his directorial debut, at 8 p.m.; and ''Sahara'' (1943), with Bogart as an American tank commander fighting alongside seasoned British troops in Libya in 1942, at 10. Directed by Zoltan Korda, this action film, with a California desert standing in for North Africa, was one of the first made by Bogart after his success in ''Casablanca'' in 1942.

MEYERSON--Dr. Marion D. of San Francisco, California died peacefully at home surrounded by family on August 10, 2011. Daughter of the late Lillian and Sherwood Diamond, born on March 9, 1935 in Brooklyn, New York. Education: BA Hunter College, NY, MA Brooklyn College, NY and a PhD. from the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana. Former Professor and Lecturer in Communicative Disorders at CA State Universities in Fresno, San Francisco, and San Jose. Life Member of both the California Speech and Hearing Assn. and the American Speech and Hearing Assn. Marion also spent ten years with the Howard Hughes Medical Center in San Francisco. Specialties included syndromes, multi-cultural factors, and anatomy and physiology related to speech and hearing. Survived by Bernard, her husband of 56 years, daughters Beth and Susan, son-in-law Edward, grandchildren Jacob, Aliya, Matthew, and Jordan, sister Maida, niece Hope, and nephew Mark. Donations in her memory may be made to "The Tower Foundation of SJSU" with notation to the Marion D. Meyerson Endowed Scholarship Fund and mailed to The Tower Foundation of SJSU, One Washington Square, San Jose, CA 95192-0257.

Jay-Z and Kanye West have broken a record set by Coldplay for the most iTunes downloads of an album during its first week of release, as their collaboration 'Watch the Throne' sold more than 290,000 digital copies on Apple's music service, a publicist for Mr. West said. The album was released last Monday after months of hype and publicity, and it was exclusively avaible on iTunes for the first three days, doubtless boosting its sales on the service. Coldplay, the British pop band, set the record for its fourth album, ''Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends,'' which was downloaded 282,000 times on iTunes in its first week on sale. The overall official first-week sales for ''Watch the Throne,'' including digital and hard copies, will be released by Nielsen SoundScan on Wednesday morning. It is widely expected to make its debut at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart with sales in the range of 410,000 to 450,000, Billboard reported.

SUZUKI--Dr. Yasunosuke of Scarsdale NY, Professor Emeritus of Pathology and Community Medicine at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine died on August 9th, 2011. He was born in Shimoda, Japan in 1929 and graduated from Keio Medical School. Dr. Suzuki was a preeminent pathologist in asbestos related diseases. His research led to a global re-examination of asbestos use, and to massive class action suits by workers who had died from cancer. Suzuki received the Ramazzini Award and the Selikoff Lifetime Achievement Award. He is survived by his wife Mieko, and three children: Hiroko, Motoyuki, and Takaaki; and four grandchildren: Katherine, Theo, Thomas, and Miyo. Memorial Service: Saturday, August 20th, 11:30am, Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, Department of Preventative Medicine Scholarship Fund.

STEVENS--Peter Dunsmore, M.D. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Peter Dunsmore Stevens, director of endoscopy at New York - Presbyterian Hospital/ Columbia University Medical Center and associate professor of clinical medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. One of the country's premier interventional endoscopists, he helped develop minimally invasive techniques for treating pancreatic and biliary disease, including by pioneering single-operator cholangios- copy and making this technique a standard of care. He was also the first gastroenterologist in New York to help perform natural orifice translumenal endoscopic sur- gery. A longtime member of our medical center community, Dr. Stevens received his undergraduate and medical degrees at Columbia and completed subsequent specialty training at New York -Presbyterian/Columbia. Dr. Stevens was a past president of the New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy and founded the NYSGE course for advanced fellows. He established the interventional endoscopic fellowship at New York - Presbyterian/ Columbia, and many of his trainees have gone on to prominent faculty positions as interventional endoscopists. Admired for his prodigious talents and beloved for his kindness and friendship, Dr. Stevens will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Dr. Amy Stevens (P&S '89); son, Sam (Columbia College '15); daughter, Christina; and the entire Stevens family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia Univ. Medical Center Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO Steven J. Corwin, M.D. Exec. Vice President and COO Robert E. Kelly, M.D. Group Senior Vice President New York-Presbyterian Hospital Donald W. Landry, M.D. Chairman, Medicine Timothy C. McSHANE--Bruce W.,passed away on August 13, 2011. Born in Montclair New Jersey he was the son of Bruce Winthrop and Mary Crane. When he was 1, his father died in a car crash. Bruce was the brother of Leslie Anne Roach, Elizabeth Carter Conway, Devin McShane and Bryan McShane. After his mother remarried Gordon McShane in 1952, his family consisting then of Bruce and his older sister Leslie moved to San Raphael, California where Gordon worked. While they lived there Bryan and Devin were added to his family. In 1955 the family moved back to the east coast and took up residence in the Morristown area of New Jersey. In that year Carter was born. Bruce attended primary school at the Peck school in Morristown and in eighth grade entered Portsmouth Priory in Rhode Island as a second former. At Portsmouth in his senior year he co-captained the varsity football team and captained the wrestling team. That year he grappled to an undefeated record and was selected to the all New England Team. After graduation from Portsmouth he entered the University off Denver where he stayed for one year before volunteering for the US army draft in 1969. He did his basic training at Fort Dix, NJ and from there he went to Vietnam where he served for 15 months with the 101st Airborne in the signal corps as a Radio Telephone Operator. He was stationed mostly near the city of Hue towards the northern part of the country. There he saw much combat. In 1972 he was awarded the Bronze Star for meritorious service. After his return from Vietnam, he attended Castleton State college, earning his BA and then attended Vermont Law school in South Royalton, Vermont where he graduated with a law degree in their inaugural class. His first job out of Law School was with Marsh and McLennan in New York where he worked until he passed the New York State Bar exam at which point he joined the law firm of Rogers Hoge and Hills. In 1981 he married Celeste Marie Bertucci, a New Orleans native and together they had two daughters, Jessica Elizabeth and Kelley Tiernan. In 1984 before they had children Bruce and Celeste moved to Westport Connecticut, and the seeds of Bruce's interest in sailing sprouted, when a friend gave him an old Hobey Cat. On a daily basis he would jump into the boat after work and sail until dusk. In 1985 Bruce started his own law firm with Bill Johnston and named it Johnston and McShane. Their offices were located above Grand Central station in New York City. In 1999 he and John Flood started a sports marketing firm Old Iron. The firm represented sports figures in private marketing efforts. In 1995 Bruce and Celeste bought property in Watch Hill Rhode Island where they eventually built a house. Over the next ten years Bruce kept up his interest and love of boating in the waters surrounding Watch Hill and Newport mostly with motor craft.In 2006 after doing much research he bought the sailing yacht Summer Wind, a Little Harbor design, 47' in length, built in 1986. Over the last five years, Bruce sailed that vessel throughout the western waters of the Atlantic - much of it solo. His sailing adventures took him as far south as Cartagena, Colombia, to the east and west boundaries of the Caribbean and down to Bermuda several times. Bruce's love of boating and fascination with the sea drove him. Sailing became his love and his life. Bruce is survived by his siblings and his family. A funeral service with Full Military Honors will take place at the Watch Hill Chapel, 5 Bluff Avenue, Westerly, RI, on Thursday, August 18 at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Wounded Warriors Project: woundedwarriorsproject.org For online condolences, please go to: www.gaffneydolanfuneral home.com

James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera's music director, has received two previously undisclosed back operations since the spring, when he canceled a Met tour to Japan and his schedule at the Tanglewood Music Festival, his brother said on Tuesday. But now, without the excruciating pain that has plagued him over the last several years because of back problems, Mr. Levine is planning to begin rehearsing at the Met right after Labor Day and has not canceled any performances, said his brother, Tom Levine. ''The surgeries have done what they're supposed to do,'' he added. The increasingly frail Mr. Levine, 68, has withdrawn from numerous performances in recent seasons because of various health problems. In March he stepped down as the music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Last year he had a major operation to address spinal stenosis, which causes painful compression of the spinal cord. But the pain returned last season, Tom Levine said. His brother did not respond to other measures. ''It made sense to do another surgery,'' Tom Levine said, and that happened on May 31. The stenosis problem recurred, so another operation came on July 20, timed to give him enough of a recovery and rehabilitation period so he could be ready to conduct at the Met. ''He's in very good spirits,'' Tom Levine said. ''He's very, very positive and very, very optimistic.'' The conductor is scheduled to make his first appearance of the season leading ''Don Giovanni'' on Oct. 13.

Depending on whom you ask, Grimes, the 23-year-old synth-pop musician from Montreal whose real name is Claire Boucher, evokes Björk, Enya, Daft Punk, Donna Summer, Mariah Carey, the Eurythmics, Nicki Minaj, Toni Basil, Zola Jesus or the Smiths. For her part, Boucher describes her bewildering, genre-defying soundscapes and high-pitched falsetto as "post-Internet." What, exactly, does this mean? "The music of my childhood was really diverse because I had access to everything, so the music I make is sort of schizophrenic," she explained by phone. Boucher will travel to New York this week to play at MoMA P.S. 1 on Saturday. "Basically I'm really impressionable and have no sense of consistency in anything I do."

I crossed the border from Idaho nine days ago, and I've been eating up reasonable chunks of daily mileage this week -- except for the day off I took today -- but I am only barely across the center line of the state. Two rare Chinese Louhan head sculptures dating to the Tang Dynasty (618-906), each worth some $800,000, were stolen recently from an undisclosed location in Westport, Conn., according to police there, who have been joined by the FBI in an investigation of the theft. The statues, carved from sandstone, were part of a private collection. Police told Sky News that although the theft was reported Monday, it could have happened any time over the last two weeks.

After undergoing two separate heart procedures since leaving office a decade ago, former President Bill Clinton changed his diet to slow the progression of heart disease. "At Thanksgiving, I had one bite of turkey," he told CNN's chief medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta.

Michael Lewis's Vanity Fair article on why Germany now calls the shots in the Eurozone is delightfully, mischievously Swiftian. Lewis ties Germans' relationship to money to, well, their relationship to excrement. As his source, he cites the work of a Berkeley anthropologist, Alan Dundes, whose book "Life Is Like a Chicken Coop Ladder" argues that German folklore is uncommonly obsessed with anality. To support the thesis that this obsession is at the root of Germany's economic dominance (and its faulty risk-taking), Lewis uncovers myriad examples of fecal focus in German colloquialisms and proverbs.

Organizers of a tribute concert for Michael Jackson in Britain scratched the rock band Kiss from the lineup on Tuesday after fans complained that the band's front man, Gene Simmons, had called Mr. Jackson a child molester, according to wire service reports. ''We have listened to Michael's fans and are grateful to have been alerted to these unfortunate statements by Gene Simmons,'' Chris Hunt, the chief executive of Global Live Events, which is promoting the event, said in a statement. He called the decision to book Kiss ''an oversight.''

A chart last Thursday with the Pragmatist column, about light bulbs, misstated the average cost of an L.E.D. bulb that delivers light equivalent to that of a 60-watt incandescent. It is $2.92 per 1,000 hours based on the national average utility rate of 11 cents a kilowatt-hour and an average purchase price of $40. It is not $1.32. (That is the cost just for the electricity.) The column also misstated the components that produce light in an L.E.D. They are a mix of aluminum, indium and other materials, based on a compound semiconductor called gallium nitride rather than on silicon chips.

A new front has opened in the behind-the-scenes battle over financial regulation. Industry groups have been examining legal challenges to the Securities and Exchange Commission's new corporate whistle-blower program and a provision surrounding the extraction of oil and natural gas from foreign countries, people briefed on the talks said. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission's plan to curb speculative trading is also under fire.

CARLOS CAMPOS has opened his first men's store, and just a month after being nominated for a CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award. A wood and copper structure winds through the modest space on Orchard Street, framing his tweaked modern classics. In various nooks, shoppers will discover summer finds like a lightweight olive green anorak, $320; tartan button-down shirts, $130; and soft cotton V-neck T-shirts, $39. Mr. Campos, a Honduran expat, made himself right at home on the Lower East Side. ''The area already felt like a familia,'' he said, noting that friends had recently opened a Mexican restaurant across the street from his shop. ''We joke that we want to rename the street Carlito's Way.'' Smartly tailored wool coats, suits and leather jackets in rich autumnal rusts and blues will arrive in September. Carlos Campos, 75 Orchard Street, (212) 244-1942;

(VH1) 2011 DO SOMETHING AWARDS Jane Lynch (above, with Dax Shepard) returns as host of this ceremony honoring the best ''world changers'' who are 25 and younger, including five who will compete for $100,000. The finalists, voted on by viewers, are Sarah Cronk, a co-founder of the Sparkle Effect, which supports cheerleading squads that include students with disabilities; Taryn Guerrero Davis, who created the American Widow Project to provide resources for more than 3,000 women whose husbands have died in Iraq and Afghanistan; Mark Kabban, whose Youth and Leaders Living Actively organization combines soccer and art to empower immigrant children; Adam Lowy, whose Move for Hunger works with moving companies to strengthen the nation's food banks; and David Schwartz, who devised the Real Food Challenge to shift $1 billion of college food purchases toward local, sustainable, humane and fair-trade sources by 2020. When mega-buyouts were booming several years ago, private equity firms raced to go public. Today, the stock market has punished those firms that succeeded. Shares of the Blackstone Group, which was first out of the gate, have dropped in value by more than half since their June 2007 initial public offering. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Global Management, which reached the market later, have fallen more than 22 percent this year.

It's been a pretty good few days for Kathryn Stockett. The movie version of her mega-best-selling book, ''The Help,'' did well at the weekend box office and on Tuesday a lawsuit alleging that she had based a character in the book on a real person without permission was thrown out by a Mississippi judge. The lawsuit was filed in February by Ablene Cooper, a longtime maid for Ms. Stockett's brother's family in Jackson. In the suit, Ms. Cooper argued that the book's protagonist, Aibileen Clark, was clearly based on her given the first name as well as some other significant biographical details. The lawsuit, which sought $75,000 in damages, described the portrayal as offensive and ''emotionally upsetting.'' Such suits against an author generally have low odds of succeeding, but given that Ms. Cooper filed it with the blessing of her employers it raised some eyebrows in Jackson and elsewhere.

Since May there has been a nearly constant, subcellular buzz on the Internet about something called an Intel Ultrabook. But what, exactly, are we looking at here? First, let's understand how Intel ''releases'' notebooks. Intel makes chips. That, in general, is all they do and all they ever want to do. However, the company often releases reference designs or plans for future products. These reference designs have included embedded systems for machinery (using Intel chips), point-of-sale systems for stores (using Intel chips) and low-power ''in-vehicle infotainment systems'' (using Intel chips.)

Thinking Cap is about work in progress in the world of ideas. 'EXAM HIGH SCHOOLS AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT: EVIDENCE FROM NEW YORK CITY' a working paper by Roland G. Fryer Jr., professor of economics and faculty director of the Education Innovation Laboratory at Harvard University, and Will Dobbie, a predoctoral research fellow at the laboratory. THE QUESTION Each year millions of middle-school students nationwide spend angst-filled months waiting to hear if they scored high enough on an entrance exam to attend a selective public high school. In New York City alone more than 27,000 students apply for precious spots in the three best-known schools: Stuyvesant, Brooklyn Technical and Bronx High School of Science. What Mr. Dobbie and Mr. Fryer wanted to know was just how much of a difference attending one of these high schools makes in the long run for students with similar equal admissions test scores. Some proponents say the benefits of an environment of high achievers, more advanced coursework and higher expectations are obvious. Skeptics counter that these gifted and motivated teenagers would have done well no matter where they went. Students in these schools with low class ranks may even be less competitive when it comes to college admissions. They might be better off in less competitive environments or in schools with a wider range of student abilities. Because there are so many applicants of similar ability and achievement who are not accepted to these New York institutions, the authors were able to compare the average outcomes of students who graduated from different high schools. ''We provide the first causal estimate of the impact of attending an exam-high school in the United States on later outcomes,'' they write.

A 15-ton salt-spreading truck burst through the wall of a sprawling Sanitation Department repair depot in Queens on Wednesday morning and hung precariously in the air - 30 feet above the ground - until rescuers could free its driver, the authorities said. Police officers and firefighters converged on the location, at 52-35 58th Street, in the Maspeth neighborhood, after the front end of the truck went barreling through a brick-and-window section of the building's upper wall at about 9:30 a.m., officials said.

Checking Facebook messages on your phone is now one-tap easy. Facebook has published a new free app for iPhone and Android, Facebook Messenger, that unbundles its private message service from the all-in-one Facebook app. Rather than trying to combine your entire online life into one app, it goes the other way: Messenger, when started, goes straight to your Facebook messages, so you can read and reply to them without having to navigate through all of Facebook.

A new play by Dustin Lance Black, about a trial to overturn California's voter-approved ban on gay marriage, has found its first cast members for a one-time staged reading on Broadway. Morgan Freeman and Anthony Edwards will be among the actors performing in ''8,'' written by Mr. Black, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of ''Milk,'' and adapted from reporting and trial transcripts from the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger, in which a federal judge in San Francisco struck down California's Proposition 8 in 2010. (The ruling is currently being appealed.) Press representatives for the staged Broadway reading of ''8'' said on Wednesday that its cast will also feature Cheyenne Jackson, Christine Lahti, Rob Reiner, Yeardley Smith and Marisa Tomei. Characters in the play include Kristin M. Perry and Sandra B. Stier, a lesbian couple who were among the plaintiffs suing California over the ban; Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, the lawyers who represented them; and the judge, Vaughn R. Walker of the Federal District Court for the Northern District of California. The press representatives could not yet confirm which roles would be played by these actors, and said that additional casting was still to be announced.

GROSSMAN--Alvin, of New York City and Pawling, NY, died on August 16, 2011 at the age of 83. Survived by his best friend and beloved wife of 56 years, Sari; his daughters Elizabeth and Emily, son-in-law Philip Zisman, and grandchildren Jane and Olivia. An award-winning art director and graphic designer, born in Brooklyn, New York in 1927, he was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and Syracuse University. Art director at American Home, Venture, Family Circle and McCall's, and designer of publications for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and for French publications, including an historical guidebook to Americans in Paris. He taught courses in photography and the history of graphic design at Parsons The New School for Design, teaching recognized for its outstanding reflection of multicultural and international perspectives. He was much admired by his students. He will be remembered for his exceptional wit, love and knowledge of art and books, his work with artists and photographers, and his own inimitable artwork. He will be missed forever by his family whom he adored. Memorial Service: Friday, August 19th, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York, NY.

STULTS--Harold L.,Jr., Esq. The members of Balber Pickard Maldonado & Van Der Tuin, PC mourn the passing of Harold L. Stults, Jr., who founded the firm in 1978 as Stults Marshall & Gabler. KELLY WEARSTLER, the interior designer known for her mod-glam décor, has now put her stamp on a boutique at Bergdorf Goodman. Ms. Wearstler is no stranger to Bergdorf, having designed its BG restaurant, but this shop, which opens Thursday, will house her new fashion collection. The fifth-floor boutique, fitted out with custom-designed soufflé chairs and a periwinkle velvet sofa, will showcase her ready-to-wear pieces -- minis, full-leg pants and cropped jackets to pop over them -- and accessories like metal clutches and this perforated cuff and ring, all nicely priced. Kelly Wearstler brass cuff, $225, and gunmetal ring, $125, at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue, (212) 753-7300; bergdorfgoodman.com.

Word Wizard ($3.99) turns your iPad into a talking typewriter, and a powerful language-learning tool that is ideal for a child learning to read. To build a word, you simply touch a letter and drag it next to another letter. It snaps into place and pronounces the result in clear speech. This is an important breakthrough in reading instruction, because it leverages the iPad's size, powerful speech synthesis abilities and touchscreen, so that every letter can be a building block of phonetically accurate sound.

On the music charts this week, Jay-Z and Kanye West reached No. 1 with fewer album sales than expected, and Katy Perry tied Michael Jackson for the most No. 1 songs from one album. ''Watch the Throne,'' Jay-Z and Mr. West's new joint album, sold 436,078 copies in the United States, according to Def Jam, one of the labels behind it. That's the second-biggest week for any album this year (behind Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way''), but it was less than the 500,000 that Billboard and others had predicted, perhaps due partly to its limited availability. Released on Aug. 8, it was sold only through iTunes for its first four days before being released to all retailers on Friday.

Even during months of stubborn unemployment, the health care industry has provided a solid underpinning, reliably adding jobs in an otherwise dismal environment. For example, hospitals, nursing homes and the like added about 430,000 jobs during the recession, as the country shed 7.5 million jobs. With the latest government reports showing a meager overall gain of 117,000 jobs in July, health care remained a significant contributor with an additional 31,000 jobs for the month, a tad higher than an average monthly addition of 25,000 health jobs in the last year. Hospitals, which had a slight decline in June, added 14,000 jobs in July.

Within one year, he became lead danseur, a rare feat at his age and experience. He traveled with many dance companies and was also a member of SAG and EQUITY. He is survived by his brothers Colin and Daniel and is predeceased by his siblings Eileen, Anna, Patrick, Mary and Margaret. Visiting hours will be held at Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers on Friday from 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:45am at St. Barnabas Church. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

It was only in May that an article in New York magazine described AMC as ''the fastest-rising network in America'' and wondered if that cable channel could ''survive its own success.'' Three months later that question seems more prophetic than ever. After rapidly building its brand of original programming around prestigious series like ''Mad Men'' and ''Breaking Bad,'' AMC has been roiled by behind-the-scenes disputes and controversies at every one of its signature shows, even the ones it hasn't started broadcasting yet. Although the network received 29 Emmy Award nominations in July, that was a rare bright spot amid months of developments that were often as gloomy as the art direction for its hit zombie-apocalypse drama, ''The Walking Dead'': MARCH 23 Questions are raised about whether the fifth season of ''Mad Men'' will have its premiere as scheduled in the summer, as AMC appears to be mired in a financial dispute with Matthew Weiner, the creator and show runner of the series, and Lionsgate, the studio that produces it. Mr. Weiner objects to the network's proposals to shorten episodes by two minutes (to make room for more commercials) and to cut the cast budget. ''I don't understand why, with all of the success of the show, they suddenly need to change it,'' Mr. Weiner says.

OPENINGS On Friday, Nordstrom will open TREASURE & BOND at 350 West Broadway, (646) 669-9049; treasureandbond.com. Not a mini-Nordstrom, the store has goods that are a mix of men's, women's and children's clothing, often from up-and-coming labels, home and accessories. Shoppers can feel good knowing all profits go to one of eight New York children's charities.
LONDON -- Trading soccer stars for tens of millions of dollars has always seemed to Americans like selling prize bulls to the richest farmers. At its crudest, it does have elements of that.

STEVENS--Peter Dunsmore, M.D.,49, of Haworth, NJ. Loving husband, father, and friend. Gifted physician and teacher. Died August 13, 2011. Survived by Amy, his wife of 23 years, Sam and Christina, his children, and Bette and Elizabeth, his mother and sister. Services will be held August 28, 5pm at Church of the Atonement, Tenafly, NJ.
Q. In the old days, you could create a password-reset disk to use in case you forgot your Windows administrator password. But can do you do this on a Windows 7 computer with no floppy drive?

PERHAPS it escaped your notice that deep teal is the Pantone pick as the top color for fall 2011. Even so, it will be hard to miss the sea of blue-green fall looks now reaching the stores. At Gucci, bright teal jackets and fur pieces were layered over separates in similar hues. Haider Ackermann mixed teal and sapphire and forest green in all manner of brilliant combinations. (Tilda Swinton, who picked up on the Ackermann buzz before many fashion insiders, wore one of his gowns at Cannes, above right.) At Theyskens' Theory, a dark asymmetrical coat topped a brighter turtleneck (above left). Reed Krakoff paired a chunky sapphire sweater with a turquoise silk skirt (right). And so on. To dip your toe in the water, consider a pair of J Brand skinny jeans in Riviera blue and a loose silk blouse from Zara in royal blue, teal or jade. Add a dark teal cardigan or coat as the season turns cooler. Theyskens' Theory wool blend coat, $895; turtleneck, $375, and pleated wide-leg trousers, $575 at Theory; theory.com. Reed Krakoff hand-knit turtleneck, $1,390, and silk and wool wrap skirt, $750, at Saks Fifth Avenue; saks.com.

Former United States Open champion Lleyton Hewitt and up-and-coming American teenagers Ryan Harrison and Jack Sock are among the eight men awarded wild card spots in the main draw by the United States Tennis Association on Wednesday. Hewitt, 30, is a former world No. 1 who is trying to rebound from hip surgery last year and is currently ranked 165th. He just withdrew from the Western & Southern Open in Mason, Ohio, to rest and prepare for the Open.

KLATELL--Arline (Arla), 86, died unexpectedly at her Manhattan apartment Tuesday. She loved living in New York City and maintained, until her last hours, a life and appointment book - filled with culture, travel, friends, and family. She was the widow of Jack Klatell, DDS and sister of Steve Bragin of Bellaire Bluffs, Florida. She leaves her children, David Klatell and Nancy Lauter, and Robert and Penelope Klatell. She was the loving grandmother of Christopher Klatell and Fiona Doherty, Devon Klatell, James Klatell, Jenna and Andy Miara, and Jeremy Klatell and Megan Killelea. Her great-grandchildren, Clementine, Jack, Maeve and Sophia, will miss her dearly. A remembrance will be held Friday, August 19 at 11:30 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. The family will be receiving visitors from 1:30-5pm. In lieu of gifts or flowers, please consider supporting the arts in New York City.

The composer Philip Glass, 74, a pioneer of the Minimalist style of composing, has signed a contract to write a memoir, according to the publisher W.W. Norton & Company. The book will be published by the Norton division Liveright & Company. The publishing date was not disclosed. The publisher said Mr. Glass would explore his youth and musical influences, including working in his father's record store in Baltimore and collaborations with Ravi Shankar and Allen Ginsberg. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

''The Descendants,''Alexander Payne's first feature since his 2004 film ''Sideways,'' will be the closing night selection of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Wednesday along with the roster of 27 films that will be presented in the festival's main slate. Adapted from the Kaui Hart Hemmings novel, ''The Descendants'' tells the story of Matt King, a character played by George Clooney, who is the heir of a land-owning family in Hawaii who must learn to parent his two daughters after his wife is injured in a boating accident. The film, whose cast also includes Shailene Woodley and Amara Miller as King's daughters, will be presented at the festival on Oct. 16 at Alice Tully Hall, and is scheduled for theatrical release on Nov. 23.

MINNEAPOLIS - After a disappointing first half of the season in which he batted only .195, Andruw Jones received important advice from one of his personal batting coaches, and it seems to have had quite an impact on his second-half production.

Jose Reyes gave every indication on Friday afternoon that he was ready to rejoin the Mets. He stabbed ground balls, took batting practice and jogged across the grass at Citi Field before the team hosted the Milwaukee Brewers.

Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad on the Sunday puzzle that reads: “When this puzzle is done, look for a name (hinted at by 37 Down) hidden 17 times in the grid, each reading forward, backward, down, up or diagonally, word search-style.”

Consider the Rick Perry paradox: in a G.O.P. field notably bereft of experience in elected office, he has won nine back-to-back elections and spent the last decade as governor of America's second-most-populous state. And, though the Thread has yet to see him in person, he is apparently the Red State equivalent of Kal-El. Or so says this rapturous lede from Politico:
“I’ll be passing the back of my hand over your buttocks and then come up the insides of your legs up toward the private parts. Is that O.K.?”

After he studied photography at graduate school, Ryan Gauvin didn't follow the path that young photographers so often go on. He didn't photograph gangs. He didn't photograph trailer parks. He didn't photograph transsexuals, the suffering in Africa or any immigrants crossing the border.

Ryota Igarashi, who is in the final season of a two-year, $3 million contract, had another ineffective relief outing for the Mets on Wednesday, allowing a walk and two doubles in the ninth inning of a 7-3 victory over San Diego.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving forward on recommendations made by an internal task force studying the Fukushima Daiichi triple meltdown. But it is not moving quite the way its chairman wanted.

The fall season begins on a high note with our cover star: the jazz singer Esperanza Spalding. It continues with a trend report on the fully lined, feline eye, a look at street style in London, Cairo and Japan, and a sartorial tutorial on how to wear novelty knits, maxi coats and retro dresses. Along the way, The Selby finds Nordic foragers in Stockholm, Amy Ephron recalls her 1970s party days and Alex Kuczynski sits down with the actor Demian Bichir. In "Nightie Aphrodites," Solange Knowles and Corinne Bailey Rae, among others, show off how to pair Afros with evening gowns. And don't forget to meet the model students in "Beautiful Minds" and the women who lost their hair for Hedi Slimane in "Boy Crazy." Finally, to relax a bit - vicariously, at least - drop by the rustic retreat of the designers Isabel Marant and Jerome Dreyfuss in "Le Shack." See all stories from the issue >>

MONTEREY, Calif. -- Attendees at last June's Goodwood Festival of Speed in England were treated to the formal introduction of the Venom GT from Hennessey Performance, the tuning shop based outside Houston. The first unit of the $950,000 vehicles that sold to an American customer was delivered at the McCall's Motorworks Revival here on Wednesday.

The Bravo network denied a report on Friday that it had decided to delay the start of the new season of "The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills" because of the recent suicide of a character in the show. Instead, the network said, it would re-edit the program in hopes of starting on schedule on Sept. 5.

When Carmen Rivera bore a son 36 years ago and considered a name, she thought of a book she had recently read, "Run Baby Run." It was the gangs-to-God story of Nicky Cruz, once a self-described "warlord" of a New York City gang who found religion in his early 20s and began evangelizing against crime.
Syrian activists said that at least 18 people were killed on another Friday of mass protests against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, as my colleague Nadi Bakri reports.

After making tomato water, you'll be left with a colander full of ruddy tomato flesh that is just begging not to be thrown out. I made mine into a quick tomato sauce. I smashed a few garlic cloves, bronzed them in some oil, then added the tomato solids and let it all bubble for about 15 minutes. Spooned over pasta with a few blobs of ricotta and torn basil leaves, it made a fine dinner.

ArtsBeat is taking a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this year's New York International Fringe Festival.

MONTEREY, Calif. — Never mind the distracting one-off Testa Rossa prototypes and Shelby Cobras. For visitors to the Monterey peninsula intent on glimpsing the latest in seven-passenger crossover technology from Japan, Infiniti has brought just the thing: the JX concept.

Melissa Fay Greene thought her family was complete. By 1994, she had four children, ranging in age from 2 to 13. She toyed with the idea of having a fifth, setting the arbitrary deadline of giving birth before she turned 43, which was 11 months away. The French symphonic composer Koudlam is known for his otherworldly electronic beats, pulled from classical music to tribal, creating a psychedelic something from the future, maybe even space. Here he offers up this week's playlist, which ranges from David Bowie to the relatively unknown Japanese musical cult Geinoh Yamashirogumi, headed by the scientist Tsutomu Ohashi. Sean Hanratty was introduced to Koudlam, which is French slang for "knife stab," through the very talented visual artist Cyprien Gaillard, with whom Koudlam regularly collaborates. (Gaillard's "Fight Club"-esque film, "Desniansky Raion," which Koudlam scored, was coveted at the 2007 Basel Art Fair.) "I have been a huge fan of Koudlam's for so many years," says Hanratty of Koudlam, who is constantly traveling around the world, a hobby that no doubt influences his music. "His music has this immediate sensibility that is beautiful and detached."

Another nationally televised preseason National Football League game, another victory in the ratings. The nastiness caused by the owners' lockout does not appear to have dimmed football fans' ardor for the game, even for preseason games. The Fox telecast of the the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles exhibition game drew an estimated average of 8.7 million viewers in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. hour and 9.1 million during the the rest of prime time. The broadcast was up 45 percent compared to a game last year at this time, and helped Fox win a night when its stiffest competition was "Big Brother" on CBS (8 million total viewers) and both NBC and the CW were in repeats.
Brokers have to be quite careful when choosing the language in real estate listings.

From inside Mary Lee Ward's small and sparsely furnished living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, it sounded Friday as if a block party was in full swing in the street below. Cars and trucks honked their horns as they passed and almost 200 voices could be heard cheering and chanting.
The Larry Harlow orchestra and Johnny Pacheco performed "Lamento de un Guajiro" in "Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa)." A 40th anniversary edition of the 1971 documentary is being released on DVD.

The great filmmaker Raoul Ruiz, died this morning in Paris, at 70, from a lung infection. Just six short weeks ago, A.O. Scott interviewed him for this magazine, in anticipation of the release of his most recent film, "Mysteries of Lisbon," which has been hailed by many critics as a masterpiece. Ruiz was in poor health for some time, following the discovery of a cancerous tumor in his liver. It is a testament to his spirit that he made time to sit and talk, ranging in his conversation across eras and disciplines, just as he does in his remarkable films. As Scott wrote:

Formula One racing - and auto racing in general - goes together with music, especially rock music. And in recent years, the Formula One paddock has played host to a lot of musicians who are also fans.

The manga list has the only new arrival this week and it is a "three-in-one" edition of Bleach, a series about Ichigo Kurosaki, who sees dead people and must usher them safely into the afterlife. This reprint edition collects three volumes of the regular manga series and arrives at No. 7. In the latest twist, Mr. Kurosaki must cope with a reality show that features live exorcisms.

MONTEREY, Calif. -- A limited-edition Mini Cooper model, packed with luxury appointments usually reserved for Rolls-Royce cars, siphoned some of the excitement from the North American debut of the Mini Coupe.

New Meadowlands Stadium will be renamed for MetLife, the insurance company, possibly as early as next week. The Jets and Giants, who have been without the income from a naming rights deal, would split $17 million to $20 million annually over 20 years, according to published reports.

Amid the high-rise office buildings, towering apartment complexes and sprawling construction sites, green pockets are hard to find in Gurgaon, a New Delhi suburb that is home to the back-office operations of some of the world's biggest companies. So the local government, private companies and citizens have banded together to plant a million trees.

A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a copyright lawsuit filed against the photographer Ryan McGinley by another photographer who claimed that he relied too heavily on her work for his inspiration.

James Oestreich, a critic for The New York Times, set out last month to review a concert at Lincoln Center featuring the works of Mozart and Stravinsky. But Mr. Oestreich found himself more focused on the man seated directly behind him, who was connected to an oxygen cart or similar medical device that emitted what he called a steady -- and apparently disruptive -- ticking sound.

(See Byron York, Philip Klein, Allahpundit, Daniel Larison, Jim Antle and Ed Kilgore, among others.) Rather than recapitulating all of their points, I just want to draw three Christie-Ryan contrasts.

"Tweets from Tahrir"The New York artist Michael Waugh's T features, at a glance, three gorgeous, menacing eagles intertwined to form the rather gothic moniker of this magazine. What is less apparent is that every line, every feathery stroke of Waugh's pen and ink drawing, contains words, and specifically the words that were tweeted from Tahrir Square last February, which preceded the fall of Hosni Mubarak and his government. Scroll across the work above and glimpse an account of a revolution in progress.

Ice cream fans have a trio of events to choose from this weekend. On Sunday, the New Amsterdam Market, 100 Peck Slip (South Street), at South Street Seaport will hold an Ice Cream Sunday benefit. At least 10 pastry chefs and ice cream makers are scheduled to take part, and each will offer up to four flavors. A $35 entry fee pays for early admission, which begins at noon. Otherwise, it's $25 to sample the ice cream, from miniature sugar cones, at 1 p.m. There's also an ice cream crawl on Sunday that begins at 3 p.m. in Chelsea Market, 425 West 15th Street (Ninth Avenue). The group will meet inside the market by People's Pops and make stops at L'Arte del Gelato and more. Expect to spend $15 to $25. At Rosa Mexicano Union Square, 9 East 18th Street (between Fifth Avenue and Broadway), there will be a cooking demonstration at 10 a.m. on Saturday as part of the Rosa Mexicano Ice Cream Festival through Sept. 4. Guests will learn how to create flavors like Mexican corn truffle ice cream, during the demo, which is $30 per person or $15 for children and includes a three-course lunch afterward. Call (212) 397-0666 ext. 27 to register.

"Project Runway" has taken a while to regain its stride ever since moving from Bravo to Lifetime in 2009. The initial decision to move the show to Los Angeles, the odd mix of contestants, even the eventual winners the last couple of years have all contributed to a slightly off-kilter viewing experience.

Every time I read someone talking about the "collapsing welfare states of Europe", I have this urge to take that person on a forced walking tour of Stockholm. If you believed what the right says, a country with Sweden's level of both taxes and social benefits should be a wasteland. Strange to say, that's not what it looks like, to say the least.

"I sent my mum an old 1940s Dick Whittington comic and said something like, 'Think old cartoon sketches you would see in Punch Magazine,'" says the designer Louisa Parris about the instruction she gave her mother, Cherrill Parris-Fox, when the two decided to bring Parris's debut collection of scarves and hats to life with a series of fashion illustrations. The result: witty and heartwarming pencil drawings portraying distinguished women draped and decorated in Pariss's striped silk kerchiefs. "I thought of my grandmother's good friend, Aunt Lee," says Pariss-Fox of her inspiration. "She wore bright voluminous tops, anchored her chest with strands of pearls and always carried a large silk hankie to dab the occasional facial glistening!"
This weekend's Wealth Matters column opens with a bold statement about people who have sold stocks and are buying gold or United States Treasury bonds.

The randomized clinical trial, long the gold standard of medical research, supposedly provides the most reliable data regarding which drugs, devices and procedures prove effective on real patients and which don't. But when the people enrolled in the trial are quite different from those who will actually use the drug or device or undergo the procedure, the data are far less reliable.

A panel charged with advising New York officials on regulating a controversial form of natural gas extraction known as hydrofracking will first examine whether the state government has enough staff members to properly monitor and enforce new drilling regulations.

In June, the magazine published my article about a mob-killing in a shantytown near Johannesburg. The grisly scene had been recorded on video by a friend of mine, Golden Mtika, a freelance journalist who lived in the impoverished community. Golden himself was poor, the article explained, and he was saving money so that he could one day move his family to a safer place. The article also mentioned that he was a devout Mormon.

Every summer in Paris, wandering theatrical troupes present over 30 outdoor performances all over the city in the festival called Treteaux Nomades. Skilled at improvisation, commedia dell'arte, burlesque, music and poetry, the adventurous actors set up a wooden stage, or treteaux, and offer contemporary versions of traditional and modern plays, as well as storytelling and clown and mime acts. This year's festival will run from Aug. 22 through Sept. 4.

HEFTY FEE Google agreed to pay Motorola Mobility a $2.5 billion reverse termination fee if its proposed takeover fails to obtain antitrust clearance. This fee is about 20 percent of the $12.5 billion deal value and is significantly higher than the $375 million Motorola Mobility must pay Google if it accepts another bid. Is there any chance that it will be paid? The Deal Professor says Google is making a statement that it won't have to pay the fee. STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF

''It's too bad she won't live,'' Edward James Olmos tells Harrison Ford in ''Blade Runner.'' ''But then again, who does?'' And then again, there are those movies that just live on forever: Ridley Scott, who directed that moody 1982 science-fiction film noir, will direct and produce a new feature that is being described as a ''Blade Runner'' follow-up for Alcon Entertainment, a Warner Brothers-based financing and production company, its press representatives said on Thursday. The original ''Blade Runner,'' which was adapted from the Philip K. Dick story ''Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?'', starred Mr. Ford as a human bounty hunter (or is he?) charged with hunting down lifelike androids in a future version of Los Angeles (where Atari is apparently still a major video game publisher). Though the film got a mixed reception in its day (Janet Maslin called it ''muddled yet mesmerizing'' in her review for The New York Times), it has become a cult classic and released in at least seven different edits, with different endings depending on who was wielding the scissors.

SKOLNIK--Reva Marilyn, died on August 18, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Barry, devoted mother Ira Skolnik, M.D. and Brandon Skolnik, loving grandmother to Jonah and Zara, dear sister of Michael Rosenthal. Services Friday August 19, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

''End of the Rainbow,'' Peter Quilter's popular London drama-with-music about the final months of Judy Garland's life, will come to Broadway next year, the show's producers announced on Thursday. Performances are scheduled to begin March 19, 2012, at a Shubert theater to be announced, with opening night set for April 3. Tracie Bennett, a two-time Olivier Award winner who originated the role of Garland in London, will reprise her role on Broadway. ''End of the Rainbow,'' directed by Terry Johnson (''La Cage aux Folles''), is set in December 1968 during Garland's visit to London, a few months before her death. It features several songs for which Garland is most known, including ''The Man That Got Away,'' ''Come Rain or Come Shine,'' ''The Trolley Song'' and ''Over the Rainbow.''

An obituary and a headline on Thursday about Dr. Fritz H. Bach, who helped develop techniques to help improve people's chances of surviving organ and bone marrow transplants, misstated his age. He was 77, not 76. (As the obituary correctly noted, he was born on April 5, 1934.)

3:50 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren formed an exploratory committee on Thursday morning as she continues to consider a run for the Senate in Massachusetts, and her camp maintains that she is still doing just that: exploring. But given their gleeful reaction to this news, Bay State and some national Democrats seem primed for a painful letdown if Ms. Warren, a Harvard Law professor, ultimately decides against challenging Senator Scott Brown. Ms. Warren gained national (and polarizing) attention for masterminding the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in the wake of the financial crisis. This week, she has been traveling around Massachusetts on a ''listening tour'' to gauge support for a candidacy.

8:58 p.m. | UpdatedIn a sharp but widely predicted reversal, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday unveiled a revised slate of toll and fare increases on the major Hudson River crossings, one far less steep than the agency initially proposed. Under the new plan, E-ZPass tolls would be raised in September to $9.50 a ride at peak hours, from $8, on the George Washington Bridge, the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, and three other crossings to Staten Island.

An art review last Friday about ''La Carte d'Après Nature'' at the Matthew Marks Gallery in Chelsea, featuring work by the painter René Magritte, referred incorrectly to the curation of an earlier Magritte show at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2006-7. Stephanie Barron and Michel Draguet were the curators -- not John Baldessari, who was the show's exhibition designer.

The Health Consumer column on June 25, about improving posture to avoid back pain, misstated the optimum positioning of a desktop computer screen. The top of the screen -- not its center -- should be at or slightly below eye level. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail to The Times on Wednesday.

FLYNN--Kathleen, of Somers, NY, died at her home on August 17, 2011 following a brief illness. She was 77 years of age. A native of New York City, Kathleen was the widow of Joseph Flynn, A career law enforcement official who served with distinction in the New York City Department and later as the Chief of the Long Island Railroad Police. Kathleen and Joseph were married in 1955. Joseph Passed away in 2001. Kathleen's long and successful career in banking and finance began in the late 1950s as a Stenographer and Clerk in a local Bronx bank branch. She later moved on to Citibank where she rose steadily in management and retired as a Corporate Vice President. Kathleen is survived by her sister Mary Monahan of Tuckahoe, NY, Her brother Edward Galligan of New Rochelle, NY and Many Nieces, Nephews, and grand and great nieces and nephews who loved her dearly. Visiting will be held at the Joseph J. Smith Funeral Home, 692 Route 6, Mahopac, NY 10541 on Sunday, August 21st from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Joseph's Church, 10 Croton Falls Rd., Croton Falls, NY 10519 on Monday, August 22nd at 10am. Committal will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 10 W. Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532. Kathleen's family requests that Memorial Donations be made in her name to the New York Police & Fire Widows & Children's Benefit Fund, 767 Fifth Avenue; 2621, New York, NY 10153 (www.answerthecall.org). Services by: Flynn Memorial Home, Inc 914-963-5178 www.flynnmemorialhome.com

An obituary on Wednesday about Ralph D. Albertazzie, the pilot of Air Force One during the Nixon administration, referred imprecisely to one mission he flew. In July 1971 he flew Henry A. Kissinger to Pakistan and another pilot secretly flew Mr. Kissinger on another plane from there to China, where he discussed plans for President Richard M. Nixon's trip there. Mr. Albertazzie did not ''take Mr. Kissinger to China'' on that mission, nor did he fly President Nixon there four months later. (He did fly Mr. Kissinger to China in October of that year, then flew Nixon there four months after that.) The obituary also referred incorrectly to ''The Flying White House,'' the book Mr. Albertazzie wrote with J. F. terHorst. In that book Mr. Albertazzie wrote about himself in the third person, not the second.

The Deal Professor column on July 20, about the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn's unsolicited takeover offers, misstated his record in acquiring companies. 5:23 p.m. | Updated At least three people died and 71 were injured Thursday when a stage collapsed during a storm at an outdoor music festival in Belgium, according to The Associated Press. Blown by heavy winds, the stage fell on the opening day of the three-day Pukkelpop Festival in Hasselt, 50 miles east of Brussels. About 60,000 people were there for the event, one of the biggest alternative-rock festivals in Europe. According to local news media reports cited by The A.P., the sky grew dark as a storm went through the festival grounds, bringing hailstones and heavy winds. A video on YouTube shows the stage rigs blowing in the wind and beginning to tip over.

EDWARDS--Charles Cornell, M.D. Died at home in La Jolla, California, August 7, 2011, after a long illness. Born in Overton, Nebraska September 16, 1923, he grew up during dust storms, locust infestations, and the Great Depression. He began studies at Princeton in 1941, but after Pearl Harbor enrolled in the Navy's V-12 program, and transferred to the University of Colorado, where he earned his BA and MD. He completed an MS in surgery (University of Minnesota) and surgical fellowship at the Mayo Clinic. From 1950-1952, he served with the Marines on the front lines of the Korean War, after which he spent five years in private practice in Des Moines. In 1969 President Nixon appointed him Commissioner/U.S. Food & Drug Administration; and in 1971, he became Assistant Secretary for Health (Department of Health, Education, & Welfare). In 1975, he resigned citing Ford administration cuts to health care that adversely affected the poor and unemployed. He became president/CEO, Scripps Clinic & Research Foundation, La Jolla, in 1977 and oversaw a dramatic expansion into one of the largest employers in San Diego and a leading health care provider in California. He retired in 1993. A generous benefactor and strong proponent of philanthropy and community service, Dr. Edwards is survived by his wife of 66 years, Sue Kruidenier Edwards; children Timothy K. Edwards (Pat), Charles C. Edwards, Jr. (Karin), Nancy Edwards Schned (Eric), and David B. Edwards (Marketa); eight grandchildren; & cousin Cornell Arendt. In lieu of flowers, contributions to San Diego Hospice (www.sdhospice.org) or Voices for Children San Diego (www.speakupnow.org).

9:30 P.M. (13) VIENNA PHILHARMONIC SUMMER NIGHT 2011 Valery Gergiev, left, conducts the orchestra in the gardens of Schönbrunn Palace, a Unesco World Heritage Site. The program, taped on June 2 and presented here by ''Great Performances,'' is centered on the theme ''Virtuoso Pictures'' and features Liszt's Preludes; Kreisler's ''Concerto in One Movement After Paganini's Violin Concerto'' (Op. 6), performed by Benjamin Schmid; Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition''; and Johann Strauss's ''Viennese Spirit Waltz,'' ''On the Banks of the Danube'' and ''Quick Polka.'' 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: DEBBIE REYNOLDS This all-day tribute to one of the spunkiest actresses in the 1950s begins with ''The Affairs of Dobie Gillis'' (1953), with Ms. Reynolds as his dream girl -- a role she continues in various permutations in ''The Tender Trap'' (1955), at 8:45; ''Tammy and the Bachelor'' (1957), at 12:30 p.m.; and ''The Mating Game'' (1959), at 2. According to a lawsuit filed last week in Superior Court in Los Angeles, a former lead artist on the cartoon ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' hired accomplices to attack his art dealer and take over her gallery in order to gain control of the sale of his work - claims the artist denies. The artist, Todd White, was a character designer on ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' until 2005 and has since developed a fine art career. The lawsuit, which was brought by Margaret Howell, the owner of the Gallery HB at the Hyatt Regency in Huntington Beach, asserts that agents of Mr. White arranged to meet her at her gallery on the evening of Aug. 2, where they proceeded to assault her and imprison her for several hours while they stole $1 million worth of artwork by Mr. White as well as business documents, including confidential customer lists. The suit claims that they also forced her to take them to her home, where they stole an additional several hundred thousand dollars' worth of art by Mr. White.

Nearly 60 percent of supermarket inspections in the last year turned up violations of consumer protections, an increase over the year before, even amid a high-profile city crackdown, the Department of Consumer Affairs said. In response, the department has called for a law that would force stores to pay customers 10 times the amount of any overcharge.

Luck, or if you prefer a less loaded term, randomness, plays a significant role in any major league baseball game. A line drive caught by the third baseman might be rattling around the left-field corner if it had hit the bat just a few millimeters higher. A borderline strike three might be ball four with just a tiny change in the pitcher's grip. Usually all of these events that could go one way or another balance out over 162 games and the season ends with the best teams at the top of the standings, but only usually.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The Puns & Anagrams puzzles that we know and love in The New York Times go all the way back to Feb. 15, 1942. Underneath The Times’ first Sunday crossword was a Puns & Anagrams puzzle titled “Riddle Me This” by the maddeningly named Anna Gram. No one today knows for sure who the pseudonymous Anna Gram was, although Will Shortz tells me that he has always suspected Margaret Farrar. Mardy Fish, who lost to another former No. 1, Roger Federer, in the final here last year, will face Andy Murray, whom he has defeated in their last three meetings, Saturday in the semifinals.
Bienestan, now performing at the Jazz Standard, is a collaboration between the Argentine bandleader Guillermo Klein and the pianist Aaron Goldberg.
A thriving industry is buying and selling rapturous reviews on the Web, and academics and businesses are looking for ways to ferret out the fakes.
Payrolls climbed in 31 states in July, led by New York and Texas, while the jobless rate increased in 28, painting a mixed employment picture for last month.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia’s business index for August fell to a level that in the past has signaled a recession.
Families of victims killed on Utoya Island in July traveled to the site of the massacre for the first time.
A Scotland Yard detective was arrested on Thursday “on suspicion of misconduct in a public office relating to an unauthorized disclosure of information.”
League officials and player representatives failed to make a last-minute deal Friday.
The idea of equalizing capital gains and ordinary income rates has become the third rail of tax policy and electoral politics.
Prosecutors say the victim, Nazish Noorani, had recently texted her brother about her husband, Kashif Parvaiz: “Someday U will find me dead, but it’s cuz of Kashi.”
After 12 N.H.L. seasons, the final four with the Rangers, Chris Drury retired on Friday.
The players union said Friday that the N.F.L.’s announcement about testing for human growth hormone was premature.
As street battles raged on Friday just a half-hour’s drive from the Libyan capital, there were new signs in Tripoli that worried foreigners were urgently trying to leave.
An Israeli strike aimed at militants killed three Egyptian officers, raising tensions the day after attacks near the border that killed eight Israelis.
A proposed sale, scheduled for Dec. 14, will be the first in the part of the gulf bordering Texas since the summer of 2009 and the first sale of any kind in the gulf since March 2010.
Investors who rush to Treasuries or gold in times of turmoil should be thinking about when to get back into other securities.
Caller ID spoofing, the way hackers gain access to phone voice mail accounts, can also be used to get someone else’s credit card information.
The suspension of the deal, in which Belarus had agreed to give up its supply of highly enriched uranium, comes in response to the latest wave of economic sanctions imposed by Washington.
The reaction followed a brawl during a “goodwill” match between a Chinese and an American team on Thursday.
Some sportswriters wrestled with the logic of quarterback Terrelle Pryor’s five-game suspension by the N.F.L. after his transgressions at Ohio State.
In his new memoir, “Sex, Mom, & God,” Frank Schaeffer recounts growing up in a family revered by evangelicals, and his eventual disillusion.
Three men convicted of killing three 8-year-old boys in a 1993 murder case were freed from jail on Friday.
Syrian rights activists said security forces killed at least 18 people during the first protest since President Bashar al-Assad said military operations against demonstrators had ended.
To meet electricity demand, Japan has fired up fossil-fuel plants at great environmental and economic costs.
At least 47 people were killed when a suicide bomber detonated himself during midday prayers.
Inspectors north of Tokyo found radioactive cesium in a sample of rice from the city of Hokota, about 90 miles south of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

Prime Minister Naoto Kan has scrapped plans to meet with President Barack Obama in Washington next month, as pressure builds on him to resign in coming weeks.

Israel launched strikes on Gaza, and militants fired rockets into Israel on Friday. Egypt said two of its officers were mistakenly killed by Israelis firing at suspected militants.
In a second day of meetings Friday with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Vice President Xi Jinping called for new measures to restore confidence in global financial markets.
At least eight people are dead in the attack, which came on the day Afghans celebrate gaining independence from Britain in 1919.
