EDWARDS--Charles Cornell, M.D. Died at home in La Jolla, California, August 7, 2011, after a long illness. Born in Overton, Nebraska September 16, 1923, he grew up during dust storms, locust infestations, and the Great Depression. He began studies at Princeton in 1941, but after Pearl Harbor enrolled in the Navy's V-12 program, and transferred to the University of Colorado, where he earned his BA and MD. He completed an MS in surgery (University of Minnesota) and surgical fellowship at the Mayo Clinic. From 1950-1952, he served with the Marines on the front lines of the Korean War, after which he spent five years in private practice in Des Moines. In 1969 President Nixon appointed him Commissioner/U.S. Food & Drug Administration; and in 1971, he became Assistant Secretary for Health (Department of Health, Education, & Welfare). In 1975, he resigned citing Ford administration cuts to health care that adversely affected the poor and unemployed. He became president/CEO, Scripps Clinic & Research Foundation, La Jolla, in 1977 and oversaw a dramatic expansion into one of the largest employers in San Diego and a leading health care provider in California. He retired in 1993. A generous benefactor and strong proponent of philanthropy and community service, Dr. Edwards is survived by his wife of 66 years, Sue Kruidenier Edwards; children Timothy K. Edwards (Pat), Charles C. Edwards, Jr. (Karin), Nancy Edwards Schned (Eric), and David B. Edwards (Marketa); eight grandchildren; & cousin Cornell Arendt. In lieu of flowers, contributions to San Diego Hospice (www.sdhospice.org) or Voices for Children San Diego (www.speakupnow.org).

MOSCOW - The management of Russia's largest mining operator, Norilsk Nickel, offered on Friday to buy most of the shares held by one of the company's two feuding owners and thus resolve the dispute. Norilsk generates vast profits as the world's largest producer of nickel and palladium, and is one of the largest producers of copper, platinum, gold, silver and other rare metals. But the two largest owners, who are members of the rich coterie of industrialists known as oligarchs, have been locked in conflict for years for control.

Jose Reyes gave every indication on Friday afternoon that he was ready to rejoin the Mets. He stabbed ground balls, took batting practice and jogged across the grass at Citi Field before the team hosted the Milwaukee Brewers. But Reyes's workout in the morning at the Mets' training facility on Long Island showed that his return from a strained left hamstring was probably still days away.

Kim Clijsters, winner of the past two United States Open titles, has withdrawn from this year's tournament because of an abdominal strain. Clijsters, 28, sustained the injury last week at the Rogers Cup in Toronto. She won her first set, 6-3, against the qualifier Zheng Jie, but made it through only the third game of the second set after the injury.

A steep toll increase on the bridges and tunnels that cross the Hudson River was approved Friday morning by the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the culmination of a two-week dance among the agency, politicians and the public. The increase, to be phased in, will raise peak-time E-ZPass tolls to $9.50 from $8 beginning next month. By 2015, that toll will be $12.50. The cash toll will go up 50 percent in September, to $12 a car; by 2015, the cash toll will be $15.

From inside Mary Lee Ward's small and sparsely furnished living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, it sounded Friday as if a block party was in full swing in the street below. Cars and trucks honked their horns as they passed and almost 200 voices could be heard cheering and chanting. But this was no street party; it was not yet 9 a.m. and the crowd outside was there as a line of defense.

NAFISSIAN--Parviz, on August 18, 2011. Affiliated with Morgan Stanley for 20 years and UBS for eight years. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of David and Sheryl, adored grandfather of Elizabeth. Dear brother of Parvine and Hedy. Service Sunday, August 21, 2011, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

The death toll at the Pukkelpop music festival in Belgium, where heavy winds toppled three stages on Thursday, has risen to five, and the number counted as injured has nearly doubled to 140, Belgian officials said on Friday. The organizers of Pukkelpop, held near Hasselt, a city about 50 miles east of Brussels, also decided early Friday to cancel the rest of the event, which was to continue through Saturday. One of the biggest summer rock festivals in Europe, with eight stages and daily attendance of about 60,000, Pukkelpop had a lineup this year that included Eminem, the Foo Fighters, Fleet Foxes, Blonde Redhead and the Ting Tings.

Back in June, in a post about adjustable-rate home loans, Bucks mused about how nice it would be to have a mortgage interest rate that began with a ''3.'' The way things are going, that time may not be far off for fixed-rates loans, as well. Mortgage rates reached record lows this week, according to the weekly market survey from Freddie Mac. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate loan fell to 4.15 percent, with borrowers paying an average point of 0.7 percent. That rate is down from 4.32 percent last week.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the wig-wearing ''bad hair bandit,'' who is suspected of robbing a string of banks in the West, misstated the number of banks she is believed to have hit. As the article correctly noted, it is at least 20, not 18.

8 P.M. (HBO) UNSTOPPABLE (2010) Denzel Washington, in his fifth collaboration with the director Tony Scott, plays Frank Barnes, a veteran engineer trying to stop a runaway train speeding through Pennsylvania with a load of hazardous cargo. Chris Pine, above right with Mr. Washington, is Will Colson, the new, hotheaded conductor Frank is charged with training. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Mr. Scott, working with the cinematographer Ben Seresin and some ace sound technicians, ''creates an unexpectedly rich world of chugging, rushing trains slicing across equally beautiful industrial and natural landscapes,'' adding, ''There is something mesmerizing about these trains and the men who run them, something nostalgic too, because they seem like history machines, summoning up a past lived and also imagined, as in, for starters, 'The Great Train Robbery' (1903), 'North by Northwest' (1959) and 'Speed' (1994).' '' Alas, she said, '' 'Unstoppable' doesn't belong in that company: its story is largely forgettable, and its pleasures are transitory, limited to the actors (including Rosario Dawson and Kevin Corrigan, working up a sweat back in dispatch) and to its moments of beauty and strange comedy.'' Still, despite some ridiculous action flourishes from Mr. Scott, ''with a handful of appealing actors in tow, he sure keeps that machine going.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Richard W. Johnson, the director of the Urban Institute's Program on Retirement Policy, discusses Americans' retirement preparedness and the benefits of working later in life.

The Global Update feature on Aug. 9, about a report on AIDS in Middle Eastern and North African countries, misstated the report's findings pertaining to truck drivers, prisoners and street children. Those populations were found to frequently engage in behaviors that put them at risk for H.I.V. infection; they were not found to have high rates of H.I.V. infection.
KAHN--David Roger. Happy Birthday, Sweetheart. We miss you more each day. All our love, Mom and Dad

Forget ''I NY.'' That's old. That's dull. That's been done. Earlier this month, the city's tourism arm, NYC & Company, reintroduced its staid online store with a line of T-shirts printed with neon colors and bubblegum fonts and advertised on models wearing mustaches posing before brick walls. Evoking the palette of streetwear company Billionaire Boys Club, the shirts look ready to be worn by 16-year-olds in vintage high-tops or the 20somethings who loll in Williamsburg's parks.

It's been a rough month so far, economically and financially speaking. A fun, creative challenge is in order, as a diversion from the doom and gloom. So we're relieved that Smith Magazine is seeking ''Six Words About Work,'' as part of its ongoing Six-Word Memoir project. This summer, the online magazine has been running a contest on work-related topics, in partnership with human resources consulting firm Mercer. The winner in each category can win an iPad or BlackBerry PlayBook, and a chance to have their composition published in a ''Six Words About Work'' book.

I'm just tired. This has been going on for 18 years. DAMIEN ECHOLS, who was freed from death row Friday as one of the ''West Memphis Three,'' who were released after an unusual plea deal in the 1993 killings of three boys in West Memphis, Ark. [A1]

DURKIN--Dorothy, beloved wife, mother, colleague and friend of many, died on August 15, 2011, at age 66. Loving wife of David L. Hawthorne, with whom she recently celebrated her 38th anniversary. Devoted mother to David F. Hawthorne, who turns 30 on August 21. Dorothy was born and raised in Glen Cove, Long Island, NY. Her adoring parents Rose (87) and Frank (91) Durkin, reside in Framingham, Mass. For 41 years, Dorothy worked passionately for the NYU School of Continuing and Professional Studies, becoming a national leader in the marketing of continuing education. New Yorkers came into daily contact with her work, notably SCPS subway advertising and Bulletin covers featuring leading artists. Her creativity, strategic vision, and leadership will be remembered always. Viewing: Saturday, August 20, Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC, from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm.

DURKIN--Dorothy. Beloved colleague, generous and caring friend, brilliant, far-sighted institutional leader, and passionate advocate for the NYU School of Continuing and Professional Studies. She served our School and University with dedication, creative vision, intellectual energy, and love for 41 years. A pioneering visionary in the world of strategic program development, database analytics, and relationship-management marketing, Dorothy was known for her profound commitment to our School, to NYU, and to every person she touched. Through her infallible sense of emerging opportunities to serve the continuing higher education needs of adult learners, she has left an indelible impact on the evolution, identity, and reputation of NYU-SCPS. Widely admired for her knowledge and creative insights, Dorothy served on many boards, most notably the University Professional and Continuing Education Association (UPCEA), from which she received the prestigious Walton S. Bittner Citation for Outstanding Service. Other earned accolades include the John Caples Direct Marketing Award, numerous awards from the Council for the Advancement and Support of Education (CASE), and the Admissions Marketing Report. Perpetually kind, gracious, indefatigably loyal and charismatic, Dorothy brightened the lives of all who knew and worked with her. Our deepest sympathies, love, and support go out to her husband, David L. Hawthorne, her son, David F. Hawthorne, and her mother and father.

New Meadowlands Stadium will be renamed for MetLife, the insurance company, possibly as early as next week. The Jets and Giants, who have been without the income from a naming rights deal, would split $17 million to $20 million annually over 20 years, according to published reports. MetLife's interest in the stadium, where it is currently a cornerstone sponsor paying about $7 million annually, was first reported in June by Sports Business Journal.

Leon J. Schipper, a physicist whose passion for data led him to question the value of popular energy policies, like government subsidies for ethanol and for electric cars and the ''cash for clunkers'' program, died Tuesday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 64. The cause was pancreatic cancer, according to Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, where he had worked for more than 20 years.

A theater entry in the New Jersey calendar of events in some editions last Sunday gave an incorrect Web address for ''Real Men Pray, '' being performed today at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. at the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick. The Web site for the production is www.JoeMcRaeProduction.com, not www.crossroadstheatrecompany.org.

The Warner Music Group, which was sold to the holding company Access Industries in May for $3.3 billion, has made several changes to its board as it prepares a bid to buy EMI Music, which is being auctioned by Citigroup. Edgar M. Bronfman Jr., Warner's chairman and chief executive since he and a team of investors bought the company in 2004, gave up the role of chairman to become chief executive as a result of the Access sale. Stephen F. Cooper, a board member of one of Access's other companies, was made Warner's chairman. With the changes announced by Warner on Friday, Mr. Bronfman will become chairman again, and Mr. Cooper will take over the day-to-day operations of the company as chief executive. Mr. Cooper will remain a board member.

A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a copyright lawsuit filed against the photographer Ryan McGinley by another photographer who claimed that he relied too heavily on her work for his inspiration. In July, Janine Gordon, who is known as JahJah and is also a musician and multimedia artist, sued Mr. McGinley -- who is best known for his artfully constructed visions of young men and women -- claiming that at least 150 of his photographs were ''substantially based'' on her own and were violations of her copyright. Ms. Gordon has taken her camera into concert mosh pits and bull-riding rings and among glue sniffers in Brazil, building a body of work that likewise chronicles contemporary youth culture. Mr. McGinley responded that his work and Ms. Gordon's did not ''look alike in the slightest'' and argued that she was ''really complaining that the images share the same fundamental idea.''

6:13 p.m. | Updated Carl C. Icahn stepped up his fight with Clorox on Friday, threatening to replace the company's entire board with his own candidates after the consumer products giant rebuffed his $10.7 billion takeover proposal.

The weather this year has not only been lousy, it has been as destructive in terms of economic loss as any on record. Normally, three or four weather disasters a year in the United States will cause at least $1 billion in damages each. This year, there were nine such disasters. They included the huge snow dump in late January and early February on the Midwest and Northeast, the rash of tornadoes this spring across the Midwest and the more recent flooding of the Missouri and Souris Rivers. The disasters were responsible for at least 589 deaths, including 160 in May when tornadoes ripped through Joplin, Mo.

An article on Aug. 10 about Mike Baxter's rise from the ball fields in Queens to his debut with the Mets on Aug. 8 misstated the history of a baseball field in Bayside, Queens, known as Valle East. The name, which was never formally adopted, is a tribute to John Valle, who coached in the Bayside Little League -- not to Dave Valle, his son and a former major league player.

KIRSHENBAUM--Stanley. The family of Stanley Ira Kirshenbaum, aged 81, mourn the loss of a great son, brother, husband, father, uncle, stepfather, father-in-law, grandfather, friend and inspiration to all who knew him. Loving father to Richard and Dana Kirshenbaum, Susan Kirshenbaum and Rob Perry, beloved husband to the late Marilyn E. Kirshenbaum and Phyllis Trinin, loving brother to Chester and Paulette Kirschenbaum, Jackie and Armand Kalajian, stepfather to David and Jennifer Trinin and Emily and Rob Jacobson and loving grandfather to Lucas, Talia and Georgia Kirshenbaum. Isabelle and Rebecca Trinin and Hannah and William Jacobson. Loving uncle and great-uncle to the Kirschenbaum, Joachim and Kalajian families. Stanley led an exemplary life of morality, generosity, inspiration, vision, philanthropy and creativity. He was beloved by every person who crossed his path. Successful careers in the textile industry and finance allowed him to help those less fortunate and those whom he loved. Stanley was an army veteran who was Bronx born and raised his family in East Rockaway and Great Neck and was a generous benefactor and quiet proponent of change and generosity. His views of being conventionally unconventional will be greatly missed. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday August 21st at 11:45am. Donations can be made to: The Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stanley Kirshenbaum Scholarship Fund Mount Sinai Development Office 770 Lexington Avenue 8th Floor New York, NY 10065.
KIRSHENBAUM--Stanley. Meeting Stanley was like the first time you tasted Champagne - knowing him was like drinking it. The Mitchell Family

SITOMER--Alan, 84, of Tarrytown, NY, passed away surrounded by his family on August 17, 2011, after suffering a heart attack. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Annette, and his children, Todd Sitomer, of Springfield, NJ; Joan Sitomer and her husband Frank DeSanto, of Ypsilanti, MI; and Barbara Sitomer, of Tarrytown, NY, as well as his dear brother, Stephen Sitomer, and his wife Elaine, of Boca Raton, FL. He also leaves behind six grandchildren - Matt and his partner Wendy Hopkins, Dan and his wife Rachel, Tim and his partner Rachel Stewart, Pete, Aaron, and Jacob. Alan served proudly in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II and graduated with honors in 1949 from the New York University School of Commerce. He built a highly successful career in sales and marketing of fabrics for men's shirting and sleepwear and was a principal of Stylemaker Fabrics for many years. Family was central to his life and he is missed more than words can express. Among his other loves were golf, the New York Yankees and Giants, and all things British. He will be laid to rest at the non-denominational Trinity Church Cemetery and Mausoleum in Manhattan in a private ceremony for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Jewish War Veterans of the U.S.A., the United Jewish Appeal, or the American Civil Liberties Union. www.BallardDurand.com
DYSTOPIA GARDENS Dixon Place

BENNETT--Robert E.,a man of exceptional character, loyalty, warmth, humor and intelligence, died of cancer on August 16, 2011 in the company of his loving family at home in Norwell, Massachusetts. He was 50. Bob truly excelled in everything he set his heart, mind and hand to. Born in Morristown, New Jersey, Bob attended Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, where he distinguished himself both academically and in athletics, garnering national recognition as an All-American lacrosse goalie. He went on to Princeton University, graduating in 1982. There he was elected to serve as president of Ivy Club, one of the university's historic clubs. Bob graduated from Harvard Business School in 1986, earning the prestigious honor of Baker Scholar in recognition of academic achievement. A highly respected, highly accomplished businessman, Bob excelled at two of America's iconic firms. His early career was at Goldman, Sachs, where he spent a total of nine years, specializing in real estate investment banking. He spent the rest of his career at Berkshire Hathaway, taking on a wide range of responsibilities over 17 highly fulfilling years, and rising to the level of Senior Vice President. He served as a valued member of the Gastrointestinal Visiting Committee at Dana Farber Cancer Institute. An adoring husband of 18 years to his wife Julie, and a wonderful father to his sons Jake and Drew, he drew his greatest joy from their endeavors, especially on the hockey rink and baseball diamond. Bob's special combination of integrity, warm-heartedness, and good humor were magnetic; wherever he went, from Exeter, to Princeton to Harvard to Wall Street to the playing fields of Norwell, Bob made friends that invariably became lifelong, truly cherished members of his family. He is survived by his loving wife Julie, sons Jake and Drew, sister Catherine and her husband Fred Frailey, sister Betsy and her husband Bill Henkel, brother Jeff and his wife Kelsey, sister-in-law Constance and many nieces and nephews. Family and friends are invited to attend the memorial service celebrating Bob's life to be held on Thursday, September 8 at 3:00pm at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 59 Court Street, Dedham, MA 02026. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bob's memory to the Bennett/Wallace Family Scholarship Fund at Noble and Greenough School, 10 Campus Drive, Dedham, MA 02026 or The Bennett Family Fund for Targeted Therapies at Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 10 Brookline Place, Brookline, MA 02445. For an online guestbook, please visit www.mcnamara-sparrell.com

An article on Aug. 8 about the internal political struggles of China's prime minister, Wen Jiabao, described incorrectly his account of a 1986 trip with the Communist party leader at the time, Hu Yaobang. Mr. Wen, in a reminiscence published in People's Daily last year, said he had organized the trip, to Guizhou Province, and that Mr. Hu sent him to meet secretly with villagers. Mr. Wen did not say he had arranged such a meeting for Mr. Hu.

William A. Ackman likes a good sale. The head at Pershing Square Capital Management plans to increase his stake in J.C. Penney, whose shares have gotten slashed in recent months. According to a regulatory filing on Friday, the hedge fund manager intends to up his position to as much as 26.1 percent, up from 16.5 percent at the end of December.

A 22-year-old Indiana woman died Friday of injuries sustained at the stage collapse at the Indiana State Fair last week, becoming the sixth person to die as a result of the accident. The Star-Press of Muncie, Ind., reported that Jennifer Haskell, a student at Ball State University, died at a hospital in Indianapolis. Ms. Haskell's best friend, Alina Bigjohny, 23, was also killed by the collapse, the newspaper reported.

11:15 a.m. | Updated The surviving members of the Beatles have thrown their support behind a grassroots campaign to fight against music piracy, allowing the enormously influential band's music to be used in a short animated video to help raise awareness of the value of original music, a publicist for campaign said. Made by the Music Matters campaign, the video does not directly address the issue of piracy. The main character talks about how the Beatles and their songs marked miles-stones in his life and brought people together around the world in a profound way. The animation is simple: stick figures, some with the Beatles faces and playing guitars. The soundtrack includes tracks like ''Octopus's Garden,'' ''Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' and ''Hey Jude.'' It ends with the slogan: ''That's why music matters.''

Part of the investor's dilemma is that no matter how much data we have about the past, we have no data for the future. No matter what history says about the long-term, upward trend of the stock market, we still don't know for sure what the future will bring. So after all the spreadsheets are put away, investing becomes a matter of faith.

An article on Wednesday about the post office in North Hoosick, N.Y., which the Postal Service is considering closing, erroneously attributed a distinction to it. At 12 feet by 20 feet, it is not the second-smallest post office in the country. (The smallest one, at 7 feet by 8 feet, is in Ochopee, Fla. And at least one other post office is smaller than North Hoosick's -- a 12-foot-by-14-foot one in Ophir, Colo.) The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

10:35 p.m. | Updated EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - Just as it appeared that Osi Umenyiora's tribulations had come to an end, his preseason took another unexpected turn when the Giants announced that he had arthroscopic knee surgery Friday morning and was expected to miss three to four weeks. The operation was to remove debris from his right knee, which had swelled after each of the team's three practices this week. Umenyiora, a defensive end, practiced for the first time this training camp on Monday after a brief holdout over his contract.

Christine Lahti (''God of Carnage'') and Reed Birney (''Dream of the Burning Boy'') will star in the Atlantic Theater Company's production of ''Dreams of Flying Dreams of Falling,'' a new play by Adam Rapp, the theater announced Thursday. The show is to begin previews on Sept. 13, open Oct. 3 and play a limited engagement through Oct. 30 at the Classic Stage Company in the East Village. Neil Pepe will direct the production, which also stars Cotter Smith, Shane McRae, Katherine Waterston, Betsy Aidem and Quincy Tyler Bernstine.

There were no news conferences, no television appearances, no teary-eyed remembrances of a 12-year career. He had the players union release a statement and that was it. Mississippi is at the bottom of most health-related lists, and the Mississippi Delta is at the bottom of that bottom. But a church-based initiative is looking to improve the situation.

ConvaTec, a company owned by two private equity firms, has made a bid for Kinetic Concepts that is higher than the wound-healing technology company's $4.9 billion deal with another group of investors, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

The overwhelming majority of recreational golfers do not take lessons. It is another one of those quizzical, only-in-golf mysteries. Most of the putter talk after Keegan Bradley's Aug. 14 victory in the P.G.A. Championship was about how he became the first player to use a belly putter to win a men's major. It was a weekend of carnage at the box office, but not in the way that “Conan the Barbarian” had hoped. That gory remake, financed by Nu Image for about $90 million and distributed by Lionsgate, took in an anemic $10 million in North American theaters. A variety of factors probably contributed, including a lack of interest by women in the subject matter, terrible reviews and a release date when consumers were distracted with vacations or back-to-school preparations. Two other new films also flopped. A $30 million remake of “Fright Night” (DreamWorks Studios) sold $8.3 million in tickets, while the $15 million drama “One Day” (Focus Features) took in $5 million.

A knitwear designer gets discovered. A post from our upcoming Fall Women's issue. ''All of my knits are easy because I am not a very good knitter,'' says Alice Lemoine, 26 (above, right), as she pulls on what to the civilian eye appears to be the product of some very complicated engineering. The tangle of ropy, open stitches and sunbursts of crochet reveals itself, in the wearing, to be a cardigan. And, as Lemoine wraps it around her torso, it maps the contours of her body with the precision of a corset - that is, if a corset could ever be described as cozy. Lemoine, who is based in Paris, studied for a year at Esmod in Japan, where she picked up not just design but also patience. In typical fairy tale fashion, Rick Owens's partner, Michele Lamy, discovered her while she was still a student in Paris and helped her get her first collection into Dover Street Market. Owens then nudged her to commit to knitwear, dangling the opportunity to make pieces for his handmade Palais Royal collection as incentive. For fall, Lemoine has broken out under the label Le Moine Tricote, a play on her name that alludes to her monkish ways, ''working silently on my own.'' The collection includes shrunken jackets, tunic-length vests and charming cachecoeurs in blends of alpaca, mohair and bamboo. But don't expect cashmere anytime soon. ''I don't need luxury materials,'' she insists. ''The luxury is in the design.''

As the markets staged a dramatic show in recent weeks, tourists congregated at the symbolic center of the financial universe, Wall Street, to gaze at and take pictures of its famous landmarks. Leaders of tour groups busily pointed out places where America's wealth had been built and, lately, lost. Other tourists crowded together and looked on as TV reporters provided specifics on the latest market carnage. The vacationers in their shorts, sneakers and floppy hats were often smiling and full of fun -- in sharp contrast to the news-media images of alarm, melancholy and fatigue on the faces of traders inside the exchanges. BENJAMIN NORMAN

In trying to marry the prissiness of the Victorians with the sexual revolution of the 1960s, Tabitha Simmons has come out with an English heritage collection that is a hybrid hoot. ''Like rockabilly shoes,'' the English designer says of her inspirations, ''but - more gothic.'' The 49 styles are indeed evocative of the British Isles, with a smattering of high-heel brogues, evening sandals with chandelier trim and suede boots that look like they stepped out of ''Bedknobs and Broomsticks.'' Compared to previous collections, it is slightly more macabre, yet Simmons, now in her fifth season, continues to demonstrate an ability to imbue classic styles with a modern twist. For example, the Edna heel, a reimagined stiletto loafer, ''is beetle-crusher when it's in black and white,'' she says, ''and then we did a red and leopard version that has an element of Victoriana.'' She's certainly got a bead on the new monarchy. A pair of nude silk slippers looks fit for a duchess or a Park Avenue princess. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
Dance Jack Anderson
Television Kathryn Shattuck

IT might be one of Kuala Lumpur's oldest suburbs, but Bangsar, a well-heeled neighborhood about 20 minutes by car from the city center, is anything but tired. Over the past few years, a mix of Malaysia's best young designers and style-obsessed entrepreneurs have opened up one-of-a-kind boutiques, setting up in stylish malls and along the narrow lanes that surround them. The independent stores, coupled with a clutch of boutique hotels, like the Sekeping Tenggiri and the Terasek Brickhouse, and dining options that include excellent Indian Muslim mamak stalls and hip newcomers like the Press Room, a European-style brasserie, make Bangsar an attractive, quiet, authentically Malaysian respite from the city's buzz. NAOMI LINDT

Like many women nowadays, I shop for my bikinis in the snow and boots in the blistering heat. You could say I've adapted. There is a despairing time lapse between when collections are shown (spring in September and fall in February) and when those pieces are sold. (Fall hits stores as early as July, and spring in February.) And thanks to instantaneous gratification sites like Moda Operandi and Gilt Groupe, avid customers can now begin preordering directly from their favorite designers. ''I start planning the moment they walk down the runway,'' says the designer Margherita Missoni. But some months, like September, linger in a sort of shopping purgatory. The idea of scouring the racks while waiting for sales and holiday items to hit the floor seems outdated. And tired. So while we dally in the off-season, how does one find (and love) things to buy now? ''Seasons no longer matter so much since our life takes place in and between climatic spaces,'' Jil Sander says, referring to her +J collaboration with Uniqlo, which ends this year. ''I compose these collections with the thought of offering both sensible outerwear as well as attractive innerwear. The key is intelligent layering.'' And most would agree that special one-offs like +J, Missoni for Target and Alexa Chung for Madewell (which all become available in September) are meant to fill the a-bit-of-everything void: offering little tank tops to wear beneath hybrids of woolly-cotton dresses or as separates.

SHESTACK--Jerome J. The Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights of the American Jewish Committee deeply mourns the passing of Jerome J. Shestack, its former Chair and distinguished Steering Committee member. Jerry was a remarkable leader - always brimming with ideas, energy, and commitment to find new ways to achieve protection of human rights for all. As a champion of human rights, his devotion to this subject was spurred by the nightmare of the Holocaust and his commitment to world order and to Jewish tradition that instills a passion for human worth and dignity. He was a dear colleague, advisor, and friend, who we shall miss greatly. Our sincerest condolences to Jerry's wife Marciarose, his children Jennifer and Jonathan, and family. E. Robert Goodkind, Chair Felice Gaer, Director

The first piece commissioned for this issue was the T that appears on Page 179. It is by the New York artist Michael Waugh and features, at a glance, three gorgeous, menacing eagles intertwined to form the rather gothic moniker of this magazine. What is less apparent is that every line, every feathery stroke of Waugh's pen and ink drawing, contains words, and specifically the words that were tweeted from Tahrir Square last February, which preceded the fall of Hosni Mubarak and his government. On our Web site, you can scroll across this remarkable work and read an account of a revolution in progress. And see as well Negar Azimi's account of youth culture today in Cairo, which -- along with reports from London and Tokyo -- documents how quickly and quixotically political unrest is registered in street style (Page 133).

If you spend too much time in the August heat of training camp, you may start to experience football-related hallucinations. Bengals fans thought they saw Brett Favre in Cincinnati last week, presumably driving down Sycamore Street in a convertible with Elvis and Janis Joplin. The rumor caught fire on local talk radio, but when reporters asked Marvin Lewis if the Bengals had any interest in Favre, he made what Joe Reedy of Cincinnati.com called a bitter beer face. The Bengals quarterback situation has been the cause of much grimacing in southern Ohio; Andy Dalton's debut (69 yards on 15 passes) caused an outbreak of lemon pucker, and the mere mention of Carson Palmer around Bengals camp has been known to cause anchovy sourpuss.

PHILADELPHIA - When Jim Thome and Ryan Howard come to the plate, they dig their spikes into the left-hander's batter's box, keeping the left foot closer to the plate than the right foot. They extend their right arm, pointing the bat menacingly to some distant spot beyond the center-field wall, like a samurai offering his sword to the pitcher. Thome, who belted his 600th career homer last week, and Howard, who had 279 entering Friday, both learned from a master.

An article last Sunday about album cover art and the challenges that artists face as such space shrinks misstated the size of the typical CD cover. CRAWFORD--William W.,age 83, of Santa Fe, NM, Palm Beach, FL, and Lubbock, TX died on August 14, 2011 of complications related to congestive heart failure. The son of the late Francis Marion and Marie Crawford, he was born on October 7, 1927 in Clearwater, Florida. He grew up in Mobile, Alabama. He married Kay Crawford in Houston, TX on December 19, 1968. He graduated from Marion Military Institute, Georgetown University and Harvard Law School. He served in the United States Army in Korea from 1946 to 1948. Early in his career, he was an associate in the New York law firm of Sullivan and Cromwell, counsel to Esso Standard Oil and a partner in the New York law firm of Alexander & Green. In 1971 he moved to Chicago and became Vice President and General Counsel of International Harvester Co. In 1976 he also became Secretary of that company. In 1980 he became Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Kraft, Inc. In 1981 upon the merger of Dart Industries and Kraft, Inc. he became Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Dart & Kraft, Inc. In 1986 when the two companies split, he became Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Kraft, Inc. He retired in 1989. He was active in the American Bar Association, the Bar Associations of the City of New York and Illinois, the American Law Institute, the American Judicature Society and The Association of General Counsel. He also served on the boards of several companies, including Delchamps, Inc. in Mobile. He was a member of the Chicago Club, the Harvard Club of NYC, and The Everglades Club in Palm Beach. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Kay; children: Bill Crawford, Jr. of Austin, TX, Jonathan Crawford of Philadelphia, PA, Constance Crawford of Riverside, RI, Amelia Crawford of Cambridge, MA, and Patrick Crawford of West Hollywood, CA; brother, Captain Roderick Crawford, USN (Ret.) of Virginia Beach, VA; and grandchildren, Amelia and Joseph Crawford of Austin, TX. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a memorial to the Archbishop's Special Fund of the Catholic Foundation, Archdiocese of Santa Fe, Catholic Center, 4000 St. Joseph's Place N.W., Albuquerque, NM 87120, Attn. Most Reverend Michael J. Sheehan, Archbishop of Santa Fe; the Carmelite Monastery, 49 Mount Carmel Road, Santa Fe, NM 87505; the Christian Brothers, 100 Siringo Road, Santa Fe, NM 87505 or the charity of your choice. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday, August 23, 2011 at 10am at The Cathedral Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi, 131 Cathedral Place, Santa Fe, NM. Arrangements are under the direction of Berardinelli Family Funeral Services, 1399 Luisa Street, Santa Fe, NM 87505 (505-984-8600). Please sign our guestbook for the family at: www.berardinellifuneralhome.com

For the 24th year, the Commonwealth Vintage Dances took place in early August. This year's gathering was on the campus of Roger Williams University in Bristol, R.I. Enthusiasts of period dances, who pay $1,000 for a week of activities, are housed in dormitories. Dance classes are held every morning to prepare for evening balls in the mansions in Newport, Portsmouth and Providence, R.I. Participants relish dressing in the costumes from the 1850s, the Gilded Age and the ragtime years, and often make their own clothes. (More photos on Page 14.)
To the Sports Editor: ''An R.B.I. Leader, but Not an Elite Hitter,'' Aug. 14, struck me as a reflection of how statistics can lead one to lose sight of the forest for the trees.

When Joan Smalls walks down a runway, she sometimes says to herself, ''Get outta my way, I'm coming through!'' And it's a mantra that has served her well. Last year, the 22-year-old model became the first Hispanic woman to represent Estee Lauder in its ads for cosmetics and skin care. Aerin Lauder may have touted Smalls as a ''global beauty,'' but it took a while for anyone to take notice. Smalls, who grew up in the Puerto Rican countryside, had been floating around the fashion industry since 2007, doing small-time runway shows for the likes of Benjamin Cho or Heatherette, or the occasional department-store catalog shoot, and she once appeared in a Ricky Martin video - but her look hadn't really caught on.

INSTEAD of ''Groundhog Day,'' the Bill Murray movie, we now have Fashion's Night Out. It never ends. On Sept. 8, designers will be at their posts, just as they were this time last year, and you can go through the madness all over again. This is truly the age of reiteration. F.N.O. was a good idea when it began, back in the depths of the recession when stores were virtually empty. But now it's a party, an institutionalized kickoff to Fashion Week, and though it apparently raises money for some causes, I have to believe that the costs of security, crowd control and entertainment, not to mention the traffic headaches, outweigh the actual benefits.

Once there was this English showgirl and she used to take the stage right before Archie Rice came on, but now she is old and can barely get up from her rocking chair - but there is a trunkful of her tattered dance shoes up in the attic. And maybe she was your grandma and you just discovered them. Or maybe your granny (great-granny?) was a weathered-but-gorgeous sharecropper, a Dust Bowl refugee in frayed frock and battered boots, only - wait! - what if those boots were splattered with glitter? This welter of odd references, this battered basket of inspirations, is the driving force behind Karen Elson's new line for Nine West, a collection that also contains a bracelet that Elson was somehow able to persuade Nine West honchos to engrave on its underside ''The truth is in the dirt.'' ''Thank God they were game,'' Elson says with a laugh.

GOLDBERG--Peter. As members of the Alliance for Children and Families, we want to acknowledge the loss of our brilliant and forward-thinking leader, Peter Goldberg. Richard Altman of JCCA, Robert Harris of St. Vincent's Services, Paul Levine of JBFCS, Jeremy Kohomban of Children's Village, Nancy Ment of ANDRUS, and James Purcell of COFCCA are deeply saddened by this loss. In his work leading Families International and as President of the Alliance, Peter worked diligently on behalf of vulnerable persons everywhere. His vision and tireless dedication have helped to change the world of human services and have earned him deep respect and honor. He will be missed.
CROSS--Peter. August 14. Artist, unique, creative gentleman, will remain in our hearts forever. Max, Christina, Elaine and Dirty Girl
Pop/Jazz Ben Ratliff

The contrast between the Esperanza Spalding that you see onstage and the offstage Esperanza, jazz bassist and singer, was not immediately apparent at breakfast the day after her big sold-out show at the Montreal International Jazz Festival, the kickoff of her summer tour. Onstage she is luminous, a major chord of exuberance, swinging behind her stand-up bass, eyes closed, singing to the lights, an evangelist of joy in various cool time signatures. At breakfast, meanwhile, she was soft-spoken and contemplative, almost demure. Granted she was rushed, due to fly promptly to Paris, and then on to Prague and Montreux, Switzerland, where old jazz heads and new were already buying tickets to catch her live, performing from ''Chamber Music Society,'' the album that made her the first pure jazz musician to win the Grammy for Best New Artist.

For its fall collection of icicle-drop necklaces and pendants, Kora, the L.A.-based, African-made jewelry line, teamed up with glass makers in the Kenyan village of Kitengela. A mere two years old, Kora has dedicated itself to creating ''trade not aid'' jobs by designing and marketing hand-fashioned pieces made from recycled bone, aluminum, brass, horn and now glass. ''The colors of the glowing green glass are incredible; it's so unlike animal horn,'' says Kora's co-founder Maxandra Short (above, left). Her partner, Amy Walker, adds, ''Glass necklaces still have an organic feel, because every piece is different.'' Indeed the latest offerings, like the necklace at right ($220; go to koradesigns.com), are a softer addition to the line's usually more brawny designs, which in the past have included tribal-inspired manacles and industrial-looking chains. ''I think we're even going to be playing with color in bone,'' Walker says. ''Color is our thing now.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Robert Sullivan A former copy boy for The Times, the widely published author Robert Sullivan started writing about jazz after failing to become a jazz drummer himself. ''Natural selection took care of that dream,'' he says. In this issue, Sullivan profiles the jazz bassist and singer Esperanza Spalding (''Baby's Got Bass,'' Page TK). ''I thought my row was going to storm the stage during Inútil Paisagem,'' he says of Spalding's performance at the Montreal Jazz Festival. Sullivan is now at work on a book about the the American Revolution: ''Philosophically, the United States comes down to Jefferson or Hamilton. One guy played the fiddle every day, one guy didn't. You decide which side you're on.''

RIED--Therese J.,beloved wife of Horace J. Ried, died in her hometown of Stamford Connecticut on August 17, 2011, at the age of 75, with her family around her. She is survived by her children, Carl and his sons Matthew and Alexander, Gillian and her son Christopher, and Lucas and his wife Marnie, and their two children, Jake and Mackenzie. She is survived as well by her step children, Joshua, Amanda and her sons Zachary and Cooper, and by Adam. Additionally, she is survived by her half-sister, Heidi Grondal. Heidi is the wife of Benedikt Grondal, (2010) one-time Prime Minister of Iceland. Therese, known more familiarly as Tessa, was the adored daughter of Ruth Heinitz Jaeger and Dr. Werner Wilhelm Jaeger. Dr. Jaeger, a University Professor of Philosophy and Classics at Harvard University, was the author of many influential works including the renowned, two-volume "Padeia, Ideals of Greek Culture." Born in Berlin, Germany in 1935, Tessa and her parents moved to the United States to escape Nazi persecution in 1938. Tessa was a graduate of The Buckingham School (1952), Radcliffe College (BA 1956) and Yale University (MA 1957). With her masters degree in Linguistics, she was fluent in many languages, including French, German, Italian, Spanish, Ancient Greek and Latin. She was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. She married for the second time in 1978, to the love of her life, Horace John Ried, of Stamford, Connecticut. Ried, Advertising Director for the publication "Plastics Engineering" for 25 years, passed away in 2002. They were a couple truly meant for one another in every way, and their love was an inspiration to all who knew them. Tessa, who spent her later years working as an environmental activist and wildlife rehabilitator, had a long career of public service, including positions as Assistant Director of the Meridian House Foundation (a half-way house for the mentally ill in Stamford, CT) from 1977-1981, Assistant Director of "Gateway Communities, Inc," (a half-way house for alcoholics in Stamford, CT) from 1985-1990, and Director of Publishing at "The Volunteer Center of Fairfield County," from 1990-1999. Tessa's volunteer work began early, when she worked as an EMT for the Stamford Ambulance Corps (1972-1973) Later, She was the organizer of the environmental activist group "Save Our Swans" (1990) and Founder of "The Rippowam River Neighbors Association" (1996) as well as being a licensed wildlife rehabilitator for the State of Connecticut (2000). In addition to her extensive career, Tessa was an avid gardener, photographer, reader, writer and loved animals. A graveside service for family will be held Wednesday, August 24th, at the Union Cemetery in Stamford, CT, where Tessa will be buried next to her true love, Hal Ried. She was an extraordinary person, and is sorely missed.

BUCKLEY--Richard D. 74, passed away on Sunday July 31st at Stony Brook University Hospital, after suffering a brain hemorrhage while at his home in Quogue, NY. Mr. Buckley was Chairman of the company that bears his name. He built Buckley Radio into an industry leader as one of America's last remaining privately owned and operated radio companies. Buckley Radio owns and operates seventeen radio stations across the country, including the flagship station WOR 710AM in New York City. WOR is the legendary New York City station, which features such celebrated broadcasters as John Gambling and Joan Hamburg and also is the voice of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's weekly radio address. Radio Ink Publisher Eric Rhoads said, Rick loved radio and his people so much that he resisted the temptation of being acquired by the bigger corporations because he knew his stations were best served in the hands of someone who put the basics of localism and entertainment first. Joe Bilotta, Chief Operating Officer of Buckley Radio, who has worked for Buckley for forty-two years, said of Rick, There was no more impassioned leader than Rick Buckley. He led the company in a way that reflected the family nature of his business. It has been said that Rick carried himself with a humility and self-effacing wit that endeared him to everyone in the industry. Just one month ago, Rick stood before the New York State Broadcasters' Association to accept membership in their Hall of Fame. Rick's words stood out for his passion about radio and his love of his family and company. A native New Yorker, born and raised in Bronxville, Rick began his career in 1960 as a page at NBC. Buckley Radio was founded in the mid-1950's by his father, Richard D. Buckley, Sr. as an independently owned radio broadcasting company. Following his father's death in 1972, Rick became president of the company. Rick was a past Chairman of the Board of the Radio Advertising Bureau, a Past Chairman of the Board of the Southern California Broadcasters' Association, and at the time of his death was the Treasurer of the Broadcasters' Foundation of America. He was also a past member of the Board of Trustees at his alma mater, the University of Miami, and a member of the President's Council. Rick was instrumental in establishing the Richard D. Buckley audio lab at the University of Miami School of Communications. Rick was an avid fisherman and boater and past Commodore of the Shinnecock Yacht Club. He had a life-long love of the ocean and spending time at the beach in Quogue, NY, where he enjoyed much of the past forty summers. He was a Patriot who took great pride in the nation's Armed Forces. He was a resident of Greenwich, CT, where he also maintained his corporate headquarters. Rick is survived by Connie, his wife of thirty-seven years; their daughter Jennifer Buckley Fox, Vice President and Director of Sales at WOR; son-in-law Chris Fox, who serves as a neurosurgeon and Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy; his sisters Martha Buckley Fahnoe and Dana Buckley Tomkins; brother Brad Buckley; and two loyal dogs, Sam and Sydney. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Broadcasters' Foundation of America (broadcastersfoundation.org); or to the Richard D. Buckley Memorial Fund to support broadcasting at the University of Miami. Please send donations to: Richard D. Buckley Memorial Fund, University of Miami, P.O. Box 248053, Coral Gables, FL 33124 or give online to the fund at www.miami.edu/rbuckley. Funeral arrangements will be private. A memorial service in celebration of Rick's life will be held on Thursday, September 8 at 11am at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Branca, an Asterisk of a Different Kind,'' Aug. 15: I am one of those die-hard Brooklyn Dodgers fans who rue the day they were stolen. I am also Jewish and grew up in Brooklyn in the glory days. Until recently, I owned a cat named Koufax. I must disagree about Ralph Branca's assuming guilt. Jews don't assume guilt; we give guilt. The conversation likely would have gone more along the lines of: ''The most important pitch of your life, you couldn't throw a different pitch? Would it have been so hard?''

An article last Sunday about the documentary ''Boys of Bonneville: Racing on a Ribbon of Salt'' misspelled part of the name of the aircraft engine that powered the Mormon Meteor III, which Ab Jenkins drove in 1950 for two hours at 196 miles per hour. It was a Curtiss Conquerer, not Curtis.

In indie rock, it's not so much who you know as who knows you. And all the right people have come to know First Aid Kit, a Swedish folk duo made up of the sisters Johanna (left) and Klara Soderberg. They were discovered by Karin Dreijer Andersson (one half of the Swedish sibling duo the Knife), who released their first EP. They met Conor Oberst on the Monsters of Folk tour in Sweden; he introduced them to the producer of their next album. When First Aid Kit passed through Nashville on their American tour, Jack White invited them to record for his label. Part of a proud folk tradition - they ''enjoy singing older songs,'' Johanna says - they chose to rework Buffy Sainte-Marie's ''Universal Soldier,'' a protest song from the '60s, whose message ''is unfortunately still very relevant today.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Scandal Rattles A Reformer,'' Aug. 14: I am sure Ohio State's president, E. Gordon Gee, is a decent man. When he decided to immerse himself in the ethical sewer that is big-time college football, however, he became part of the problem, not part of the solution.

BLUMENTHAL--Daniel, of Saddle River on August 17, 2011. Beloved husband of Gloria (nee Feketis). Devoted father of Germaine Link and Desiree Abboud. Cherished father-in-law of John Link. Loving grandfather of Danielle Link, Samantha Link and Ahmed Abboud. Prior to retiring in 1998, he was the owner for over 60 years of the Danby Palicio & Villazon Cigar manufacturer. He was a WWII Veteran of the 8th Army Air Force. Service Monday, 10am at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to The Daniel and Gloria Blumenthal Cancer Center at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, NJ.

Every photograph stops time. This is the most banal, technical fact about the medium and also the source of its uncanny and remarkably durable power. The relentless momentum of mundane existence is stilled by the shutter, and some of the mysteries implicit in everyday life open up. A moment -- of high artifice or raw candor, of posed elegance or composed chaos -- is captured and then, later, delivered to our contemplative gaze. We, the beholders, are always late to the scene, which makes looking at a photograph a species of time travel. We look back, aware, at least unconsciously, that the world has moved on. After a while, so do we, turning the page and returning the image to its natural state as a permanent piece of ephemera. But sometimes we wonder: What happened next?

For the third year running, the end of summer will be celebrated in Red Square in Moscow against the onion-domed backdrop of St. Basil's Cathedral with the Spasskaya Tower Festival, named after one of the Kremlin's main towers. The festival runs from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4 and will feature Russia's Presidential Orchestra and military orchestras from Belgium, France, Great Britain, Greece, Italy, Jordan and Pakistan, as well as equestrian shows, fireworks and performances by Chinese dragon dancers and Italian banner-throwers.

The Mortgages column last Sunday, about borrowing in retirement, described incorrectly the reason given by Erika Safran, a financial planner, for why older borrowers may need to take out larger mortgages. She said they should preserve their cash flow as a cash reserve, not use the money for investments.

WOLFE--Gail. Dedicated wife of the late Harry and great friend. Your unique outlook on life, sense of humor and sardonic wit always made us smile. You will be greatly missed. Julia, Susan and Gerard Heymann

Dirk Schoenberger walks into the lobby of the Bowery Hotel wearing Prada's infamous platform espadrille wingtips - an odd choice considering that Schoenberger is the creative director of the sports style division at Adidas, a company known for its footwear. What he likes about the Pradas, he explains, is ''the mix of sharp tailoring and casual leisure.'' Having held his post for little over a year, he has pushed Adidas to hybridize in a similar manner. ''When I'm in Berlin and I see how the young guys and girls are dressing, none of them are wearing sneakers anymore. So you think, if these are the target consumers, and we are only selling sneakers, well, what are we going to do?'' The answer may be found in Adidas SLVR. Priced somewhere between Originals and Y-3 (also under Schoenberger's purview), the line has been reimagined for fall under his personal design stewardship. ''It's amazing for such a big company to be so open for discussions,'' he says. With SLVR, it is a ''new approach but still very much in the language of Adidas.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
The 36 Hours column on July 31, about Budapest, gave an incorrect Web site for La Prima Hotel, in Pest. The Web address is laprimahotelbudapest.com.

A picture caption on Aug. 14 with a news analysis article, about women imprisoned in Mexico as a consequence of that country's drug wars, misstated the age of one of the women, Karla Solorio, who was convicted of drug and weapons trafficking. As the article correctly noted, she is 26, not 27.

Picture captions last Sunday with an article about the difficulty of midlife career changes misspelled the surname of a former textile design director who opened an antiques and jewelry store. As the article correctly noted, she is Anne McInnis, not McInnes.

Here, kitty, kitty. The biggest trend in fall makeup is the fully lined, feline eye. Sexy kittens stalked plenty of fall runways, but the fiercest felines of all were found at Roberto Cavalli (below left) and Mugler (below right). According to Val Garland, who did the makeup at Mugler, all you need is a great black pencil or fab liquid liner to try this look at home. For soft-focus bedroom eyes, she suggests using Estee Lauder Artist's Eye Pencil in soft black. Smudge gently with a finger for desired depth and use a Q-tip to coax color into the lash line. For a more precise line, try a liquid product like M.A.C. Penultimate or Lancome's Artliner. ''They're fast and to the point,'' she says. ''A thick angular line from start to finish is very vixen.'' Francois Nars, founder and creative director of Nars, gave models a downturned line at Marc Jacobs. ''We were going for a 'Man Ray in 1920s Paris' feel,'' he says. ''It was deliberate but not pristine.'' He used his new Nars Larger Than Life Long-Wear Eyeliner in Via Veneto and built it up, following the shape of the eye. ''The outer corner was blunt and squared off, and I added black shadow to make it feel worn in and a bit broken.''

In the last month, Red Bulls defender Tim Ream has turned out for Major League Soccer's All-Stars against Manchester United and helped lead his team to a surprise victory at the Emirates Cup in London. The obvious reason for the host of that four-team London tournament, Arsenal of the English Premier League, to invite the Red Bulls was that they feature Thierry Henry, the Gunners' career goals leader. But Arsenal has shown more than a passing interest in Ream, 23, a central defender who has established himself in M.L.S. Ream has become an intriguing prospect for the United States national team, and has also caught the attention of scouts for some top European clubs.
TEICHMAN--Libby, on August 18, 2011 at age 97. Wife of the late Louis Teichman, mother of Lois Mirkin and Larry Teichman, grandmother and great-grandmother.
The Trend Fancy pants. Once the province of the Palm Beach doyennes, patterned slacks are now a beguiling, urban-office staple at lines as diverse as Suno, Marni and Celine.

AT Les Arts Décoratifs in Paris, the summer crowds have gravitated to the Hussein Chalayan show and highlights of Ralph Lauren's car collection. But there's another, less-heralded exhibition at the museum that shouldn't be missed. ''Plastique Ludique'' (''Playful Plastic'') presents the designs of Libuse Niklova (1934-1981), whose playthings, particularly in the 1960s and '70s, changed the look of toys in her native country, Czechoslovakia. Her inflatable buffalo, giraffe and elephant, with their simplified graphic silhouettes and bright pop colors, could be used as chairs or pool toys for small children; the three have been reissued in limited numbers and are for sale at the museum's shop. Through Nov. 6. Go to lesartsdecoratifs.fr. PILAR VILADAS

For generations, this children's game has helped settle some profound conflicts. So I've created a few additional hand gestures that might be helpful for our representatives in Washington. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

NEON hair has jumped from the runway to the street, thanks to celebrities like Scarlett Johansson (cherry red), Katy Perry (fuchsia), Rihanna and Dianna Agron from ''Glee,'' who just went hot pink. The flame-haired beauty above is the work of Ric Pipino and his lead colorist, Sean Gallagher. Mr. Pipino calls it dunking. It can be bold, nearly all-over color, color on the ends (Kate Bosworth's has turquoise tips) or color on the sly -- a layer of, say, chartreuse revealed only when the hair is pulled into a pony. Mr. Gallagher says that the more complicated the progression of color, the more difficult it is to create at home. ''This look is pulled directly from the punk era, so we never want it to look too precious,'' he said. He calls what he does ''perfected imperfections.'' Pipino 57, 115 East 57th Street. JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

MASON, Ohio - The Scotsman Andy Murray makes an inviting target for the British tabloids, especially during the Wimbledon fortnight when his every move - from his cheese pizza delivery order to his stepping out to the London theater - is reported. After the News of the World phone-hacking scandal broke, it came to light that potentially thousands of individuals had been targeted by the tabloid, including the movie stars Gwyneth Paltrow, Sienna Miller, Jude Law and Hugh Grant. Does Murray, who defeated Mardy Fish on Saturday in the semifinals of the Western and Southern Open, have any reason to believe he may have been among the hacking victims?

Meet the model students - the hard-working women wearing the best of fall's back-to-school-inspired looks in the photographer Angelo Pennetta's portfolio ''Beautiful Minds.'' Here, they tell T about life on campus, hitting the sales racks versus the stacks, and how to prep for everything from costume parties to pop quizzes. The second of a two-part series. Kinga Rajzak Goldsmiths College, University of London (class of 2011), B.A. (Hons) in Sociology and Politics The 24-year-old Slovakian beauty has worked with the likes of Steven Meisel and Juergen Teller, and most recently walked in couture shows for Chanel and Alaia. She's amazed by how much she enjoys being swept up in fashion but admits she ''never wanted to be boxed into the category of 'the model.' '' It's her studies in sociology and politics, she insists, that have always taken priority. A 2011 graduate of Goldsmiths College, in London, Rajzak still craves intellectual pursuits and hopes to return for graduate school.

It started when my very Parisian friend, staying at my New York apartment, hand-washed her lingerie and neatly hung the coordinating pairs along the shower rod. Bras and panties in tandem styles: frilly florals by Only Hearts, nude sheers from Eres and a hot pink number that could have only been from Agent Provocateur. So French, so chic. I squirmed in my mismatched red cotton briefs and orange satin bra. Why had it never dawned on me to match? ''I only started buying sets when I got married,'' says the author and Vogue contributing editor Plum Sykes, remembering a pistachio and cream lace combo she fell in love with on the Rue des Saints-Peres in Paris. ''Young women today seem to be more aware of the trend for beautiful matching lingerie,'' says Cynthia Gabay, Myla's creative director. ''Your underpinnings say as much about you as a person as your choice in clothing or accessories.'' My early-20-something self now officially desires grown-up glamour - and one trip to Bergdorf's later, taps and teddies are joined at the hip. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

I moved to Brooklyn in July of 2004, just in time to watch my mother die. She was supposed to be getting better; the chemo was working. I'd rented an apartment with Jay, this cute guy I'd started dating. But a week after pulling up in a U-Haul, I found myself cleaning out my childhood home with my siblings. Our parents were both gone now; anything that we couldn't take with us had to fit in a 20-cubic-yard Dumpster. I could barely squeeze the little I saved into the one-bedroom Jay and I shared. Jay (who held me up at the funeral and painted our place all my favorite colors and quickly proved to be much more than just a cute guy) had to shimmy sideways to get between my father's easy chair and my mother's broken desk.

Every fashion-loving gal has that one piece she just can't part with. For Erica Reid, it's a cozy old Joseph turtleneck: ''I've had it for 14 years. It's been with me through my girlfriend, fiancée, wife, pregnancy and mother stages.'' (She's married to the record executive L. A. Reid.) When Erica, a budding author, isn't swaddled in her security sweater, she rocks fierce pieces from Alexander McQueen, Preen, Erdem and Norma Kamali (''so old school'') as well as a vintage collection that would make Kate Moss weep. She opts for high street style from the likes of H&M and Topshop when the mood strikes. ''There's no shame in my game,'' she says. ''I am not a slave to labels.

Brokers have to be quite careful when choosing the language in real estate listings. Some phrases describing homes for sale, like ''great for young people,'' ''excellent for Catholics'' or ''only manly men need apply'' would be considered discriminatory and therefore illegal under fair housing laws.

An opinion essay on Aug. 14 about the Iranian opposition group Mujahedeen Khalq, or Warriors of God, referred imprecisely to the findings of a RAND Corporation study in 2009 about members at the group's operating headquarters, Camp Ashraf, in Iraq. The study found that up to 70 percent of the members -- not at least 70 percent -- might have been held against their will.

An article last Sunday about church leaders' denouncing Alabama's new immigration enforcement law misstated the number of bishops who sued, arguing that the new statute would ''make it a crime to follow God's command to be Good Samaritans.'' It was four, not three.

There's no address - the road has no name . . . it's not even really a road . . . it seems like it's in the middle of nowhere,'' says the French accessories designer Jerome Dreyfuss, explaining how to (possibly never) find the rustic country retreat he shares with his wife, the fashion designer Isabel Marant, and their 8-year-old son, Tal. Surrounded by acacia trees on the banks of the Loing River in Fontainebleau, the tiny clapboard cottage is only 35 miles southeast of central Paris, but it feels worlds away, thanks to its untamed, verdant surroundings and lack of mod cons like electricity, heat and plumbing. (You flush the loo the old-fashioned way - with buckets of water hand-pumped from a spring.) The spartan setting suits the family just fine. ''It's surprising how little you really need,'' Dreyfuss says. ''The expression 'less is more' takes on real meaning here.''

VideoThe best-selling authors James Patterson and Rick Riordan talk about encouraging children, particularly boys, to love reading. Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Holland Cotter on the 1960s Los Angeles art scene and Hunter Drohojowska-Philp's ''Rebels in Paradise''; the novelists James Patterson and Rick Riordan; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host.

An obituary last Sunday about Nancy Wake, a British agent who worked with the French Resistance during World War II, referred incorrectly to two of the honors she received. She was given the George Medal, Britain's second-highest civilian honor, and the Medal of Freedom, the United States' second-highest. Britain and the United States did not award her ''their highest civilian honors.''

Hoping to crib a zeitgeisty brand of urban longing, many an artist has sought out the Missed Connections classifieds on Craigslist. But no one has quite conjured the weirdness, and wistful loveliness, of these digital messages in a bottle like the Brooklyn illustrator Sophie Blackall. First conceived as a blog, her Chinese ink and watercolor series is now collected in ''Missed Connections'' (Workman, $14). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
WEBB--Bim, of Free Union, VA, died Saturday. Treasured husband, father, brother, uncle, sponsor and friend.

Scientists have long sought easier ways to make the costly material known as enriched uranium -- the fuel of nuclear reactors and bombs, now produced only in giant industrial plants. One idea, a half-century old, has been to do it with nothing more substantial than lasers and their rays of concentrated light. This futuristic approach has always proved too expensive and difficult for anything but laboratory experimentation.

In the midst of their tumble from the top of the National League Central, the Pittsburgh Pirates made a significant investment in their future at Monday's deadline to sign drafted players. The Pirates gave $13 million to two Scott Boras clients: $8 million for pitcher Gerrit Cole, the No. 1 overall pick, and $5 million for outfielder Josh Bell, the 61st. Baseball America ranked Bell the best corner outfielder in the draft, but his commitment to the University of Texas scared off other teams. The Pirates took him anyway, reasoning that if Bell did not sign, they would get a similar pick as compensation next year. And if he did sign, they would have the equivalent of two upper-first-round talents.

EDWARDS--Charles Cornell, M.D. Died at home in La Jolla, California, August 7, 2011, after a long illness. Born in Overton, Nebraska September 16, 1923, he grew up during dust storms, locust infestations, and the Great Depression. He began studies at Princeton in 1941, but after Pearl Harbor enrolled in the Navy's V-12 program, and transferred to the University of Colorado, where he earned his BA and MD. He completed an MS in surgery (University of Minnesota) and surgical fellowship at the Mayo Clinic. From 1950-1952, he served with the Marines on the front lines of the Korean War, after which he spent five years in private practice in Des Moines. In 1969 President Nixon appointed him Commissioner/U.S. Food & Drug Administration; and in 1971, he became Assistant Secretary for Health (Department of Health, Education, & Welfare). In 1975, he resigned citing Ford administration cuts to health care that adversely affected the poor and unemployed. He became president/CEO, Scripps Clinic & Research Foundation, La Jolla, in 1977 and oversaw a dramatic expansion into one of the largest employers in San Diego and a leading health care provider in California. He retired in 1993. A generous benefactor and strong proponent of philanthropy and community service, Dr. Edwards is survived by his wife of 66 years, Sue Kruidenier Edwards; children Timothy K. Edwards (Pat), Charles C. Edwards, Jr. (Karin), Nancy Edwards Schned (Eric), and David B. Edwards (Marketa); eight grandchildren; & cousin Cornell Arendt. In lieu of flowers, contributions to San Diego Hospice (www.sdhospice.org) or Voices for Children San Diego (www.speakupnow.org).

Slide over, Holland. The Vermont county that claims Henry Leland, the founder of Cadillac, as a native son now holds the Guinness World Record for the largest parade of Cadillacs. On Wednesday, 298 Cadillacs gathered for a parade at the Orleans County Fair in northern Vermont, according to an e-mail from Jamie Panas, a spokeswoman for Guinness.

The Cleveland Indians were in Boston this month when Jack Hannahan, a reserve infielder, learned that his wife, Jenny, had gone into labor. She had been on bed rest since the 24th week of her pregnancy, and this was Week 28. Hannahan, of course, wanted to fly to Cleveland as soon as he could. But there were no flights home until the next morning, and renting a private plane would cost $35,000. For Hannahan, who is making $500,000, it was simply too expensive.

GOODGOLD--Sally G.,82, died Thursday, August 18, 2011 at Lenox Hill Hospital. The beloved wife of the late Dr. Murray Goodgold, adored mother of Iris and Jay (Karen), cherished grandmother of Michael, Deena and Jonathan and sister of Betty Gottfried. Services will be held at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam, at 12:30pm Sunday, August 21. Shiva will be held following the burial.

Free chocolates on the pillow are nice, but some luxury hotels are upping the ante with fancy cars for guests to use at no charge. Misty Ewing, the director of public relations for Virtuoso, a luxury travel network, said it was ''a huge convenience for guests'' and ''helps in building traveler loyalty.'' The Elysian in Chicago, for example, recently bought five Lexuses, and has drivers ready to drop guests off at destinations within two miles of the hotel.

Adding Italy and Austria to a Trip to Zermatt I'm considering an 8-to-10-day family trip with my wife and two high school boys to ski Zermatt/Cervinia around New Year's and would like to combine it with travel to historical cities or sites in the region, maybe Italy, Austria or Germany. Suggestions? Jeff Leavell, Racine, Wis.

From Herman Melville's ''Bartleby, the Scrivener'' to Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities,'' New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club intends to generate lively online discussion of works -- classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non -- that centrally feature the city. Join The New York Times's new Big City columnist, Ginia Bellafante, on Sept. 6 from 1 to 4 p.m. for a live discussion of the first club selection, Colum McCann's award-winning novel ''Let the Great World Spin,'' which revolves around Philippe Petit's high-wire walk between the twin towers in 1974.
