A five-story, 12,000-square-foot town house on the East Side, which sold for $23 million after more than two years of being on and off the market, was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records. The seller, Derek M. Quinlan, is an Irish real estate investor whose fortunes took a dive when the housing market crashed in 2008. As his debt climbed into the hundreds of millions of dollars, he was forced to sell off many assets, according to British newspaper accounts. A Scottish bank, one of his lenders, repossessed his 102-foot yacht, the newspapers reported.
Messages from The Liberation of Egypt, 2011.

The bubbly flowed, the diamonds too. For one good-time girl in '70s L.A., it seemed as if the party would never end. Adapted from ''Loose Diamonds and Other Things I've Lost (and Found) Along the Way,'' to be published by William Morrow in September. Some names have been changed. I have a theory that single women who buy Champagne by the case rarely end well.

BEATON--John Hudson, Jr.,died August 10, 2011 in Natick, MA. Born in Cambridge, MA on April 11, 1931 to John and Hilda (Hewitt) Beaton. He joined the US Navy after high school graduation and was stationed in Brooklyn, NY. After naval service, he worked first for IBM and then for the City of New York. Since 1970 he owned and lived in one of the historic cottages at Warren Place in Brooklyn, NY. During his retirement years he pursued his love of cooking, classical music, gardening, theatre and travel. He was a volunteer at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and at the City Center. He is survived by his brothers Richard and Edward, his sister Margaret Buchanan and numerous multigenerational nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Thelma Midgette and his brother George. Services are private.

GUIHER--Elizabeth Liddy Hart. Died August 17, at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore with her two daughters in attendance. Beloved wife of James M. Guiher, and mother of Catharine Brownfield Guiher and Mrs. Deborah Guiher (Jeff) Chamblee. Born to Catharine Louise Davis and Edward Hart in Charleston, WV, October 9, 1928, she was raised in Clarksburg, WV and graduated from Wilson College in Chambersburg, PA. She was an amateur singer, harpsichordist, and recorder player, passionately interested in Early Music; and during her long residence in New York, she was on the board of Art of the Early Keyboard (ARTEK) and Music Before 1800. She was for many years a volunteer at the Volunteer Referral Center and the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. A descendant of John Hart, the signer of the Declaration of Independence, she was predeceased by her brother John Bud Hart, sisters Isabelle Wilson and Catharine Canky Brown, and cousins Virginia Ginga Hood Rogers and David Lincoln Hood. Following her brother, who lived in Rome for 40 years, she visited Italy many times with her family and friends in Rome and at a large farmhouse in Umbria. She also vacationed in Nantucket for 47 years at a small rustic home away from home. She is also survived by her two grandchildren, Rebecca Guiher Chamblee and Benjamin Guiher Chamblee. Her sunny disposition and generous spirit enriched us all and will be greatly missed. Burial will be at the Bridgeport Cemetery in Bridgeport, WV. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. Contributions may be made in Liddy's memory to The Art of the Early Keyboard, Inc., 170 West 73rd Street, #

ADLER--Lillian Josefsberg, passed away with her family by her side on August 14, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Lewis Adler and Leonard Josefsberg. Loving sister to Nettie and aunt to Cynthia. She will forever be missed.

VATSKE--Roberta L.,70, died August 8. Memorial service 11am on September 4. Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC. Actress, singer, voice teacher. Survivors: aunt, brother, nieces, nephew, cousins and friends.

In Los Angeles, everyone's a hybrid. Caterer-dancer. Shop girl-singer. Bartender-drama student. Take Justin Kern: model, screenwriter and now fashion designer. Kern and his partner, Stephanie Danan, film producer and fashion designer, have founded Co, a collection of luxurious mega-basics: slip dresses, silk tanks and skirts, L.B.D.'s, skinny leather pants and the kind of big old fancy furs that Margot Tenenbaum would adore. The Royal Tenenbaum, in fact, is the personification of the Co customer - a woman who pictures herself in a variety of cinematic situations. To illuminate this idea, Kern and Danan (far right) collaborated with the actress Elodie Bouchez and the director Thomas Bangalter of Daft Punk on a four-minute film that they describe as a period piece with a sci-fi twist. (The film will have its premiere on T's Web site during Fashion Week.) ''We wanted to give the clothes an identity through the characters that we imagine inhabiting them,'' Danan says. Margot, fictional character-muse, are you listening? This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Ruth Brinker, who founded one of the first social service agencies dedicated to providing meals to AIDS victims too weak or impoverished to feed themselves, died Aug. 8 at her home in San Francisco. She was 89. The cause was complications of vascular dementia, her daughter Lisa said.

Teanaway Valley, Wash. CHECKING the Forest Service Web site before a hike this weekend into the Alpine Lakes Wilderness, I noticed a curious warning: ''Aggressive mountain goats have been reported. Use caution and move away.'' No. Really? But they're so photogenic -- snow-white, sinewy, with gravity-defying dexterity -- and, until recently, so rarely encountered. The fatal goring of a hiker last year by a rogue goat in Olympic National Park has not only changed the way we anthropomorphize these wild animals, but it's prompted $10 million in wrongful-death claims by the victim's family, and new warnings about the perils of nature.

ALL EXCLUSIVE: More of fall's novelty knits from the photographer Paul Maffi, plus Vanessa Traina tells us what's to love about the season's quirky sweaters; the filmmaker Patrick Sher documents Sebastian Kim's maxi coat shoot; and more scenes from the streets of Cairo, London and Tokyo.

ENLISTING her mother to help publicize her first scarf and hat collection, Louisa Parris sent Cherrill Parris-Fox a 1940 cartoon and suggested that her mom think along the lines of something that came out of an old Punch magazine. The results are wonderfully witty pencil drawings of a blowsy dowager draped in Ms. Parris's striped silk. ''I thought of my grandmother's good friend, Aunt Lee,'' Mrs. Parris-Fox said. ''She wore voluminous tops, anchored her chest with strands of pearls and always carried a large silk hankie to dab the occasional facial glistening.'' Go to louisaparris.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

You can learn a lot about a man by the way he disembowels an avocado. Demian Bichir, the Mexican film star, stood in my kitchen at lunchtime testing the pile of avocados on the counter. He wanted to make guacamole the way he used to as a busboy at Rosa Mexicano in the 1980s, during his first sustained lap as an actor in the United States. Instead of a contrived lunch date at a restaurant, digital recorders whirring, he decided to come over to my apartment with a bottle of Patron tequila and his hands ready for cooking.

THE dawn of each new day, predictable as it may seem, holds potential for surprise. Over a month of daybreaks, I sought out various locations that might show New York in a new light as morning revealed itself. As the sun rises, the city begins to awaken -- at first slow and peaceful, like a lone figure walking down the street or a ferry floating by. Often it is not the sunrise itself but its effects that prove most interesting: the glow that turns a rundown street radiant, the fog creating mystery, reflections off buildings and water that transform the commonplace into the poetic.

An article last Sunday about the rise of hostility to Muslim immigrants in the Netherlands misstated the deportation policy advocated by Geert Wilders, an avowed anti-Muslim Dutch politician who leads the country's third-largest party. Mr. Wilders has said that immigrant Muslims and their children should be deported if they break the law, or engage in behavior he has described as ''problematic, '' or they are ''lazy.'' He has not advocated deportation for all immigrants and their children.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Preparing Triathletes for the Chaos of Open Water,'' Aug. 15: Most of us who swim in open water know about how difficult it is to swim in a choppy water race with people right next to you, stroking and kicking in your face.

WEXFORD--Susan Elizabeth, (nee Bott), a Reading Specialist in the New York City School System for twenty-eight years, died on August 10, 2011 at River Terrace in Lancaster, Massachusetts. She was seventy-two and lived in Manhattan. Ms. Wexford, the daughter of Mary Cecelia Elizabeth Murphy and John Joseph Jerome Bott, was born in Kingston, New York in the Mid-Hudson Valley, where her Mother's family had been landholders and real estate developers since the early 1800's. A graduate of Trinity College, Burlington, VT and The College of Saint Rose, she began her career in Education in 1960 as a Kindergarten teacher in Kingston. She later taught in France and Germany with the Department of Defense Overseas Schools. Ms. Wexford retired from the New York City School System in 1995. She was associated for twenty-four years as a Real Estate Broker with the Debra Kameros Company and The Debra Kameros Group/Prudential Douglas Elliman. Ms. Wexford was married in 1967 to Vincent Jonathan Bochis. The marriage ended in 1984. She is survived by her sisters Mary Cecelia Alise of Dracut, Massachusetts and her children Kathryn Sullivan and Caryn Danahy and Jacqueline Scott of Decatur, Georgia and her children, Susannah, John-Thomas and Christopher Scott.

Three of Brooklyn's greenest beauty queens share their favorite all-natural products, like fancy face creams and organic aphrodisiacs. Spirit Demerson ''I've spent a lifetime trying to reconcile my obsession with luxury beauty products with my commitment to a healthy, sustainable lifestyle,'' says Demerson, founder of spiritbeautylounge.com. She has created her own criteria for green-lighting products, including cruelty-free testing and sustainable packaging.

Ian Marber, the well-known London-based nutritionist and author (a k a the Food Doctor), helps his celebrity clientele stay slim and healthy using a revolutionary technique. ''I don't blind people with science,'' he says. ''I simply teach them how to eat.'' Super-Eating Marber debunks diet trends du jour in favor of good old healthy eating, which he says should involve strategic nutrient combining. His fave combos are simple. For example, use fresh garlic in a dressing for romaine lettuce. ''The sulphur in garlic works well with the lettuce's folic acid.'' Or have a cantaloupe and green tea for breakfast. ''Melon offers plenty of vitamin C, which has a synergistic interplay with catechins in the tea.'' His own ideal meal? ''I could eat salmon and fava beans drizzled with a little truffle or walnut oil every single day.'' For convenience-seeking clients, he has a namesake line of healthy cereals, bars, butters and snacks.

Costco, the membership warehouse-club chain, was an early leader in offering electric-vehicle charging to its customers, setting an example followed by other retailers, including Best Buy and Walgreen. By 2006, Costco had installed 90 chargers at 64 stores, mostly in California but also some in Arizona, New York and Georgia. Even after General Motors crushed its EV1 battery cars, the Costco chargers stayed in place. Yet just as plug-in cars like the Nissan Leaf and Chevrolet Volt enter the market, Costco is reversing course and pulling its chargers out of the ground, explaining that customers do not use them.

GAYNES--Alice B.,90, died on August 18, 2011, after a short illness. She is mourned by her children and their spouses, Helen and Donald Goddard, Drs. Phillip and Judy Bukberg, and Anne and Tony Gleeson; her grandchildren, Nat, Lem, Matt, Lexie, Adam, Molly, and Rachel, her seven great-grandchildren, and numerous friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

Haider Ackermann says the words ''far away'' as though they were a whisper in the wind or a rustle in the grass. It's his woman he is talking about, an amalgam of his memories of a childhood in Africa: noble Nigerian robes, a clink of tribal jewelry, the Muslim chador framing the face, women wrapped in swathes of fabric with the body undulating beneath.

A few years ago, the chef Fredrik Andersson closed his popular bistro, Mistral, to search for a new kind of cooking. ''We needed a fresh way to think,'' he says. Andersson and his fellow chefs, Victor Fransson and Peter Goldberg, found it in Enskededalen, a forested borough where hundreds of different herbs were ripe for the picking. With the new incarnation of Mistral came a minimalist aesthetic and a whimsical, free-form approach that emphasizes vegetables, supplied by three local farms. ''When you focus on things that grow, your cooking becomes hyper-seasonal,'' Andersson says. ''It never stands still.'' ABBY AGUIRRE

SAUVAGEOT--Henry E. Henry E. Sauvageot, deeply beloved brother of Diane Sunnen, Charles Sauvageot and Anne-Laure Houghton, uncle to Dari Handjani, Alexandra Houghton and Nicholas Houghton, nephew to Ellen-Mary and Richard Soule, cousin to Roland Soule, Debby Soule Apple and Rod Soule, passed away suddenly at his home in Los Angeles on July 30, 2011. He was preceded in death by his beloved father, Jean Marie Sauvageot, his grandparents, former French Senator Edmond Sauvageot, Anne-Marie Sauvageot, Brig. Gen. Bradford G. Chynoweth (Ret.), Grace Woodruff Chynoweth and his uncle, W. Edward Chynoweth. Born August 11, 1955, Henry grew up in Belgium, Germany and France until he was 12, when his family moved to Berkeley. He attended Bentley School, Lick-Wilmerding High-School, U.C. Berkeley, the MBA program at Golden Gate University and the ITP Program, Tisch School of the Arts at NYU. He was a Creative Director, Information Architect and Interaction Designer who held leadership positions in the Interactive Solutions Design and Entertainment fields, having worked at Agency.com, HBO, Disney, Tryarc, PacifiCare and Oshyn, among other companies on a freelance basis, but his true calling was as a writer. In the course of his life he wrote three novels and five screenplays. Henry left the Bay Area to move to New York where he lived for 17 years before moving to Los Angeles in 2003. Henry was a unique and talented man, striving for perfection in all his endeavors. A writer who loved to read, his interests ranged widely. His reading interests included literature, history, psychology, comics, philosophy, artificial intelligence, film, chaos theory and yoga. Aside from his prolific reading and writing, he was a gifted athlete. He was an ace tennis player, having been a member of The Berkeley Tennis Club in his youth, and a natural and talented golfer. He also mastered swimming, surfing, fencing, archery, horseback riding and jazz dance. He loved nature and all his life had a deep connection to animals and the natural world. Henry's spirit was influenced by the variety of places he had lived throughout his life. One friend described his humor as having "that New York edge." At the same time, his deepest connection was to France where he spent much of his youth. Although single at the time of his death, Henry was married for five years in the 1980s and had several passionate relationships during his lifetime. He was a fundamentally shy and private man who unfortunately did not find the "woman of his dreams" during his time here on earth. Henry always encouraged those around him to reach for their better selves. His kind, sensitive and generous heart, nobility of mind and spirit and his magnanimous nature will be deeply missed by those who knew him best. In Pace Requiescat. A private service will be held by family. Donations can be made in Henry's memory to the U.C. Berkeley, Undergraduate Scholarship Fund, or to the Red Burns Scholarship Fund at NYU, Tisch School of the Arts, ITP Program.

Luang Prabang, Laos, Feb. 11, 2011 While traveling through Southeast Asia on a photographic tour, we stopped in Luang Prabang, one of the most charming cities I have ever seen. I peeked in a window of a monastery, expecting to see attentive pupils, but instead caught this Buddhist technophile, framed in perfect Rembrandt-esque lighting. SUSAN WOOG WAGNER, White Plains

In Mannheim, Germany, car horns and engines are among the noted soloists scheduled to perform a multimodal musical piece on Sept. 10. Called ''Autosymphonic,'' the composition will be performed at the city's Friedrichsplatz outdoor arena to celebrate the 125th anniversary of the combustion-engined, three-wheeled automobile developed by Karl Benz in the German city and patented in 1886.

KRAWITZ--Rhoda, Ph.D.,passed away peacefully surrounded by her devoted family and friends. She is survived by her beloved husband of over 59 years, Herman, her sons Joshua and David and his partner Betsy Kunkel, her grandchildren Noah and Jared, her nephew Daniel Rubenstein and his wife Leah, her "adopted" son Vincent Covello and her brother Ed Nayor. She was an accomplished psychoanalyst and a passionate creative soul who infused her life with music and the arts. Private services. Well-wishers will be received on Sunday, August 21 at the family home from 1-5pm. Memorial donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera.

Washington, Aug. 23, 1861 Just before 11 a.m., Rose O'Neal Greenhow, a dark-haired, dark-eyed Washington widow in her 40s, walked toward her house on 16th Street. Greenhow circulated among the capital's elite social circles, and her home stood within sight of the White House. Despite the sweltering heat, she stopped to talk with a neighbor. A Union guard, she learned, had been placed in front of Greenhow's house earlier that morning.

Work on a landmark office tower on Fifth Avenue will remain halted under a judge's order filed in a lawsuit challenging renovations to the structure, the former Manufacturers Trust Company building, at 510 Fifth Avenue, at 43rd Street. New York City had filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit by preservationists who charged that the owner of the building, Vornado Realty Trust, disregarded restrictions intended to protect the interior. But Justice Lucy A. Billings of State Supreme Court in Manhattan denied that motion last week and converted the temporary restraining order she issued last month into a preliminary injunction. It bans Vornado from doing additional work on the site until she considers the merits of the case.

A group of researchers at Northwestern University is reporting that men who identify themselves as bisexual are indeed sexually aroused by both women and men. The new report is notable, in part, because the same research group had earlier challenged the very existence of male bisexuality, reporting in 2005 that many men who said they were bisexual had arousal patterns more typical of homosexual men.

Having learned a thing or two about thoughtful thread count at Citizens of Humanity, the breakout designer Leila Nasseri put fabric right up there with fit when planning her knits line, Whetherly. "If you want to feel good without trying too hard, that means asking yourself, 'How good does this feel against my skin?,' too," Nasseri says. Using lightweight jerseys and the softest supima cottons, then applying silicone and enzyme washes to enhance the way these fabrics take color, Nasseri lets the achieved fluidity and flexibility inform her tees' shapes and silhouettes. To keep your Whetherly tee feeling every bit as soft as the day you bought it, Nasseri says: "Hand-wash in cold water, air-dry to prevent pilling, and fold, don't hang." Consider it done.

John Locke, the first self-published author to sell one million e-books on Amazon.com, has made a deal with Simon & Schuster for the sales and distribution of his print books. Mr. Locke said he wanted to allow readers "traditional access" to his books, which include the Donovan Creed thrillers and several westerns. I am not at all surprised that LVMH executives are talking to Marc Jacobs about moving from Louis Vuitton to Dior, as Women's Wear Daily reported on Monday. Not to disparage Mr. Jacobs's talents, but where else can they look? With few exceptions, the strategy of Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, has been to load up his brands with big, bankable stars, and there are not many of them available. Shortly after John Galliano was dismissed from Dior, editors put together an imaginary list of candidates: Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, Tom Ford, Nicolas Ghesquiere of Balenciaga, among others. Yet for obvious reasons these individuals might be happy where they are, as would Sarah Burton, the creative director of Alexander McQueen, whose name surfaced soon after the royal wedding in April. According to WWD, she rebuffed overtures from LVMH.

For more information, go to fringenyc.org.There isn't much at the center of "Winner Take All (A Rock Opera)," at the Bleecker Street Theater, but there's a lot surrounding it, all delightful. Basically, Ricky (Jared Zirilli), a singer-musician, argues with his girlfriend, Catie (Anna Ellinsfeld), dies on his motorcycle and goes to heaven. There he is recruited by angels (Jacquelyn Graham, Darren Lorenzo and Kyle Lamar Mitchell) to confront the Devil (Brian Charles Rooney) and his minions (Kat Nejat and Zakiya Young) in a face-off with "the future of music and all creation at stake." Catie is roped in; she can sing too, you see, and someone has to restore Ricky's life.

TRIPOLI, Libya -- Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed on Monday as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule. In the city's central Green Square, the site of many manufactured rallies in support of Colonel Qaddafi, jubilant Libyans tore down posters of him and stomped on them. The rebel leadership announced that the elite presidential guard protecting the Libyan leader had surrendered and that their forces controlled many parts of the city, but not Colonel Qaddafi's leadership compound.

Most of the putter talk after Keegan Bradley's Aug. 14 victory in the P.G.A. Championship was about how he became the first player to use a belly putter to win a men's major. Bradley used an Odyssey White Hot XG Sabertooth that was nearly 47 inches long. I'm a golf traditionalist, but I'm also tired of the debate. Long putters will never be banned at this point and they no doubt help some people keep playing golf. Let's get used to them. While covering the tournament, however, I was struck by how many players were using putters of a similar design to Bradley's Sabertooth. Odyssey and several other makers are churning out models with weighted flanges on either end of the putter head and a certain amount of open space directly behind the putter face. Although different in design, these putters seem like an evolution of the old reliable Two-Ball Odyssey putters - the first putters especially crafted to calm our wandering eyes over short putts.

It was a weekend of carnage at the box office, but not in the way that ''Conan the Barbarian'' had hoped. That gory remake, financed by Nu Image for about $90 million and distributed by Lionsgate, took in an anemic $10 million in North American theaters. A variety of factors probably contributed, including a lack of interest by women in the subject matter, terrible reviews and a release date when consumers were distracted with vacations or back-to-school preparations. Two other new films also flopped. A $30 million remake of ''Fright Night'' (DreamWorks Studios) sold $8.3 million in tickets, while the $15 million drama ''One Day'' (Focus Features) took in $5 million. ''The Help'' (DreamWorks) was No. 1, as strong word of mouth powered that period drama to an impressive $20.5 million in ticket sales for a two-week total of $71.8 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. ''Rise of the Planet of the Apes'' (20th Century Fox) was second, taking in about $16 million for a three-week total of $134 million. ''Spy Kids 4: All the Time in the World'' (the Weinstein Company) was third with a humdrum $12 million in ticket sales. ''Conan,'' starring Jason Momoa (from ''Game of Thrones'' on HBO), was fourth and ''Fright Night'' fifth. ''One Day'' placed ninth.

10 P.M. (13, 49) RFK IN THE LAND OF APARTHEID: A RIPPLE OF HOPE The filmmakers Larry Shore and Tami Gold chronicle the five-day visit of Senator Robert F. Kennedy to South Africa in 1966, during some of the worst years of apartheid. Using archival footage and interviews, this documentary touches on Kennedy's ''Day of Affirmation'' speech of the University of Cape Town; his visit to Stellenbosch University, an intellectual center of Afrikaner nationalism; his meeting with Chief Albert J. Luthuli, the former leader of the African National Congress, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1960; and his journey to Soweto, the country's largest black township, where he gave voice to the chief's call for a free South Africa (above, Kennedy and his wife, Ethel, meeting the populace). 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: JOAN CRAWFORD It's said that Crawford relished the role of movie star, refusing to take out the garbage unless she was fully made up and answering fan letters by hand on her personalized stationery. This 13-film (and one documentary) tribute to the woman born Lucille LeSueur in San Antonio begins with ''Forsaking All Others'' (1934), a farce also starring Clark Gable and Robert Montgomery. ''Mildred Pierce'' (1945), for which Crawford won an Oscar as the determined mother of an ungrateful daughter (Ann Blyth), is shown at 11 p.m.

WASHINGTON - Early in Bill Clinton's presidency, his populist advisers saw their spending plans crash into resistance from Wall Street, which demanded deficit-cutting austerity. ''I used to think if there was reincarnation, I wanted to come back as the president or the pope or a .400 baseball hitter,'' Mr. Clinton's political strategist, James Carville, lamented at the time. ''But now I want to come back as the bond market. You can intimidate everyone.''

For a lot of golfers, the late summer and approaching fall is the best time to play. It's less crowded and the air is crisper. A personal choice of mine is to head for the hills, where the foliage and scenery enhance every round. But if you play where there are elevation changes, you will find yourself with a lot of sidehill and downhill lies off the tee. If you are faced with this situation, the golf magazines and instruction manuals will tell you to aim more to the left when the ball is below your feet (for a right-handed golfer) and to aim more to the right if the ball is above your feet. Dan Spooner, the director of golf at the Leatherstocking Golf Course in Cooperstown, N.Y., has been a P.G.A. pro for more than 30 years. He has spent his career teaching students how to play off the uneven lies so common to golf courses in Central New York.

The battling Gallagher brothers are it again, and this time the feud is heading to court. Liam Gallagher, erstwhile singer of Oasis, is suing his brother and former bandmate, Noel, for saying last month that Liam's hangover forced the band to cancel a concert two years ago. According to The Associated Press, Liam said in a statement he wants an apology and for Oasis fans ''to know the truth'' about what happened - it was not a hangover that kept him from performing at the 2009 V Festival, but laryngitis. Liam also disputed his brother's claim that ''the demise of Oasis followed a massive row in which he claimed I demanded to advertise my clothing range Pretty Green in the Oasis tour program.''

Pixar Animation Studios, battered a bit by critics of late for its embrace of sequels like ''Cars 2,'' announced two new original films over the weekend, although details were spare and both are still untitled. The first one is slated for Christmas 2013 and will tackle dinosaurs - specifically, what would have happened if they had not vanished. Bob Peterson, a two-time Oscar nominee for his screenwriting work on ''Up'' and ''Finding Nemo'' (and the voice of Roz the taskmaster slug in ''Monsters Inc.''), is directing this film. Pete Docter, who directed ''Up,'' will tackle the second project, which is headed toward 2014 and is set inside the human mind. (Hey, a lot of people thought ''Up'' sounded ridiculous, too.) The announcements were made at D23 Expo, a biannual event in Anaheim, Calif., dedicated to all things related to the Walt Disney Company. The three-day gathering, attended by about 40,000 fans, is designed to stir up the company's fan base by unveiling details about new films, television shows, merchandise and theme park attractions. The Pixar news was greeted with rapture, but the reaction was tepid to exclusive footage from ''John Carter,'' an expensive fantasy set for March release about a Civil War veteran mistakenly transported to Mars. That film, which depicts sharply unattractive aliens, represents the live-action directing debut of Andrew Stanton, an Oscar winner for ''Wall-E'' and ''Finding Nemo.''

GEBHARDT--Frances S.,died August 4, 2011 after brief Hospice care for her lung cancer. She was born in Greensboro, NC, on October 27, 1925. Her family moved to New York City in 1935, where Fran lived most of her joyous life. Her last days were spent surrounded by her devoted family. Loved by countless family and friends for her cheerful, optimistic outlook on life, she treasured and took pride in three areas. First came her loved and loving family. Her 67-year marriage to John bore a daughter, Claudia, and a son Jeff. Claudia is the mother of two outstanding girls, Dana and Lynn. Jeff and his wife Gonda add five more beautiful grandchildren: Aiyana, Taimah, Naomi, Maya, and Kaylee. Fran delighted in them, carrying pictures that she would show to anyone at a moment's notice. All looked forward to seeing Grandma Fran at every opportunity. She loved having them visit so that she could show them the sights of Manhattan. Her second source of pride was her 21 years with the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York. She admired this pioneer organization of group medical practice. Dozens of former co-workers remember her as supervisor, mentor, and colleague. They speak of her smile lighting up any room that she entered. After retirement Fran had a second career as a volunteer in the emergency room of St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She comforted distraught patients and their worried relatives as only a calm and empathetic person could. After seventeen years she was honored as "Best Volunteer of the Year." She was deeply saddened by the closing of this vital resource in April of last year. She loved music of all kinds, living it rather than just hearing it. She also seemed almost to become part of the flowers, greenery, and trees that made the wonders of nature so important to her. Her buoyant and loving spirit will live on through her husband, children, grandchildren, and all of those who knew and loved her. Friends may call from 1 to 2pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue, Manhattan, on Sunday, September 18, with a celebration of her life to follow at 2pm.

4:57 p.m. | Updated Getting noticed at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a matter of numbers. Some 2,500 events make up the multi-arts extravaganza, which continues through Aug. 29, and according to a recent article in The Scotsman, 188 of them are American theatrical productions, many of which originated in New York. (That's about the same number of shows, in total, playing at the New York International Fringe Festival, which finishes up this week.) The allure of Edinburgh remains powerful, even though another number - the price tag on bringing a show to Scotland - can be as daunting as the size of the festival itself. Beyond salaries and production costs, there are airline tickets, accommodations and daily expenses - beer, haggis and the like.

AT&T said Thursday that it is getting rid of its lower-tier texting plan that lets people pay $10 a month for 1,000 text messages. Instead, the company plans to offer new subscribers only one plan: unlimited texting for $20 a month. Those who don't want to fork over $20 can choose to pay for each text, starting at 20 cents a message. AT&T said the move was an effort to streamline and simplify its offerings, promising that that existing customers would be able to keep their existing plans, even if they switch to a new phone.

ConvaTec, a company owned by two private equity firms, has made a bid for Kinetic Concepts that is higher than the wound-healing technology company's $4.9 billion deal with another group of investors, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday. ConvaTec, which is owned by Avista Capital Partners and Nordic Capital, has obtained ''highly confident'' financing letters from Goldman Sachs and the Jefferies Group. Such correspondence means that while ConvaTec has not secured formal lending commitments, its investment banks believe that they can arrange the necessary debt financing.

Since the early days in the 1940s, computers have routinely been described as ''brains'' - giant brains or mathematical brains or electronic brains. Scientists and engineers often cringed at the distorting simplification, but the popular label stuck. Wait long enough, it seems, and science catches up with the metaphor. The field of ''cognitive computing'' is making enough progress that the brain analogy is becoming more apt. I.B.M. researchers are announcing on Thursday two working prototype cognitive computer chips.

The overwhelming majority of recreational golfers do not take lessons. It is another one of those quizzical, only-in-golf mysteries. Most of us could use help and the help is widely available, so, naturally, most golfers instead keep their heads down (or not) and plod on, hoping to master the game on their own. According to the National Golf Foundation, roughly 11 percent of all golfers take lessons.

Google, which announced the purchase of Motorola Mobility last week for $12.5 billion, is wading into a crowded mobile device market. Beyond the largest 10 makers in the second quarter, other companies accounted for a full third of market share (35.8 percent). As important for Google (not to mention Apple and Research in Motion), jockeying continues for share of smartphone operating systems. Google's Android led in the second quarter, with 43 percent of the market, followed by Symbian (22 percent), Apple's iOS (18 percent) and RIM (12 percent).

With a title like "American Ninja Warrior," one can't help but raise an intrigued eyebrow, and that curiosity turned into solid ratings for NBC on Monday when the season finale of the obstacle course program reached nearly four million total viewers. Its audience actually grew in the second hour, averaging 4.3 million viewers and winning the 10 p.m. time slot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the highest-rated program in that advertiser-coveted category for NBC in that time slot since the "Macy's Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular."

A month after Egypt's controversial antiquities chief, Zahi Hawass, was ousted in a cabinet reshuffle, Egypt's prime minister, Essam Sharaf, has appointed a successor. Mr. Sharaf had previously indicated that he planned to return the council to its former status.

The Blind Barber in the East Village loves a good surprise. On the surface it operates as a classic barbershop, piles of shorn hair on the floor and all, but it also houses a secret speakeasy in the back room offering banquette seating, live D.J.'s and top-shelf whiskey. Now, not even their canisters of barbicide can be trusted. Teaming up with Joya, the New York company that makes all-natural fragrances for Rodarte and Opening Ceremony, the Bind Barber has crafted a signature soy wax candle that's packaged to look just like the antiseptic used to keep combs and scissors minty fresh. Notes of lavender, smoke and leather echo the scents of an old-fashioned cut and shave. Now that's sharp.

For Vera Farmiga, a Ukrainian-American actress whose reputably selective film career includes "Down to the Bone," "The Departed" and 2009's "Up in the Air," which garnered her an Academy Award nomination, the movies are a family affair. In her directorial debut, "Higher Ground," based on the novel by Carolyn S. Briggs and opening on Aug. 26, Farmiga handles a solid cast of actors, which includes her younger sister Taissa Farmiga and John Hawkes ("American Gangster" and the forthcoming drama "Martha Marcy May Marlene"), as she recounts the story of a woman named Corinne Walker - a mother and wife and child of God - who struggles with doubt and disbelief as she searches for her identity, her "instrument." "I wanted to make sure that what pervaded the film was the character of music and its capacity to unite people," says Farmiga of her hymn-heavy picture, produced by Farmiga and her rocker husband, Renn Hawkey, of the band Deadsy. Just days before the film's opening, Farmiga spoke to The Moment about family, how she came upon "Higher Ground" and what separates the girls from the women.

They've played some of the toughest characters that New York and Baltimore had to offer, and now Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris are headed into a famously rugged depiction of New Orleans in a 2012 Broadway production of "A Streetcar Named Desire," its producers said on Tuesday. Ms. Rubin-Vega, who originated the role of Mimi in the New York Theater Workshop and Broadway incarnations of "Rent," will play Stella, the timid wife of Stanley and sister of Blanche DuBois. Mr. Harris, who played the drug kingpin Avon Barksdale on the HBO drama "The Wire," will play Mitch, Stanley's muscle-building pal who develops an attraction to Blanche. Blair Underwood and Nicole Ari Parker were previously announced to play Stanley and Blanche in this latest "Streetcar" revival, the first time that the Tennessee Williams play has been presented on Broadway since 2005. It will be directed by Emily Mann, the artistic director of the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., and presented in the spring at a theater to be determined. It is produced by Stephen Byrd and Alia M. Jones of Front Row Productions, who produced the 2008 Broadway revival of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" that featured an African-American cast.

Over time, I've come to the realization that I can't win each and every league I'm a part of, so by this point in the year, I'm focusing on 2012 in several cases. A couple of my leagues have a rule that unless a minor league prospect is drafted and held on a roster, he cannot be picked up on the waiver wire until he's promoted to the big leagues. In many keeper leagues, there is a provision for allowing a certain number of minor leaguers to be drafted. Therefore, top prospects like Mike Trout, Julio Teheran and Eric Hosmer didn't come up on waivers because they were already on rosters in such leagues.

Work on a landmark office tower on Fifth Avenue will remain halted under a judge's order filed in a lawsuit challenging renovations to the structure, the former Manufacturers Trust Company building, at 510 Fifth Avenue, at 43rd Street. New York City had filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit by preservationists who charged that the owner of the building, Vornado Realty Trust, disregarded restrictions designed to protect the interior. But Justice Lucy A. Billings of State Supreme Court in Manhattan denied that motion last week and converted the temporary restraining order she issued last month into a preliminary injunction. It bars Vornado from doing additional work on the site until she considers the merits of the case. Preservationists consider the building - a former bank designed by Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill - a model of Modernism. The building's transparent interior was designated a landmark in February. But two months later the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission allowed Vornado to change some of the elements in reconfiguring the space for a clothing store, Joe Fresh.

1 P.M. (HBO2) SUNSHINE STATE (2002) Real estate developers wreak havoc on a Florida beachfront resort in this multigenerational civics lesson from John Sayles, organized around the histories of two families, one white (the Temples), the other black (the Stokeses). Marly Temple (Edie Falco, above with Marc Blucas), a sardonic young woman who runs a strategically placed family motel, is the closest thing to a central character. Jane Alexander plays her grandly histrionic mother, and Ralph Waite is her partly blind curmudgeon of a father. Eunice Stokes (Mary Alice) is the revered pillar of Lincoln Beach, a black-owned, middle-class enclave that the developers are planning to obliterate. When her daughter (Angela Bassett) shows up with her husband (James McDaniel) after being exiled in disgrace 25 years earlier, old wounds bleed. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that Mr. Salyes had created ''a cinematic mosaic of American lives unprecedented in its range, balance, subtlety and evenhandedness.'' By the end, he added, ''you feel you've not only touched the soul of each one but also tasted some salty essence of our national life. A crucial ingredient of that essence, the movie suggests, is a nagging, unappeasable restlessness that may be the emotional engine driving American capitalism.'' 8:15 A.M. (MoreMax) ADAPTATION (2002) The director Spike Jonze and the writer Charlie Kaufman (along with his fictional twin, Donald, who is also credited with writing the screenplay) journey into metafiction in this movie about the two Kaufmans (Nicolas Cage, in both roles) and Susan Orlean (Meryl Streep), a writer for The New Yorker whose book ''The Orchid Thief'' inspired the film. Chris Cooper, above, won an Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as an orchid obsessive; Ms. Streep and Mr. Cage also received Oscar nominations.

KUALA LUMPUR -- The Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim began his defense in his sodomy trial on Monday, declaring the charges ''a vile and despicable attempt at character assassination.'' After Mr. Anwar delivered a 32-page statement in which he said the trial was a conspiracy by Prime Minister Najib Razak to send him into ''political oblivion,'' Mr. Anwar's lawyers disclosed that they had issued subpoenas compelling Mr. Najib and his wife, Rosmah Mansor, to appear in court as witnesses.

WOLINTZ--Arthur, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Arthur Wolintz. Dr. Wolintz was a world renowned neuro-ophthalmologist. For merger advisers this year, it has been good to be an independent. Two big deals last week - Google's $12.5 billion takeover bid for Motorola Mobility and Hewlett-Packard's $11.7 billion purchase of Autonomy - underscored the growing influence of boutique investment banks. Among the firms that helped propel the two transactions were Qatalyst Partners, Centerview Partners and Perella Weinberg Partners, as well as the biggest independent investment bank, Lazard.

Lionel Mendoza, 54, a truck driver from the Bronx, flaunted his bodybuilder's physique on Saturday and said, ''You could say this body was literally built by the streets of New York City.'' Mr. Mendoza does not lift weights. He prefers to work out on city sidewalks doing pull-ups, dips and other calisthenics on any handy piece of street apparatus. The horizontal bars that support the ''Walk/Don't Walk'' signs will do. Or better yet, the broad overhead pipes of a scaffold over a stretch of sidewalk.

Parents who have a child with autism have about a 1 in 5 chance of having a second child with autism, a far greater risk than previously believed, new research shows. The findings, published in the journal Pediatrics, are significant because they come from the largest study to date focusing on the risks of autism among siblings.

There was no immediate warning about whether audience members in the first five rows might be spattered with stray bits of clay, but on Monday the producers of the musical version of ''Ghost,'' the supernatural romance that showed us how the living and the dead could collaborate around a pottery wheel, said it will come to Broadway in the spring. ''Ghost the Musical,'' with a book adapted by Bruce Joel Rubin from his screenplay for the 1990 film that starred Demi Moore, Patrick Swayze and Whoopi Goldberg, and a score by Dave Stewart and Glen Ballard, will open in April at a Nederlander Theater to be determined, press representatives for the production said. The Broadway production will be directed by Matthew Warchus, a Tony Award winner for ''God of Carnage,'' who is also director of the current West End production of ''Ghost the Musical'' at the Piccadilly Theater in London. That production stars Richard Fleeshman and Caissie Levy as the couple whose love transcends the mortal plane and Sharon D. Clarke as the psychic who helps reunite them, though no Broadway casting was immediately announced.

He was a major force in regulation of recycled wastewater, staunch defender of public health in relation to public water supply, renowned for his integrity and plain speaking defense of technical positions. WOLINTZ--Arthur Harry Dr. FACS, FACP. A man of exceptional character, integrity, intelligence, affection, and caring, passed away on August 22, 2011, in the presence of his devoted wife and adoring daughters. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated Summa Cum Laude from SUNY, Downstate Medical Center in 1962, and was inducted into the Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society. Often called the Father of Neuro-Ophthalmology in New York; Board certified in both Neurology and Ophthalmology; author of "Essentials of Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology," over 55 peer reviewed articles, and several book chapters; on the staff of nearly every hospital in Brooklyn and trained hundreds of future physicians. Distinguished Teaching Professor at SUNY Downstate; Director of Neuro-Ophthalmology Fellowship Program and Subspecialty Service; director, Department of Ophthalmology and Neuro-Ophthalmology, Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center; councilor for Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society; Honorary Surgeon for Neuro-Ophthalmology to the NYC Police Department. Member of the Flatbush Jewish Center for over seven decades, and President of FJC for 10 years. Survived by his wife of 47 years, Carol Sue (nee Bergstein), children Dr. Robyn J. Wolintz Weintraub and Paul Weintraub, Rabbi Ellen S. Wolintz-Fields and Jonathan Fields, grandchildren Felicia, Erica and Emily Weintraub, Cameron, Coby and Samuel Fields, siblings Libby and Philip Krackow, Florence and David Stachel and numerous nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday, August 24, 2011 at 1pm, Flatbush Jewish Center, East 5th Street and Church Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers or food, donations may be made to Autism Speaks; Flatbush Jewish Center; or a charity of your choice.

The father of Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer who died last month, said he has had to return donations to people who supported his plan to set up a foundation in his daughter's name because someone else had claimed ''The Amy Winehouse Foundation'' as an Internet domain name, The Guardian reported Monday. Mitch Winehouse said he was putting the nascent charity on hold until a legal dispute over the domain name is cleared up. ''Somebody else pinched it off of us before we could get it registered,'' Mr. Winehouse said, according to the BBC. ''All these donations which are coming in -- we don't know what to do with them at the moment.''

LIKA--Arthur, passed away at home, in New York City, with his family by his side on August 21, 2011. Born in Permet, Albania, October 25, 1925, he came to the United States with his parents in 1937. He was the son of the late Kosta and Victoria Lika. Art entered the U.S. Army in 1943 at Ft. Devons, MA. He served with the 409th Infantry Regiment and Third Army in the European Theater of Operations. He fought in the Battle of the Bulge as a rifleman. Art then became a combat photographer and artist-war correspondent for General George S. Patton and the Third Army Press Camp. He was awarded both the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart. After the war, Art attended Shrivenham University in England and then continued studies at Columbia University in New York. He left Columbia when he was offered the Art Director position at Mack Trucks. There he created the Mack Truck bulldog icon. In 1955, Art started his own design and advertising business called Lika Associates. His accounts included Gillette Company, General Electric, Japan Air Lines, Avco and American Express, for which he designed the original corporate logo and credit card. Art will always be remembered for his complete devotion to family. He is survived by his loving wife, Hope; son, A.J.; daughter, Victoria and his sister, Mary Lika Nastu and her husband Michael Nastu. Arthur Lika will be laid to rest on Tuesday, August 23rd from 5-8pm at Larson Funeral Home, 2496 North Avenue, Bridgeport, CT. The funeral mass will be held on Wednesday morning, August 24 at 10:30am at St. George Albanian Orthodox Church, 5490 Main Street, Trumbull, CT 06611. Interment immediately following at Mountain Grove Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New York City at the Society of Illustrators Club. Donations can be made in his name to: The Glaucoma Foundation, www.glaucomafoundation.org.

NEW YORK An article on Monday about the selection of robin's egg blue -- some say it's teal -- as the color to represent the Second Avenue subway line misspelled the surname of the executive director of the Pantone Color Institute, which surveys fashion designers to determine the color of the year. (It happens to be teal.) The executive director is Leatrice Eiseman, not Iseman.

Women who are overweight or obese when they become pregnant may be more likely to have children who develop asthma as teenagers, new research shows. The findings could point to yet another consequence of the rising rates of obesity worldwide. Scientists have already documented a number of complications that are more likely to arise in women who are obese before they become pregnant, among them a greater risk of stillbirths, preterm deliveries and gestational hypertension.

WEEKEND A movie review on Friday about ''One Day,'' from the Danish director Lone Scherfig, misidentified the language spoken in ''Italian for Beginners,'' one of her earlier films. It was Danish, not English.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about the federal government's increasing use of ''cloud computing'' services misstated the cause of a service disruption to Amazon's cloud service in April. The cause was technical trouble, not a security breach.

John Locke, the first self-published author to sell one million e-books on Amazon.com, has made a deal with Simon & Schuster for the sales and distribution of his print books. Mr. Locke said he wanted to allow readers ''traditional access'' to his books, which include the Donovan Creed thrillers and several westerns. Simon & Schuster, which called it ''a win-win for all concerned,'' said it would begin to print and distribute Mr. Locke's books in February, making them available in bookstores and through online retailers. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

When the U.C.L.A. School of Law announced a $10 million gift from Lowell Milken to establish a business law institute in his name earlier this month, the university described him as a ''pioneer in education reform'' and a ''leading philanthropist.'' Behind the scenes, Mr. Milken's big donation has set off an internal debate at the school. While many faculty members welcomed the money, one of the University of California, Los Angeles's top business law professors has said the gift poses deep ethical problems and reputational risks, given Mr. Milken's run-in with securities regulators two decades ago.

McDADE--Herbert Hardinge Jr.,died peacefully at his Florida home August 17th after a short illness. He was 84. Born April 6, 1927, in Brooklyn, NY, he was the oldest son of Mabel and Herbert McDade. He graduated from Brooklyn Prep, The University of Notre Dame, where he received a BS in Biology, and Laval University, in Quebec, Canada, where he received a BPH in Philosophy. Mr. McDade spent 62 years working in the pharmaceutical industry. After graduation in 1950, he took a job in sales at The Upjohn Company. He worked at Upjohn for 20 years, rising to Director of Laboratory Procedures. He left in 1970 to co-found and become Publisher of Family Health Magazine, a pioneering publication focused on health and wellness. In 1973, he joined the Revlon Corporation, where he was President of Revlon Healthcare and Revlon Healthcare International. In 1986, he became Chairman, CEO and President of Armour Pharmaceuticals. In 1989, he formed his own consulting firm, The Thoma Corp, advising dozens of companies on all matters related to pharma, with a specific focus on licensing deals outside the U.S. He sat on numerous boards of biotech and pharmaceutical companies, and chaired the boards of Discovery Labs, Chemex Corporation, Access Pharmaceuticals, and CytRx Corp. Outside of work, his focus was his faith and his family, but he always found some room for Notre Dame football and golf. He was a member of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem of the Catholic Church. He also served as a Eucharistic Minister. He was a founding board member of St. Thomas Aquinas College in Santa Paula, California, now a highly acclaimed liberal arts college. Mr. McDade is survived by his high school sweetheart and wife of almost 60 years Anne F. McDade; his brother Brian of Cataumet, MA, four children, and eight grandchildren. A mass of Christian burial was held at Church of the Resurrection, followed by interment at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations in Mr. McDade's name may be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City.

WOLINTZ--Arthur, M.D. SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the passing of Arthur Wolintz, M.D., distinguished teaching professor of ophthalmology. For many years, Dr. Wolintz served with distinction as chair of ophthalmology, a department he established. He was instrumental in helping to develop neuro-ophthalmology as a subspecialty. He will be especially remembered for his deep commitment to students and to the Downstate College of Medicine Alumni Association. A 1962 summa cum laude graduate from Downstate, he had a distinguished career of scholarship and was the recipient of many honors. He was awarded the rank of SUNY distinguished teaching professor in 1995, the highest SUNY honor for an academician. A funeral service will be held at 1:00pm on Wednesday, August 24, at the Flatbush Jewish Center, 327 East 5th Street, Brooklyn. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Wolintz's wife, Carol, his daughters Robyn and Ellen, and other family members and friends. John C. LaRosa, MD President Ian L. Taylor, MD, PhD Dean of the College of Medicine Douglas R. Lazzaro, MD Chair of Ophthalmology

Smokers have much higher odds of developing bladder cancer than previously believed, and the changing makeup of cigarettes may be a factor, new research shows. While cigarettes are more typically associated with lung cancer, researchers have known for years that smoking also raises the risk of bladder cancer among both men and women. Previous studies based on people who smoked prior to the 1990s had put the risk for smokers at about three times the risk seen among nonsmokers.

If Larry Fink were a wildlife photographer, he would have been mauled long ago. Fink works close - too close, no doubt, for the comfort of some of his very famous subjects, who appear alternately drunk, dazed and even a little bit scary in some of his pictures. As the official photographer for Vanity Fair's Oscar shindig for roughly a decade, Fink has made Hollywood parties look as fatiguing as they are fabulous, and his aweless impressions are now collected in "The Vanities" (Schirmer/Mosel, $68). Here is Hugh Hefner, shot from the neck down, at a table with two amply bosomed bunnies. We see even less of Kate Moss (just the back of her legs in a crowd). Ethan Hawke slumps in front of Julie Delpy, who seems annoyed. "These photographs are glimpses of interactive citizens who happen to be idolized and coveted the world around," Fink says. "But for me, they're just folks."

Another changing of the guard is taking place at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Sylvia Waters, the longtime artistic director of Ailey II, will retire on June 30, 2012, the company plans to announce on Thursday. She went on to guide and train young dancers for nearly four decades, including Robert Battle, the company's new artistic director. Ms. Waters has named Troy Powell, a teacher, choreographer and former dancer, as her successor. Mr. Powell has served as the associate artistic director for Ailey II since 2003.

Taavo Somer, the charismatic restaurateur behind Freemans and Peels, will open his third restaurant, Isa, on the south side of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, next month. Having spent the last two years building the space and embracing naïveté and improvisation - letting the design of the tables "go where the wood wants to go," for example - Somer has coined the term "primitive modernism" to describe the restaurant's generally rustic look. "It speaks to that part of us that longs for something real, organic, dirty and alive," he says, "that wants to pick up some rocks, logs, meat and cook over a fire." The menu, by the chef Ignacio Mattos, formerly of Il Buco, goes to wonderfully unexpected places and features succulent, fall-off-the-bone pig's tail, a bright consommé made with herbs from the restaurant's roof garden and a cashew-dressed vegan salad that tastes curiously like a classic Caesar. Is that a rebellion against the comfort food that's dominated New York tables? "This is the most fun I've had in nine years," Somer says. "We're trying things and making things. We just want to lose the fear, throw a little caution to the wind, dance badly and have a blast."

For months, almost every development out of Libya seemed to confirm my initial pessimism about our quasi-war against Muammar Qaddafi. But happily that's changed in the last week, with the sudden collapse of his regime and the apparent victory of the rebels. As in post-Saddam Iraq and post-Taliban Afghanistan, many of the scenarios for what comes next in Libya could ultimately pose as many risks to American interests as Qaddafi himself ever did, and I agree with all the voices pointing out that the tyrant's fall doesn't necessarily vindicate our intervention, to say nothing of the dubiously legal means by which America was taken to war in North Africa. But I also think it's important for critics of the war to acknowledge the significance of the last few days' events. While few intervention skeptics "maintained that we could not possibly defeat the regime" (as Ramesh Ponnuru puts it), many of us worried that the administration's (understandably) risk-averse approach to the conflict might create a permanent stalemate, leaving an armed-and-dangerous Qaddafi in power in Tripoli while Western warplanes circled impotently overhead. Qaddafi's defeat doesn't necessarily promise a happy outcome in the long run, but at the very least it guarantees that we will be spared that particular worst-case scenario, while holding out the possibility of a Libya unified and at peace - rather than a Libya partitioned and perpetually patrolled by Western forces, which is where we seemed to be headed a month ago. Declarations of victory are ridiculously premature, but for a country and a White House starved for any sort of good news, the fall of Qaddafi should be cause for (suitably restrained) celebration.

"Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit" is probably the most popular sentence in the world that is not meant to be read. "Lorem Ipsum" (shorthand for the entire, seemingly endless body of Latin text) is the green screen of the publishing world - placeholder copy used by designers to replicate how a block of text will look and how many words it will fit before swapping in the fully written article. This apparent gibberish, however, has been used for this purpose since the 1500s, and its foundation goes back even further. According to lipsum.com:

Eight years ago, we made a mistake that we've only recently stopped paying for. As mistakes go, this one was hardly disastrous, and in some ways it even helped me clarify my understanding of why mistakes happen and what we can do to avoid them. I have found that most mistakes fall into one of three categories: planning, procedures, or performance. It's important to understand what kind of mistake has been made before you try to deal with it.

The White House introduced plans on Tuesday to loosen the regulatory burden for American companies, announcing cuts in regulations that administration officials said would save more than $10 billion over five years. Administration officials said the regulatory changes, including the streamlining of tax forms, some visa applications and other bureaucratic red tape, would help promote job growth in the private sector. The move had been anticipated as part of President Obama's efforts to curry favor with the business community by eliminating unnecessary or outdated rules.

ONGERTH--Henry J. He was a major force in regulation of recycled wastewater, staunch defender of public health in relation to public water supply, renowned for his integrity and plain speaking defense of technical positions. A 1935 graduate of UC Berkeley with a 1950 University of Michigan MPH he was an internationally recognized Sanitary Engineer, the California State Sanitary Engineer, Chair of the Conference of State Sanitary Engineers, Member of the USEPA National Drinking Water Advisory Committee, and elected to the National Academy of Engineering. Dead at 98, preceded by Mary his wife of 70 years, he leaves three sons, seven grandchildren, and one great grandchild in fond remembrance.

FoodCorps, which started last week, is symbolic of just what we need: a national service program that aims to improve nutrition education for children, develop school gardening projects and change what's being served on school lunch trays. I've been looking forward to this for months, because it's such an up: 50 new foot soldiers in the war against ignorance in food. The service members, most of them in their 20s, just went to work at 41 sites in 10 states, from Maine to Oregon and Michigan to Mississippi. (FoodCorps concentrates on communities with high rates of childhood obesity or limited access to healthy food, though these days every state has communities like that.)

Pataki of New York, who has considered running for president in the past, is again mulling a bid for the Republican nomination and is planning a high-profile appearance in Iowa this weekend. Organizers said they expected that he would clarify his intentions at the event.

GRUSS--Stanley M.,79, peacefully, on August 21st. A man of great dignity, faith and affection, beloved husband of his late Bernice, devoted father, brother, uncle and grandfather, he will be greatly missed by his two adoring daughters, sons-in-law and six grandchildren. Loving brother to his late sister, Frances, and to his brothers and sisters in law, all of whom survive him. He was a leading member of the Fort Tryon Jewish Center for over 50 years, including years of service as congregation president. The love and selfless care provided by our dearest friend Anne Lawrence has been a blessing to him and to everyone who loved him. Services at Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday, August 23rd at 11:30am.

Previously the family owned just under 7 percent of the Class A shares.

They've played some of the toughest characters that New York and Baltimore had to offer, and now Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris are headed into a famously rugged depiction of New Orleans in a 2012 Broadway production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' its producers said on Tuesday. Ms. Rubin-Vega, who originated the role of Mimi in the New York Theater Workshop and Broadway incarnations of ''Rent,'' will play Stella, the timid wife of Stanley and sister of Blanche DuBois. Mr. Harris, who played the drug kingpin Avon Barksdale on the HBO drama ''The Wire,'' will play Mitch, Stanley's muscle-building pal who develops an attraction to Blanche. Blair Underwood and Nicole Ari Parker were previously announced to play Stanley and Blanche in this latest ''Streetcar'' revival, the first time that the Tennessee Williams play has been presented on Broadway since 2005. It will be directed by Emily Mann, the artistic director of the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., and presented in the spring at a theater to be determined. It is produced by Stephen Byrd and Alia M. Jones of Front Row Productions, who produced the 2008 Broadway revival of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' that featured an African-American cast. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

6:30 P.M. (FX) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON (2008) Brad Pitt received an Academy Award nomination for his portrayal of Benjamin Button, a man born in his 80s in 1918 New Orleans who ages in reverse into the 21st century in this adaptation of a whimsical short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cate Blanchett (above with Mr. Pitt) is Daisy, the dancer who loves Benjamin at whatever stage he is in his life. And Taraji P. Henson, who also received an Oscar nod, is the nursing home caretaker who raises him when his father abandons him. From Fitzgerald's ''odd, somewhat unpromising kernel, the director David Fincher and the screenwriter Eric Roth have cultivated a lush, romantic hothouse bloom, a film that shares only a title and a basic premise with its literary source,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film ''sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist's condition in a spirit that owes more to Jorge Luis Borges than to Fitzgerald.'' Above all, Mr. Scott said, the movie ''is a triumph of technique,'' with Mr. Fincher adding ''a dimension of delicacy and grace to digital filmmaking. While it stands on the shoulders of breakthroughs like 'Minority Report,' 'The Lord of the Rings' and 'Forrest Gump' (for which Mr. Roth wrote the screenplay), 'Benjamin Button' may be the most dazzling such hybrid yet.'' The film won Oscars for art direction, makeup and visual effects. 8 A.M. (IFC) PAN'S LABYRINTH (2006) Guillermo del Toro directed this fable, set in a dark forest in Spain in 1944, about a young girl whose fantasies are trampled by her stepfather's fascist politics. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, received Academy Awards for cinematography, art direction and makeup. Ivana Baquero plays the heroine, Ofelia, who longs to believe in fairies, princesses and magic lands; Doug Jones (above with Ms. Baquero) is the woodland creature (a couple of them, actually) who charges her with three tasks. ''Fairy tales (and scary movies) are designed to console as well as terrify,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''What distinguishes 'Pan's Labyrinth,' what makes it art, is that it balances its own magical thinking with the knowledge that not everyone lives happily ever after.''

A month after Egypt's controversial antiquities chief, Zahi Hawass, was ousted in a cabinet reshuffle, Egypt's prime minister, Essam Sharaf, has appointed a successor. Mohamed Abdel Fattah, the head of the antiquities sector at the Supreme Council of Antiquities, will become the council's secretary general, the position Mr. Hawass held before former President Hosni Mubarak elevated the council to a ministry. Mr. Sharaf had previously indicated that he planned to return the council to its former status. Mr. Abdel Fattah's positions are not well-known, and reaction to his appointment, which was first reported last week in the Egyptian press, has so far been muted. He was quoted by the Egyptian newspaper Al Masry Al Youm as pledging to resolve disagreements among the council's leadership and root out corruption. He said he would complete several unfinished construction projects, while cautioning that others would have to be postponed because of a lack of money. Much of the council's budget comes from ticket sales to museums and archeological sites, and tourism to Egypt has been decimated by the revolution.

King -- not by the Drifters, for whom he had been the lead singer. (Mr. King recorded both songs shortly after leaving the group.)

Bill Moyers says he is returning to public television in January, but he won't be found on the PBS lineup. His new hourlong weekly show, ''Moyers & Company,'' will focus on one-on-one interviews with people not often heard on television, ''thinkers who can help us understand the chaos of this time,'' Mr. Moyers said by telephone. ''We're going to be concerned with the state of democracy and the state of affairs,' he said, ''but we will leave the daily and weekly story to others and try to do the back story.'' The program will be based at WNET in New York City and distributed free to public television stations by American Public Television, an alternative distributor to PBS. In a letter to public television executives he said that WNET was considering showing the program at 6 p.m. on Sundays. Mr. Moyers, 77, retired from PBS in April 2010.

He always felt his was the best possible life he could live. He made us feel the same way. We will miss him.

GENEVA -- A slim figure in a dark suit, Brahumdagh Bugti, 30, could pass for a banker in the streets of this sedate Swiss city. But in truth he is a resistance leader in exile, a player in an increasingly ugly independence war within Pakistan. He has been on the run since 2006, when he narrowly escaped a Pakistani Army operation that killed his grandfather and dozens of his tribesmen in the southwestern province of Baluchistan. And since then, the government's attempt to stamp out an uprising by the Baluch ethnic minority has only intensified, according to human rights organizations and Pakistani politicians.

McCABE--Catherine. Catherine McCabe (nee Henry), wife, mother, professor, counselor, friend and a long time resident of New Rochelle, NY died peacefully on Tuesday August 23 at age 85. A woman of great dignity, faith and affection, Cay was born on January 7, 1926 to John and Theresa Henry in the Bronx. She was raised in New Rochelle and was a 1947 graduate of the College of New Rochelle. Cay married Hugh McCabe in 1949 and with him raised seven children. While the older children where in school and the youngest were in pre-school, Cay earned two masters degrees, one in Theology at Manhattan College and one in Pastoral Counseling at Iona College. She had also begun her career as a professor of Religious Studies at Iona that would span more than 30 years and touch the lives of generations of Iona students. Cay and Hugh had a wonderful partnership including working at the college they loved, Iona. Both were participants in the social movements of the 60's. She balanced her family, career and studies while still being active in her church (Holy Family in New Rochelle) and her community. As her granddaughter Kate Walsh wrote in a college paper about her, her roles as a mother, activist, and professor were intertwined throughout the era and helped fuel each other rather than come in conflict. The relationships she formed as a mother and professor pushed her to become active in social movements for the 1960s. Her involvement in the movements informed her parenting, and her role as a professor came into her life because of her experiences as a wife and mother. In the 1970s, with her family's support, Cay enrolled in the doctoral program at Fordham University. Unfortunately Hugh died suddenly in 1978 leaving Cay to raise her still young family so she did not complete her degree. She retired from teaching in 1994 and spent the remainder of her life traveling, reading, and spending time with her family and friends. Cay is survived by her seven children, Hugh (Janet), Thomas (Joan), Mary (William Walsh), Mark (Beth), David (Evelyn), Lawrence (Nancy) and Catherine (Jill), her seventeen grandchildren, Jennifer, Drew (Jodie), Sean, Glynis, Claire, Kate, Jack, Colin, Brian, Emily, Maura, Courtney, Alanna, Madeline, Mary, Hugh and Katherine and her six great-grandchildren Haley, Zachary, Serena, Nolen, Aria and Phoenix. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, on Friday Aug. 26th at 10:30am. Interment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, you may make a donation in Cay's name to Hope Community Services, 50 Washington Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801 914-636-4010 info@hope-cs.org.
GROSSMAN--Myrna, 76, of Brookfield, CT passed away peacefully in her sleep on August 23, 2011 leaving a husband of over 50 years, four grown sons and six loving grandchildren.

MANDEL--Merven, 90, beloved husband, father and grandfather and renowned aeronautical engineer passed away in his home. He is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Yvette, and his three children and five grandchildren. While working for General Applied Science Lab (GASL) from 1959-67, he designed the mission and trajectory analysis on supersonic combustion-powered hypersonic planes (SCRAMJET). As an engineer with Sperry Gyroscope from 1957-1959, he worked on missile aerodynamic design and performance and, from 1967-1984, on submarine design and weapons system engineering. He also worked for Lockheed (1948-1953). He earned BS and MS degrees in Aeronautical Engineering from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, where he won many awards, including Tau Beta Pi and Sigma Xi honor society memberships. He served in the Navy from 1942-46. He was later a volunteer at the Cradle of Aviation Museum, where he restored aircraft of significance to Long Island and served as a docent. He also had a great passion for many personal pursuits. He flew planes and gliders, sky-dived, drove race cars, was an ace rifle and pistol marksman and was an expert crossword puzzle solver. But most importantly, he was a compassionate, loving man and a great role model and friend to all who had the privilege of knowing him. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Hospice Care Network (99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY) or the Cradle of Aviation Museum (516-572-4026).

BUDNY--Lorraine, was born Lorraine Y. Girouard in Chicopee, Massachusetts. After living in many states in the Northeast, she settled in Manhattan, New York. With a great desire to be involved in the fashion world, she became Director of Fashion Promotion at Lord & Taylor under Dorothy Shaver. This led to being named Fashion Editor at Harper's Bazaar under Diane Vreeland. She was a fashion model for Saks Fifth Avenue designer Bonnie Cashin and soon became her assistant. She also worked with Claire McCardal as her model and assisted her with her publicity. She eventually became a sportswear designer with such contemporaries as Anne Klein and Anne Fogarty. Her fashions were sold to Saks Fifth Avenue, Henri Bendel, Bergdorf Goodman, as well as Lord & Taylor and Bloomingdales, and shops across the country. She received the Medemoiselle Magazine Achievement Award and was nominated twice for the Coty Award. For years she has been the publisher, editor and reporter for the "soft gossip" newsletter, "etcetera," news about Northwest Connecticut and beyond, such as Dutchess County, Manhattan and more. She started it as a column for a local newspaper. It grew to a half-page in space. She then published it herself until The New Milford Times, under Trip Rothchild, took it on as a regular column in it's newspaper. She also wrote free-lance pieces for magazines and newspaper Op-Ed pages for many years. Her column was read by many of our illuminaries in our Litchfield Hills and enjoyed by many others. Mrs. Budny will be remembered for her great philanthropy, generosity, and support of the arts locally as well as in New York City. Her worldwide travels and experiences were included many times in her many articles. Lorraine passed away on August 17, 2011 in Litchfield. She is survived by her husband's nephew, Ronald C. Budny of Litchfield, CT and niece, Debra Jean Budny Schmidt of Knoxville, TN. There will be no formal funeral services. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society, 38 Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06854. Services entrusted to Rowe Funeral Home of Litchfield.

Willis E. Hartshorn, director of the International Center of Photography since 1994, announced on Tuesday that he would step down for health reasons. No successor has been named, and Mr. Hartshorn, known as Buzz, said he would remain in his post until the institution's board of trustees completed what it said would be ''an international search'' for a new director. Mr. Hartshorn, 60, said he had been grappling with Parkinson's disease since about 2004 and that about five years ago he informed the board of his situation. He was invited to continue at the helm of the center, a move that he said was ''a very humane thing that reflects well on this organization.'' But he has come to the conclusion, he said, that ''I'm not the guy'' to lead the center in the next phase of its expansion. ''I'm seven years into this thing, and I can feel the difference physically,'' Mr. Hartshorn said. ''It's not fair to them, and the best thing for me and my family is that I pace myself in an appropriate way.'' He said that he would maintain an affiliation with the center, most likely by curating exhibitions or teaching courses, or both.
