This Sunday, the seventh floor of the Museum of Art and Design will be transformed into a 1990s vortex of cyberpunk phosphorescence, Web 1.0 social networking and conceptual snacking (e.g., scented high-potency oxygen). Snack the Planet kicks off the museum's Fun fellowship, which gives local night-life innovators carte blanche to create outsize party experiences at the museum. Lauren Devine and Patrik Sandberg, who masterminded the event, were inspired by the seminal Angelina Jolie film "Hackers" (1995) and its credo to "hack the planet," but promise to collude with the present as well, with performances by the up-and-coming acts Pictureplane, Teengirl Fantasy and Mykki Blanco; an immersive multimedia "entertainment zone" designed by Thunder Horse Video; and advanced tweeting modalities engineered by DIS Magazine's Nick Scholl, whose colleagues are supplying the souvenir branded condoms. Next up, Gag!, the long-running night at Metropolitan gay bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn hosted by Cameron Cooper and Zach Cole, will host what it is billing as a free store (in fact it will operate on a barter system) specializing in homegrown hipster esoterica during Fashion Week.Snack the Planet: Saturday, Aug. 27, 12-5 p.m. and Sunday, Aug. 28, 12-10 p.m. Bands play on Sunday only, starting at 5 p.m.

In Today's Times:The debt plan that lawmakers agreed to this month would sharply reduce budget deficits over the next decade, but the extension of the Bush-era tax rates would more than consume those savings, the Congressional Budget Office warned on Wednesday. The stars were aligned for the cover-story photo shoot in this Sunday's magazine. To accompany "The Fierce Intimacy of Tennis Rivalries," by Gerald Marzorati, the former editor of the magazine, the current editor of the magazine, Hugo Lindgren, suggested putting a modern face on some familiar tennis icons from the not-too-distant past. So we enlisted the comedian and "Saturday Night Live" regular Andy Samberg and the photographer Walter Iooss Jr., whose work has been appearing in Sports Illustrated for decades (indeed, Iooss had shot all of our original subjects), along with an ace styling team and crew. (We also brought in a digital team to stir its magic into the images, but more about that in a later blog post.) As the magazine's photo director, Kathy Ryan, put it, the day was "pure pleasure," which we hope some of these behind-the-scenes photographs will reveal.

Her campaign’s controlling instincts go beyond the candidate’s makeup and wardrobe.
The Red Iguana in Salt Lake City, facing extensive construction on its street, is considering opening a second restaurant just blocks away.
Staying active will give Pat Summitt, the women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, the best chance to stave off decline and give Alzheimer’s a public face.
A Category 3 hurricane may veer into North Carolina’s beaches on Saturday. So far, however, a relaxed mood prevails, as many hang on to the last bits of their summer.
Orders for big manufactured goods gained 4 percent in July, the biggest jump since March, but the increase was limited mainly to aircraft and automobiles.
New York has an abundance of inadvertent not-quite-art available for viewing, if you are open to it.
Several buildings in Washington remained closed Wednesday morning as engineers checked for structural damage after an earthquake on Tuesday.
For Adidas, a controversy over New Zealand All Blacks team jerseys became a lesson in the risks of associating a corporate brand with a national obsession.
A small town previously known, to the extent it was known at all, for its mineral deposits has now gained notice for another geological phenomenon.
South Korea is casting votes for the first time in a referendum on social policies: whether to provide all children with free lunches regardless of income.
President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and Kim Jong-il met on Wednesday to discuss North Korea’s nuclear program as well as proposed economic projects.
Rebels sought to strengthen their control of Tripoli, placing a nearly $2 million bounty on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, as loyalist fighters freed journalists.
Wall Street indexes turned sharply positive late Wednesday after a strong rally on Tuesday.
Red lentils have a refreshing flavor and a sproutlike crunch.
Iris Apfel, who has a wardrobe so large it is kept in a warehouse, will soon be selling her designs on the Home Shopping Network.
Well-off women stock their wardrobes surreptitiously, frequently and online.

RIBICOFF--Casey ( Lois ), a woman of exceptional character, dignity and style. Beloved widow of Senator Abraham A Ribicoff. Loving Mother of Peter and his wife Angela. Proud Grandmother of Andrew, Jake and Jessica. Caring Sister of June Herman of Indianapolis. She was devoted and grateful to all of her loving friends who became family to her. She loved them all dearly. She served on the Board of the John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for 20 years. She also served on the Board of WNET for over 20 years and retired as Honorary Vice Chairman. She was a founding member with Bill Blass, Judy Peabody, and Glenn Bernbaum of the AIDS Care Center at New York Hospital. She loved every minute of her life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Weill Cornell Medical College, in memory of Casey Ribicoff, for the Dr. J. Ruggiero Research Fund, 1300 York Avenue, Box 314, New York, NY 10065. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St, (5th Ave) on Tuesday, September 20 at 11am.

An article on Wednesday about a judge's questioning of the legal team for Levi Aron, the Brooklyn man accused of murdering an 8-year-old Borough Park boy in July, misstated Mr. Aron's whereabouts on Tuesday. He appeared in court briefly by video conference from Rikers Island; he did not physically appear in court before being sent back to Rikers Island.
These productions are part of the New York International Fringe Festival, which continues through Sunday; (866) 468 7619, fringenyc.org. 'THE MOUNTAIN SONG'

Seattle's Intiman Theater, which laid off its entire staff and closed its doors in April, has taken a first step toward reopening, hiring a consulting artistic director to come up with a plan to present to potential backers and the theater's creditors, The Seattle Times reported. For now, the board has hired Andrew Russell, 28, the theater's former associate producer, through Oct. 1. If he and the board succeed in raising enough money to implement his plan, which will involve presenting a ''micro-season'' next summer, then he will be kept on and the board will begin to hire other staff.
Q. How do you update the software on an Apple TV?

Samuel Menashe, a Greenwich Village poet whose jewel-like, gnomic short verse won him an ardent following in Britain and belated recognition in the United States when the Poetry Foundation gave him its first Neglected Masters Award in 2004, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 85. The cause was complications of heart disease, Nicholas Birns, a literary critic and friend, said.

BUTLER--Mary E.,72, of Red Bank, NJ, formally of New York City passed Saturday. Mary attended Sacred Heart and St. Catherine's Academy in the Bronx. She took great pride in her 17 years of work at NYU, her Irish heritage and she will be dearly missed by all. Viewing Friday August 26 at Thompson Memorial Home, Red Bank.
A critic's notebook on Aug. 9 about the Newport Jazz Festival in Rhode Island misstated the attendance for the rainy Sunday of the event. It was 3,808 -- not 5,000, the number of tickets issued.
Q. If I block someone on Google+, can that person still see the things I post?

Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts stirred a bit of a tempest when he said on the campaign trail in Iowa that ''corporations are people, my friend.'' Some called the remark tone deaf, saying it fed into the perception of him as an out-of-touch millionaire. But on the campaign trail Wednesday in Keene, N.H., Mr. Romney showed no signs of distancing himself from the remarks.

The Obama administration is considering further actions to strengthen the housing market, but the bar is high: plans must help a broad swath of homeowners, stimulate the economy and cost next to nothing. One proposal would allow millions of homeowners with government-backed mortgages to refinance them at today's lower interest rates, about 4 percent, according to two people briefed on the administration's discussions who asked not to be identified because they were not allowed to talk about the information.

Pictures were taken, hugs and kisses exchanged, and only a few tears shed Wednesday morning outside the Brandeis Educational Campus on West 84th Street, where kindergartners lined up for the first day of school. Other than the fact that classes were beginning more than two weeks before they will at most city schools, the new Upper West Success Academy seemed to be having a pretty typical first day.

A premiere screening of the documentary ''Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory,'' about the recently released prisoners known as the West Memphis Three and updated to reflect news events in that case, will be presented at the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday. The ''Paradise Lost'' documentaries, directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, have chronicled a 1993 Arkansas murder case in which three 8-year-old boys were killed and three men, Damien Echols, Jason Baldwin and Jessie Misskelley Jr., were convicted in 1994. The documentaries ''Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills,'' released in 1996, and a 2000 follow-up, ''Paradise Lost 2: Revelations,'' pointed to missteps in the investigation and the prosecution of the case. Last Friday, Mr. Echols, 36, Mr. Baldwin, 34, and Mr. Misskelley, 36, were freed after a legal procedure in which they were required to plead guilty, though the men maintain they are innocent.

President and Founder of Associated Global Systems from 1958 - present. His love of life and generosity touched so many lives. We will miss him always. Services Thursday, August 25, 2011 at 9:30am at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Central Park Conservancy and/or Columbia University Cancer Research Fund. For more information contact freemantanya@gmail.com.

Study after study revealed a troubling lack of reliability in eyewitness identifications. CHIEF JUSTICE STUART J. RABNER, of the New Jersey Supreme Court, on new rules that will make it easier for defendants to challenge eyewitness identifications in criminal cases. [A4]

Another changing of the guard is taking place at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Sylvia Waters, the longtime artistic director of Ailey II, will retire on June 30, 2012, the company plans to announce on Thursday. Ms. Waters began her career with the company as a dancer in 1968 and Mr. Ailey chose Ms. Waters to lead the junior troupe in 1974. She went on to guide and train young dancers for nearly four decades, including Robert Battle, the company's new artistic director. Ms. Waters has named Troy Powell, a teacher, choreographer and former dancer, as her successor. Mr. Powell has served as the associate artistic director for Ailey II since 2003. As part of its coming City Center season, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will pay tribute to Ms. Waters with a special performance on Dec. 11. She plans to remain involved in the Ailey organization following her retirement, leading the Ailey Legacy Residency, a new lecture, technique and repertory program for college-level students.

Marco Rubio, the freshman Republican senator from Florida, seems to many in his party the ideal candidate for vice president, having demonstrated proven appeal in a key swing state while drawing Hispanic voters to his party. But in a speech Tuesday night at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., Mr. Rubio said he would not seek that job. ''I have no interest in serving as vice president for anyone who could possibly live all eight years of the presidency,'' he said, adding: ''So the reality of it is, I'm not going to be the vice-presidential nominee. But I look forward to working for whoever our nominee is.''

An obituary on Wednesday about Ross Barbour, the last surviving original member of the vocal group the Four Freshmen, misstated the name of the conservatory at Butler University in Indianapolis where he studied. It was the Arthur Jordan Conservatory of Music, not the Arthur Conservatory of Music.

SINGER--Penny. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Penny Singer and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alan Fischer, President

It was blues night at Sugar Bar on Tuesday, and the musicians were working through their grief over the loss of Nick Ashford, the singer and songwriter who with his wife, Valerie Simpson, wrote some of the greatest songs of the Motown era. Halfway through a wailing tune in a minor key, Jermaine Paul, a young soul singer, started to talk, over the vamp, about what Mr. Ashford, whose chair was empty, meant to him, and he voiced what many in the room were feeling.

On the music charts this week, Jay-Z and Kanye West's album holds at No. 1 for a second week, a new song by Lil Wayne is the most downloaded, and a Los Angeles indie-pop band has a hit song on its hands nearly a year after releasing it. Last week ''Watch the Throne'' (Roc-a-Fella/Def Jam/Roc Nation), Jay-Z and Mr. West's well-publicized joint effort, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, although with the album available only at iTunes for most of that week its 436,000 sales were a little lower than had been expected. Now widely available, ''Watch the Throne'' sold 177,000 copies in its second week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a 59 percent drop but enough to keep it at No. 1.

An obituary in some editions on Tuesday about the songwriter and singer Nick Ashford misstated the given name of the woman with whom Mr. Ashford and Valerie Simpson wrote the Ray Charles hit ''Let's Go Get Stoned.'' She is Josephine Armstead, not Joey. (Through the years she has been variously billed as Josephine, Jo, Josie and Joshie.)

Babies don't take direction very well (if they did we should start by getting them to shush on airplanes), but Me Ra Koh has made a specialty of coaxing warm, memorable photos from infants, newborns and children. She has had her work showcased on Oprah, written how-to books such as ''Your Baby in Pictures,'' and teaches women's workshops. She shared some pointers on how to capture a baby's fleeting moments in a way that will charm not only family, but friends, neighbors, and maybe the occasional photography aficionado.

An obituary on Wednesday about Nora Bredes, the primary organizer of a campaign against the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, misstated the surname of her sister, who survives her. She is Amy Bredes, not Pirro.

MADEWELL, more girlie and romantic than its preppy J. Crew parent, is introducing its first catalog, out this week. Printed on oversize 10-by-13-inch paper, the inaugural issue highlights the work-wear heritage of the Madewell company (it dates from 1930s Bedford, Mass.) with a denim feature; shows off its whimsical styling, in fashion layouts with Dree Hemingway in boyish looks and Karmen Pedaru in mixed patterns (right); and shares the fall must-haves of the indie music darling Binki Shapiro of Little Joy. The catalog will be available at Madewell shops on Saturday, or you can request a copy at madewell.com.

The myTouch 4G Slide is a well designed phone offering a spacious keyboard, a terrific camera, a fast processor and one of the most infuriating features I have ever encountered -- a Wi-Fi calling app that charges you voice minutes. First, the good stuff. The phone's showpiece is its 8-megapixel camera. It is still not a replacement for a quality point-and-shoot camera, but it is better than most phone cameras.

While the spotlight of the latest technology boom has been trained on a cluster of popular consumer applications like Facebook, Groupon and Zynga, investors are increasingly taking a shine to the start-ups building the infrastructure for those Internet powerhouses. Silicon Valley's largest venture capital firms are raising their stakes in so-called enterprise companies, which provide software, analytics and other services to business customers. They are betting that the emerging players in this space, typically considered the least sexy part of technology, will siphon market share from the lumbering giants like Oracle and Microsoft.
RIBICOFF--Casey. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

TO say that coats are a big fall fashion trend sounds a bit like breaking the news that swimsuits are going to be hot next summer. Well, you might ask, when are they not? But the fall runway collections made a fairly convincing case for rethinking the role of outerwear in our wardrobes. Designers like Vera Wang, Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra put parkas front and center in their shows, while hybrid styles of bombers, blanket coats, ponchos, peacoats, toggle coats and toppers appeared just about everywhere else. It was as if the fashion world was making a collective stand against those ubiquitous puffer jackets that make most of us look as if we're wearing bubble wrap.

The Cases feature on Tuesday, about a patient's decision to delay surgery for a cerebral aneurysm, omitted a type of testing that makes some patients worry about radiation exposure. The test, a CT angiogram, involves X-ray radiation, which poses a far greater health risk than the nonionizing radiation employed in the magnetic resonance angiography scan that the patient underwent. The article also described the angiogram procedure incorrectly. It involves a catheter sent up from a vein in the leg to inject contrast dye for brain imaging; it does not involve a camera being run up to the brain.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about efforts to find a tenant for the former J.P. Morgan building at 23 Wall Street misstated the number of residents in Lower Manhattan. There were 22,904 residents before the 9/11 attacks and 56,000 in 2011 -- not 13,046 and 28,198 respectively.

An article on Wednesday about a downgrade of Japan's credit rating by the ratings agency Moody's Investors Service misstated Japan's grade from another agency, Standard & Poor's. It is AA , not AA. (A grade of AA is S.& P.'s fourth-highest, equivalent to the AA3 rating announced by Moody's.)

MOD dresses, those teasy trapezes and shifts of 1960s London, came out swinging once more for fall. At Yves Saint Laurent, an A-line dress in perforated patent leather was accented with white gloves and tall lace-up boots. At Prada, drop-waist dresses in Mondrian-like prints were tweaked with belts slung low on the hip and aviator caps. At Costume National, mock turtleneck numbers looked almost futuristic. But nowhere was the mod mood more pronounced than in the debut collection of Sofia Sizzi, whose elegantly tailored line, called Giulietta, was inspired by 1960s film and fashion. The pencil dresses and pantsuits, most in black and white wool crepe, are modern in their own way. Chic and fuss-free. From left: Crepe de Chine graphic print dress at Prada boutiques. Wool and silk panel dress at Costume National, 160 Mercer Street, (212) 431-1530. Perforated patent-leather dress at YSL boutiques. Giulietta dresses at Barneys New York; Patron of the New, 151 Franklin Street, (212) 966-7144; and netaporter.com.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Steven P. Jobs, whose insistent vision that he knew what consumers wanted made Apple one of the world's most valuable and influential companies, is stepping down as chief executive, the company announced late Wednesday. ''I have always said that if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple's C.E.O., I would be the first to let you know,'' Mr. Jobs said in a letter released by the company. ''Unfortunately, that day has come.''

BOTWAY--Jacqueline J.,of New Rochelle, NY, Clinton Corners, NY and Key West FL, passed away August 20, 2011 at her home after a prolonged illness. She was born in St. Louis, MO, earned her pilot's license upon her high school graduation and received a B.A. from the University of Georgia. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Clifford Botway; children Cooper and Jill, and grandchildren Clinton and Danica. Mrs. Botway traveled the world extensively and supported cultural, charitable and social works throughout her life. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, a Dame of The Order of the Holy Cross of Jerusalem and was active in numerous local historical, art and women's clubs. A private burial is planned, at her request.

An obituary on Monday about the champion marathon runner John J. Kelley misstated his fastest marathon time. It was 2 hours 20 minutes 5 seconds -- not 2 hours 14 minutes 38 seconds. (Kelley did finish the 1956 Boston Marathon in 2 hours 14 minutes 33 seconds, but the course that year was later found to be more than 1,000 yards short of regulation marathon length.)

It can be tough for a show to stand out among the almost 200 productions in this year's New York International Fringe Festival, which runs through Sunday. (Ending the title of your show with the words ''The Musical!'' is so 10 years ago.) One way to stop passers-by in their tracks is to design eye-catching artwork -- to be used online and in print -- that says ''Look at me. Come see the show. If it's not good, keep me as a bookmark.'' ArtsBeat took a look at some of the most clever and striking postcards created for productions in this year's Fringe, and talked to some of the designers behind the 3 1/2-by-5-inch billboards.

An article on the Itineraries page on Tuesday about the lengthy lines to clear customs at American airports misstated a provision of the federal Customs and Border Protection's Global Entry program. Enrollees may enter the United States by scanning their passport at a kiosk; they do not scan a card.

Andy Warhol said that ''In the future, everyone will be world famous for 15 minutes.'' With its second line of iPhone, iPad and MacBook covers featuring Warhol artwork, the manufacturer Incase is apparently going for a half hour. The first collection, released last April, featured five designs, including the screen print of a banana featured on the cover of the influential album ''The Velvet Underground & Nico.''

McCABE--Catherine. Catherine McCabe (nee Henry), wife, mother, professor, counselor, friend and a long time resident of New Rochelle, NY died peacefully on Tuesday August 23 at age 85. A woman of great dignity, faith and affection, Cay was born on January 7, 1926 to John and Theresa Henry in the Bronx. She was raised in New Rochelle and was a 1947 graduate of the College of New Rochelle. Cay married Hugh McCabe in 1949 and with him raised seven children. While the older children where in school and the youngest were in pre-school, Cay earned two masters degrees, one in Theology at Manhattan College and one in Pastoral Counseling at Iona College. She had also begun her career as a professor of Religious Studies at Iona that would span more than 30 years and touch the lives of generations of Iona students. Cay and Hugh had a wonderful partnership including working at the college they loved, Iona. Both were participants in the social movements of the 60's. She balanced her family, career and studies while still being active in her church (Holy Family in New Rochelle) and her community. As her granddaughter Kate Walsh wrote in a college paper about her, her roles as a mother, activist, and professor were intertwined throughout the era and helped fuel each other rather than come in conflict. The relationships she formed as a mother and professor pushed her to become active in social movements for the 1960s. Her involvement in the movements informed her parenting, and her role as a professor came into her life because of her experiences as a wife and mother. In the 1970s, with her family's support, Cay enrolled in the doctoral program at Fordham University. Unfortunately Hugh died suddenly in 1978 leaving Cay to raise her still young family so she did not complete her degree. She retired from teaching in 1994 and spent the remainder of her life traveling, reading, and spending time with her family and friends. Cay is survived by her seven children, Hugh (Janet), Thomas (Joan), Mary (William Walsh), Mark (Beth), David (Evelyn), Lawrence (Nancy) and Catherine (Jill), her seventeen grandchildren, Jennifer, Drew (Jodie), Sean, Glynis, Claire, Kate, Jack, Colin, Brian, Emily, Maura, Courtney, Alanna, Madeline, Mary, Hugh and Katherine and her six great-grandchildren Haley, Zachary, Serena, Nolen, Aria and Phoenix. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, on Friday Aug. 26th at 10:30am. Interment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, you may make a donation in Cay's name to Hope Community Services, 50 Washington Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801 914-636-4010 info@hope-cs.org.

An article last Thursday about a Manhattan roof terrace referred incorrectly to the teenage children of Wendy Evans Joseph, one of the terrace's owners. They are from her second marriage, not her first.

ON THE LAM Of the 26 defendants criminally charged in the government's insider trading investigation centered on Raj Rajaratnam, left, the hedge fund billionaire, only one has not been convicted or pleaded guilty: Deep Shah. Mr. Shah, a former bond analyst at Moody's Investors Service, has been declared a fugitive and is believed to be in Mumbai. On Tuesday, a federal judge ordered Mr. Shah to pay the government $34.6 million related to the Securities and Exchange Commission's insider trading lawsuit against him. PETER LATTMAN

8 P.M. (Discovery) RISING: REBUILDING GROUND ZERO Steven Spielberg is an executive producer of this six-part series, shown across two nights and based on a concept from Danny Forster of the Science Channel's ''Build It Bigger,'' which chronicles the rebirth of the World Trade Center site, above, in Lower Manhattan and the people behind it: architects, planners, construction workers and residents who have reclaimed their neighborhood. The first three episodes, shown consecutively, look at the plans for the 1,776-foot One World Trade Center; construction progress; and the concept behind the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, which will use physical remnants from the attack, including first-response vehicles and the steel footings of the original towers, to recount the story of Sept. 11. 8:30 A.M. (FX) SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE (2008) A young man from a poor area near Mumbai (Dev Patel, near right, with Anil Kapoor) becomes a game show contestant and explains how he knows the answers to all those questions in this contemporary fairy tale from Danny Boyle. The film is ''a gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''In the end, what gives me reluctant pause about this bright, cheery, hard-to-resist movie is that its joyfulness feels more like a filmmaker's calculation than an honest cry from the heart about the human spirit (or, better yet, a moral tale),'' she said, adding that Mr. Boyle ''plucked my heartstrings'' with ''well-practiced dexterity, coaxing laughter and sobs out of each sweet, sour and false note.''

GREEN--Richard A.,died of congestive heart failure on August 22, 2011. He was a graduate of Harvard College ('47) and Law School ('52), an assistant US attorney in the Southern District of New York, a practicing criminal lawyer in New York City, and an active member of the City Bar Association. In Washington, DC he continued his work on law reform and was a trial lawyer until his retirement. He is survived by his wife Lorna (Paul), his sons Charles Case and Thomas Freeman, and two grandchildren. Service and burial will be held at Beth Israel Congregation in North Adams, MA. Donations may be made to Capital Caring in Falls Church, VA.

It was the bar whose name everybody knew, even though it had no sign: Chumley's, in Greenwich Village. A speakeasy during Prohibition and a destination for tourists seeking a snapshot or New Yorkers seeking a nightcap, Chumley's has been closed since a wall collapsed in April 2007. Chumley's owners had said they hoped to reopen in a few weeks, then a few months. By 2008, they had removed the booths and tables -- and the photographs that had lined the walls -- and stored them for safekeeping. The building's landlord, Margaret Streicker Porres, said in August 2008 that she hoped the work would be completed in midfall of that year.

Toll Brothers, the luxury home builder, reported earnings that were better than analysts expected after a tax benefit, and demand for its homes by those buying up, remained stronger than other segments of the market. Net income for the third quarter ended July 31 was $42.1 million, or 25 cents a share, up from $27.3 million, or 16 cents, a year earlier, the company said on Wednesday in a statement.

WEILER--Martin E.,M.D., 85, died peacefully on August 19th in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico. Dr. Weiler was a graduate of Syracuse University and Chicago Medical School. He also served a tour in the Pacific Theater where, in May 1945, he survived a deadly kamikaze attack while aboard the USS Bunker Hill. During his 51 years of psychiatric practice Dr. Weiler eased the suffering of countless troubled souls. In the final decades of his career, he passed along his extensive knowledge of his profession to younger colleagues in the field as an associate professor of psychiatry at The College of physicians and surgeons at Columbia University. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Julia, his sister-in-law and brother-in-law Ellie and Jose, and his nephew, Jesse. A private memorial service is planned.

Steven P. Jobs, one of the most successful chief executives in corporate history, once said he never thought of himself as a manager, but as a leader. And his notion of leadership revolved around choosing the best people possible, encouraging them and creating an environment in which they could do great work. But the Apple team, analysts say, will face a far greater trial in achieving continued success without Mr. Jobs in charge.

The Skin Deep column on June 23, about beauty products for use at the beach, contained an incorrect inference about the bergamot in the Kate Spade perfume Twirl. The company says it is formulated to prevent blistering; it does not contain the bergamot mentioned in the article, which causes burning in the sun. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

ONGERTH--Henry J. He was a major force in regulation of recycled wastewater, staunch defender of public health in relation to public water supply, renowned for his integrity and plain speaking defense of technical positions. A 1935 graduate of UC Berkeley with a 1950 University of Michigan MPH he was an internationally recognized Sanitary Engineer, the California State Sanitary Engineer, Chair of the Conference of State Sanitary Engineers, Member of the USEPA National Drinking Water Advisory Committee, and elected to the National Academy of Engineering. Dead at 98, preceded by Mary his wife of 70 years, he leaves three sons, seven grandchildren, and one great grandchild in fond remembrance.

FOR a pack of designers, python proved the leather of choice for boots this fall. Fiercely patterned it may be, but snakeskin turns out to be a versatile accessory. Python boots were shown with navy suits at Valentino, with pastel plaids at Missoni, with mixed prints at Dries Van Noten (left). But, lordy, exotic skins don't come cheap, with many models topping $2,000. Here are options that will give you the look without necessarily breaking the bank. Worn with jeans, a turtleneck and a wool coat, they can be a chic everyday basic. From left: Miu Miu python boots, $1,390 at Saks Fifth Avenue; saksfifthavenue.com. Dries Van Noten python-print leather boots, $882 at Barneys New York; barneys.com.

Time to prepare some room in the ancestral crypt of ''The Addams Family'': that Broadway musical, adapted from the creepy, kooky clan depicted in Charles Addams's New Yorker cartoons (with a nod to the 1960s television comedy), is closing on Dec. 31, its press representatives said on Wednesday. The $16.5 million musical production, which features a book by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice and music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa, had a bumpy transition to Broadway. After an out-of-town tryout at the Oriental Theater in Chicago where it received positive and negative reviews, its lead producers, Stuart Oken and Roy Furman, drafted Jerry Zaks to oversee significant changes to the show, which is directed and designed by Phelim McDermott and Julian Crouch.

GREENE--Roger, 86. A happy, lucky man. For 60 years, he loved being married to Jonnie, who thought he was the best decision she ever made. He loved his children, Tracey and Seth, and their spouses, Phillip and Marina, and they loved him back. His grandchildren, Sophie and Enoch Riese, thrilled and adored him. He always felt his was the best possible life he could live. He made us feel the same way. We will miss him.

Performances of all 23 Broadway musicals and plays have been canceled for Saturday and Sunday, producers and theater owners announced late Friday afternoon, in recognition that many actors, crew members, and others face the same transportation and weather concerns as audience members do as Hurricane Irene bears down on the East Coast of the United States. Most Broadway shows had been scheduled to go on this weekend. This is the first time since the theater stagehands' strike of 2007 that Broadway has closed down en masse; the last emergency shutdown of Broadway was in 2003, when a blackout closed theaters for a night. Before that, the last time Broadway was dark was following the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001. No show producers on Friday could recall weather-related conditions (let alone forecasts) shuttering all of Broadway as well as virtually all Off Broadway. The cancellations will probably amount to a loss of a few million dollars for Broadway shows; standard practice is for ticket-holders to be offered refunds or exchanges from their point of purchase.

The legendary English singer-songwriter Marianne Faithfull, who is also an actress, presents us with her playlist this week. "It's heavy in the cornerstone classics of music," says the Jam's curator, Sean Hanratty, of the list, which includes Leonard Cohen and the Clash. "It's full of the timeless stuff that you never really lose, the records you own and would never part with." Faithfull's first hit, "As Tears Go By" (1964), which Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and the Rolling Stones manager Andrew Loog Oldham helped write, remains one of the best ballads of all time. The song, along with her highly publicized relationship with Jagger, put her on the map as one of rock's biggest stars. "You Can't Always Get What You Want," on the Stones album "Let It Bleed," released in 1969, was one of many songs written about Faithfull. "I think some people forget - certainly not me - that she also co-wrote 'Sister Morphine,' " says Hanratty of the track on the Stones's 1971 "Sticky Fingers" album. (The song is reportedly about her life and battles with drug abuse, specifically heroin.) For the past five decades, we have seen Faithfull reinvent herself as a performer and musician, in collaborations with the likes of David Bowie, Tom Waits, Emmylou Harris, Nick Cave and others, while keeping her place as one of the most influential female singer-songwriters of all time. "With the impending hurricane and Virginia's earthquake, we are kind of in need of the classics," Hanratty says. Faithfull will perform her classics, as well as songs from this year's album, "Horses and High Heels," at Manhattan's City Winery on Dec. 18.

For the inaugural phase of its new retail endeavor, the Brooklyn design incubator 3rd Ward thought inside the box - specifically, a salvaged shipping container it calls Shopbox. The store opened this Friday, and, like its neighbors at Dekalb Market in Brooklyn, makes its home in a repurposed rectangular storage unit. Painted a can't miss-bright green, and with prominent window displays on two sides, Shopbox showcases a rotating assortment of wares, which, after signing up using an on-site iPad, shoppers can purchase via text. Merchandise is then shipped directly to your address, a play on the shipping-container conceit itself, according to 3rd Ward's retail director, Jeffrey Opdyke. "This was an opportunity to create a beautiful jewel box of a design store and meld it with the latest technology," he says. "We're creating a totally new shopping experience."

We came, we shucked, we concurred with the "Gentle Island" tag line. Prince Edward Island, a crescent-shaped patch of land off the coast of New Brunswick, and Canada's smallest province, is the kind of place where the dinner rush starts at 4:30. During the high season, which runs from May to October, it's one big seafood banquet: oysters, clams, mussels, halibut, lobsters, haddock, salmon and scallops are all on the menu, and all from just down the road. The seafood used to hit your plate deep fried beyond recognition, but these days your fish could come grilled, your steamers actually steamed. Last month, my husband, our 1-year-old son and I set off in search of fishy stuff and found plenty, along with a few other simple summer pleasures, like the local classic-rock radio station (hello, Queen!).

There's nothing stale about Fresh's new retail concept. The beauty brand's fragrant flagship in Manhattan's Union Square has been completely redesigned by Mapos, a young architecture firm headed up by two former Peter Marino disciples. Inspired by Old World bakeries, laboratories and apothecaries, the space is bisected by a massive reclaimed walnut "kitchen" table that contains stacks of vintage botanical books and offers a comfy place to perch while testing products. Custom and antique details abound, including an old English communal wash basin, a unique "Sensorial Bar," (where discontinued fragrances are available on tap) and a large glass display case that makes Fresh's prettily packaged soaps look like confections in a pastry shop.

The T-shirt, the hat, the oversize tennis ball: buying one or many of these are a rite of passage for the tens of thousands of fans who attend the United States Open each year. But on hot, humid days, there is little appeal in walking around with a sticky plastic bag of these goodies.

The financial crisis has been good to Warren E. Buffett. The billionaire investor snatched up shares of Goldman Sachs and General Electric during some of the darkest days of 2008, injecting life and funds into the companies and turning a handsome profit later. On Goldman alone, Mr. Buffett netted $1.7 billion.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about identifying and treating kidney disease, erroneously included two painkillers on a list of drugs that are toxic to people with the disease. Aspirin and acetaminophen, when used at recommended doses, are considered safe for kidney patients.

As many North Carolinians braced for Hurricane Irene, it was business as usual at the Winston-Salem Open, the final men's tune-up for the United States Open. ''It's a beautiful day, 85 degrees with a slight breeze,'' Bill Oakes, the tournament director, said by telephone on Thursday, shortly before the start of play.

A simmering battle between Sarah Palin and Karl Rove has flared up again, with Mr. Rove accusing the former vice-presidential candidate of having a ''thin skin.'' The latest spat comes in the wake of Mr. Rove's suggestion that Ms. Palin's schedule suggested she would be making a presidential bid. That led to some pushback from her political action committee, which in a blog post said ''DC pundits'' -- obviously alluding to Mr. Rove -- were spreading false information about her.

A Manhattan appeals court ruled unanimously on Thursday that the city should release performance rankings of thousands of public school teachers to the public, denying a second attempt by the teachers' union to keep the names confidential. With the loss, the union, the United Federation of Teachers, is running out of legal options in its year-old fight to keep the rankings secret. The union said Thursday that it was appealing the ruling to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, which does not have to accept the case.

DJEREJIAN--Robert A.,New York City architect and former Senior Managing Partner of HLW International, died on August 21, 2011. He is survived by his beloved wife of 15 years, Patrice. Loving father of Linda Eigeman and husband Chris, Madeline, Pier Shiever and husband H.R. Dear brother of Ambassador Edward Djerejian, and wife Francoise. Adored grandfather of Beatrix Iris and Henrietta Hyacinthe Shiever and Gabriel Bedros Eigeman. Devoted Uncle of Gregory Djerejian and wife Stephanie, and Francesca Djerejian. Cherished grandniece Isabel and grandnephew Sebastian. Also, treasured mother-in-law Zovinar Najarian Lair. Endeared brother-in-law Michael Lair and wife Ruth, nephew Cameron and niece Mackenzie. Funeral service will be Saturday, August 27 at 10:30am, St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Ave, NYC, 10016. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory, may be made to Pratt Institute for a scholarship in Bob's name. 718-230-6810.

MEITERMAN--Judy, 70, of Marlboro, New Jersey passed away on Thursday, August 25, 2011. Judy was born March 7, 1941 in Russia to the late Rafael and Ruth Feifowicz. Beloved wife of Morris for 51 years, loving mother to Steven and Bernard, dedicated grandmother to Michael, Gabriella, Mark and Monica and dear sister to Itzchak Feifowitz and Benjamin Feifowicz. The funeral will be conducted at Congregation Sons of Israel Holocaust Memorial Chapel, 613 Ramsey Street, Lakewood, New Jersey at 1pm. Shiva will be held through Wednesday August, 31. (732) 946-2787.

A tap-dancing Steven McRae, one of the principal dancers at London's Royal Ballet; the New York- and Sweden-based Pontus Lidberg Dance company; and the Australian Ballet are joining the mix of this season's Fall For Dance festival at New York City Center, which will run from Oct. 27 to Nov. 6, the festival announced Wednesday. Twenty companies and choreographers are taking part in the popular series, which features all tickets at $10 - a price which will now include the fruits of a large-scale renovation of the theater. Other international companies include Lizt Alfonso Dance of Cuba, Richard Alston Dance Company from the United Kingdom, the Royal Ballet of Flanders, China's TAO Dance Theater and the Vertigo Dance Company from Israel. Domestic entries include Lil Buck, the Joffrey Ballet, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Jessica Lang Dance, Mark Morris Dance Group, New York City Ballet and Trisha Brown Dance Company.

Eddie Colon, of Harlem, hopped off his bicycle, casually leaned the bike against a rectangular post of red metal and browsed the flavors at an Italian-ice cart tended by a sidewalk vendor. This was the northwest corner of 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard on Wednesday night, and the red post Mr. Colon used as a bike stand was a type found every few blocks in New York City. It is a shoulder-high device with two metal flaps: a red one with a symbol of a flame - ''Fire'' - and a blue one with a symbol of a badge - ''Police.'' Each flap flips up to reveal a button to press for emergency help.

EDISON, N.J. - Because he leads the money lists of both the PGA and the European Tours, the Englishman Luke Donald was asked this week at the Barclays about the possibility of becoming the first player to finish a season as the top money winner on both. ''I'm more concerned with winning the Race to Dubai and the FedEx Cup,'' Donald said. ''Winning trophies rather than the title of being leading money winner is much more important to me.''

An article on Aug. 18 about the Panel for Educational Policy's approval of a service contract with Verizon to provide phone and Internet services for two years at New York City schools misstated the amount that Verizon is alleged to have gained from working with a city consultant who is now under investigation for theft. A federal complaint estimated it at around $800,000, not $400 million. (Neither the company nor the Department of Education has released a figure.)

An article on Thursday about Steven P. Jobs's leadership of Apple misstated the year he returned to the company after being pushed out in 1985. He came back as an adviser in 1996 -- not 1997, which was when he became chief executive.

SAR Academy / SAR High School is deeply saddened by the loss of Mrs. Sylvia Genauer, mother of SAR founder Blu and Rabbi Yitz Greenberg, grandmother and great-grandmother of many SAR alumni, current students and teachers. SAR High School, established in 2004, was dedicated to the memory of JJ Greenberg z"l, Sylvia's grandson. Savta Sylvia was an amazing woman and role-model. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The SAR Family

An article last Friday about the failure of the green economy to create as many jobs as many politicians had envisioned referred incorrectly to the cost to homeowners of a program to weatherize homes using federal stimulus money. The program does not require any upfront money from consumers.

A chart in some editions on Thursday with an article about the resignation of Steven P. Jobs as chief executive of Apple misstated the year that the Apple II computer was introduced. It was April 17, 1997 -- not 1996. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/businessday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the resignation of Michele M. Moody-Adams as the dean of Columbia College misattributed a quotation about her in some copies. It was Claire Sabel, the editor of the undergraduate news blog Bwog -- not Alex Frouman, of the University Senate -- who said, ''She put in all the regular appearances, but nothing really beyond that, so she didn't have a lot of enemies but she also didn't have a lot of champions.'' (Mr. Frouman commented on the need to ensure that any future dean is open to working with students.)

The United States surgeon general has a new message for American women: It's O.K. to have a bad hair day. As the country's leading spokespeople on public health, surgeon generals often weigh in on issues of national importance like tobacco smoke and disease prevention. But when the current surgeon general, Dr. Regina M. Benjamin, visited a trade show in Atlanta this month, it was to talk about what has become something of a pet cause: Too many women forgo exercise because they're worried it will ruin their hair.

When you're the single, attractive secretary of state of the United States, you're bound to pick up groupies in all corners of the international diplomatic scene. But for Condoleezza Rice, who has charmed diplomats from Rome (the Italian foreign minister, Massimo D'Alema) to London (Foreign Minister Jack Straw of Britain) to Pictou, Nova Scotia (the Canadian diplo-hunk Peter McKay), perhaps the strangest of all has always been Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

FU--Z.Y. The Dean, faculty, alumni, students, and friends of The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science at Columbia University greatly mourn the loss of our beloved benefactor, Z.Y. Fu, whose extraordinary generosity was transformational for Columbia Engineering School, ensuring its role as a global leader in science and technology for the 21st century. Since 1997, his landmark gift has supported an enormous number of faculty, students, programs, and research, and we are extremely grateful for his remarkable foresight in moving our School forward. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Joan; his brother-in-law, Dr. C.K. "John" Chu '06HON, professor emeritus of applied mathematics and chairman emeritus of the Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics at The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science; and other members of the family. Feniosky Pena-Mora, Dean and Morris A. and Alma Schapiro Professor, and the entire community of The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science

HOLUSHA--John. October 31, 1942 - August 26, 2010. Although our adventure was cut short a year ago, there's been no shortage of tributes, memories and good will from friends and colleagues. How you loved to tell a story, getting a purposeful look, brushing the hair from your forehead, taking a breath of air and then off and away, with a good one that was funny, or interesting or important, and always in great detail. John, you were an idealist and a crusader at heart, with a broad sense of what was right. Somehow you always managed to emphasize that instead of carping on what was wrong. Your way of looking at things without prejudice seemed to put order into what you wrote, as well as into our lives. Miss ya! Kathy, Terry, Family & Friends

In 2000, Harry M. Markopolos made a presentation to a senior enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The topic: Bernard L. Madoff Securities, an investment business with remarkably steady returns. He offered possible explanations for the firm's uncanny success, including an explosive one. ''The entire fund is nothing more than a Ponzi scheme,'' wrote Mr. Markopolos, then a Boston money manager, in his submission to the agency.

An article on Thursday about the Obama administration's consideration of a proposal to allow homeowners with government-backed mortgages to refinance them at today's lower interest rates misstated Edward DeMarco's title at the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. He is its acting director, not its chairman.

Former officials of Lehman Brothers, including Richard S. Fuld Jr., its former chief executive, have agreed to pay $90 million to settle a shareholder lawsuit that accused them of misleading investors about the investment bank's health in the months leading up to its collapse. In a court filing on Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, 13 Lehman executives and directors asked a judge to release insurance proceeds that would pay for the settlement.

An article on Aug. 15 about Representative Darrell Issa's business dealings, using erroneous information that Mr. Issa's family foundation filed with the Internal Revenue Service, referred incorrectly to his sale of an AIM mutual fund in 2008. A spokesman for the California Republican now says that the I.R.S. filing is ''an incorrect document.'' The spokesman, Frederick R. Hill, said that based on Mr. Issa's private brokerage account records, which he made public with redactions, the purchase of the mutual fund resulted in a $125,000 loss, not a $357,000 gain. And the article, using incorrect information from the San Diego county assessor's office, misstated the purchase price for a medical office plaza Mr. Issa's company bought in Vista, Calif., in 2008. It cost $16.3 million, the assessor's office now says -- not $10.3 million -- because the assessor mistakenly omitted in public records a $6 million loan Mr. Issa's company assumed in the acquisition. Therefore the value of the property remained essentially unchanged, and did not rise 60 percent after Mr. Issa secured federal funding to widen a road alongside the plaza.

DJEREJIAN--Robert A. Patrice Djerejian, wife of 15 years, daughters Linda, Madeline, and Pier, and their families are deeply saddened by the death of beloved and devoted husband and father Robert Djerejian. Born on July 6, 1931, Bob was a true pioneer. After graduating from Pratt Institute's School of Architecture in 1955, he went on to a highly successful career with HLW, becoming the firm's unofficial ambassador to the Middle East and establishing offices in Beirut, Athens, and, later, Riyadh. He exhibited the same adventuresome spirit in his personal interests; he loved to race his Aston Martin DBSV8 in Limerock, CT, and took first place in 2009. He also had a passion for mountain climbing, scaling the Matterhorn, the Riffelhof, and Mount Kilimanjaro, and was a champion of his wife's international vocal career. To his family, dear friends, and admiring colleagues, he will be remembered as a stunning, charming, and gifted man, and will remain an eternal inspiration. Funeral services Saturday, August 27, at 10:30am, St. Vartan Cathedral, 630 Second Ave., NYC 10016, (corner of 34th Street and Second Ave.). In lieu of flowers, gifts in memory of Robert Djerejian may be made to Pratt Institute, in support of a scholarship in his name. Checks should be made payable to Pratt Institute and sent to: Pratt Institute, Institutional Advancement, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11205. Please include "In Memory of Robert Djerejian" in the check's memo line. For questions, please call (718) 230-6810.

GOODGOLD--Sally, Practitioner of Bagel Diplomacy, Dead at 82. Sally Goodgold, community activist, died on Thursday, August 18, 2011. She was the first woman president of the City Club of New York. The 450 member good-government group, founded in 1892, called itself "the oldest continuously active, non-partisan, voluntary civic organization in the country". Until 1974, its membership was limited to men. Sally described her favorite method of operation as "bagel diplomacy". She would say, "I have people over to my apartment between 8 and 9:30am and I feed them and keep them talking for as long as it takes to chew through a whole bagel. Stanley Zabar once said he knew the state of the city by the size of my bills". The City Club was perhaps best known for its monitoring of city government administrations in the areas of zoning, landmarks, financing, delivery of services, housing and transportation. It held Friday luncheon meetings with prominent speakers, and each year sponsored the prestigious Bard Awards for Excellence in Architecture and Urban Design. The Club sponsored its famous "Distinguished New Yorker" Award annually at a gala black-tie dinner. It also published a critical monthly newsletter, The Gadfly. In describing her work at the City Club, Sally Goodgold said, "I try to fill the potholes in government. You can be both an innovator and a traditionalist all in the same dress". Mrs. Goodgold was an energetic, talkative woman with a wry sense of humor whose hands were constantly in motion when she spoke. She said that one of her shining moments as a community activist occurred in 1975 when she walked into City Hall with a Federal check for $13 million for the repair of the crumbling West Side Highway between 72nd and 82nd Streets. She said that she and the late State Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal had managed to convince Federal officials that the West Side Highway, because it was elevated, was really a bridge and therefore entitled to an appropriation from the Federal Bridge Repair Fund. Stanley Turkel Former Chairman, City Club of New York

The Art Institute of Chicago has named Douglas Druick, a curator there for 26 years and the chairman of two departments, as its new director, the institute announced Wednesday. Mr. Druick, 66, has been the acting director since June 30, when the former director, James Cuno, departed to become the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles. Reached in the director's office on Wednesday morning, Mr. Druick, who previously led the prints and drawings and European painting and sculpture departments, said that he felt his intimate knowledge of the museum gave him ''a very good perspective of the ways we can grow.'' He said that his goals included changing gallery installations, hiring a new education director, pursuing the production of online catalogs and expanding the ways that technology is used to provide both on-site and remote access to the collection.

''Leo,'' a solo show featuring a gravity-defying performance by Tobias Wegner, above, is the winner of the 2011 Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh award, to be presented at a ceremony Friday in the Scottish capital. The show, one of more than 800 theater productions in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this year, is presented by the German company Circle of Eleven and will receive a full production in New York next winter. In ''Leo,'' directed by Daniel Briere, Mr. Wegner moves through a wordless narrative about a man trapped in a room where the laws of gravity are skewed, pulling him not toward the ground but in other directions. The show was well reviewed in Edinburgh. The Best of Edinburgh Award is presented to an original show never presented in New York and is chosen by Ms. Tambor; members of her theatrical foundation; and Joyce McMillan, Jackie McGlone and Mark Fisher, arts writers for the newspaper The Scotsman. The winner is given a New York production with all expenses paid, including travel and lodging. ''Leo'' will run Jan. 11-Feb. 5 at the Clurman Theater.

LIBOR LAWSUIT Charles Schwab, the prominent brokerage firm and investment manager, sued 11 major banks on Tuesday, claiming they conspired to manipulate a borrowing benchmark used to set interest rates. In a pair of lawsuits filed in the Federal District Court in San Francisco, the firm accused the banks, including Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, of conspiring to manipulate the London Interbank Offered Rate. That conspiracy, the suits allege, allowed the banks to artificially deflate the numbers used to calculate Libor, thereby throwing off interest rates for Libor-based securities and depriving investors of the returns they would have earned had the numbers been accurate. KEVIN ROOSE

Is finance a game, or is it much more important than that? It should be something else entirely. Finance ought to provide an economy with an efficient means of allocating capital. It should provide a means of price discovery of assets, whether real or financial. It should provide a safe and reliable payments system. Financial innovations are worthwhile if, and only if, they help in those areas.

9 A.M. (Bravo) MILK (2008) Sean Penn (above) won the Oscar for best actor for his performance as the title character in this biopic from Gus Van Sant. Mr. Penn portrays Harvey Milk, a neighborhood activist elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1977 -- and one of the first openly gay elected officials in the country -- who was killed the next year, along with the city's mayor, George Moscone (Victor Garber), by a former supervisor, Dan White (Josh Brolin). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''accessible and instructive, an astute chronicle of big-city politics and the portrait of a warrior whose passion was equaled by his generosity and good humor.'' He added: ''Mr. Penn, an actor of unmatched emotional intensity and physical discipline, outdoes himself here, playing a character different from any he has portrayed before. This is less a matter of sexuality -- there is no longer much novelty in a straight actor's 'playing gay' -- than of temperament.'' Milk was an extrovert, Mr. Scott said, whose sometimes sloppy self-presentation camouflaged an incisive mind and a ferociously stubborn will. ''All of this Mr. Penn captures effortlessly through voice and gesture,'' Mr. Scott continued, ''but what is most arresting is the sense he conveys of Milk's fundamental kindness, a personal virtue that also functions as a political principle.'' Dustin Lance Black also earned an Oscar for best screenplay. 12:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE BANGER SISTERS (2002) Susan Sarandon plays Lavinia, a conservative Phoenix housewife whose carefully camouflaged past as a '70s rock groupie threatens to resurface when her partner in backstage adventure, Suzette (Goldie Hawn), unexpectedly shows up for a visit, and a handout. Geoffrey Rush, in town to kill his father, is the failed screenwriter who hasn't had sex in a decade. But Suzette will take care of that. ''For all the charm effused by its stars, 'The Banger Sisters,' written and directed by Bob Dolman, emerges as a pallid, unconvincing pipe dream,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The Times. ''I've known several superannuated groupies, and in real life they are much more like Patsy and Edina, the bitter, self-deluded harpies of the British series 'Absolutely Fabulous,' than Ms. Hawn's ageless, spiritually unsullied evangelist of hip.''

As my Sunday column appears, I'll be in transit to Libya, insha'allah. But this column grew out of my family vacation this summer back in Yamhill, Oregon, where I grew up. Like everyone in journalism, I had been focused on the debt ceiling debates, but what I saw in Yamhill was a different economic scourge: unemployment. It really puzzles me that 25 million Americans could be unemployed or under-employed, and yet the issue has never really gotten much traction. In the last month or two, it has gained more visibility and President Obama says he is pivoting to jobs -- but none of the proposals on the agenda come close to matching the severity of the unemployment picture.

HUNTINGTON--Eleanor, longtime resident of Rye, New York, passed away peacefully at home on August 24, 2011, with her family by her side. Mrs. Huntington was born on October 2, 1938 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She graduated from Raven Hill Academy in Philadelphia, and attended Manhattanville College for two years before transferring to and graduating from the University of Pennsylvania in 1960 with a B.A. in History. It was at the University of Pennsylvania that Mrs. Huntington met her devoted husband of fifty years, Robert H. Huntington, who she married in 1960. Mr. Huntington passed away in 2010 after a long illness. Shortly after marrying, they moved to Rye, New York, where she remained active in community and church affairs over the next forty years. Among other activities, she served on the Board of Directors of Samaritan Counseling Center (formerly Sound Shore Counseling Center), and was a founding member of the Rye Youth Council Outreach Program. She was the Treasurer and later three-term President of the 26th Twig, an organization devoted to raising funds for United Hospital in Port Chester. Mrs. Huntington later served on the Board of Directors for United Hospital. She was also an active member of the Rye Garden Club and its Conservation Committee. Mrs. Huntington was also an active member of the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, where she taught religious education for many years, and served as a Eucharistic Minister. She later was instrumental in forming the Interfaith Church Group or "ICARE," an organization devoted to training individuals to assist parishioners in need. Mrs. Huntington was a longtime member of the Apawamis Club in Rye, New York, where she played competitive tennis and golf for many years, and later served as the Chairwoman of the Women's Golf Program. She is survived and will be missed by her three children: Robert H. Huntington III and his wife Katherine of New York City; Thomas Andrew Huntington and his wife Melissa of Oakland, California; and Betsy Gallagher and her husband Jim of Rye; along with five grandchildren, Amanda and John Huntington, Ben Huntington, and Emma and Georgia Gallagher. Ellie was loved and respected by her family and large circle of devoted friends. Her humor, great stories and competitive fire will be sorely missed. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Tuesday from 5pm to 8pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday, August 31 at 11:00am at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Open Door Family Medical Centers: (https://support.opendoor medical.org/sslpage.aspx.).

The T-shirt, the hat, the oversize tennis ball: buying one or many of these are a rite of passage for the tens of thousands of fans who attend the United States Open each year. But on hot, humid days, there is little appeal in walking around with a sticky plastic bag of these goodies. The United States Tennis Association is trying to change this admittedly minor inconvenience.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the final round of the Senior Players Championship misstated the circumstances of Fred Couples's winning putt on the third playoff hole. He nearly holed his approach shot for an eagle -- not a birdie -- and then he hit a short birdie putt to defeat John Cook. And also because of an editing error, the article misstated the significance of the championship. It was Couples's first major title as a senior and second major title over all, after the 1992 Masters. It was not his second overall title on the Champions Tour. (He has won five times on the tour.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Texas A&M's efforts to change athletic conferences misidentified, in some copies, the university's current conference. It is in the Big 12 -- not the Southeastern Conference, which it hopes to join.

EIGEN--Robert J.,on August 26, 2011. Husband of Joan for 51 years; father of Wendy, David and his wife, Cindy; grandfather of Emily, Lexi, Zach, Max, Jack and Sam; brother of Marcia. Born on April 11, 1935, Bob graduated from Dartmouth and got his MBA from the Amos Tuck School of Business. A year later, he met the love of his life, Joan, and his career took off. From accountant to mortgage broker to real estate developer, Bob loved to create and had an incredible eye for architecture. He also was active in many charities. Bob loved golf, his gin game, fine wine, a glass of Dewars, but most of all his family. We will miss his ever strong presence. In lieu of flowers, Contributions may be made in memory of Mr. Robert J. Eigen to Weill Cornell Medical College (memo: Weill Cornell Medical College, Center for Cancer Prevention Research), c/o Alison Zayas, Office of Development, Box 123, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065. For more information please call: 646-317-7359. Service Monday 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76 St., at Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

The artistic director of the Cherry Lane Theater said on Thursday that she no longer planned to sell its building in Greenwich Village to pay down debts, and added that the theater's recently precarious financial situation had been eased due to new rental income and changes to business practices. Angelina Fiordellisi, who bought the theater building at 38 Commerce Street in 1996, announced last year that she was fielding offers from buyers and making plans to step down as artistic director. (Her hope was that a buyer would continue operating the 179-seat main stage and 60-seat studio theater as a company.) At the time, she said that a drop in income from rental fees, ticket sales, and government and foundation support had contributed to a total budget deficit of $250,000.

Lady Gaga, Beyonce and Katy Perry have been deemed threats to ''cultural national security'' in China. The Ministry of Cultural has ordered music download sites to delete songs by the pop divas, as well as songs by the Backstreet Boys and other musicians, The Associated Press reported. Cultural officials posted a list of 100 songs that it wanted removed from Chinese Web sites by Sept. 15, threatening unspecified punishments if the order was not complied with.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about a South Korean case involving market manipulations through trading in convertible bonds, referred imprecisely to the target of the accusations. While two former traders for Credit Suisse have been indicted, no charges have been filed against the bank. And a front-page capsule summary also misstated the targets. The accusations involved a Korean affiilate of Deutsche Bank and employees of both Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse; no charges have been filed against either bank.

New York City officials issued what they called an unprecedented order on Friday for the evacuation of about 370,000 residents of low-lying areas at the city's edges -- from the expensive apartments in Battery Park City to the roller coaster in Coney Island to the dilapidated boardwalk in the Rockaways -- warning that Hurricane Irene was such a threat that people living there simply had to get out. Officials made what they said was another first-of-its-kind decision, announcing plans to shut down the city's entire transit system Saturday -- all 468 subway stations and 840 miles of tracks, and the rest of the nation's largest mass transit network: thousands of buses in the city, as well as the buses and commuter trains that reach from Midtown Manhattan to the suburbs.

At sporting events like the United States Open, garbage is garbage, whether it organic or inorganic: at the end of the day, it has to be hauled away. Of course, recycling can save tens of thousands of dollars in disposal fees and even produce some income from recyclers. That is why the Open has an ambitious program to recycle glass, plastic, aluminum and cardboard.

WILMINGTON, N.C. -- The first punch from Hurricane Irene landed here on Friday, foreshadowing with brutal authority what is to come as this vast storm, its most forceful winds stretching outward for 90 miles, churned north toward New York. Mandatory evacuations were ordered all along the Eastern Seaboard, as far north as the New Jersey shore and parts of New York City. Roads and highways were filled with caravans of ousted vacationers and homeowners, many fleeing under still-sunlit skies in anticipation of torrential rains, dangerous tidal surges and the likelihood of days without power.

They won't be making it rain. Three big presidential fund-raisers scheduled for this weekend in the Hamptons are up in the air thanks to the impending arrival of Hurricane Irene, currently hurtling toward New York.

At Woodstock, Joan Baez sang a famous folk ballad celebrating Joe Hill, the itinerant miner, songwriter and union activist who was executed by a Utah firing squad in 1915. ''I never died, said he'' is the song's refrain. Hill's status as a labor icon and the debate about his conviction certainly never died. And now a new biography makes the strongest case yet that Hill was wrongfully convicted of murdering a local grocer, the charge that led to his execution at age 36.

Though Jon Stewart was, for a time, an MTV employee in the 1990s, we never figured him for a flannel-flying grunge-rock fan. Our misconceptions notwithstanding, Mr. Stewart, the ''Daily Show'' host and comedy pundit, will host a Q. and A. session with the surviving members of Nirvana to be broadcast on SiriusXM satellite radio and timed to the 20th anniversary of that band's best-selling album ''Nevermind.'' SiriusXM said on Thursday that the musicians Krist Novoselic and Dave Grohl as well as the ''Nevermind'' producer Butch Vig will participate in the two-hour program with Mr. Stewart, which will be broadcast live on Sept. 24 at 8 p.m. on SiriusXM Channel 34 (a channel also known fittingly as Lithium). The discussion will field questions from callers as well as members of a live studio audience at SiriusXM's studios in New York. SiriusXM said it planned to choose the audience members for this event via an online contest, though it might want to keep a watch out for this woman.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the removal of two murals in an Art Deco rental building in Manhattan misspelled the surname of a 100-year-old resident who remembered their origins. The resident, who recently died, was Rachael Klausner, not Klaussner. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

An article on Wednesday about an exiled tribal leader from Baluchistan, a southwestern province of Pakistan, misstated the year that Pakistan was created. It was 1947, not 1948. The fighters from the leader's Bugti tribe were shown at a gathering in January 2006, not this past January.

8 P.M. (HBO) CONVICTION (2010) In yet another hardscrabble role, Hilary Swank, right, plays Betty Anne Waters, the product of a negligent mother and foster care, who pushes through college and law school while working at a bar and rearing two sons in an effort to defend -- finally --her beloved and mercurial brother, Kenny (Sam Rockwell), for a murder conviction she believes to be unjust. ''For a while 'Conviction,' based on the true story of a New England woman's long struggle to win freedom for her imprisoned brother, feels as if it just might escape the stifling conventions of the crusader-for-justice melodrama,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film from Tony Goldwyn. But soon enough the movie ''goes into lockdown, as the talents of a number of superb actors are stifled by an airless, by-the-numbers story,'' he writes, adding: ''The intriguing question of Kenny's character -- not his guilt or innocence, but the quicksilver temperament that makes both seem plausible -- fades as the story of Betty Anne's hard work and sacrifice gains momentum. And Ms. Swank's performance shrinks in scope as her character's monomaniacal devotion to freeing Kenny takes over the movie.'' Ultimately, '' 'Conviction' tells a great story,'' Mr. Scott added. ''If only it could have been a great movie.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton examines the moral issues surrounding the use of drones, remotely piloted aircraft that can drop bombs. Fred de Sam Lazaro reports on the growth of the Ghanaian economy and a university that trains Ghanaians to become ethical leaders in their fledgling democracy. And the Rev. Dr. Robert M. Franklin, president of Morehouse College, discusses the importance of the new Martin Luther King Jr. National Memorial, along the south side of the Mall in Washington.

Because of an editing error, an essay on Page 11 this weekend, about the religious beliefs of Republican presidential candidates, misstates the proportion of Americans who believe that extraterrestrials live among us. It is about a third, not a majority. The essay also erroneously includes Rick Santorum among politicians affiliated with evangelical Christianity. Mr. Santorum is Catholic.

1:51 p.m. | Updated The latest possible presidential bid by former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York has gone the way of his previous possible bids: it ended before it began. Mr. Pataki, whose flirtations with running for president stretch back more than a decade, canceled a planned trip to Iowa this weekend and announced on Friday that he will not pursue the Republican nomination ''at this time.''

The Saturday Profile article last week, about Japan's most prominent pair of antinuclear activists, Yuichi Kaido, a lawyer, and Mizuho Fukushima, a lawmaker, misidentified Ms. Fukushima's political party. It is the Social Democratic Party, not the Socialist Party. The article also misstated the location of a nuclear reactor that Mr. Kaido had sought to close through a lawsuit. The reactor, Monju, is in Fukui prefecture, not Shiga. And the article referred incompletely to the outcome of the lawsuit. While Mr. Kaido won in a lower court ruling in 2003, the ruling was overturned by the Supreme Court.

Exorbitant college textbook prices have given rise to a ''textbook rebellion,'' which may be coming to a campus near you. A coalition of students, parents, professors and organizations including the Student Public Interest Research Groups, have banded together to promote more affordable alternatives to the $200 textbook - an amount that is not uncommon for science, economics, accounting and math students, among other pricey majors.

Local coverage of National Football League exhibition games once again inflated early broadcast network numbers on Thursday. ''Big Brother'' on CBS reached new, albeit football-assisted, heights with a double-eviction episode that aired after the N.F.L. broadcast. The reality show's ratings matching its season best in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and the total audience was just under 8.5 million viewers - the largest viewership for the show since Sept. 2007. CBS won the night handily by filling the rest of its slate with reliable reruns of ''Big Bang Theory'' (7.9 million viewers) and The Mentalist (6.1 million). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SWARTSBERG--Mildred Kronenberg, a resident of Mill Valley for 34 years, died peacefully in her sleep, at home, Saturday, August 20th, 2011 on the 99th birthday of her late husband Jerry Swartsberg. A graduate of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, Class of 1933, Mildred had a passion for all the arts, sports and The New York Times crossword puzzle. She was great at anything she tried. She was one smart cookie! She is survived by her daughters Karen Swartsberg of Boothbay, Maine, and Janie Teitelbaum of San Rafael, California.
