Somewhere within the rambling recesses of ''Cow Play'' there lurks a great drama. Thankfully, Charlie Polinger, a wunderkind director, has gone spelunking into the depths of Matthew George's script to retrieve it. ''Cow Play,'' at Dixon Place, follows the brothers Mark and Jed, who grew up on a struggling dairy farm. Mark escapes to college, graduate school and an eventual obsession with an 11th-century tapestry; Jed, in a word, doesn't.

Using a debit card for purchases has become second nature to many of us. But now some banks are taking steps that make the cards less attractive, by charging monthly fees for their use with some checking accounts. The moves follow the heated debate over limiting the ''swipe'' fees that banks charge retailers for processing debt transactions. Banks say they have to make up that lost interchange-fee income from somewhere -- for example, by eliminating debit card rewards programs, and by adding fees on customers for shopping with debit cards.

NEPOMNYASHCHY--Vyacheslav "Slava." The Harriman Institute at Columbia University marks with deep sorrow the passing on August 18 of Slava Nepomnyashchy, husband of Catharine Nepomnyashchy, former director of the Harriman Institute, and father of Olga. Slava was a Soviet "refusenik", who met Cathy in 1970 in Sochi. Cathy was not granted a visa to enable a wedding in the USSR, and Slava was denied visas for five years and served two years in a construction battalion in Siberia before being allowed to emigrate. Their marriage took place in Rumson, N.J. in 1977. Timothy Frye, Director

EIGEN--Robert J. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Robert J. Eigen, beloved husband of Joan Eigen, and extends sincere sympathy to his two children, grandchildren and other members of his family. Arthur S. Loring, President Alan Curtis, Acting Secretary

RIBICOFF--Casey. The patients and staff from the Center for Special Studies at The New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell mourn the loss of our friend and benefactor Casey Ribicoff. From the beginning of the AIDS epidemic Casey was an advocate for the sick and stigmatized. Casey was a founder of the Fete de Famille and, through that benefit, she and a small group of friends worked tirelessly over many years to rally some of the most powerful in our society to the cause of the most vulnerable. Her loyal support and guidance were critical to the development of our program. We will miss her great spirit and friendship. Jonathan Jacobs, M.D Executive Director Samuel Merrick, M.D. Medical Director

The Boston Symphony Orchestra has canceled its performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony scheduled for Sunday afternoon at the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass., because of the approach of Hurricane Irene. The performance of the Ninth Symphony, which traditionally ends the orchestra's season at the festival, was to have been conducted by Lorin Maazel. All other Tanglewood events scheduled for Sunday have also been canceled, but the Tanglewood Jazz Festival is still scheduled to run from Thursday to next Sunday. The orchestra says that this is the first time it has canceled a concert in its 75-year residence at Tanglewood, despite occasionally heavy weather in the surrounding Berkshire Hills. Refunds will be available. Information can be found online or, as of Monday, at (617) 638-9395.

In the decade or so before the Nazis came to power in Germany, the Bauhaus school was known for its groundbreaking modern art, architecture and design - and its terrific parties. In fact, Walter Gropius, the Bauhaus founder, decreed that wild theme parties -- where students and professors would dress up, recite poetry, show what they were working on, and generally have a good time -- were to be part of the curriculum. These days, a version of those parties, called Farbfest, held at the Bauhaus building in Dessau, about an hour and a half outside of Berlin, are back. This year's festivities will be on Sept. 2 and 3.

Until World War II, art and antiques dealers were situated near the new hub, along Potsdamer Strasse. In recent years, galleries have taken their place.

Le Filet, a restaurant specializing in seafood, proves that there’s more to the Montreal food scene than meat.

If you earn most of your income on 1099s, brace yourself for extra preparation, paperwork and discussion of your financial picture when applying for a mortgage.

Wisconsin’s addition of the dynamic quarterback Russell Wilson marks an evolution from its between-the-tackles roots.
Paperback books of particular interest.
Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
An avid chronicler of Harry Potter’s exploits, Dan Kois is also the creator of Ron Weasley’s Facebook page and wrote an obituary for Hedwig the owl.
A reader responds to a recent review of “My Faraway One: Selected Letters of Georgia O’Keeffe and Alfred Stieglitz.”
A reader responds to a recent essay on George R. R. Martin.
A reader responds to a recent review of David Deutsch’s “Beginning of Infinity.”
In this illustrated novel, a woman content to be alone meets her mate.
This dystopian novel reveals a world where music is banned and punishment is swift.
A psychologist argues that pronouns, articles, prepositions, auxiliary verbs and conjunctions reflect our interior lives.
The poet Tracy Smith imagines a soundtrack for the universe and mourns her father, who worked on the Hubble Telescope.
A sequel to “The Magicians” revolves around an unexpected quest.
A biography of the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Wendy Wasserstein reveals a full and complicated life.
In Julie Otsuka’s novel, Japanese women sail to America in the early 1900s to become the wives of men they have not met.

Books about the history of smallpox, Shakespeare’s impact, Anna Politkovskaya’s journalistic work in Russia and growing up in the Southern Baptist church.

The creases, the annotations and the blood stains all imprint a book with the fact of my having read it.
Robert Coover’s classic revels in the sun-bright vitality of the game while plumbing its dark truths.
A mother-daughter car trip along Lake Michigan’s eastern shores, stopping at beach towns along the way.
A family car trip along the lake, from New Buffalo to Ludington, included stops at lively beach towns along the way.
New on DVD: Sergei Eisenstein’s “Strike,” from 1925, and films starring the actor Dirk Bogarde.
Joann Sfar’s film about Serge Gainsbourg is not your standard biopic, but a portrait of the chain-smoking, alcohol-fueled singer-songwriter who was a towering culture hero to the French.
Steven Soderbergh’s latest film, “Contagion,” has an all-star cast and a sky-high body count and belongs to the fitfully popular Hollywood genre of the disaster movie.
Faced with persistently low numbers of black members, and a bias lawsuit, the New York Fire Department is undertaking a recruitment drive that is unprecedented in its history.
He has already played the president, Nelson Mandela and God. (Twice.) And his new science show is exactly what we need in these inspiration-deficient times.

Jefferson Friedman is a tough composer to pigeonhole, given his high-energy eclecticism and his penchant for free appropriation of both rock and classical conventions.

Spotify and other music-streaming services online have not yet perfected the seamless playback or refined their search capabilities.

IF Larry Fink were a wildlife photographer, he would have been mauled long ago. Mr. Fink works close -- too close, no doubt, for the comfort of some of his very famous subjects, who appear alternately drunk, dazed and even a little bit scary. As the official photographer for the Vanity Fair Oscar party for roughly a decade, he has made Hollywood events appear as fatiguing as they are fabulous, and his refreshingly aweless impressions are now collected in ''The Vanities'' (Schirmer/Moser, $68). Here is Hugh Hefner, shot from the neck down, seated with two equally headless (but amply bosomed) bunnies. We see even less of Kate Moss (just the back of her legs). Ethan Hawke slumps in front of Julie Delpy, who looks bored. ''These photographs are glimpses of interactive citizens who happen to be idolized and coveted the world around,'' Mr. Fink explains in the introduction. ''But for me, they're just folks.'' STEPHEN HEYMAN
1988 CONTEMPORARY $1,875,000

Partner at Millbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. Board member of Urban Stages and Women's Prison Association. Adored husband of Cathy Pradie, loving father to Peter (Carlisle) and David (who predeceased him); stepfather to Charlotte and Maxime; grandfather to David and Andrew; uncle to Brooks, Curtis and Keogh. A celebration of his life will be held September 16 at 11am at the Church of St. Luke-in-the Fields, 487 Hudson St., New York City. Memorial contributions to Women's Prison Association.

EIGEN--Robert. Our dearest friend for almost 50 years, we will remember all the good times and enjoy recalling them. We send our deepest condolences to Joan, Wendy, David and Cindy and the grandchildren. So long our dear friend, we will miss you so very much. Judy and Burt Resnick and the Resnick Family

An essay last Sunday by the playwright Katori Hall about a staged reading in Russia of her play ''The Mountaintop,'' about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., misspelled the surname of an actor who belongs to the Satirikon theater company in Moscow. His name is Grigory Syatwinda, not Sywatinda.

THERE was a time -- say, from the rise of Grandmaster Flash in the 1970s to the fall of the 42nd Street grindhouse in the '90s -- when a singular trend in portrait photography took root in New York, from Times Square to Harlem to Coney Island. Street photographers, usually wielding Polaroid cameras, set up backdrops airbrushed onto bedsheets, hung those sheets from the gates of shuttered storefronts and invited passers-by to pose in front of them in exchange for small donations. The backdrops, to exercise the imagination slightly, were an urban version of medieval unicorn tapestries, evoking icons like gleaming BMWs or wads of $1,000 bills accompanied by slogans like ''Living Large'' or ''I Wanna Sex You Up.'' For the photographers who used them, like Louis Mendes (''Shaft with a camera,'' a Facebook fan once called him), the backdrops were an easy way to make a little ''coffee money,'' as he put it. For the clientele, they were both souvenirs from a night on the town and pictorial proof of personality. That painted Tweety bird? That's so me, man; that's what I'm about.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

EIGEN--Robert J. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend and devoted supporter Robert Eigen, beloved husband of our esteemed Honorary Overseer Joan Eigen. Robert and Joan, cherished members of the Einstein family, have been passionate supporters of cancer research at the Albert Einstein Cancer Center and have served on our Cancer Research Advisory Board. Robert joined the Einstein Men's Division shortly after its inception in 1961 and served as Chair from 1969-70. Joan is a member of our National Women's Division and a past president of its Westchester/Fairfield Chapter. Their devotion to Einstein inspired Joan's parents, the late Lucille and Edward Kimmel, to become Benefactors and Edward to serve as an Overseer. To Joan and the entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Richard M. Joel, President Yeshiva University Ruth L. Gottesman, Chair Albert Einstein College of Medicine

GOLDBERG--Irwin U.,beloved husband for 55 years of Alice Goldberg, died in Connecticut on August 17 at age 86. Irwin served as a Navigator in the Army Air Force during WWII. After the war, he received a B.A. and an M.A. from the University of Denver. Following executive research and marketing positions at Grey Advertising and General Foods, he and partners formed a marketing consulting firm. His abiding interests in the welfare of children in need stemmed from his knowledge of the childhood experience of his orphaned mother. He devoted years of service to the Jewish Child Care Association, and become President and Chairman. In addition to his adoring wife, he is survived by dear nieces and nephews, sister-in-law, and loving cousins, and by the many children whose lives he enhanced. Irwin's lively sense of humor and extraordinary kindness and empathy inspired in others affection and love. The world is a better place for Irwin's having been here. Donations in Irwin's memory may be made to the Jewish Child Care Association. Memorial Service at the Yale Club on Sunday, September 18 at 3pm.
GRODEN--Lawrence "Larry", 83, passed on August 20, 2011. Played woodwinds with "Big Bands". Graveside service August 29, 2011, 1:30pm Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens.

THE breakout designer Leila Nasseri put fabric right up there with fit when planning to introduce her cool knits line called Whetherly. ''If you want to feel good without trying too hard, that means asking yourself, 'How good does this feel against my skin?,' too,'' Ms. Nasseri said. Choosing lightweight jerseys and the softest supima cotton, then adding silicone and enzyme washes to enhance the way her fabrics take color, she succeeds at turning T-shirts into treasures. To keep your Whetherly's feeling every bit as soft as the day you bought them, Ms. Nasseri said, ''Hand-wash in cold water, air-dry to prevent pilling and fold, don't hang.'' Consider it done. T-shirt, $150; go to p45.com/collections.cfm?start=25. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

If Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck had entered last April's N.F.L. draft, he probably would have been the No. 1 overall pick. Instead, he decided to return to college, giving himself another chance to win the Heisman Trophy and possibly a national title. Luck, who is a redshirt junior but a senior academically, enters this season on top of the college football world. Now he must figure out how to stay there, how to prepare for his pro career, and how to savor a year that should be a highlight in the life of any soon-to-be 22-year-old. There is precedent for him to consider. A small number of star college quarterbacks in recent years also returned for their senior years. With Luck in mind, they and those close to them shared the reasons behind their decisions and what they learned from the experience.
Man on Street (''The Pawnbroker,'' 1964, uncredited) Grand Central Commuter (''Where Were You When the Lights Went Out?'' 1966)

RIEHM--John W. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and long-time Board member, John "Jack" W. Riehm. Jack served on our Board since 1983 and received the United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Trustee Award in 1996. He supported many Montefiore initiatives, most notably, The Children's Hospital at Montefiore which opened in 2001. Montefiore has benefited by his dedication and service. He will be remembered as being so principled, so focused and so decent. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife of 70 years, Doris, his three daughters, Susan Riehm Braden, Sandra Riehm Shepard and husband Joe, Elizabeth Ganin and husband Bruce and son, John Riehm lll, and his entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees

In 2007, Chad D. McEvoy completed a study that examined the N.C.A.A.'s use of major penalties to punish Division I-A football teams from 1987 to 2002. McEvoy found that the teams' mean winning percentage in the five years after penalties were imposed was .566, compared with a .547 winning percentage in the five years before infractions.

Because of an editing error, an essay on Page 11 this weekend, about the religious beliefs of Republican presidential candidates, misstates the proportion of Americans who believe that extraterrestrials live among us. It is about a third, not a majority. The essay also erroneously includes Rick Santorum among politicians affiliated with evangelical Christianity. Mr. Santorum is Catholic.

When we last saw Helen and John Taylor back in 2009, they were breaking the fuel economy record for driving the 48 contiguous states, setting a mark of 67.9 miles per gallon in a Volkswagen Jetta TDI. On Tuesday, they finished another tour of the continental United States, this time in a 2012 Chevrolet Cruze Eco, averaging 64.4 m.p.g. to establish a new mark for a gasoline-powered vehicle. (The Jetta TDI was diesel fueled; Guinness, which confirmed the Taylors' 2009 record, does not distinguish between the two fuels, though diesel engines are generally more fuel efficient.)

ARRICALE--Frank C.,81, of New York City passed away on August 26, 2011. Beloved husband of Maria, devoted father of Frances, Irene and Marc, and adored grandfather of Isabella and Gary. Frank was an extraordinary educator, leader and public servant. He tirelessly served his beloved City of New York in numerous official capacities over his career, including as Commissioner of Relocation/Management Services under Mayor Lindsay's Administration, Executive Director of Personnel for the NYC Board of Education, and Schools Superintendent in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Frank also was devoted to the Catholic Church, and taught religion and theology for 40 years. His family and friends will celebrate his life at a memorial service at Lloyd's Funeral Home in Bayside, Queens on Monday, August 29 from 6-8pm. A funeral mass will be held at St. Brigid's Church in Brooklyn on Tuesday, August 30 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Autism Speaks in his memory. The Arricale Family
An article last Sunday about a boom in Miami Beach summer tourism misstated the title of Guy Chetwynd at the Soho Beach House hotel. He is the national director of sales, not the general manager.

Because of a production error, an entry on the e-book fiction best-seller list on Aug. 14 for ''Playing Dirty'' misstated the author's name and the publisher, and described the plot incorrectly. The author is Susan Andersen -- not Kiki Swinson, the author of a 2009 novel with the same title. And the publisher is HQN, not Kensington. (Andersen's book appeared on the mass-market fiction best-seller list with the correct author, publisher and description.)

NEWMANN--John M.,PhD 70, died peacefully of natural causes in Oakland, CA on August 12, surrounded by his loving family. Born July 11, 1941 in Highland Park, IL, the second son of Harold and Maxine Newmann, John will be remembered for his remarkable resilience, his ability to find humor in any situation, his staunch advocacy for patients with renal and organ failure, his ardent passion for Louis Armstrong and jazz, and his love and complete devotion to his adoring family and many lifelong friends. John graduated cum laude with a BA in Religion from Amherst College in 1963, a PhD in Economics and International Relations from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University, in 1974 and a Masters in Public Health from Harvard University in 1980. He worked for the Ford Foundation from 1967-1978 on economic development, living in Indonesia from 1967-1971 until he was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease and began hemodialysis at age 30. Kidney failure transformed John's and his family's lives. In the early 1970s, he and his family were among the first to perform self-dialysis at home. John became a nationally recognized authority on hemodialysis, patient quality of life and organ donation, and an award-winning consultant to the medical profession, patient and research organizations and government public policy panels. He served on many national boards, including the National Kidney Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing, the American Kidney Fund and the American Association of Kidney Patients, of which he was president for four years. He also served on various task forces for the National Institutes of Health and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Few, if any, institutions concerned with kidney or organ failure did not benefit from John's leadership and guidance. John's first wife, Mary Misch Newmann, preceded him in death by 19 days. They are survived by their daughters, Sara (Doug Sovern), of Berkeley, CA, and Emily (John Darrah), of Cambridge, MA, and their granddaughters Maxine and Sadie Newmann Darrah. John is survived by his life partner for the last two decades, Judy Solomon Engelberg of Chevy Chase, MD, with whom he enjoyed humor, travel, music, art and their close inter-connected families. John is also survived by his second wife, Lisa Aronson Newmann of Housatonic, MA, and by his loving brothers, Fred (Carolyn Hegeler) of Madison, WI and Bill (Rachel) of Olympia, WA. The three brothers were known in the family for their zany antics and for always "sticking together." When he was 11 years old, John met and played piano with Louis Armstrong in Chicago, beginning a cherished friendship that lasted until Armstrong's death in 1971. John's devotion to Satchmo's music continued until the last moments of his own life. As Louis once said, "what we play is life" and what a wonderful life John had. "We'll keep it rolling for you." A celebration of John's life will be held October 29 at 3pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House in Cambridge, MA. Donations in John's memory may be made to the "John Newmann Memorial Fund" at the American Association of Kidney Patients (www.aakp.org) 800-749-2257 and the Louis Armstrong House Museum: www.louisarmstronghouse.org 718-478-8274.

PELL-LIE--Sharon, passed away August 24, 2011. Beloved wife of Carl Lie and cherished daughter, sister, niece, aunt and friend.

POMRENZE--Seymour J. (Sholom). The Yeshiva University family is grieved by the passing of Col. Seymour J. Pomrenze (US Army Retired), z'l, a revered and decorated WWII hero who also received the 2007 National Humanities Award from President George Bush in the White House for his part in rescuing important materials, documents, Torah Scrolls and works of art looted by the Nazis across Europe and restoring them to their rightful owners. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved and devoted wife, Brondell, his son Rabbi Jay Pomrenze, a member of the Yeshiva College Board who with his wife Huti, is a YU Guardian, and his daughters: Hava Levene, Debby Flegg, Haya Pomrenze and Davida Stein Scheinerman and their respective husbands, and all his grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor and RIETS Rosh Hayeshiva

''I have always said that if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple's C.E.O., I would be the first to let you know.'' Steven P. Jobs, who announced his resignation as Apple's chief. Mr. Jobs, who has been on medical leave since January, will become chairman of the company. ''Absolutely, the numbers look too high to us.'' Doug Cliggott, a United States equity strategist at Credit Suisse, on analysts' earnings estimates for the second half of 2011, which have remained high even as economists have ratcheted down their growth forecasts. ''I remain confident that we have the capital and liquidity we need to run our business.'' Brian Moynihan, chief of Bank of America, after Warren Buffett, in a vote of confidence, announced plans to invest $5 billion in the company.

The Local Intelligence column last Sunday, about the majestic staircase at San Francisco City Hall, referred incorrectly to a prohibition against buildings being taller than the United States Capitol. There is no federal law barring a state Capitol from exceeding the height of the federal Capitol.

JAFFE--Anne, The only child of Natalie Turkus and Joseph Blaine, died on August 19th. Born and raised in Brooklyn, she graduated from Erasmus Hall and Brooklyn College. She taught at P.S. 11 until 1960 when she wed Arnold Jaffe and settled in Amsterdam, NY. She leaves behind her husband, two daughters: Alice (Scott Israel) and Anita (Stan Horton), and grandsons Joel and Nate. A free-spirited intellectual, fiercely compassionate and ahead of her time, she will be greatly missed.

Kirk Herbstreit, a former Ohio State quarterback and captain, recently made headlines when he announced that, amid a scandal rocking the Buckeyes' football program, he and his family would move from their home in Columbus, Ohio, to Nashville. He said he was tired of continual criticism from a ''vocal minority'' of Ohio State fans who do not understand that his job as an ESPN analyst requires objectivity. Shortly after moving, he deleted his Twitter account after those fans followed him to the site and, Herbstreit said, wanted him to defend his allegiance to Ohio State, where his father, Jim, was a captain and a coach.

GREENSPAN--Corinne L. passed away at age 90 on August 17th at her home in Palm Beach, Florida. A former New Yorker and devoted wife of the late George Greenspan, she is survived by her son Andrew, her daughter-in-law Andrea, and her grandchildren Benjamin and Samuel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017.

You can help protect the world's natural and cultural resources. The Global Sustainable Tourism Council, a branch of the United Nations, has posted a survey asking for feedback about proposed changes to its minimum standards, which businesses and governments use in tourism and development plans. Countries like Cambodia (above) and Egypt have already adopted the nearly 40 standards set in 2008 (new.gstcouncil.org/resource-center).

From the season's kickoff on Thursday to the Bowl Championship Series title game in New Orleans on Jan. 9, college football offers a wealth of teams, trends and characters to follow. When Joe Paterno became the coach at Penn State in 1966, a gallon of gas cost 32 cents, the Dow Jones industrial average was six years away from cracking 1,000 points for the first time and Nebraska was a member of the Big Eight, still to transition to the Big 12 (and now they're in the Big Ten).

Music was everywhere in the North, it seemed, during the summer of 1861. From presidential appearances to Union rallies, everyone was singing -- usually emotional versions of ''Yankee Doodle'' or ''Hail, Columbia'' or ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' It's forgotten today, but in 1861 America didn't have an official national anthem; each of those songs functioned more or less informally as the nation's rallying cry at some point in its history. The problem was, few could agree which one, if any, was popular enough to stand as the country's official song -- at a time when more and more people thought it needed one. In response, a group of Manhattan power brokers -- lawyers, politicians, businessmen, scholars and a former senator and New York governor -- who called themselves the National Hymn Committee, decided to find a new official anthem.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

From the season's kickoff on Thursday to the Bowl Championship Series title game in New Orleans on Jan. 9, college football offers a wealth of teams, trends and characters to follow. A sixth year of eligibility gives Houston quarterback Case Keenum another shot at rewriting the N.C.A.A. record books. And it gives the Cougars another chance at returning to Bowl Championship Series relevance. Houston rode the nation's highest-scoring offense to 10 wins in 2009, led by Keenum's Football Bowl Subdivision-best 5,632 yards passing and 44 touchdowns, and expectations were high heading into last season.

THE Arts District, sandwiched between downtown Los Angeles and the concrete expanses of the Los Angeles River, is part of the city's industrial core. The area, formed as a Business Improvement District (artsdistrictla.com) in 2006 looks forbidding at first: a no-man's land of factories, cold storage warehouses, cracked streets, peeled paint and broken glass. But for an increasing number of people it has also become one of the city's most appealing, and special, hangouts, as the district has exploded with restaurants, bars, galleries and boutiques -- not to mention artists, who've gobbled up new factory studios and lofts, and often use streetside walls and storefronts as their canvases. Visitors should take an intrepid attitude, though: many places appear derelict outside but reveal savvy and often well-designed surprises within. SAM LUBELL

RIBICOFF--Casey. The patients and staff from the Center for Special Studies at The New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell mourn the loss of our friend and benefactor Casey Ribicoff. From the beginning of the AIDS epidemic Casey was an advocate for the sick and stigmatized. Casey was a founder of the Fete de Famille and, through that benefit, she and a small group of friends worked tirelessly over many years to rally some of the most powerful in our society to the cause of the most vulnerable. Her loyal support and guidance were critical to the development of our program. We will miss her great spirit and friendship. Jonathan Jacobs, M.D Executive Director Samuel Merrick, M.D. Medical Director

From the season's kickoff on Thursday to the Bowl Championship Series title game in New Orleans on Jan. 9, college football offers a wealth of teams, trends and characters to follow. Colorado is in the Pacific-10 - sorry, the Pacific-12. So is Utah. Boise State is in the Mountain West. Nebraska threw away a century-plus of rivalries for inclusion in the Big Ten. What are we going to do without the Victory Bell? (That was awarded to the winner of the Nebraska-Missouri game, but alas.) Texas Christian is joining the Big East, although not until 2012. Fresno State, Hawaii and Nevada will join Boise State in the Mountain West in 2012, and will play out the string in a Western Athletic Conference facing significant questions about its future. The conference will add Texas-San Antonio and Texas State in 2012.

WHITMER--Martin Taylor, 78, of Dallas, TX, died peacefully in Portland, ME on August 13, 2011. His entire immediate loving family was by his side. Born in Manhattan on September 11, 1932, he was the son of Laura Taylor Whitmer, of Haverhill, MA., and Robert Foster Whitmer Jr., of Lancaster, PA. Martin attended Greenwich Country Day School, St. Paul's School, Yale University (1954) (Berzelius/ Zeta Psi), and Harvard Business School (1958). He completed ROTC training and served in the US Army as a 1st Lieutenant where he received the National Service Defense Medal. In 1961 he married Lela Fiesole Hall of Scituate, MA and they lived in Boston and Princeton, NJ while Martin worked for the Cabot Corp. In 1969, Martin and Lela moved to Dallas where he worked for Texas Industries and later as business consultant for Whitmer & Associates. Martin excelled at fly fishing, wing shooting, tennis, skiing, cooking game and photography of the natural elements. He enjoyed reading military history, smoking fine cigars and his annual trip to Prouts Neck, Maine. He devoted time to counseling at the Small Business Administration. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Lela; devoted son, Martin Taylor Whitmer, Jr, and his wife Julie Thurmond Whitmer, adoring daughter, Lele Whitmer McKenry and her husband James R. McKenry, Jr.; sister Laura Taylor Spadone; brother Robert Foster Whitmer, III and his wife Lili Pell Whitmer; brother-in-law E. Winthrop Hall; three precious grandchildren, Martin Taylor Whitmer, III (Tate) Brooks Thurmond Whitmer and Priscilla Gray Moore Whitmer; and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, Martin's family would appreciate donations made to the Scarborough Land Conservation Trust (PO Box 1237, Scarborough, ME 04070-1237), Operation Kindness (3201 Earhart Drive, Carrollton, TX 75006), the Salvation Army or the charity of your choice

Owners of some of Nissan's most popular S.U.V.'s and pickup trucks are experiencing failures of their automatic transmissions because radiator coolant is leaking into the systems. While the automaker has offered an extended warranty for the radiators, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and other safety organizations have received numerous complaints from owners alleging they have spent thousands of dollars for transmission repairs because the added radiator warranty coverage only applied to vehicles with fewer than 80,000 miles.

Tannehill replaced Johnson in A&M's win over Kansas and started the rest of the way, helping the Aggies win six straight before losing in the Cotton Bowl to Louisiana State, 41-24.

Budd Hopkins, a distinguished Abstract Expressionist artist who -- after what he described as a chance sighting of something flat, silver, airborne and unfathomable -- became the father of the alien-abduction movement, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80. The cause was complications of cancer, his daughter, Grace Hopkins-Lisle, said.

An article last Sunday about efforts by a University of Chicago student to make insects a staple of the American diet rendered incorrectly the amount of methane and nitrous oxide emitted in the breeding of many edible insects compared with livestock. It is one-tenth and one three-hundredth, respectively, not 10 times less and 300 times less. The article also misstated the amount of pork that is produced by 10 grams of livestock feed. It is three grams, not three pounds.

STOTHERS--Richard Blair, age 72, died on June 28, 2011 at his home. Survived by his brother, Hedley Stothers, his nephews Josh Nims, Seth Nims and Hedley Stothers III, and his nieces Ruth Stothers Dolan and Sarah Stothers. Predeceased by his sister, Susan Stothers Nims. Graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Princeton University and Harvard University. Richard Stothers walked into the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies in June 1961, a first-year graduate student looking for a summer job, carrying a one-paragraph note from a professor recommending him simply as a "very good man". Within two years, he published four papers in the most prestigious journal, the Astrophysical Journal, received his Ph.D. from Harvard and became a permanent staff member of the Goddard Institute, where he worked the rest of his life. He became a world expert on the structure of stars, as well as their origin and evolution. It was Dr. Stothers' work and technical advice that stimulated Dr. Robert Jastrow, the founding director of the Goddard Institute, to write his famous book, Red Giants and White Dwarfs. Dr. Stothers was a scholar of classical mold, able to read original papers in several languages. He published almost 200 papers, mostly in astrophysics and solar physics. In the last two decades of his life he spent much of his time on climate science, especially investigating ancient writings to extract information on climate change throughout recorded history. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Community Fund, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

RIEHM--John (Jack) Wilk, longtime resident of Bronxville, New York, died 26 August 2011, of natural causes at his home in Tucson, Arizona. Born in 1920 in Peoria, Illinois, to John and Martha Riehm. He was awarded a Bachelor of Science with Honors from Bradley University. With the outbreak of World War II, he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and married the love of his life Doris Pancratz. After the war, he completed his Juris Doctorate at the University of Michigan and accepted a position with the New York law firm Cravath, Swain and Moore. He left New York for Dallas, Texas, and the SMU School of Law where he started as an Associate Professor and rose to Dean of the Law School. As Dean, he initiated programs that would lead to a Doctor of Science Law degree, Comparative Law for Latin American lawyers and the creation of the Southwest Graduate School of Banking at SMU. He was responsible for the move of the Journal of Aviation Law and Commerce to the SMU Law School. He served several terms of office with the Southwestern Legal Foundation. In 1963, he moved back to New York as Director and Executive Vice-President of Matthew Bender Law Publishing and then to Thomas J. Lipton as Secretary and General Counsel. He retired from Lipton as Executive Vice-President. Not one to really retire, he began the venture capital business R&G Ventures, Inc. He served on the Boards of Lipton, Unilever, US Life Corporation, and the Board of Montefiore Medical Center, part of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was a Director of US Life Insurance Company and President of Freedom House. John's interest in law, economics and aviation continued after his retirement. He was a voracious reader, four newspapers a day as well as best sellers. His favorite activity was the forty summers he spent at the ranch, Spear-O-Wigwam, in the Big Horn Mountains of Wyoming. His sweet tooth was with him to the end. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Doris Riehm, his three daughters, Susan Riehm Braden of San Marcos, Texas, Sandra Riehm Shepard and husband Joe of Tyler, Texas, Elizabeth Ganin and husband Bruce of Tucson, Arizona, son John Riehm III of Tucson, Arizona, five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The family would like to thank their neighbor Dave Edwards, the caregivers of Home Instead and Hospice for the special care you provided. The family will have a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

THERE'S nothing stale about Fresh's new retail concept. The beauty brand's fragrant flagship in Manhattan's Union Square has been completely redesigned by Mapos, a young architecture firm headed by two former Peter Marino disciples. Inspired by old-world bakeries, laboratories and apothecaries, the space is bisected by a massive reclaimed walnut ''kitchen'' table that contains stacks of vintage botanical books and offers a comfy place to perch while testing products. Custom and antique details abound, including an old English communal wash basin, a Sensorial Bar (where formerly discontinued fragrances are available on tap) and a large glass display case that makes Fresh's prettily packaged soaps look like confections in a pastry shop. At 872 Broadway; (212) 477-1100. SANDRA BALLENTINE

CECIL BEATON produced a torrent of work, not unlike Andy Warhol and Takashi Murakami, who collaborated with Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton. In a new book, ''Cecil Beaton: The New York Years,'' Donald Albrecht suggests that his methods of working in a variety of media, his blurring of the lines between art and commerce, and his promotional skills made him ''remarkably prescient.'' Certainly Beaton was able to move from one medium to another: fashion photography, portraiture, illustration, costume and set design. I'm sure many designers today wish they could be liberated from their studio bunkers; the demands of work keep them pinned down like enemy fire. A few have time to express themselves in other media (and I don't mean HSN), but most have to do their dreaming with pins and fabric and mood boards. It's not so bad.

Texas A&M's time as a member of the Big 12 Conference is all but over. In a conference call Saturday that included the Big 12's university presidents, R. Bowen Loftin, the president of Texas A&M, essentially said the Aggies were leaving, and there was nothing the Big 12 could do to keep them, according to a person with firsthand knowledge of the call. Multiple presidents on the call used the words ''amicable divorce'' when discussing the Aggies' departure. That would seem to suggest that there will not be any legal wrangling. Paramount in negotiations to allow Texas A&M to leave the conference is the university's buyout, which is estimated in the $15 million range. While no timetable was discussed, the feeling on the call was that the Aggies' departure could happen as soon as the end of next week.

The Height of Spectacle: A Stopover in Dubai We've been invited to a wedding in Mumbai next February and plan to fly there via Dubai, stopping off for two to three days. We'll be four to six adults, ages 25 to 59. Can you suggest the best way to make use of our stopover? We like a bit of adventure along with the must-see items. No bungee jumping, but lots of walking and hiking are fine.

ODD COUPLES: Dog books have long been a staple of the best-seller list. But has the world ever seen as probing a work of zoological investigative reporting as ''Unlikely Friendships: 47 Remarkable Stories From the Animal Kingdom''? Jennifer S. Holland's irresistible volume, No. 7 in its sixth week on the paperback nonfiction list, features heartwarming stories of interspecies love and adorable photographs that are heart-stopping in more than one sense. Everything seems copacetic between the nearsighted deer and the black poodle shown canoodling on a bed in Canal Fulton, Ohio, but one wonders about the long-term stability of the relationship between the polar bear and the sled dog shown cavorting in the Canadian Arctic, not to mention the lioness and baby oryx shown strolling together in Kenya's Samburu National Reserve. Might a sequel resemble a slasher movie more than an Animal Planet special? Holland quotes a conservationist speculating that the lioness (nicknamed Kamunyak, or ''Blessed One,'' in tribute to her ''almost biblical'' behavior), who serially adopted five more baby oryxes after the first one was devoured by a male lion, may have lost her pride at a critical moment in her development, thus fueling her ''quirky obsession.'' ''Kamunyak and the calf are a living paradox,'' the conservationist said. ''Their intimacy defies the laws of nature.''

Riehm. Jack served on our Board since 1983 and received the United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Trustee Award in 1996. He supported many Montefiore initiatives, most notably, The Children's Hospital at Montefiore which opened in 2001. Montefiore has benefited by his dedication and service. He will be remembered as being so principled, so focused and so decent. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife of 70 years, Doris, his three daughters, Susan Riehm Braden, Sandra Riehm Shepard and husband Joe, Elizabeth Ganin and husband Bruce and son, John Riehm lll, and his entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees

Jim Thome's 600th home run landed in the bullpen. Derek Jeter's 3,000th hit - a home run - found a fan who gave the ball right back. The Oakland Athletics' Hideki Matsui was not as lucky. Matsui crunched his 168th major league homer on July 20; combined with his 332 in Japan, it was his 500th home run. The ball landed in the right-field stands in Detroit, and Matsui hoped to get it for his father, who runs a museum dedicated to him in Japan. But the fan declined the A's offers of signed memorabilia.

SMITH--Ralph K. 85, of Locust Valley, NY on August 23. Attorney, beloved partner and father, devoted friend and volunteer, graduated from Sewickley, PA High School in 1942, joined the 63rd Infantry Division of the Army in 1943, receiving a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. Graduated Dartmouth College in 1948 Phi Beta Kappa, President of Delta Tau Fraternity. At Harvard Law School served as president of the Chancery Club. Partner at Sage Gray Todd and Sims 1951-1986, Townley & Updike 19871995, Snow Becker Krauss 1996-2011. Numerous volunteer positions include Trustee/VP of Seamen's Church Institute; Governor, Chairman of Executive Committee Hundred Year Association of New York; Governor of the Creek Club; Trustee Green Vale School. Survivors include longtime partner Faye Argentine of New York, NY; daughter Hillary Goodridge of Boston, MA; son Russell Smith of Mamaroneck, NY; granddaughter Annie Goodridge of Boston, MA; sisters Anne Smith VanderWolk of Pinehurst, NC and Margaret Smith Wenzel, M.D. of Naples, FL; brother Jay Smith of Princeton, NJ; sister-in-law Suzi Smith of Collinsville, CT; former wife Ann K. Smith of Vero Beach FL; thirteen nieces and nephews. Ralph touched so many with his incredible generosity, humor and zest for living. He will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues, clients and many friends. Services private.

SIKIRICA--Stanley, SGM US Army (ret.), died August 25, 2011 of cancer in Buffalo at the age of 84. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Maud (Ahrens) and daughters, Karin, Janet (Gregory Barton), Eileen Torre (Nelson), and Chloe. Proud grandfather of Barrett and Sam Torre, Pim and Bruno McCarthy and Noah Barton. A decorated war hero serving 30 years during WWII, Korea and Vietnam, he was the recipient of many medals for his leadership and courage. A FULL FLOOR condominium at the Residences at the Ritz-Carlton at 50 Central Park South, selling for $30 million, was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.There was no record on Streeteasy.com of an official listing for the nearly 6,000 square-foot apartment, so it may have changed hands directly between the buyer and the seller. The seller was Scott A. Bommer, a hedge-fund manager whose quick 2008 sale of his co-op at 1060 Fifth Avenue for $48.5 million -- at a $2.5 million dollar profit six months after he bought it -- made a big splash in real estate circles. Now he has made a $1.5 million profit on the Ritz Carlton condo, although it has been on and off the market since 2008, when he listed it for $35 million, less than four months after buying it. Mr. Bommer, the founder of SAB Capital Management, paid $28.5 million for the Ritz Carlton condo in July 2008. A previous listing described the apartment as having four bedrooms, four bathrooms, 27 large windows and three terraces, providing multiple views of the park and Fifth Avenue.The buyer was listed under a limitedliability company Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previous week, ending Wednesday. E-mail: bigdeal@nytimes.com

Does our society devote too much time and money to education? In a Room for Debate forum, Peter Thiel, a co-founder of PayPal, argues that college is a waste for many. Some comments in response follow. The full debate is at nytimes.com/roomfordebate. PETER THIEL Talented, motivated, creative people tend to earn more than their peers throughout life. In today's world, they're also more likely to complete college. Colleges, for obvious reasons, claim that they make all the difference. There's a similar difference in earnings between Brooklynites who work in Manhattan and Brooklynites who work in Brooklyn. Anyone who thinks that crossing the Brooklyn Bridge makes people more productive should think about buying it.

A picnic at the elk rut viewing area at the Charles M. Russell Wildlife Refuge in Montana may not sound romantic, but it is a rare opportunity to see the mating rituals of one of the largest congregations of elk in the West. In September, visitors to the Great Plains will get to do that and more, when the American Prairie Foundation, an organization that works toward preserving and cultivating North America's Great Plains and its history, partners with the Yellowstone Safari Company to offer the first commercial tour of the American Prairie Reserve. The five-day safari costs $2,350 per person based on double occupancy, and will include transportation from Great Falls, Mont., and accommodations at the Grand Union Inn in Fort Benton and at the American Prairie Foundation's lodge. (For more information, 866-586-1155, yellowstonesafari.com.)

SMITH--Ralph K. 85, of Locust Valley, NY on August 23. Attorney, beloved partner and father, devoted friend and volunteer, graduated from Sewickley, PA High School in 1942, joined the 63rd Infantry Division of the Army in 1943, receiving a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. Graduated Dartmouth College in 1948 Phi Beta Kappa, President of Delta Tau Fraternity. At Harvard Law School served as president of the Chancery Club. Partner at Sage Gray Todd and Sims 1951-1986, Townley & Updike 19871995, Snow Becker Krauss 1996-2011. Numerous volunteer positions include Trustee/VP of Seamen's Church Institute; Governor, Chairman of Executive Committee Hundred Year Association of New York; Governor of the Creek Club; Trustee Green Vale School. Survivors include longtime partner Faye Argentine of New York, NY; daughter Hillary Goodridge of Boston, MA; son Russell Smith of Mamaroneck, NY; granddaughter Annie Goodridge of Boston, MA; sisters Anne Smith VanderWolk of Pinehurst, NC and Margaret Smith Wenzel, M.D. of Naples, FL; brother Jay Smith of Princeton, NJ; sister-in-law Suzi Smith of Collinsville, CT; former wife Ann K. Smith of Vero Beach FL; thirteen nieces and nephews. Ralph touched so many with his incredible generosity, humor and zest for living. He will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues, clients and many friends. Services private.

ARRICALE--Frank C.,81, of New York City passed away on August 26, 2011. Beloved husband of Maria, devoted father of Frances, Irene and Marc, and adored grandfather of Isabella and Gary. Frank was an extraordinary educator, leader and public servant. He tirelessly served his beloved City of New York in numerous official capacities over his career, including as Commissioner of Relocation/Management Services under Mayor Lindsay's Administration, Executive Director of Personnel for the NYC Board of Education, and Schools Superintendent in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Frank also was devoted to the Catholic Church, and taught religion and theology for 40 years. His family and friends will celebrate his life at a memorial service at Lloyd's Funeral Home in Bayside, Queens on Monday, August 29 from 6-8pm. A funeral mass will be held at St. Brigid's Church in Brooklyn on Tuesday, August 30 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Autism Speaks in his memory. The Arricale Family

RIEHM--John W. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and long-time Board member, John "Jack" W. Riehm. Jack served on our Board since 1983 and received the United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Trustee Award in 1996. He supported many Montefiore initiatives, most notably, The Children's Hospital at Montefiore which opened in 2001. Montefiore has benefited by his dedication and service. He will be remembered as being so principled, so focused and so decent. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife of 70 years, Doris, his three daughters, Susan Riehm Braden, Sandra Riehm Shepard and husband Joe, Elizabeth Ganin and husband Bruce and son, John Riehm lll, and his entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees

RAIFF--Stanley, 81, husband and long-term partner of Dr. Howard Coron, Professor Emeritus of NYU's Steinhardt School of Education, died on July 19th. He was cremated. Stan and Howard were together for 41 years. Stan was an entrepreneur and his greatest love was the theatre. At 18 he went to Syracuse University and got both a Bachelors and Masters degrees in Speech and Hearing and Teaching English to secondary students. At Syracuse University he had a childrens' theatre company. He produced two long running TV series, The Tinker Shop and Through Childrens' Eyes for which he won a regional Emmy. Stan then went on to be a special teacher in Virginia for three years. Here too he had a TV and radio program. In his twenties he produced and directed in summer stock, regional theatres and in New York City at the Theatre de Lys. Stan then became a business person. His positions among others included being the director of publicity and promotion for North and South America for Alitalia Airlines and the editor and writer for the European Travel Commission. Educational programs for schools sponsored by major corporations followed for which he won industry awards. Stan went back to producing educational programs. His Catskill IDEA program, an after school program was considered by New York State officials as one of the best in the State. Stan was deeply concerned about abused children and animals throughout his life. He wrote for many newspapers and magazines and also wrote a travel book for children going to Europe, called "Get Ready, Get Set, Go" published by Random House. Stan leaves behind his partner Howard and Howard's sons and their families, his brother Keith and family, cousins and friends. He will be sorely missed. On their 25th anniversary Stan and Howard had a Jewish Commitment ceremony and were married in 2007 in Vancouver, Canada. They showed others that same sex marriages can enrich and support families and communities.

TRATTNER--Andrew Martin, of Lake Mary, Florida, died unexpectedly of a heart attack on August 3rd, 2011. He was 53 years old. Husband of Joanne, beloved father of Samantha and Jonathan, adored son of Richard and the late Norma Trattner, caring brother of Kenneth, stepson of Eileen and son-in-law of Dr. Gordon and Stella Fink. Andrew was raised in Hewlett, L.I. and was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. He spent most of his career in software development and information technology. He was president along with his wife Joanne of Lakeside Design a company specializing in products for the gift, craft and stationery industries. Andrew was very active in the Orlando Jewish community serving on several Temple Boards and was a key player in establishing Orlando's sister city project in Israel. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to his favorite organizations ARZA, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY or NFTY, 633 Third Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10017.
WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30--8/30/03. In my heart always. Your daughter, Wendy

Last week's Metropolitan cover article, ''The High Price of Looking Like a Woman,'' by Laura Rena Murray, spurred outrage and debate online about the widespread use of silicone injections by transgender women -- many of whom turn to so-called pumpers who practice illegally and often end up disfiguring their clients' bodies. Following are excerpts from the discussion on NYTimes.com. Readers also reacted to Neil Genzlinger's City Critic column about New York practices he would like to see ticketed. This was heartbreaking. I hope that an investigation and crackdown is launched to prosecute these hack ''doctors.'' It is so wrong, on every level.

An article last Sunday about the third round of the Senior Players Championship misidentified the golf course where the tournament was held from 1991 to 2006. It was at TPC Michigan in Dearborn -- not at Dearborn Country Club, which hosted the tournament in 1990.

At 21, Mike Stanton of the Marlins is already putting himself in elite company. With only two more home runs this season, he will be in the top 10 of players to hit 54 career home runs by the season in which they turned 21.* Stanton hits them with frequency (his at-bat-per- home run ratio is second highest on the list), and with power (his home runs this season have traveled an average of 418 feet, with four going farther than 450 feet.)

SWARTSBERG--Mildred Kronenberg, a resident of Mill Valley for 34 years, died peacefully in her sleep, at home, Saturday, August 20th, 2011 on the 99th birthday of her late husband Jerry Swartsberg. A graduate of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, Class of 1933, Mildred had a passion for all the arts, sports and The New York Times crossword puzzle. She was great at anything she tried. She was one smart cookie! She is survived by her daughters Karen Swartsberg of Boothbay, Maine, and Janie Teitelbaum of San Rafael, California.

BELENKY--Allen A. Dad, It has been 44 years since you left us, but your love, compassion and creativity are eternal. I see you each day in your original paintings which adorn my home. Missing you always. Love, Katrin

A review on Aug. 7 about ''The Pirates of Somalia,'' by Jay Bahadur, attributed an erroneous distinction to the hijacking of the United States cargo ship Maersk Alabama by Somali pirates in 2009. It was one of several -- not the first -- American-flagged vessels to be seized within 200 years. (At least two other such incidents preceded the Maersk Alabama one. In 1968, North Korean forces seized the U.S.S. Pueblo, a Navy intelligence-gathering ship, and in 1975, the Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodia seized the United States merchant ship Mayagüez.) The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, The New York Times Book Review, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018. The e-mail address is books@nytimes.com.
BANTA--Melissa Wickser, a long-time contributor to the State University of New York at Buffalo and the local Buffalo arts scene, died on August 18th, her 86th birthday.

STOTHERS--Richard Blair, age 72, died on June 28, 2011 at his home. Survived by his brother, Hedley Stothers, his nephews Josh Nims, Seth Nims and Hedley Stothers III, and his nieces Ruth Stothers Dolan and Sarah Stothers. Predeceased by his sister, Susan Stothers Nims. Graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Princeton University and Harvard University. Richard Stothers walked into the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies in June 1961, a first-year graduate student looking for a summer job, carrying a one-paragraph note from a professor recommending him simply as a "very good man". Within two years, he published four papers in the most prestigious journal, the Astrophysical Journal, received his Ph.D. from Harvard and became a permanent staff member of the Goddard Institute, where he worked the rest of his life. He became a world expert on the structure of stars, as well as their origin and evolution. It was Dr. Stothers' work and technical advice that stimulated Dr. Robert Jastrow, the founding director of the Goddard Institute, to write his famous book, Red Giants and White Dwarfs. Dr. Stothers was a scholar of classical mold, able to read original papers in several languages. He published almost 200 papers, mostly in astrophysics and solar physics. In the last two decades of his life he spent much of his time on climate science, especially investigating ancient writings to extract information on climate change throughout recorded history. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Community Fund, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

An article on Aug. 14 about the Greek island of Hydra, which has become a stronghold of contemporary artists, misstated the distance of the island from Athens and the body of water that diners at a taverna there would have seen. It is about 45 miles from Athens, not 120 miles, and the taverna would have looked out over the Saronic Gulf, not the Aegean Sea. And because of an editing error, the article erroneously attributed a distinction to the island. It is not a Unesco World Heritage Site.

NEWMANN--John M.,PhD 70, died peacefully of natural causes in Oakland, CA on August 12, surrounded by his loving family. Born July 11, 1941 in Highland Park, IL, the second son of Harold and Maxine Newmann, John will be remembered for his remarkable resilience, his ability to find humor in any situation, his staunch advocacy for patients with renal and organ failure, his ardent passion for Louis Armstrong and jazz, and his love and complete devotion to his adoring family and many lifelong friends. John graduated cum laude with a BA in Religion from Amherst College in 1963, a PhD in Economics and International Relations from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University, in 1974 and a Masters in Public Health from Harvard University in 1980. He worked for the Ford Foundation from 1967-1978 on economic development, living in Indonesia from 1967-1971 until he was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease and began hemodialysis at age 30. Kidney failure transformed John's and his family's lives. In the early 1970s, he and his family were among the first to perform self-dialysis at home. John became a nationally recognized authority on hemodialysis, patient quality of life and organ donation, and an award-winning consultant to the medical profession, patient and research organizations and government public policy panels. He served on many national boards, including the National Kidney Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing, the American Kidney Fund and the American Association of Kidney Patients, of which he was president for four years. He also served on various task forces for the National Institutes of Health and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Few, if any, institutions concerned with kidney or organ failure did not benefit from John's leadership and guidance. John's first wife, Mary Misch Newmann, preceded him in death by 19 days. They are survived by their daughters, Sara (Doug Sovern), of Berkeley, CA, and Emily (John Darrah), of Cambridge, MA, and their granddaughters Maxine and Sadie Newmann Darrah. John is survived by his life partner for the last two decades, Judy Solomon Engelberg of Chevy Chase, MD, with whom he enjoyed humor, travel, music, art and their close inter-connected families. John is also survived by his second wife, Lisa Aronson Newmann of Housatonic, MA, and by his loving brothers, Fred (Carolyn Hegeler) of Madison, WI and Bill (Rachel) of Olympia, WA. The three brothers were known in the family for their zany antics and for always "sticking together." When he was 11 years old, John met and played piano with Louis Armstrong in Chicago, beginning a cherished friendship that lasted until Armstrong's death in 1971. John's devotion to Satchmo's music continued until the last moments of his own life. As Louis once said, "what we play is life" and what a wonderful life John had. "We'll keep it rolling for you." A celebration of John's life will be held October 29 at 3pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House in Cambridge, MA. Donations in John's memory may be made to the "John Newmann Memorial Fund" at the American Association of Kidney Patients (www.aakp.org) 800-749-2257 and the Louis Armstrong House Museum: www.louisarmstronghouse.org 718-478-8274.

AUFFARTH--Hank. The Board and Staff of The Child Center of NY mourns the sudden passing of Hank Auffarth, revered board member for 30 years, 13 as its President. While his professional accomplishments were within the banking industry, they paled in comparison to his charitable work with our agency. Hank was an extraordinary ambassador on behalf of the children we serve and worked tirelessly to provide thousands of at-risk kids with the tools they need to succeed in life. Dick Jay, Board President Sandra Hagan, Executive Director

RIBICOFF--Casey ( Lois ), a woman of exceptional character, dignity and style. Beloved widow of Senator Abraham A Ribicoff. Loving Mother of Peter and his wife Angela. Proud Grandmother of Andrew, Jake and Jessica. Caring Sister of June Herman of Indianapolis. She was devoted and grateful to all of her loving friends who became family to her. She loved them all dearly. She served on the Board of the John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for 20 years. She also served on the Board of WNET for over 20 years and retired as Honorary Vice Chairman. She was a founding member with Bill Blass, Judy Peabody, and Glenn Bernbaum of the AIDS Care Center at New York Hospital. She loved every minute of her life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Weill Cornell Medical College, in memory of Casey Ribicoff, for the Dr. J. Ruggiero Research Fund, 1300 York Avenue, Box 314, New York, NY 10065. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St, (5th Ave) on Tuesday, September 20 at 11am.

POMRENZE--Seymour J. (Sholom). The Yeshiva University family is grieved by the passing of Col. Seymour J. Pomrenze (US Army Retired), z'l, a revered and decorated WWII hero who also received the 2007 National Humanities Award from President George Bush in the White House for his part in rescuing important materials, documents, Torah Scrolls and works of art looted by the Nazis across Europe and restoring them to their rightful owners. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved and devoted wife, Brondell, his son Rabbi Jay Pomrenze, a member of the Yeshiva College Board who with his wife Huti, is a YU Guardian, and his daughters: Hava Levene, Debby Flegg, Haya Pomrenze and Davida Stein Scheinerman and their respective husbands, and all his grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor and RIETS Rosh Hayeshiva

SWARTSBERG--Mildred Kronenberg, a resident of Mill Valley for 34 years, died peacefully in her sleep, at home, Saturday, August 20th, 2011 on the 99th birthday of her late husband Jerry Swartsberg. A graduate of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, Class of 1933, Mildred had a passion for all the arts, sports and The New York Times crossword puzzle. She was great at anything she tried. She was one smart cookie! She is survived by her daughters Karen Swartsberg of Boothbay, Maine, and Janie Teitelbaum of San Rafael, California.

SIKIRICA--Stanley, SGM US Army (ret.), died August 25, 2011 of cancer in Buffalo at the age of 84. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Maud (Ahrens) and daughters, Karin, Janet (Gregory Barton), Eileen Torre (Nelson), and Chloe. Proud grandfather of Barrett and Sam Torre, Pim and Bruno McCarthy and Noah Barton. A decorated war hero serving 30 years during WWII, Korea and Vietnam, he was the recipient of many medals for his leadership and courage. Youngest of nine, born November 20, 1926 in Johnstown, PA to Katherine (Sobecky) and Peter Sikirica. Donations may be made to the Glaucoma Research Foundation or ASPCA.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Julius, M.D.,96. Died of congestive heart failure, August 24, 2011, Tiburon, CA. Survived by wife of 64 years, Nanette, two sons, Peter and Stephen, two grandchildren, Julia and Theo. JAFFE--Anne, The only child of Natalie Turkus and Joseph Blaine, died on August 19th. Born and raised in Brooklyn, she graduated from Erasmus Hall and Brooklyn College. She taught at P.S. 11 until 1960 when she wed Arnold Jaffe and settled in Amsterdam, NY. She leaves behind her husband, two daughters: Alice (Scott Israel) and Anita (Stan Horton), and grandsons Joel and Nate. A free-spirited intellectual, fiercely compassionate and ahead of her time, she will be greatly missed.

Some of the tributes to Mike Flanagan, the former Baltimore and Toronto left-hander who died last week, mentioned the game he pitched on the next-to-last day of the 1987 season. The Blue Jays were tied with the Tigers for the American League East lead, and Flanagan pitched 11 innings of a 12-inning loss in Detroit. Since that day, only one pitcher has ever worked more innings in a game: Andy Hawkins for the Yankees on July 6, 1990, in the first game of a doubleheader against Minnesota. Hawkins pitched 112/3 innings but gave up two runs and lost, 2-0. In his previous start, Hawkins had thrown an eight-inning no-hitter in Chicago and lost, 4-0. Neither feat -- allowing four runs in a no-hitter, or pitching into the 12th inning of a game -- seems likely to be repeated.

RIEHM--John (Jack) Wilk, longtime resident of Bronxville, New York, died 26 August 2011, of natural causes at his home in Tucson, Arizona. Born in 1920 in Peoria, Illinois, to John and Martha Riehm. He was awarded a Bachelor of Science with Honors from Bradley University. With the outbreak of World War II, he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and married the love of his life Doris Pancratz. After the war, he completed his Juris Doctorate at the University of Michigan and accepted a position with the New York law firm Cravath, Swain and Moore. He left New York for Dallas, Texas, and the SMU School of Law where he started as an Associate Professor and rose to Dean of the Law School. As Dean, he initiated programs that would lead to a Doctor of Science Law degree, Comparative Law for Latin American lawyers and the creation of the Southwest Graduate School of Banking at SMU. He was responsible for the move of the Journal of Aviation Law and Commerce to the SMU Law School. He served several terms of office with the Southwestern Legal Foundation. In 1963, he moved back to New York as Director and Executive Vice-President of Matthew Bender Law Publishing and then to Thomas J. Lipton as Secretary and General Counsel. He retired from Lipton as Executive Vice-President. Not one to really retire, he began the venture capital business R&G Ventures, Inc. He served on the Boards of Lipton, Unilever, US Life Corporation, and the Board of Montefiore Medical Center, part of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was a Director of US Life Insurance Company and President of Freedom House. John's interest in law, economics and aviation continued after his retirement. He was a voracious reader, four newspapers a day as well as best sellers. His favorite activity was the forty summers he spent at the ranch, Spear-O-Wigwam, in the Big Horn Mountains of Wyoming. His sweet tooth was with him to the end. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Doris Riehm, his three daughters, Susan Riehm Braden of San Marcos, Texas, Sandra Riehm Shepard and husband Joe of Tyler, Texas, Elizabeth Ganin and husband Bruce of Tucson, Arizona, son John Riehm III of Tucson, Arizona, five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The family would like to thank their neighbor Dave Edwards, the caregivers of Home Instead and Hospice for the special care you provided. The family will have a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

TRATTNER--Andrew Martin, of Lake Mary, Florida, died unexpectedly of a heart attack on August 3rd, 2011. He was 53 years old. Husband of Joanne, beloved father of Samantha and Jonathan, adored son of Richard and the late Norma Trattner, caring brother of Kenneth, stepson of Eileen and son-in-law of Dr. Gordon and Stella Fink. Andrew was raised in Hewlett, L.I. and was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. He spent most of his career in software development and information technology. He was president along with his wife Joanne of Lakeside Design a company specializing in products for the gift, craft and stationery industries. Andrew was very active in the Orlando Jewish community serving on several Temple Boards and was a key player in establishing Orlando's sister city project in Israel. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Donations in his memory may be made to his favorite organizations ARZA, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY or NFTY, 633 Third Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

BELENKY--Allen A. Dad, It has been 44 years since you left us, but your love, compassion and creativity are eternal. I see you each day in your original paintings which adorn my home. Missing you always. Love, Katrin

9 P.M. (MTV) 2011 MTV VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS The awards dare to go hostless at this annual ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. Nominees for best new artist include Big Sean, Foster the People, Kreayshawn, Wiz Khalifa and Tyler, the Creator. Competing for best pop video are ''Rolling in the Deep,'' by Adele, above; ''Till the World Ends,'' by Britney Spears; ''Grenade,'' by Bruno Mars; ''Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.),'' by Katy Perry; and ''Give Me Everything,'' by Pitfull, featuring Ne-Yo, Mayer and Afrojack. Among those scheduled to perform are Beyoncé, Bruno Mars, Chris Brown, Lady Gaga and Lil Wayne. Red carpet reporting begins at 8. 6:45 A.M. (Showtime) THE GHOST WRITER (2010) In this moody tale from Roman Polanski, Ewan McGregor is ''at his ingénue best'' as a writer for hire, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. His job is to clean up the unfinished memoir of Adam Lang, a former British prime minister played by ''a superb Pierce Brosnan,'' after the previous writer has washed up on an American beach. Olivia Williams is Lang's wife, a brainy beauty with secrets. And the Langs' marital relationship is meant to evoke that of Cherie Booth and Tony Blair. Mr. Polanski delivers ''this pulpy fun at such a high level that 'The Ghost Writer' is irresistible, no matter how obvious the twists,'' Ms. Dargis added. ''The pleasures of a well-directed movie should never be underestimated.''

NEWMANN--John M.,PhD 70, died peacefully of natural causes in Oakland, CA on August 12, surrounded by his loving family. Born July 11, 1941 in Highland Park, IL, the second son of Harold and Maxine Newmann, John will be remembered for his remarkable resilience, his ability to find humor in any situation, his staunch advocacy for patients with renal and organ failure, his ardent passion for Louis Armstrong and jazz, and his love and complete devotion to his adoring family and many lifelong friends. John graduated cum laude with a BA in Religion from Amherst College in 1963, a PhD in Economics and International Relations from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University, in 1974 and a Masters in Public Health from Harvard University in 1980. He worked for the Ford Foundation from 1967-1978 on economic development, living in Indonesia from 1967-1971 until he was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease and began hemodialysis at age 30. Kidney failure transformed John's and his family's lives. In the early 1970s, he and his family were among the first to perform self-dialysis at home. John became a nationally recognized authority on hemodialysis, patient quality of life and organ donation, and an award-winning consultant to the medical profession, patient and research organizations and government public policy panels. He served on many national boards, including the National Kidney Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing, the American Kidney Fund and the American Association of Kidney Patients, of which he was president for four years. He also served on various task forces for the National Institutes of Health and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Few, if any, institutions concerned with kidney or organ failure did not benefit from John's leadership and guidance. John's first wife, Mary Misch Newmann, preceded him in death by 19 days. They are survived by their daughters, Sara (Doug Sovern), of Berkeley, CA, and Emily (John Darrah), of Cambridge, MA, and their granddaughters Maxine and Sadie Newmann Darrah. John is survived by his life partner for the last two decades, Judy Solomon Engelberg of Chevy Chase, MD, with whom he enjoyed humor, travel, music, art and their close inter-connected families. John is also survived by his second wife, Lisa Aronson Newmann of Housatonic, MA, and by his loving brothers, Fred (Carolyn Hegeler) of Madison, WI and Bill (Rachel) of Olympia, WA. The three brothers were known in the family for their zany antics and for always "sticking together." When he was 11 years old, John met and played piano with Louis Armstrong in Chicago, beginning a cherished friendship that lasted until Armstrong's death in 1971. John's devotion to Satchmo's music continued until the last moments of his own life. As Louis once said, "what we play is life" and what a wonderful life John had. "We'll keep it rolling for you." A celebration of John's life will be held October 29 at 3pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House in Cambridge, MA. Donations in John's memory may be made to the "John Newmann Memorial Fund" at the American Association of Kidney Patients (www.aakp.org) 800-749-2257 and the Louis Armstrong House Museum: www.louisarmstronghouse.org 718-478-8274.
WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30--8/30/03. In my heart always. Your daughter, Wendy

WASHINGTON -- Determined to avoid any comparisons with the federal government's failed response to Hurricane Katrina, the Obama administration made a public display Saturday of the range of its efforts to make sure officials in the storm-drenched states had whatever help they needed from Washington. President Obama, who returned to Washington a day early from his summer vacation on Martha's Vineyard, visited the headquarters of the Federal Emergency Management Agency shortly after noon. While there, he checked in on the National Response Coordination Center, a 24-hour command center based at FEMA, where dozens of federal employees from a range of agencies were assembled around the clock to help orchestrate the response to Hurricane Irene.

Josephine Potuto got a close look at the N.C.A.A.'s methodology for punishing universities while serving nine years on the committee on infractions, including as the chairwoman from 2006 to 2008. Potuto says the N.C.A.A. should eliminate rules like the one that restricts coaches from sending text messages to recruits. That would enable the N.C.A.A. to focus on important issues, she said.

The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 14, about avoiding large data roaming fees on phones when trav- eling abroad, misstated the time pe- riod for a program in which Verizon Wireless offers a loaner phone for those traveling to a country where Verizon phones are not compatible. The loaner phone is available for those taking a trip of 21 days or less, not 21 days or more.

WHITMER--Martin Taylor, 78, of Dallas, TX, died peacefully in Portland, ME on August 13, 2011. His entire immediate loving family was by his side. Born in Manhattan on September 11, 1932, he was the son of Laura Taylor Whitmer, of Haverhill, MA., and Robert Foster Whitmer Jr., of Lancaster, PA. Martin attended Greenwich Country Day School, St. Paul's School, Yale University (1954) (Berzelius/ Zeta Psi), and Harvard Business School (1958). He completed ROTC training and served in the US Army as a 1st Lieutenant where he received the National Service Defense Medal. In 1961 he married Lela Fiesole Hall of Scituate, MA and they lived in Boston and Princeton, NJ while Martin worked for the Cabot Corp. In 1969, Martin and Lela moved to Dallas where he worked for Texas Industries and later as business consultant for Whitmer & Associates. Martin excelled at fly fishing, wing shooting, tennis, skiing, cooking game and photography of the natural elements. He enjoyed reading military history, smoking fine cigars and his annual trip to Prouts Neck, Maine. He devoted time to counseling at the Small Business Administration. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Lela; devoted son, Martin Taylor Whitmer, Jr, and his wife Julie Thurmond Whitmer, adoring daughter, Lele Whitmer McKenry and her husband James R. McKenry, Jr.; sister Laura Taylor Spadone; brother Robert Foster Whitmer, III and his wife Lili Pell Whitmer; brother-in-law E. Winthrop Hall; three precious grandchildren, Martin Taylor Whitmer, III (Tate) Brooks Thurmond Whitmer and Priscilla Gray Moore Whitmer; and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, Martin's family would appreciate donations made to the Scarborough Land Conservation Trust (PO Box 1237, Scarborough, ME 04070-1237), Operation Kindness (3201 Earhart Drive, Carrollton, TX 75006), the Salvation Army or the charity of your choice
