SMITH--Ralph K. 85, of Locust Valley, NY on August 23. Attorney, beloved partner and father, devoted friend and volunteer, graduated from Sewickley, PA High School in 1942, joined the 63rd Infantry Division of the Army in 1943, receiving a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. Graduated Dartmouth College in 1948 Phi Beta Kappa, President of Delta Tau Fraternity. At Harvard Law School served as president of the Chancery Club. Partner at Sage Gray Todd and Sims 1951-1986, Townley & Updike 19871995, Snow Becker Krauss 1996-2011. Numerous volunteer positions include Trustee/VP of Seamen's Church Institute; Governor, Chairman of Executive Committee Hundred Year Association of New York; Governor of the Creek Club; Trustee Green Vale School. Survivors include longtime partner Faye Argentine of New York, NY; daughter Hillary Goodridge of Boston, MA; son Russell Smith of Mamaroneck, NY; granddaughter Annie Goodridge of Boston, MA; sisters Anne Smith VanderWolk of Pinehurst, NC and Margaret Smith Wenzel, M.D. of Naples, FL; brother Jay Smith of Princeton, NJ; sister-in-law Suzi Smith of Collinsville, CT; former wife Ann K. Smith of Vero Beach FL; thirteen nieces and nephews. Ralph touched so many with his incredible generosity, humor and zest for living. He will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues, clients and many friends. Services private.

BEAUREGARD HOUSTON-MONTGOMERY (LEFT): I never wanted to be a drag queen, because I was a very pretty boy, but I was never a pretty girl. It was more about androgyny. Alexis had all these beautiful costumes in his apartment. I remember that the dog kept trying to eat my turban. I walked around this way all the time. I had a full-time job in a hospital, and it was a real struggle to live this way. People were very threatened by it. And people also copied us all the time. David Bowie used to be my neighbor at the Chelsea Hotel, and he never took his eyes off me. I was like, What's her problem? He was very observant. I had shaved my eyebrows -- that was my look. And suddenly he had no eyebrows. ALEXIS DEL LAGO: I was sitting in my apartment on 89th and Riverside with Beauregard and my dog, Tiffany. We were playing around the house. Beauregard was supposed to be my son, Tadzio, in ''Death in Venice,'' and I was supposed to be his mother. We were duplicating it in our own way. Beauregard was a beautiful boy, and I was a beautiful woman, and ''Death in Venice'' was just opening in the theaters. We went to see it, and we loved it, and we decided it's our life.

BELENKY--Allen A. Dad, It has been 44 years since you left us, but your love, compassion and creativity are eternal. I see you each day in your original paintings which adorn my home. Missing you always. Love, Katrin

RAIFF--Stanley, 81, husband and long-term partner of Dr. Howard Coron, Professor Emeritus of NYU's Steinhardt School of Education, died on July 19th. He was cremated. Stan and Howard were together for 41 years. Stan was an entrepreneur and his greatest love was the theatre. At 18 he went to Syracuse University and got both a Bachelors and Masters degrees in Speech and Hearing and Teaching English to secondary students. At Syracuse University he had a childrens' theatre company. He produced two long running TV series, The Tinker Shop and Through Childrens' Eyes for which he won a regional Emmy. Stan then went on to be a special teacher in Virginia for three years. Here too he had a TV and radio program. In his twenties he produced and directed in summer stock, regional theatres and in New York City at the Theatre de Lys. Stan then became a business person. His positions among others included being the director of publicity and promotion for North and South America for Alitalia Airlines and the editor and writer for the European Travel Commission. Educational programs for schools sponsored by major corporations followed for which he won industry awards. Stan went back to producing educational programs. His Catskill IDEA program, an after school program was considered by New York State officials as one of the best in the State. Stan was deeply concerned about abused children and animals throughout his life. He wrote for many newspapers and magazines and also wrote a travel book for children going to Europe, called "Get Ready, Get Set, Go" published by Random House. Stan leaves behind his partner Howard and Howard's sons and their families, his brother Keith and family, cousins and friends. He will be sorely missed. On their 25th anniversary Stan and Howard had a Jewish Commitment ceremony and were married in 2007 in Vancouver, Canada. They showed others that same sex marriages can enrich and support families and communities.

EIGEN--Robert J.,on August 26, 2011. Husband of Joan for 51 years; father of Wendy, David and his wife, Cindy; grandfather of Emily, Lexi, Zach, Max, Jack and Sam; brother of Marcia. Born on April 11, 1935, Bob graduated from Dartmouth and got his MBA from the Amos Tuck School of Business. A year later, he met the love of his life, Joan, and his career took off. From accountant to mortgage broker to real estate developer, Bob loved to create and had an incredible eye for architecture. He also was active in many charities. Bob loved golf, his gin game, fine wine, a glass of Dewars, but most of all his family. We will miss his ever strong presence. In lieu of flowers, Contributions may be made in memory of Mr. Robert J. Eigen to Weill Cornell Medical College (memo: Weill Cornell Medical College, Center for Cancer Prevention Research), c/o Alison Zayas, Office of Development, Box 123, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065. For more information please call: 646-317-7359. Service Monday 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76 St., at Amsterdam Ave., New York City.
Theater Steven McElroy

SWARTSBERG--Mildred Kronenberg, a resident of Mill Valley for 34 years, died peacefully in her sleep, at home, Saturday, August 20th, 2011 on the 99th birthday of her late husband Jerry Swartsberg. A graduate of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, Class of 1933, Mildred had a passion for all the arts, sports and The New York Times crossword puzzle. She was great at anything she tried. She was one smart cookie! She is survived by her daughters Karen Swartsberg of Boothbay, Maine, and Janie Teitelbaum of San Rafael, California.

BERLER--Lillian S. was born in Brooklyn on October 21, 1916 and passed away in Tallahassee, Florida on July 21, 2011. She was a spirited 94 year old. She lived most of her life in Brooklyn and Queens. In 2001, after her husband of 55 years passed away, she moved to Tallahassee to be near her daughter. Lillian is survived by her daughter Ellen Berler and son-in-law Rob Contreras. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Hy and cherished son Andy. Online condolences may be made at www.abbeyfh.com.

The cover review on Aug. 7, about ''A Book of Secrets,'' by Michael Holroyd, together with a drawing that accompanied the review, misattributed the following poem: ''My heart was more disgraceful, more alone, / And more courageous than the world has known. / O passer-by, my heart was like your own.'' When Lloyd Carr came to Michigan as an assistant in the early 1980s, he recalled that Coach Bo Schembechler was making $60,000 per year. Times have changed. As salaries, bowl payouts and television contracts have skyrocketed, the sport's problems have also escalated. What Carr would like to see is a more nimble N.C.A.A. ''Somewhere, I think they need an ability to react quicker or more quickly to the issues than they've been able to do in the past,'' he said. ''Someone has to have the ability to make decisions because the bureaucracy of the N.C.A.A. is extremely cumbersome.''

Never to be confused with cutoffs, the concept is still a long way from the corporate office.

The cover review on Aug. 7, about ''A Book of Secrets,'' by Michael Holroyd, together with a drawing that accompanied the review, misattributed the following poem: ''My heart was more disgraceful, more alone, / And more courageous than the world has known. / O passer-by, my heart was like your own.'' STOTHERS--Richard Blair, age 72, died on June 28, 2011 at his home. Survived by his brother, Hedley Stothers, his nephews Josh Nims, Seth Nims and Hedley Stothers III, and his nieces Ruth Stothers Dolan and Sarah Stothers. Predeceased by his sister, Susan Stothers Nims. Graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Princeton University and Harvard University. Richard Stothers walked into the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies in June 1961, a first-year graduate student looking for a summer job, carrying a one-paragraph note from a professor recommending him simply as a "very good man". Within two years, he published four papers in the most prestigious journal, the Astrophysical Journal, received his Ph.D. from Harvard and became a permanent staff member of the Goddard Institute, where he worked the rest of his life. He became a world expert on the structure of stars, as well as their origin and evolution. It was Dr. Stothers' work and technical advice that stimulated Dr. Robert Jastrow, the founding director of the Goddard Institute, to write his famous book, Red Giants and White Dwarfs. Dr. Stothers was a scholar of classical mold, able to read original papers in several languages. He published almost 200 papers, mostly in astrophysics and solar physics. In the last two decades of his life he spent much of his time on climate science, especially investigating ancient writings to extract information on climate change throughout recorded history. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Community Fund, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Julius, M.D.,96. Died of congestive heart failure, August 24, 2011, Tiburon, CA. Survived by wife of 64 years, Nanette, two sons, Peter and Stephen, two grandchildren, Julia and Theo. Graduated Indiana University in 1936; then an M.D. in Scotland. Served in the U.S. Army in China. Awarded a Bronze Star. After WWII, he was an orthopedic surgeon in Forest Hills, NY.

SIKIRICA--Stanley, SGM US Army (ret.), died August 25, 2011 of cancer in Buffalo at the age of 84. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Maud (Ahrens) and daughters, Karin, Janet (Gregory Barton), Eileen Torre (Nelson), and Chloe. Proud grandfather of Barrett and Sam Torre, Pim and Bruno McCarthy and Noah Barton. A decorated war hero serving 30 years during WWII, Korea and Vietnam, he was the recipient of many medals for his leadership and courage. Youngest of nine, born November 20, 1926 in Johnstown, PA to Katherine (Sobecky) and Peter Sikirica. Donations may be made to the Glaucoma Research Foundation or ASPCA.

MUNN--Orson D.,died at home in Southampton on August 25, 2011. Survived by wife Patricia G. Munn; children Linda Munn and Orson D. Munn III and his wife Christine Munn; and grandchildren Caroline McConnaughey, Sasha Munn, Cara Munn and Cameron Munn. Private family interment in Southampton Cemetery. A memorial gathering will be scheduled for a date to be determined in September. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to either Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or Class of 1947 Scholarship Fund, Princeton University, PO Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357.

NEXT month, Isa, the new restaurant by Taavo Somer of Freemans and Peels fame, opens on the south side of Williamsburg in Brooklyn. Mr. Somer, who spent the last two years building the space by embracing naïveté and improvising (i.e., letting the design of the tables ''go where the wood wants to go,'' for example), describes Isa's look and vibe as ''primitive modern.'' ''It speaks to that part of us that longs for something real, that wants to pick up some rocks, logs, meat and cook over a fire,'' he said. The menu, by the chef Ignacio Mattos, formerly of Il Buco, features succulent fall-off-the-bone pig's tail, a bright consommé made with herbs from the restaurant's roof garden, a cashew-dressed vegansalad that tastes curiously like a classic Caesar, and steak served with slim re-imagined potato skins. ''This is the most fun I've had in nine years,'' Mr. Somer said. ''We're trying things and making things. We just want to lose the fear, throw a little caution to the wind, dance badly and have a blast.'' At 348 Wythe Street. Go to isa.gg. KEN MILLER

On Aug. 30, 1861, Maj. Gen. John C. Frémont, commander of the Union Western Department in St. Louis, issued a proclamation of martial law. "All persons who shall be taken with arms in their hands," he announced, "shall be tried by court-martial, and if found guilty will be shot." This was harsh, but perhaps to be expected in the strife-torn region. But Frémont went further. "The property, real and personal, of all persons in the State of Missouri, who shall take up arms against the United States, or who shall be directly proven to have taken an active part with their enemies in the field, is declared to be confiscated to their public use, and their slaves, if any they have, are hereby declared freemen."

Chefs, food gurus and other friends of Alice Waters gathered Friday and Saturday at the U.C. Berkeley Art Museum to ring in a weekend of festivities in celebration of Chez Panisse, the redwood restaurant where Waters began developing her organic food revolution 40 years ago. The "simple little place where we could cook and talk politics," as Waters once famously described her restaurant, was honored with a Chez Panisse-inspired procession and the unveiling of a photographic portrait of Waters, to be hung in the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery. "I just love that this portrait was taken at the Edible Schoolyard in the fall," Waters told the crowd on Friday. The weekend's events - intimate dinners cooked in homes around the Bay Area by different chefs, among them a pig roast in Michael Pollan's backyard - doubled as fund-raisers for the Edible Schoolyard Project, Waters's program in which students create and tend an organic garden as part of their school curriculum. "Normally people have big giant events and you don't have an opportunity to really talk to people," Waters said of the dinner parties yet to come. "So I thought, instead of trying to mount that big event that we would have a lot of small events and they would have different venues, different cooks, different people at the table." The Selby was there to capture it all. Here, the first of four dispatches from a delicious anniversary.

Jonas Kaufmann, a major international tenor who has become an increasingly important presence at the Metropolitan Opera, plans to go ahead with an Oct. 30 recital at the house just two months after undergoing chest surgery, the Met said on Monday. He also remains committed to a run as the title character in a new production of Gounod's "Faust," which opens on Nov. 29, and to appearances in the "Ring" cycle in the spring, the Met said. "Jonas Kaufmann has assured the Met through his management that he plans to sing all of his scheduled performances here this season," according to a company statement. Mr. Kaufmann said on his Web site that he needed to have an operation to remove a node from his chest. "I do not wish anyone to become alarmed reading this, but my physicians have ordered me to have the surgery done as soon as possible, and it will take place after my appearance in Stockholm on Sept. 2," he said. He is scheduled to sing in the Jussi Björling gala that day at the Royal Opera. Mr. Kaufmann's Web site lists five other performances in October, starting on Oct. 10.

James W. Pennebaker's new book "The Secret Life of Pronouns," which I reviewed in The Times Book Review on Sunday, makes it hard to stop thinking about pronouns and the other little "function words" that Mr. Pennebaker, a social psychologist at the University of Texas at Austin, sees as "the keys to the soul." Mr. Pennebaker is admirably omnivorous when it comes to looking for material that will show how these stealthy words - which include articles, prepositions, conjunctions and auxiliary verbs - reflect our social psyche. One of his more unexpected sources is the lyrical canon of the Beatles.

ROMEO, Mich. -- Sitting behind the wheel of a gently rumbling 2012 Ford Mustang Boss 302 here on the tarmac apron at Ford's proving grounds, I put my foot on the brake, pushed the speed control's Set button and watched the tachometer needle sweep through its range. With Jeff Seaman, the Mustang program manager, providing instruction from the passenger's seat -- a brave man, he -- I released the Set button, then used the plus and minus controls to set the tach to 4,200 r.p.m. When the needle returned to idle, I pressed the speed control's On button to lock in the r.p.m. setting.

HONG KONG -- A study sponsored by the solar power industry has concluded that the United States ran a trade surplus of $1.88 billion in solar technologies last year, as exports of raw material and factory equipment for the solar sector outpaced imports of finished solar panels. The report is clearly aimed at addressing worries about the rapid rise of Chinese solar panel manufacturers, who now represent 58 percent of the world's solar panel manufacturing capacity.

An experimental pill to prevent blood clots exceeded already high expectations as a better therapy for millions of people with atrial fibrillation, according to final results of a worldwide study released on Sunday. The study was featured at the European Society of Cardiology in Paris and simultaneously published on the Web site of The New England Journal of Medicine.
