4:56 p.m. | Updated New estimates indicate that flooding at the Weston Playhouse will cause between $100,000 and $200,000 in damages. Fears about Hurricane Irene may have shuttered Broadway this weekend, but the worst havoc to a theater occurred roughly 230 miles to the north in flood-ravaged Vermont. The Weston Playhouse, which is celebrating its 75th season this summer, was overrun on Sunday with between 6 and 12 feet of water in the orchestra pit, prop shop, dressing rooms and other parts of the lower levels of the theater, causing $100,000 in damage and upending the schedule for its new musical, ''Saint-Ex.''
A classical music listing for the New York Philharmonic's performance of ''Resurrection,'' at 7:30 p.m. on Sept. 10, misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (212) 875-5656.

They're coming back, sweeties: Patsy Stone and Edina Monsoon, the foul-mouthed, fashionably wasted ladies portrayed by Joanna Lumley and Jennifer Saunders in the comedy series ''Absolutely Fabulous,'' will return to television in a series of anniversary specials, the BBC said on Monday. Created by Ms. Saunders, the original ''Absolutely Fabulous'' - ''Abfab'' to its friends - chronicled a public-relations executive (Edina) and a magazine editor (Patsy) whose efforts to remain hip and find sex in the city would leave Carrie Bradshaw utterly appalled. Over five seasons and various specials that were shown in Britain between 1992 and 2004 (and on American television on Comedy Central and Logo), the ladies drank and drugged their way through London and experienced the occasional adverse reaction to eating solid food.

When Novak Djokovic steps onto the court for his first round match at this year's Open, it'll be his New York debut as world number one, but it will be the unfamiliar player on the other side of the net who will be making history. That man is Conor Niland, a 29-year-old Irishman, who, together with countryman Louk Sorensen, will be the first Irish players ever to compete in the main draw of the U.S. Open. ''We're pretty certain in saying that no Irish player has made it into the U.S. Open main draw,'' said Des Allen, the C.E.O. of Tennis Ireland, who is at the moment stuck in Dublin due to Hurricane Irene, trying to find a flight to New York for the Open.

CULLMAN--Edgar M. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Edgar M. Cullman, a true philanthropist whose more than 50 years of service on The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees were marked by his integrity, conviction, and generosity. His family's legacy of leadership at Mount Sinai began with the Hospital's founding in 1852, and Edgar joined the Board of the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1950. His work in that role inspired in him a lifelong advocacy for nursing and patient care, interests which he passionately championed upon joining the Mount Sinai Board of Trustees in 1957. Edgar remained deeply involved throughout his decades of service, speaking often to the doctors and nurses to express his appreciation and seek their insights to improve patient care. He applied that learning to the founding of The Joseph F. Cullman Jr. Institute for Patient Care, established by him and his brothers Lewis B. Cullman and Joseph F. Cullman 3rd in memory of their father. Along with his equally dedicated wife Louise, Edgar was a reliable benefactor who made many substantial gifts over the years that were instrumental in securing Mount Sinai's financial future and excellence. His spirit of commitment survives him through our cherished partnership with Louise and his children, Lucy Cullman Danziger and Boards of Trustees members Edgar M. Cullman Jr. and Susan R. Cullman. In recognition of the staunch commitment, extraordinary contributions, and devoted generosity of Edgar and the entire Cullman family, Mount Sinai will honor the Cullmans during the Noble Deeds Society Dinner in October. We dearly wish Edgar could have been there to hear how much his service has meant to us. On behalf of Mount Sinai, we extend our heartfelt condolences to Louise, Lucy, Edgar Jr., Susan, his brother Lewis and the entire Cullman family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees,The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

With every minute that went by in his first-round match Monday at the United States Open - and those were a lot of minutes, 264 of them, to be exact - Germany's Philipp Petzschner tried to evaluate the body language of his opponent, Albert Ramos of Spain. CULLMAN--Edgar Meyer, of New York City and Stamford, CT died peacefully on August 28th at 93, the 73rd anniversary of his marriage to Louise Bloomingdale. A legend in the cigar business, Edgar was Chairman of General Cigar from 1961-2005. He was the third generation of his family to serve on the Board of Trustees of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and he served in this capacity for over 50 years. He was the President of the Hotchkiss School Board of Trustees, and had a long standing involvement with Yale University. A staunch supporter of Yale football, Edgar rarely missed a game. Other passions were Atlantic salmon, horseback riding and tennis. He considered himself an excellent dancer and delighted in serving family and friends vegetables from his garden. The former Chairman of the Board of the Tryall Club in Jamaica, he was awarded "Commander of Distinction" Jamaica's highest honor from its Government for a non-Jamaican. Edgar is survived by his wife Louise, and their three children: Lucy Cullman Danziger and her husband Mike, Edgar M. Cullman Jr. and his wife Ellie, Susan Cullman and her husband, John Kirby, along with six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and three step-grandchildren. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Joseph F. Cullman, Jr. Institute for Patient Care, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, One Gustave L. Levy Place Box 1167, New York, NY 10029

Broadway musicals and plays grossed only $11.6 million last week, a sharp drop from overall tickets sales of $20.1 million during the previous week - the result of New York City's shutdown over Hurricane Irene, which led to the cancellation of typically profitable performances on Saturday and Sunday. Nearly 131,000 people saw Broadway shows before theaters went dark for the storm, compared to about 218,000 the week before. The box office data, released on Monday afternoon by theater owners and producers through their trade association, the Broadway League, were the best measures of the economic consequences of Irene on the nation's unofficial theater capital.

FADING PROBLEMS Two settlements of investor securities fraud claims against former officers and directors of Lehman Brothers provide another sign that the federal government is unlikely to pursue criminal or civil charges stemming from the firm's collapse in 2008. When the government is pursuing criminal and civil investigations, private securities lawsuits are usually viewed as less important to deal with, according to White Collar Watch. A settlement of the investor lawsuits is usually the last step in wrapping up a case, not the first. PETER J. HENNING

While the United States military has Defcon, the tiered alert system used during times of national crisis, Wall Street has fashioned a critical event of its own, Sefcon. The industry conference known as Sefcon is devoted to the relatively obscure swap execution facility, or SEF, the electronic derivatives marketplace designated under the Dodd-Frank Act, the sweeping financial regulatory overhaul. With Washington cracking down on derivatives, Sefcon's nod to Defcon was not coincidental.

2:45 p.m. | Updated As municipal crews around the Northeast worked to clean up after Hurricane Irene, Representative Michele Bachmann did her own damage control after she used a Florida political rally to suggest that the recent natural disasters were God's way of sending a message to Washington. ''I don't know how much God has to do to get the attention of the politicians,'' she told a group of generally older residents on Florida's Gulf Coast on Sunday, referring to the need to rein in spending. ''We've had an earthquake; we've had a hurricane. He said: 'Are you going to start listening to me here? Listen to the American people because the American people are roaring right now.' ''

Armond and Dorothy Rudolph had talked about their plans for more than a decade. They had a mutual horror of a lingering decline in their final years. They'd joined an organization that supports the right to end life when illness or pain becomes overwhelming; they'd attended meetings and given both their children literature on the subject. They'd drafted advance directives. ''Their great fear was that they'd end up in a nursing home,'' their son, Neil Rudolph, told me. ''That was hell for them, to have people waiting on them, to have no independence.''

Jonas Kaufmann, a major international tenor who has become an increasingly important presence at the Metropolitan Opera, plans to go ahead with an Oct. 30 recital at the house just two months after undergoing chest surgery, the Met said on Monday. He also remains committed to a run as the title character in a new production of Gounod's ''Faust,'' which opens on Nov. 29, and to appearances in the ''Ring'' cycle in the spring, the Met said. ''Jonas Kaufmann has assured the Met through his management that he plans to sing all of his scheduled performances here this season,'' according to a company statement. Mr. Kaufmann said on his Web site that he needed to have an operation to remove a node from his chest. ''I do not wish anyone to become alarmed reading this, but my physicians have ordered me to have the surgery done as soon as possible, and it will take place after my appearance in Stockholm on Sept. 2,'' he said. He is scheduled to sing in the Jussi Bjorling gala that day at the Royal Opera. Mr. Kaufmann's Web site lists five other performances in October, starting on Oct. 10. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MTV made much of the fact that the 2011 edition of its Video Music Awards, held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Sunday night, would go hostless, but that it went off without any apparent supervision came as a surprise. This was maybe the most bleeped award show in history, and certainly among the lewdest: Lady Gaga's opening monologue, in drag, channeling Andrew Dice Clay and Denis Leary; Cloris Leachman swapping foul talk with the ''Jersey Shore'' cast; Justin Bieber making phallus jokes with his girlfriend, Selena Gomez, during the preshow. The flat toilet humor of last year's host, Chelsea Handler, had nothing on this.

INGBERMAN--Jeanette, 59, August 24, 2011. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the non-profit cultural center Exit Art honor the life and memory of our beloved Co-Founder and Executive Director, Jeanette Ingberman. Collaborating with her husband, Exit Art Co-founder and Artistic Director, Papo Colo, Ingberman curated 175 exhibitions, festivals, and theater pieces, which featured some of the most aesthetically-compelling and politically-engaged art programming internationally. For the past thirty years, under the leadership of Ingberman, Exit Art has provided a much-needed venue for the work of traditionally under-represented groups, such as those dealing with racial, ethnic, gender, and sexual diversity, and for programming investigating critically important, but overlooked cultural and social issues. The history of Exit Art is testimony to Ingberman's intellectual and artistic vision, her boundless generosity and optimism, and her faith in the power of love and creativity to transform the world. We extend our deepest sympathy to her brother Israel Ingberman and family, and to Colo, her creative and romantic partner, with whom she so fully shared her remarkable life. The Exit Art Board of Trustees, Charles Kremer, Board Chairman, Alberta Arthurs, Board President

10 P.M. (13) ARMADILLO (2011) Janus Metz follows a platoon of Danish soldiers through Helmand Province in Afghanistan in a film that has a lot in common with ''Restrepo,'' the war documentary by Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. As in ''Restrepo,'' he said, the men's ''sincere devotion to duty, and their interest in making a difference in an unfortunate part of the world, is challenged by a pervasive sense of the enterprise's difficulty.'' Despite enormous technological advantages, ''the mutual incomprehension of these men and the Afghans they're helping -- who may or may not be the same people they're fighting -- seems almost intractable. And the soldiers' frustration proves explosive.'' An intense firefight and its bloody aftermath turns the film ''into a queasy ethical puzzle,'' Mr. Scott said. ''What happens is shocking, and yet it also seems, especially to the soldiers, completely logical and acceptable. It is certainly possible to believe otherwise, but the achievement of this film is to forestall and complicate easy judgment. You emerge shaken and bothered, which may sound like a reason not to see the movie. It is actually the opposite.'' 2:20 P.M. (Cinemax) THE INFORMANT! (2009) In Steven Soderbergh's retelling of a real-life whodunit reported in a book (and for The New York Times) by Kurt Eichenwald, Matt Damon, above, adds some pounds and a prosthetic nose to play Mark Whitacre, a biochemist and Archer Daniels Midland executive who informs on his company's involvement in a global price-fixing scheme. Scott Bakula and Joel McHale are the F.B.I. agents who become so protective of Whitacre that they carry around a picture of his family after wiring up his body and briefcase. ''Like all of Mr. Soderbergh's movies, this one can be appreciated on purely formal terms, for the clarity of its images and the economy of the storytelling,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times. ''But it is Mr. Soderbergh's insistence on seeing the A.D.M. scandal as a collective tragedy rather than as another white-collar crime that gives the movie force, resonance, feeling. In the face of such corruption perhaps only laughter will do: after all, for a while now the joke has most definitely been on us.''

STAVE--George, 88, artist, died peacefully of respiratory failure in his home in Cranbury, New Jersey, on August 26, 2011, surrounded by his family. Born July 29, 1923, in Los Angeles, he was the oldest of three sons of Wilma (nee Moore) and George Arne Stave, a Norwegian immigrant. After growing up in Salinas, California, he returned to Los Angeles at the age of 17 as a scholarship student at the Chouinard Art Institute. In his early 20s he worked as a set painter in the art department of Paramount Studios and as a painting instructor at the Jepson Art Institute. He moved to Paris in 1949 and studied painting at the Academie Julian. In 1951 he was awarded a Fulbright Act grant for a year's study in India, and thereafter traveled extensively throughout Southeast Asia and Japan, studying and collecting art. Returning to New York in the mid-1950s, he was briefly a student of the abstract expressionist painter Robert Motherwell at Hunter College, and took classes at the Art Students League. He turned away from avant-garde movements in his own art, preferring representational painting, which was his lifelong passion. He exhibited his impressionistic portraits, interiors, and especially closely observed landscapes and still lifes in galleries and museums in California, New Jersey, and New York. A member of United Scenic Artists union, he worked for most of his career as a set painter for NBC Studios and, later, Lincoln Scenic Studios, in New York. In 1956 he married Mahbubeh Mahboubian, an Iranian student at the Manhattan School of Music, who survives him, along with three daughters, Pari Stave of Cranbury, Shirin Stave-Matias of Tomar, Portugal, and Kian Stave of New York; a son-in-law, Fausto Matias; and three grandchildren.

The tenor Salvatore Licitra, who made a splash with a last-minute substitution for Luciano Pavarotti at the Metropolitan Opera in 2002, was severely injured in a motor-scooter accident in Sicily on Saturday night and was in serious condition with severe head injuries, according to news reports and his Web site. The site said Mr. Licitra was operated on at Garibaldi di Catania hospital, in Catania, Sicily. Doctors there said his condition was touch and go, according to La Repubblica, the Italian daily. The Reuters news agency said Mr. Licitra lost control of his scooter while traveling near Ragusa on Saturday evening. He was not wearing a helmet, the news agency said. Mr. Licitra, 43, emerged in the late 1990s as a rising star, but some critics have said that he has not fulfilled his early promise. He was born in Switzerland to Sicilian parents and grew up in Milan.

The New Yorker's Ryan Lizza has posted a response to my criticisms of the way his recent profile of Michele Bachmann portrayed the evangelical writer and activist Francis Schaeffer. In his post, Lizza attempts to justify his article's claim that Schaeffer's 198o book "A Christian Manifesto" urges "the violent overthrow of the government if Roe v. Wade isn't reversed." I had disputed this point, noting that Schaeffer only urged Christians to consider acts of non-violent civil disobedience against the post-Roe abortion regime (offering examples like the non-payment of taxes and public sit-ins), while explicitly warning his readers against an "overreaction [that] crosses the line from force to violence." It seems inevitable to have finger-pointing whenever a hurricane makes landfall. If the storm weakens, there are charges of alarmism and fear-mongering. If it veers or strengthens, hammered communities cry out. With Hurricane Irene, it was mostly the former, as various factions with axes to grind piled on the National Hurricane Center. (A case in point was Patrick Michaels, a climate scientist at the anti-regulatory Cato Institute who last Friday said the storm should be renamed "Hurricane Hype," adding that he doubted it would "cough up even eight bodies." With the death count far higher, he apologized through the Watts Up With That blog.)

Today in The New York Times Janet Maslin reviews Marc Spitz's new book, "Jagger: Rebel, Rock Star, Rambler, Rogue." She liked the book, and so do I. Like Coco Chanel, Pierre-Henri Mattout was born in Saumur, the medieval French town in the Loire Valley famous among wine snobs for its superb cabernet franc appellation, Saumur-Champigny. The town also happens to be an equestrian center of France, home to the Cadre Noir, one of the world's most prestigious riding schools. "It's very uptight, very bourgeois and very elegant," says Mattout, who, as a p'tit garçon, dreamed not of mounting a Lusitano but of being the academy's head tailor. Accordingly, Mattout's latest men's collection - all jodhpur-style chinos, leather elbow patches and whipcord wool blazers in dragoon red - is a paean to his horse-loving hometown. But rather than reboot some bygone vision of aristo chic, Mattout drew on his design experience at Dior Homme, Dunhill and Victorinox. The result is a modern sportswear collection of uncommon elegance, detail-obsessed yet refreshingly remote from the work-wear-inspired stuff that's glutting American runways.

La Garçonne is the minimalist's go-to for everything from straightforward trousers to streamlined satchels by Maison Martin Margiela. Now, after several years of offering other designers' basics, the Web site's founder, Kris Kim, is taking a stab at her own label. La Garçonne Moderne stocks such luxurious staples as hand-knit boatnecks, men's-wear-inspired button-downs, sleek sheath dresses and pegged trousers. And for those e-commerce dabblers too nervous to buy a pair of pants without trying them on, La Garçonne offers five different product views plus so much descriptive detail that buying a pair of wide-leg trousers with just enough stretch to conform to your body is pretty much a cinch. Cashmere coat, $1,450. Wool trousers, $525. Go to lagarconne.com.

The "Gatz" star Gary Wilmes, who played Tom Buchanan in that nearly seven-hour-long Elevator Repair Service adaptation of "The Great Gatsby," will be getting less stage time in his next project, though it's hardly a demotion. Mr. Wilmes is set to start in the coming Broadway transfer of "Chinglish," the David Henry Hwang comedy about an American businessman who encounters linguistic and cultural difficulties on a trip to China, its press representatives said Wednesday. Jennifer Lim, who played a strong-willed Chinese official in the play's Chicago production at the Goodman Theater, will reprise her role on Broadway, as will the cast members Angela Lin, Christine Lin, Stephen Pucci, Johnny Wu and Larry Zhang. Leigh Silverman, who directed "Chinglish" in Chicago, will also stay on for the Broadway run, which will be presented at the Longacre Theater. It is scheduled to begin previews Oct. 11 and open Oct. 27.

Here's another outcome that "Lost" fans aren't going to be happy with: Matthew Fox, a star of that twisty-turny, probably made-up-as-it-went-along ABC drama, has been charged with assault by a bus driver who says he punched her outside a Cleveland nightclub, CNN reported. The bus driver, Heather Bormann, said that Mr. Fox tried to board the charter vehicle she was driving early Sunday morning for a bachelor party he was not invited to, and that he became physical when she barred him from entering. "I told him, 'Sorry, buddy, this is a private party,' " Ms. Bormann told Cleveland.com. " 'You get off my vehicle.' I told him three times." Mr. Fox, who is in Cleveland shooting the film "I, Alex Cross," was allowed to take a taxi back to his hotel.

Can a stroll help ease depression? That question preoccupied Dr. Madhukar H. Trivedi, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, after several of his patients, all suffering from serious depression, mentioned that they felt happier if they went for a walk. The patients in question were taking the widely prescribed antidepressants known as S.S.R.I.'s, for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, but not responding fully. They remained, by clinical standards, depressed. Dr. Trivedi and his colleagues began to wonder if adding a formal "dose" of exercise would increase their chances of getting better.

A former lead artist on the cartoon series ''SpongeBob SquarePants,'' who faces a lawsuit from his art dealer concerning what she says was his hiring of accomplices to burglarize her gallery, has fired back with his own suit, accusing her of fraud. The dealer, Margaret Howell of the HB Gallery in Huntington Beach, Calif., sued the artist, Todd White, this month in Superior Court in Los Angeles. She asserted that he had hired several men to go to her gallery on the evening of Aug. 2, where, according to the suit, they assaulted her and stole $1 million worth of Mr. White's artwork, along with gallery records, including customer lists.

An article on Tuesday about the prospect of astronauts' having to abandon the International Space Station misstated the timing of the installation of the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer particle physics experiment at the station. It was installed in May, not last year.

Tropical Storm Irene moved through New York City on Sunday knocking out power, causing flooding in some neighborhoods and knocking over many trees. In one corner of Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, the storm also set off a fight -- over bees.

BOGIN--Abba. The Board of Directors of "The Bohemians" (New York Musicians' Club) announces with deep sorrow the death of Abba Bogin, our esteemed president, on August 25, 2011. At least 25 top United States companies paid more to their chief executives in 2010 than they did to the federal government in taxes, according to a study released on Wednesday. The companies -- which include household names like eBay, Boeing, General Electric and Verizon -- averaged $1.9 billion each in profits, according to the study by the Institute for Policy Studies, a liberal-leaning research group. But a variety of shelters, loopholes and tax reduction strategies allowed the companies to average more than $400 million each in tax benefits -- which can be taken as a refund or used as write-off against earnings in future years.

KRAWITZ--Rhoda. Members of the New York Freudian Society mourn the death of our esteemed colleague Rhoda Krawitz, a longtime member and friend passed away several weeks ago. We honor her contributions to our society and work as a psychoanalyst.

The movie star James Franco (''Rise of the Planet of the Apes'') is no longer linked to a planned Broadway revival of the Tennessee Williams drama ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' Mr. Franco's publicist said on Monday, and the production itself will not happen this fall as previously reported, according to the director attached to the project. ''Sweet Bird,'' a 1959 play about the gigolo and wannabe actor Chance Wayne and his companion, the Hollywood has-been Alexandra Del Lago, had been one of the most anticipated Broadway productions for the fall because of the names involved: Mr. Franco as Chance, the Academy Award-winner Nicole Kidman as Alexandra, and David Cromer as the production's director (given his Off Broadway success with ''Our Town'').

THE ARTS An article on Saturday about ''Odysseus at Hell Gate,'' a site-specific work commissioned for Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, referred imprecisely to Materials for the Arts, which provided supplies for the project. It is a program run by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs; it is not a nonprofit group. (Friends of Materials for the Arts is a nonprofit group created to support the program.)

Just how many people were fascinated/flustered/baffled by Lady Gaga's gender-bending turn on the MTV Video Music Awards? Well 12.4 million people were watching on Sunday night, the biggest viewership for any show in the 30-year history of the cable channel and continuing the upward ratings trend for the annual awards. Last year's VMAs drew 11.4 million viewers. The fact that MTV set a record on Sunday is all the more significant because swaths of the East Coast were without power because of Hurricane Irene.

It used to bother Sergei Bubka, the tennis player and son of the legendary Ukrainian pole-vaulter with the same name, when reporters would ask him about his father. AT&T also plans to commit to maintaining its and T-Mobile's more than 25,000 call-center jobs in the United States.

Operation Hope built a nonprofit powerhouse over the last decade, spinning a stockpile of donations from Wall Street firms into 27 financial education centers across the country. But the charitable organization's donor base has retrenched in the wake of the financial crisis. Citigroup's foundation last year cut its giving 60 percent, to $115,000. The ING Foundation delayed paying its $300,000 commitment to Operation Hope. And the CIT Group, a lender that was once one of the organization's biggest benefactors, stopped giving altogether.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about product placement in telenovelas misstated a provision of a partnership between Univision and Televisa, the two major Spanish-language television networks. Univision already films its own telenovelas; the partnership does not allow the network to film them for the first time. The article also quoted incorrectly from comments by David Lawenda, president of advertising sales and marketing for Univision. He referred to the network's ''dollar-volume growth'' -- not its ''dollar-value growth.''

CULLMAN--Edgar M. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Edgar M. Cullman, a true philanthropist whose more than 50 years of service on The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees were marked by his integrity, conviction, and generosity. His family's legacy of leadership at Mount Sinai began with the Hospital's founding in 1852, and Edgar joined the Board of the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing in 1950. His work in that role inspired in him a lifelong advocacy for nursing and patient care, interests which he passionately championed upon joining the Mount Sinai Board of Trustees in 1957. Edgar remained deeply involved throughout his decades of service, speaking often to the doctors and nurses to express his appreciation and seek their insights to improve patient care. He applied that learning to the founding of The Joseph F. Cullman Jr. Institute for Patient Care, established by him and his brothers Lewis B. Cullman and Joseph F. Cullman 3rd in memory of their father. Along with his equally dedicated wife Louise, Edgar was a reliable benefactor who made many substantial gifts over the years that were instrumental in securing Mount Sinai's financial future and excellence. His spirit of commitment survives him through our cherished partnership with Louise and his children, Lucy Cullman Danziger and Boards of Trustees members Edgar M. Cullman Jr. and Susan R. Cullman. In recognition of the staunch commitment, extraordinary contributions, and devoted generosity of Edgar and the entire Cullman family, Mount Sinai will honor the Cullmans during the Noble Deeds Society Dinner in October. We dearly wish Edgar could have been there to hear how much his service has meant to us. On behalf of Mount Sinai, we extend our heartfelt condolences to Louise, Lucy, Edgar Jr., Susan, his brother Lewis and the entire Cullman family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees,The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

The Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa continues to grapple with health problems. Reuters reported that Mr. Ozawa has withdrawn from a music festival set to take place this week in China and organized by the Saito Kinen Festival of Matsumoto, Japan. The news agency also cited unconfirmed reports that Mr. Ozawa had been hospitalized for tests. After conducting a performance of Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' Mr. Ozawa canceled two other Saito Kinen Festival concerts last week because of dehydration and pneumonia, Reuters said. Mr. Ozawa, above, had surgery for esophageal cancer last year and withdrew from concerts at Carnegie Hall in the spring while recovering from back surgery.

I wasn't surprised when the administration of George W. Bush sacrificed the environment for corporate profits. But when the same thing happens under a Democratic administration, it's depressing. With little or no public input, policies that benefit corporations regardless of the consequences continue to be enacted. No wonder an April 2010 poll from the Pew Research Center found that about only 20 percent of Americans have faith in the government (it's one thing upon which the left and right and maybe even the center agree). But maybe this is nothing new: as Glenda Farrell, as Genevieve ''Gen'' Larkin, put it in ''Gold Diggers of 1937,'' ''It's so hard to be good under the capitalistic system.''

I'VE never lived in a place where people are as happy to see summer end as the South. It's brutal here in Atlanta by August. Cucumbers lay fat and bitter in gardens that have cooked for months in heat that gets close to 100 degrees. No one can move, let alone think too hard about supper.

An article on Aug. 5 about British lawmakers' calls for Piers Morgan, the CNN talk show host and a former editor of a British tabloid, to appear before a parliamentary committee investigating illegal hacking of cellphone messages contained a number of errors. The name of the tabloid newspaper Mr. Morgan edited from 1995 to 2004 is The Daily Mirror, not The Mirror. The BBC reported that it had uncovered records showing that The Daily Mirror and a sister newspaper, The Sunday Mirror -- not the Trinity Mirror group, their parent company -- used private investigators 230 times during a two-year period in the late 1990s. But the BBC did not say that the hiring of those investigators occurred under the ''editorship'' of Mr. Morgan. (He was editor of The Daily Mirror at the time.) The article also included incorrect details about an alleged hacking involving a phone message in 2001 from Paul McCartney to Heather Mills, who were introduced by Mr. Morgan, and who were dating at the time. In an interview Ms. Mills gave to the BBC about phone hacking, she said that a Trinity Mirror journalist -- not an executive -- called her and quoted verbatim from the voicemail. (Mr. Morgan raised questions about the veracity of her account, but in a statement issued by CNN on his behalf, he referred to the conversation she claimed to have had as involving an ''executive.'') It was the BBC that bleeped the name of that person; Ms. Mills did not omit the person's name. And it was the BBC -- not Ms. Mills -- who said that Mr. Morgan was not the person who made that call.

Among the many young players carrying the burden of high expectations in this tournament, few have a heavier weight to bear than Laura Robson, a 17-year-old from England who is among the game's most promising talents. Robson's serve is one of the biggest on tour. What she lacks is experience, which makes Wednesday's matchup with the veteran Anabel Medina Garrigues intriguing. Medina Garrigues's counterpunching game was honed on the red clay of her native Spain, though she is still a dangerous player on hardcourts. If Robson's serve is on and she can keep her frustration in check, this could be an interesting match.

CULLMAN--Edgar Meyer, of New York City and Stamford, CT died peacefully on August 28th at 93, the 73rd anniversary of his marriage to Louise Bloomingdale. A legend in the cigar business, Edgar was Chairman of General Cigar from 1961-2005. He was the third generation of his family to serve on the Board of Trustees of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and he served in this capacity for over 50 years. He was the President of the Hotchkiss School Board of Trustees, and had a long standing involvement with Yale University. A staunch supporter of Yale football, Edgar rarely missed a game. Other passions were Atlantic salmon, horseback riding and tennis. He considered himself an excellent dancer and delighted in serving family and friends vegetables from his garden. The former Chairman of the Board of the Tryall Club in Jamaica, he was awarded "Commander of Distinction" Jamaica's highest honor from its Government for a non-Jamaican. Edgar is survived by his wife Louise, and their three children: Lucy Cullman Danziger and her husband Mike, Edgar M. Cullman Jr. and his wife Ellie, Susan Cullman and her husband, John Kirby, along with six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and three step-grandchildren. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Joseph F. Cullman, Jr. Institute for Patient Care, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, One Gustave L. Levy Place Box 1167, New York, NY 10029

Somalia is now suffering its worst drought in 60 years. A quarter of the population has fled famine and conflict, heading west into Kenya. More than 1,300 people a day stream into the complex of refugee camps at Dadaab, Kenya, which is now housing more than 430,000 people in camps designed for 90,000. Many Somalis arrive near death after journeys of weeks with little food. Large numbers of them are children, often without parents.At Dadaab they receive food, medical care, basic shelter - the emergency relief they need. But they will probably spend years in that desolate grid of white tents, eating gruel that gets thinner toward the end of the month. The camp lacks the money to provide even subsistence rations. In exchange, the refugees give up their rights to move freely and to work.

In 1933, when Alfonso Bialetti introduced the Moka Express, Italy's economy wasn't doing much better than it is today. The Great Depression was in full swing, major banks were failing, unemployment was rampant and Italians were forced to curtail their spending. Like those of us who have limited our trips to Starbucks since the start of the current recession, the Italians of the early 1930s were easing up on their trips to the cafe. The Moka Express, a stovetop espresso machine that was meant for the home, provided both an affordable espresso and a beautiful object to make it in.

The owners of a German art gallery say they have uncovered works by the Expressionist painter Otto Dix - three watercolors and a study for a portrait - at a Bavarian estate, Reuters reported. Two of the paintings are titled "Naechtens" and "Soubrette" while the third, "Strich III," shows a street-scene with prostitutes; the fourth is a study for a 1926 portrait of the art dealer Alfred Flechtheim, Reuters said. The works date from 1922 to 1925. The gallery owners, Herbert Remmert and Peter Barth, identified the works at an estate owned by the daughter and granddaughter of Hans and Martha Koch, the news agency said. Hans Koch was a doctor and art collector; Martha Koch left him for Dix and later married the artist. The gallery has collaborated in the past with the family in searching for works at the estate, Reuters said.

Since moving to Los Angeles in 1988, the architect Michael Maltzan has been a keen observer of his adopted city. Fresh out of graduate school on the east coast, he says, "L.A. was a difficult city to get your arms around as a designer," and he began to think beyond its expansive, overwhelming scale to its personality and identity, its reality. In a new book, "No More Play: Conversations on Urban Speculation in Los Angeles and Beyond" (Hatje Cantz, $50), Maltzan initiates a series of conversations between leading figures in the repartee of the city, diverse voices that echo and underscore the multiple personalities of the city itself. "Los Angeles," Maltzan believes, "is at a threshold. The vast physical space of the city, which has allowed it to be such a phenomenal place of creativity, experimentation and innovation, just doesn't exist in the way it did a few decades ago." Optimism and possibility - the idea of the city as a laboratory where anything can happen - are two inherent qualities of L.A.'s identity that have been tied to its ability to constantly expand physically. "Now that we no longer have that capacity," he wonders, "how can we continue to produce that all-important sense of optimism so the city can continue to evolve?"

HILLSBORO, N.D. -- A word or two about perseverance, which is an essential -- maybe the essential -- carry-on for a cross-country cyclist. If I didn't have it, it would be worth trading my rain gear for it, and I say this having ridden much of the past two days in the rain. The truth is that just about anyone can make a trip like this -- you don't have to be in great shape or own a top-flight bike -- as long as you're willing to keep pedaling. If you can't muster the desire to keep your legs going day after day, your physical condition won't matter, and whatever you pack in your saddlebags won't either.

When it comes to junk mail, the rule, for 15 years, has been: Never respond. Don't even try to unsubscribe, even if they give you instructions for doing so. Hari Kaur has been teaching yoga for 20 years as a private instructor and at other people's studios, most recently in New York, but it was only late last year that she decided she wanted to start her own Jazz Yoga school -- the world's first, as far as she knew. What she didn't know was much about how to start and run a business. But one of her students happened to be an experienced entrepreneur who had recently started his fourth company, and he gave her some smart-sounding advice on funding, marketing and leasing a space. When she came up with more questions, he told her she ought to check out that latest business of his, which happened to be a free online service focused on ... how to start a company.

Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 21 about an Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia statement that said it had launched a 100-attack campaign to avenge Osama bin Laden's death gave an abbreviation for the militant group that is used for a different group. A.Q.I.M. is the abbreviation for Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, not for Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

The monumental former Citizens Saving Bank at the Bowery and Canal Street - portal to Manhattan, gateway to Chinatown and impregnable fortress of thrift - is the kind of neighborhood cynosure that just looks like a landmark. But it wasn't until this month. ''The building was a strong visual anchor for pedestrians, el passengers or anyone coming on and off the Manhattan Bridge,'' Robert B. Tierney, the chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said Aug. 9, as the 87-year-old bank building was designated an official city landmark. (A copy of the 19-page designation report is available as a PDF.)

An article on Wednesday about a report contrasting federal tax payments with the chief executive's pay at 25 American corporations included an inaccurate estimate of the average tax benefit received by the companies because of a miscalculation by the report's author, the Institute for Policy Studies. The average benefit is $304 million, not more than $400 million. The article also misstated the position of Ivan Seidenberg at Verizon, one of the companies in the report. He is chairman, not chief executive. (Mr. Seidenberg stepped down as chief executive on Aug. 1.) The error was repeated in a picture caption.

The Church of Scientology is certainly no shrinking violet when it comes to defending itself. Known for its aggressive litigiousness and scorched-earth public relations approach, the church's latest target is The New Yorker, which in February published a 25,000-word article that painted Scientology as corrupt and cultish.

An Op-Ed article on Saturday about new legislation affecting voting rights incorrectly paraphrased a quotation by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The quotation is ''we will be able to hew out of the mountain of despair a stone of hope,'' not ''a mountain of stone.''

Last week, we published a case study that looked at a choice facing Red Iguana, a Salt Lake City Mexican restaurant that was deciding where, and how, to expand. Founded in 1985 by Ramon and Maria Cardenas, the 130-employee company offers sit-down restaurant service as well as catering and fast-food operations. Now owned by Ramon and Maria's daughter, Lucy, and her husband, Bill Coker, the 100-seat Red Iguana was facing two problems, one that most restaurateurs would die for and another that most would die to avoid. In September 2008, the restaurant was featured on the Food Network's ''Diners, Drive-ins and Dives,'' and soon there was an hour-and-a-half wait for seating almost every night. Then came word that the city would be building a light-rail line down the middle of the restaurant's street, construction that could potentially force the restaurant to close occasionally, or at least eat into its revenue by dissuading some of the 700 diners who came every day, 363 days a year.

Completing a monthlong countdown on Current TV titled ''50 Documentaries to See Before You Die,'' Morgan Spurlock named the Top 10 in the final episode on Tuesday night. Before Wednesday, the last time Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina won a match at the United States Open, he beat Roger Federer in the men's singles final in 2009. That triumph, which announced del Potro as an elite player among the most elite players at age 20, took place almost two years ago. It also marked the beginning of the worst stretch of his career, including a 2010 season mostly lost to a lingering wrist injury.

Although it's a bit late for disaster preparedness gear, especially post-Irene, the Eton Axis ($70) may be a nice addition to your next hurricane party supply list. The Axis is a combination radio, flashlight and charger. It has a built-in rechargeable battery and includes a seven-band weather radio that picks up local alerts as well as AM and FM stations.

Kelli O'Hara will be the leading lady in the new Broadway musical ''Nice Work If you Can Get It,'' the producers announced on Wednesday. She will star opposite Matthew Broderick in the show, which includes songs from the George and Ira Gershwin catalog and a book by Joe DiPietro (''Memphis''). Kathleen Marshall (''Anything Goes'') will be the director and choreographer. Ms. O'Hara will play Billie Bendix, a bootlegger who meets a wealthy playboy named Jimmy Winter (Mr. Broderick) on the weekend of his nuptials. A news release describes the show, set to open in April 2012 at a theater to be announced, as ''a new take on a classic 1920's musical farce.''

An article on Friday about the doubling of obesity rates worldwide in the last three decades was published in error. The article, by The Associated Press, was written in February and concerned findings of a study published that month in The Lancet, a British medical journal. The journal published a series of new studies on obesity on Friday, and a Times editor seeking the A.P. report on those findings erroneously retrieved the February article.

BERLIN -- The man German security officials call a major security risk looks like a figure from a rap video, especially with the tattoos on his hands. The right one says ''STR8,'' and the left one ''Thug.'' ''This is from the days when I lived the life of an unbeliever,'' said the man, Denis Mamadou Cuspert, as he clenched his fists and looked at the tattoos. ''Allah will erase them from me one day.''

The reigning Wimbledon champions and the world's top ranked doubles team, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, suffered a first-round upset at the hands of Ivo Karlovic of Croatia and Frank Moser of Germany, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2, on Wednesday at the U.S. Open. An early break in the third set pushed the Bryans down a steep hill. Then, serving at 2-4, Mike Bryan faced three break points and couldn't climb back up, popping up a soft half-volley that Karlovic chipped away, giving the challengers a 5-2 lead.

He served the Club with tireless support and commitment for many years. His versatility as pianist, conductor, composer, arts administrator, and mentor to many young musicians will be long remembered.

Many Tea Party supporters have been less than enthusiastic about the prospect of Mitt Romney becoming the Republican nominee for president in 2012, but now that antipathy is becoming louder. Several Tea Party groups in the early primary state of New Hampshire are planning to protest outside a Romney speech on Sunday. They will be joined by FreedomWorks, the libertarian advocacy group that has helped Tea Party groups to grow across the country and that on Wednesday dismissed Mr. Romney as a ''political opportunist'' for trying to claim Tea Party support.

Last week, our financial Superman, the mild-mannered Midwesterner Warren E. Buffett, swooped in again to save another bank, the financial markets, the American economy and just maybe our precious way of life. Mr. Buffett's purchase of $5 billion worth of Bank of America preferred stock (on his usual generous terms, including long-lasting warrants to buy common stock at an attractive price) immediately stiffened the upper lips of chattering investors and pundits. Bank of America's chairman hailed it as a ''vote of confidence'' in the bank. It was also celebrated as a signal that the worst was over in the rout recently experienced by the American financial sector.

I recently saw a list of cheesy local TV commercials that got me laughing and thinking. Why exactly do these spots have such a time-honored place in our culture? In Corpus Christi, Tex., where I grew up, the high priest of the daytime local genre was Mr. Louie of Mr. Louie's Wig City. Day after day, he took to the airwaves, entering our living rooms while standing in front of hundreds of Styrofoam heads, each with a thousand-mile stare and some kind of Eva Gabor number on top. He'd shout their names as if they were horses coming down the home stretch: the Aspire! The Invitation! The Lite and Airy and Cheer! The Perk!

WASHINGTON-An era in the American military came to an end on Wednesday when David H. Petraeus, the most influential general of his generation, retired with a 17-gun salute and a warning that coming budget cuts should not lead to the ''hollow Army'' that occurred after the Vietnam War. Just 11 days before the 10th anniversary of Osama Bin Laden's attacks on New York and Washington, General Petraeus also implicitly cautioned that the United States should not abandon the troop-intensive and expensive counterinsurgency doctrine that was his hallmark when he commanded the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. The general spoke as the Obama White House is shifting from a broad counterinsurgency strategy of trying to build roads, schools and good government in Afghanistan to a narrower and more secretive counterterrorism mission of hunting down terrorists.

After almost two years of delays for Game's newest release, ''The R.E.D. Album'' (DGC/Interscope) -- and a promotional campaign that included the West Coast rapper sporting a red-dyed mohawk -- it opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Game narrowly beat Jay-Z and Kanye West's ''Watch the Throne'' (Roc-a-Fella/Def Jam/Roc Nation), which had 94,000 sales in its third week out. But both those albums will soon be pushed down the chart with the arrival of Lil Wayne's latest, ''Tha Carter IV'' (Cash Money/Universal Republic). Billboard predicted that the album -- released at midnight on Monday, shortly after Lil Wayne gave the closing performance on MTV's Video Music Awards -- could have opening-week sales as high as 900,000. (His last, ''Tha Carter III,'' sold just over 1 million in its debut week in 2008.)

KAELIN--William G.,age 82, of Quechee, VT, passed away on August 28, 2011. Bill, the son of the late William C. and Kathryn (Graf) Kaelin of East Rockaway, NY, is survived by his children and their spouses, William, Jr. and Carolyn Kaelin of Boston, MA, Michael and Carol Kaelin of Wilton, CT, Thomas and Linda Kaelin of Woodbury, CT, Margaret and Glen Holland of Hingham, MA, and Robert and Linda Kaelin of Glastonbury, CT; his sister, Ann Moran of Sound Beach, NY; fifteen wonderful grandchildren; and numerous cousins, nieces, nephews and in-laws, all of whom he loved very much. In addition to his parents, Bill was predeceased by his brothers, Arthur and Robert Kaelin, and his former wife, Nancy Kaelin, the mother of his five children. Bill was an international tax lawyer and an avid saltwater fisherman. He graduated from Duke University and the Duke University School of Law, and began his legal career at Kramer, Marx, Greenlee & Backus in New York City in 1954. He later served as counsel to Healy & Baillie LLP in New York, and as General Counsel to the New York office of Gill & Duffus, a commodities trading firm based in the UK, before practicing law full time on his own. Bill also earned an LL.M. in Taxation from the New York University School of Law. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, September 2, at 10:00am in St. Paul Church, Main Street, Glastonbury, CT. Burial will follow in Holy Cross Cemetery, Glastonbury. Friends may call at the Mulryan Funeral Home, 725 Hebron Avenue, Glastonbury, on Thursday, September 1, from 5:00 to 8:00pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Kaelin Laboratory at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 10 Brookline Place, 6th Floor, Brookline, MA 02445, with a notation that the donation is in memory of William G. Kaelin, Sr. To share memories, please visit mulryanfh.com.

School is starting again, which means many people will reluctantly have to start paying closer attention to the time. As some music lovers have discovered, the small, square iPod Nano model can also pull double-duty as a wristwatch with one of the optional watchband accessories available for it. Getting to the clock function is easy -- just tap the Clock icon on the Nano's home screen -- but there are other time-related functions built into the Nano that are not as obvious. For example, you can set it so that the clock is always the first screen you see when you wake the Nano from sleep. Tap the Settings icon on the Home screen, then tap General, then Date & Time and turn on the ''Time on Wake'' option. And when you have the clock on screen, swipe your finger from right to left once to see the Nano's built-in stopwatch program, and swipe twice from right to left to see the player's programmable timer feature.

RIBICOFF--Casey. The staff and Board of Trustees of WNET mourn the loss of our longtime Trustee and former Vice-Chairman Casey Ribicoff. Casey helped to lead The Campaign for Thirteen, and her contributions to public television have benefited millions of viewers across the country. We extend our deepest sympathies to her son, Peter Mathes, and her family. James S. Tisch, Chairman, Board of Trustees Neal Shapiro, President and CEO WNET New York Public Media

Risk-taking is a rare thing among tablet makers. As far as operating systems are concerned (and assuming you're not Apple), your company can try to go it alone, as RIM has done and H.P. tried to do. But most manufacturers have gotten on board the Android bandwagon. From a design standpoint, the options would appear to be even more limited, boiling down to how big or small you would like your rectangle to be.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about new questions surrounding the murder case that resulted in the execution of the union activist Joe Hill in 1915 misidentified the city in Colorado where some of his ashes were scattered at a cemetery. It is Lafayette, not Denver.

The recession has not been kind to the pet industry. While their finances are in flux, pet owners are less likely to splurge on toys or grooming, and fewer vacations spell empty kennels at the boarding house. In fact, prospective owners are less likely to take on the financial burden of a new dog or cat to begin with. As you can see in the video above, David Lang, owner of a Manhattan business called Pet Chauffeur, is keenly aware of these challenges. Fifteen years ago, Mr. Lang noticed that the subway system's vast ridership included few dogs. Passengers can bring small pets on board in carrying cases, but owners of larger dogs cannot travel with their pets by subway, bus or taxi. Sensing he could fill a void, he founded Pet Chauffeur, a taxi service for animals, in 1996.

MUNN--Orson D. We extend our deepest sympathies to the family of this outstanding sportsman and conservationist. An avid waterfowler, Orson served on our board over 30 years, deeply believing he had an obligation to perpetuate waterfowl research and restoration programs for future generations to enjoy. His wise counsel and friendship will be greatly missed. Waterfowl Research Foundation

An article in some editions on Tuesday about Texas A&M's efforts to leave the Big 12 conference misstated the manner in which Texas A&M's president, R. Bowen Loftin, notified the chairman of the Big 12, Brady Deaton, of Texas A&M's intentions. It was through a telephone call, not a letter.

'MAY I CURSE A REFEREE? SWEAR WORDS AND CONSEQUENCES,'by Andrea Praschinger and Christine Pomikal, freelance scientists, and Stefan Stieger, who teaches psychology at the University of Vienna. This article appeared in the June issue of the Journal of Sports Science and Medicine. THE QUESTION: Seeing players curse the referee is as much a part of a game as is drinking beer in the stands. Still, under the Laws of the Game issued by FIFA, international soccer's governing body, the use of a swear word by a soccer player warrants a red card, an immediate ejection from the game. But as researchers have discovered, referees' decisions are influenced by what's happening on the field, the level of crowd noise, the timing of an incident and the location of the contest itself.

The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit organization that runs the TKTS discount ticket booths in New York City, recently announced it was starting the Autism Theater Initiative, which aims to make theatergoing accessible to children and adults with autism. The program kicks off on Oct. 2 with a matinee of ''The Lion King.'' ''Parents of autistic kids are concerned,'' said Lisa Carling, the fund's director of accessibility programs. ''They want their child to be comfortable, and they don't want people thinking they are bad parents because they can't calm their child down.''

On Monday, Malek Jaziri became the first Tunisian player to ever win a match at a Grand Slam tennis event during the Open era, which began in 1968. On Thursday he will play Mardy Fish, the top-seeded American, in a show court at the United States Open.

Tracing what they say is an illegal shipment of Indian hardwood, federal agents raided offices and factories belonging to Gibson Guitar Corporation last week for the second time in two years, seizing documents, computer hard drives, pallets of wood, guitars and tools. Henry E. Juszkiewicz, Gibson's chief executive and part-owner, accused the federal government of bullying the famed guitar maker. He said the agents had misread Indian laws regarding the export of ebony and rosewood fingerboards.

9 P.M. (Nickelodeon) WHAT HAPPENED? THE STORY OF SEPTEMBER 11, 2011 ''Must we revisit a horrific event that kids today don't even remember because they were too young, or weren't born yet?'' Linda Ellerbee, above, asks in an introduction to this ''Nick News'' special. ''Wouldn't a little ignorance be blissful here? Maybe. If it were possible. But the noise around the 9/11 anniversary is going to be too loud for kids to ignore, and they'll get a lot of misinformation.'' This hourlong program was devised to give young viewers a forum to discuss the day's events and to address questions about the attacks with the help of experts like Akbar Ahmed, the chairman of Islamic studies at American University; Aaron Brown, CNN's principal anchor that day; Ari Fleischer, a press secretary in the Bush administration; and Thomas H. Kean, the chairman of the 9/11 Commission. The special is complemented by an online discussion guide for parents, educators and caregivers, created in partnership with the American Psychological Association. 8 P.M. (Discovery) RISING: REBUILDING GROUND ZERO Steven Spielberg is an executive producer of this six-part series, based on a concept from Danny Forster of the Science Channel's ''Build It Bigger,'' which chronicles the rebirth of the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan and the architects, planners, construction workers and residents who have reclaimed the neighborhood. The three remaining episodes, shown consecutively, will look at the cathedral-like transportation hub beneath the site of the twin towers; the memorial commemorating the names of the thousands who died; and those who survived and returned to help rebuild.

There's an old saying among building contractors: a job can be done three ways -- cheap, fast and well. But you can pick only two out of three. That's a useful model for laptops. In this case there are three variables: cheap, light and powerful. Razer, a maker of gaming peripherals, has stepped into the laptop market with the Blade, a laptop that is light (6.9 pounds with a 17-inch display; compare that with Alienware's 17.3-inch M17x R3 laptop, which starts at 9.4 pounds) and powerful (the Blade has a 2.8 gigahertz Intel Core i7 processor).

''I never thought I would have a secondary line store,'' Zac Posen said, surveying his first-ever boutique. ''But it feels completely appropriate and thrilling.'' The cozy new Z Spoke shop in the meatpacking district stocks his flirty party dresses, daytime outfits in wool and jersey and leather goods -- all nicely priced. There are Rod Keenan hats, Illesteva sunglasses and, of all things, a fashion library in a small sitting area in back. Mr. Posen asked Michael Gallagher, of the East Village shop Gallagher Paper Collectibles, to curate a selection of rare and vintage books ($50 to $400), which Mr. Gallagher will keep restocked. Cool. Z Spoke, 875 Washington Street; (212) 691-1926. zspoke.us.

Arsenal was the most active team before European soccer's summer transfer period ended Wednesday night, plugging holes in its leaky defense by adding the towering German central defender Per Mertesacker and the Brazilian left back Andre Santos, and reinvigorating its midfield in one of the busiest days in the club's history. The moves came three days after Arsenal was thrashed, 8-2, by English Premier League rival Manchester United and amid mounting pressure on Manager Arsene Wenger to do something - anything - to strengthen the team. The Gunners had until recently been sellers in the transfer market, collecting more than $100 million by selling their two most creative midfielders, Cesc Fabregas (to Barcelona) and Samir Nasri (to Manchester City), and defender Gael Clichy (to Manchester City).

Norwegian officials have sentenced the painter Odd Nerdrum to two years in prison on charges that he evaded paying the full amount of taxes on $2.6 million that he made selling artwork between 1998 and 2002. Mr. Nerdrum, who is Norwegian but now lives in Iceland, remains free and said he planned to appeal the sentence, which was handed down Aug. 17. ''I have paid 100 percent taxes,'' he said in a telephone interview.
KELLER--Eleanor. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to her family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

With her long, dark braid flying through the air behind her, Christina McHale fired an ace to win her second-round match at the United States Open on Wednesday, then calmly lifted her arms to celebrate. She had just beaten the No. 8 seed, Marion Bartoli, in straight sets, 7-6(2), 6-2, in front of a packed grandstand stadium, prompting pockets of fans to leap to their feet in joy. But to her and her admirers, that upset was no surprise. It was the second time in just two weeks that McHale - a 19-year-old from Englewood Cliffs, N.J. - had defeated a top-10 player. In Cincinnati before the Open, she also beat Caroline Wozniacki, the world's No. 1. So Bartoli knew McHale would be hard to beat, just not impossible to beat, which McHale was on Wednesday.

Mirjana Lucic Vs. Francesca Schiavone Lucic turned pro at age 15, and two years later, in 1999, she reached the semifinals of Wimbledon. But then Lucic vanished from the game, dealing, she said later, with an abusive father and financial troubles. After a seven-year hiatus, Lucic returned to the main draw in 2010 and is back again this year facing a tough second-round challenge against the seventh-seeded Schiavone. On Tuesday, Lucic displayed plenty of her signature power against the qualifier Marina Erakovic, winning in a relatively error-free three sets. But Schiavone is a much tougher opponent, and a win here for Lucic would be a monumental upset. But just seeing Lucic back and playing well is reason enough to check in on this one. BERNARD TOMIC VS. MARIN CILIC As I have said in this space many times, Cilic has the game to win a Grand Slam someday -- and this match will tell us a great deal about whether that day could come a week from Sunday. Cilic had a nice win against the rising young American Ryan Harrison in the first round, and his reward is meeting a rising young Australian in the second. But Tomic is a very different player from Harrison -- one whose game is made to frustrate and annoy a player like Cilic. On his surprising run to the quarterfinals at Wimbledon, Tomic displayed an astounding variety of spins, angles and slices. More impressively, the 18-year-old Tomic displayed mental toughness well beyond his years. ALIZE CORNET VS. ROBERTA VINCI Vinci is a scrappy defender who wins with quickness, a nasty slice backhand and one of the better forehands on the women's tour. At 28, she is having the best year of her career, breaking into the top 20 for the first time. This summer she has notched wins against Ana Ivanovic, Yanina Wickmayer and No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki. Vinci still has some tough matches ahead of her, but don't be surprised to see her in the fourth round or even in the quarterfinals. Her opponent is nothing short of an enigma. Two years ago, Cornet was a teenager on the rise and viewed as a can't-miss top-10 talent. After a solid 2008 season, she entered 2010 ranked 11th in the world -- and it has been downhill since. MICHAEL LLODRA VS. KEVIN ANDERSON Llodra, a 6-foot-3 Frenchman, was generally known as a doubles specialist until a few years ago, when he realized his throwback, take-no-prisoners, serve-and-volley style worked pretty well in singles, too. Since then, he has become a top-25 player, and shows no signs of slowing down at the age of 31. Anderson is a big-hitting South African who, at 25, is having the best results of his career this year. At 6-8, he is one of the tallest players on tour, and has one of its biggest serves. ARON PILHOFER

CULLMAN--Edgar M. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the loss of Edgar Cullman, husband of Life Trustee, Louise Cullman. Mr. Cullman was a dear friend and benefactor of WCS and the Bronx Zoo. His devotion to animals and to the conservation of wildlife inspired us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife and to his entire family. Ward W. Woods, Chair, Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society

McFADDEN--Faith Abbott, 80, August 30, 2011, after courageous battle with cancer, peacefully at home, children by her side. Born February 25, 1931 to late Ernest Abbott and Ruth Wenzlick, survived by loving sisters Marjorie and Nancy. Beloved wife of late James P.; beloved mother of Maria, Pat, Regina, Christina and the late Robert. Loving "Granny" of James, Anna, Grace, Sophia and Rachael. Dedicated writer, author, editor, she used these talents in tireless pro-life efforts. Viewing Thursday, September 1, 2-4 and 7-10, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. Funeral Friday, September 2, 10:00am, Church of St. Agnes, 143 E. 43rd.

The Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture won't open until 2015, but it is already mounting exhibitions. Next up, the museum announced on Tuesday, is an exhibition on Thomas Jefferson and slavery, organized with the Thomas Jefferson Foundation at Monticello. The exhibition, which will examine the lives of six slave families at Monticello, will open Jan. 27, 2012, in a gallery at the National Museum of American History. It will include artifacts in the Smithsonian's collection, including a lapdesk that Jefferson used to write the Declaration of Independence, as well as objects that have been discovered through excavations at Monticello like marbles, tools, a brass shoe buckle and a bone toothbrush.

CULLMAN--Edgar M. A distinguished and warm presence in our lives over many years, whose passing saddens all who knew him. His many commitments to philanthropy were matched by a personal regard and genuine interest in ours lives, as step sons of his brother Lewis. He and his wife Louise were especially close to our late mother Dorothy Cullman. We extend our deepest condolences to Lewis, Louise, Lucy Danzinger and her husband Mike, Edgar Jr. and his wife Ellie, Susan and her husband John Kirby, and the many other members of the Cullman family. Bruce William and Frederick C. Benenson

The heat wave that gripped the city in late July is turning out to have been a fairly deadly one. Fourteen people are now certified to have died of weather-related hyperthermia, combined with other medical conditions, from July 22 to July 25, the city medical examiner's office said Wednesday. Five more died of the heat in August, bringing the total for the summer to 19. The dead included a 10-year-old girl in Brooklyn and a 97-year-old woman in the Bronx who both succumbed on July 23, when the temperature hit 100 degrees, as well as a 48-year-old Manhattan woman who died on July 25, when the heat wave finally broke after nine straight days with highs of 89 degrees or above.

KAYTON--Eloise Caroline, 84 years old, December 13, 1926 to August 28, 2011, passed away gently on First Day saying she was going home. A tireless New York City Psychoanalyst and Social Worker, she retired from her practice at age 80. She joyfully spent her last nine years with her dear grandsons Dante (14) and Nakai (13), son-in-law Dominic, and daughter Loraine. She is also survived by daughter Madeleine C. Biondolillo and Mad's beautiful children Rachel, Anthony and David. In true Quaker fashion, Eloise hoped any condolence gifts are made via a donation to the American Friends Service Committee with a memo to read: "NYMRO Internship Program on behalf of Eloise Kayton". Checks can be mailed to the American Friends Service Committee, Donor Services, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, PA 19102. Momma, walk in the light wherever you may be.

On Saturday, there were eight wood-frame, century-old bungalows perched above Jamaica Bay on the eastern edge of Broad Channel, the small island community squeezed between the Rockaways and the Howard Beach section of Queens. By Sunday morning, as Tropical Storm Irene churned across New York City, there were seven; the remains of the eighth - located at 12-08 Church Road - had collapsed into the bay.

There are several things that may explain why Sarah Palin is traveling to Iowa and New Hampshire to attend Tea Party rallies over the Labor Day weekend. Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska and 2008 Republican vice presidential nominee, could be using the trips as a prelude to an already planned presidential campaign, serving up the latest in a series of not-so-subtle hints about the importance of the states where voting will begin early next year.

BRIEF REPRIEVE The hedge fund magnate John A. Paulson, below, has endured a long, hot summer, with two of his largest funds seemingly in free fall. Few if any major managers have done as poorly as Mr. Paulson this year. His funds' performance have become an industry obsession. But last week, the storm broke momentarily for Mr. Paulson. His Advantage fund gained 2.3 percent, and the Advantage Plus gained 3.5 percent. AZAM AHMED

Are basketball players the new trophy husbands? The recent marriage of Kim Kardashian, a k a the Most Famous Woman in the World, to Kris Humphries, a journeyman National Basketball Association player four years her junior, suggests something of a minor social trend. Kim joins two other prominent women who have recently become attached to N.B.A. players less accomplished (or at least less famous) than they are. One of them is, of course, her sister. The other is the $25-million woman of the tennis world. OPPOSITES ATTRACT? Kris who? That was the reaction of many of Kim Kardashian's fans when reports leaked that she was dating Kris Humphries, 26, a player on the New Jersey Nets (one who averaged just 10 points a game last year). In contrast, Kim, 30, is a pop culture phenomenon, with a net worth estimated at $35 million and an array of perfume, clothing and jewelry lines. Like her sister Kim, Khloe Kardashian, 27, is a reality-TV regular, with starring roles in three shows on E! Meanwhile, Lamar Odom, 32, despite earning two championship rings with the Los Angeles Lakers, has never quite hit the elite level in his 12-year playing career. A plot line in one episode of ''Khloe & Lamar'' was whether he would finally make the All-Star team last season. He didn't. Maria Sharapova, 24, is the highest-paid female athlete in the world, with estimated annual earnings of $25 million. She entered this week's United States Open as the No. 3 seed. Her fiancé, Sasha Vujacic, 27, earned $5.5 million last season, playing first with the Los Angeles Lakers and then the New Jersey Nets. This summer, he is playing for Anadolu Efes, in the Turkish League.; THE COURTSHIP: Kim and Kris met in late 2010, near the end of the filming of ''Kourtney & Kim Take New York.'' According to Life & Style, the new couple was first spotted at Maxwell's bar in Hoboken, N.J., where the weight-conscious Kim ''ordered a goat cheese salad and a veggie burger (hold the bun)!'' In a word: whirlwind. The two married in September 2009, after dating for one month. In a radio interview, Khloe said that she initially disliked Lamar when they met at a Los Angeles party (''I was like ew, ew, ew!''), but then she ended up giving him her phone number anyway. The couple met in the fall of 2009 at a barbecue at the home of a mutual friend. Their first public date came in November of that year when the two were spotted at a U2 concert in New Jersey. As a couple, they are hard to miss: He is 6-7 and she is 6-2.; POPPING THE QUESTION: According to People magazine, when Kim walked into her Beverly Hills home on May 18, Kris was waiting in her bedroom on bended knee with four words written in red rose petals: Will you marry me? "OMGGGGGGG!!!!!!!!" Kim wrote on her blog a week later. "It's true! I couldn't be happier!'' Describing their quick marriage, Khloe said, ''Every single feeling in my body was like 'This is it.' '' Still, just in case, the couple signed a pre-nup. According Radar Online, if they split, Khloe will get $500,000 for every year they are married as well as courtside Lakers tickets for everyone in her family. Sasha proposed to Maria in October 2010 -- at the Serbian-born basketball player's home in Manhattan Beach, Calif. -- on the anniversary of the day they first met. ''He completely surprised me! I'm so lucky and very much spoiled," Maria told a reporter for Us magazine.; SEALED WITH A RING: Kate Middleton's massive sapphire 18-carat engagement ring is practically a dime-store novelty compared with the custom-designed, 20.5-carat Lorraine Schwartz diamond engagement ring that Kim got from Kris. Estimated value: $2 million. Khloe's engagement ring ( 12.5 carats and a reported cost of $850,000) was flashed on the covers of OK! magazine (''My Dream Wedding'') and Life & Style (''Khloe: I'm So In Love'') when the couple posed for wedding photos. A modest bauble by Kardashian standards, Maria's 8-carat diamond ring is said to be worth about $250,000. The two have yet to set a wedding date. ''We're young,'' she recently said. ''We have got many more years to spend with each other.''

BOSTON - Red Sox catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia spoke Tuesday night about the way Latin players act and play the game as a way of explaining Francisco Cervelli's emotional behavior. Moments later, concerned he may have stereotyped a large group of people, Saltalamacchia clarified that he had actually meant young players.

Human rights activists in Bahrain, the tiny but strategically important Persian Gulf monarchy, said security forces there killed a 14-year-old boy on Wednesday as they violently dispersed a protest in the oil town of Sitra, just south of the country's capital, Manama. The Bahrain Youth Society for Human Rights published photos of the dead boy, whose name has been given as Ali Jawad Ahmad, and of the bloodstained sidewalk where they said security forces fired tear gas directly at a crowd of demonstrators. Witnesses said Ali was in the crowd and was hit in the head by a tear gas canister. He died shortly after at the hospital.

An article last Thursday about the death of a second person in a stabbing rampage at an Upper Manhattan building gave an incorrect identification from the police in some editions for the additional victim. She is Yanzhi Wang -- not Yigao Chen, another a resident of the building. (The other resident who died was Ignacio Reyes-Collazo.)

WILLIAMS--Richard. RAF Wing Commander (Ret) Richard Williams OBE died in Manchester, Vermont on August 30, 2011. He was born in Kew Gardens, England on April 8, 1918, the youngest of eight children. At the age of 8, he was sent to a Quaker boarding school, the Downes School, and subsequently attended Leighton Park College near Reading, England. In January, 1939, Richard joined the 73rd Squadron of the RAF, seeing action in the so-called "phony war" in France and the frantic escape from Brittany when France fell. He was reassigned to Biggin Hill, the RAF's principal fighter station defending London during the Battle of Britain. Richard was the officer in charge of England's top-secret radar ground stations along the English Channel which were a decisive factor in the Battle of Britain. In 1942, he was asked to join the Combined Munitions Assignment Board in Washington, DC as a radar specialist. For his contributions throughout the war, Richard was awarded the Order of the British Empire by Great Britain (for services to the RAF delegation and the British Air Commission) and the Legion of Merit by the United States (for services to the Combined Chiefs of Staff). Richard remained in the aeronautical industry all his life, ultimately becoming President of the overseas division of Lear Siegler. He retired to Manchester, VT in 1982 and spent winters in Beaufort, SC. An avid golfer, he served as president and chairman of the board of trustees of Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, VT. He was a member of the U.S. Seniors, the Vermont Seniors, Callawassie Golf Club, St. George's Society, the RAF Club and was a Golden Eagle of the Wings Club. He leaves a wife of 37 years, the former Polly Simmons Barrows, of Dorset, VT, a son, David Williams of New York City, a daughter, Olwen Williams of Norton, MA, three stepdaughters, Susan Wood of Tampa, FL, Sally MacQuart of Manchester, VT and Belinda Thomas of Lexington, KY, five grandchildren, Jessica Paulus, Timothy Paulus, Eric Paulus, Conway Williams and Phoebe Williams, and numerous step-grandchildren. His previous wife of 20 years, Katharine Landis of Logansport, Indiana, died in 1971. There will be a private memorial service in Manchester, Vermont.

WITH hurricane season threatening the final days of summer, a buoyant raincoat in an eye-popping color could help to keep spirits high. Anthropologie has teamed up with British Millerain, a family-run company in Yorkshire, which has been making waxed leather and oilskin fabrics since 1880, to produce the wax-finished Heritage raincoat here. It comes in bright red with a vintage butterfly-print lining, and in yellow with navy and white dots on the inside. With a storm-ready jacket and a pair of Wellies, you'll be English countryside proper. Heritage cotton raincoat, $288 at Anthropologie shops; anthropologie.com.

August was already a wet month long before Tropical Storm Irene swept across New York City. But the storm's deluge made August one for the record books. It is now the wettest month ever recorded since meteorologists began keeping records in Central Park in 1868.

Some of the most colorful characters in the Union cavalry could be found not in the saddle of a foam-flecked charger, but in the seat of a company wagon. These ubiquitous drivers of teams of horses or mules, known as teamsters, occupied the bottom of the chain of army command. But the Union Army was a fluid hierarchy, where men of talent and drive could rise quickly - even men who started out on the lowest rung.

More companies in an industry mean more competition and all the benefits that flow from competition -- lower prices, more choices and more innovation.
