Maybe it's anticipation for the new iPhone 5, but something has electronics trade-in sites coming out of the walls. They pretty much all offer the same proposition: the best price for your used electronics. They can't all be right, which leaves it to you to find the sites, enter your data and sort out the results. Hardly worth the $2 you'd get for a fourth-generation iPod Shuffle.

Albacore, which I write about this week in City Kitchen, is quite delicious when it is fresh, but most of it ends up in cans. When buying canned, it is a good idea to look for albacore that comes from small boats that take smaller fish: tastier, sweeter and lower in mercury. These cans are usually marketed by cooperatives, and contain no additives, like soy or vegetable broth. And at the risk of sounding un-American, generally speaking, better-quality canned tuna comes from elsewhere, like Italy or Spain. Imported tuna belly, ventresca, packed in olive oil, tends to be pricey, best thought of as a delicacy rather than a commonplace lunchbox item.

Donald Young has long been burdened by the lofty expectations that came with being the youngest-ever world junior number one at age 16. Pegged as a talented underachiever who flailed due to poor coaching, the Chicago native went a long way to silencing his critics on court 17 Friday, showing stamina and heart in a dramatic, potentially career-changing, four-hour, 21-minute victory over the No. 14 seed, Stanislas Wawrinka, 7-6, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6 (1).

The Spanish and Italian interest rate spreads -- the difference between their borrowing costs and Germany's -- are widening again. So we're drifting back toward the point at which these countries might enter vicious circles of falling confidence and rising debt burdens.

To get pictures like the ones in this week's cover story - a photo portfolio of ironworkers 70-plus stories off the ground at One World Trade Center - you have to do more than ride a couple hoists, climb a couple flights of temporary stairs and then open the camera shutter. You have to decide a year earlier that you want to get to the top, and then spend months persuading the Port Authority to let you do so. Then your photographer has to take two five-hour Occupational Safety and Health Administration classes devoted to construction-site safety, and a four-hour fall safety-awareness class. (Otherwise, how would you know that you really don't want to be tethered to anything that can't hold at least 10 times your weight? Because falling has the effect of making you heavier.) Finally, you have to go back-and-forth with the Port Authority for days to make sure you're on the building at the very beginning of a new two-floors-per-fortnight cycle, before the safety "cocoon" goes up, so your photographer can get the best possible views of the ironworkers against the skyline.

Federal regulators filed suits on Friday against several of the nation's leading banks, seeking billions in compensation for huge losses by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on mortgage-backed securities the banks assembled during the housing boom, The New York Times reports. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, Barclays and Nomura are among the defendants in the suits, brought by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which oversees Fannie and Freddie. Cole Stryker, a freelance writer and media consultant living in New York, spent years digging into Internet culture and communities, both as a participant and as a blogger covering viral phenomena. He's the author of a new book called "Epic Win for Anonymous: How 4chan's Army Conquered the Web." He discussed with me what it's like exploring the seedy underbelly of the Internet, the rise of Anonymous, and why it and 4chan, widely considered one of the darkest and most subversive corners of the Internet, may be one of the most important and influential creations to emerge from the modern Web.

This week's playlist - which the Jam's Sean Hanratty calls "atypical" - comes from the Danish designer Henrik Vibskov, who is known primarily for his untraditional, fantastical and almost childlike take on fashion. But Hanratty says that Vibskov's "wildy inventive talents" extend far beyond just clothing. "I have always had such a love for his work, but even more because of his varied interests and artistic nature," says Hanratty of the established artist whose autumn-winter 2009 show featured models donning oversize Amish hats while powering black and white striped, human-size hamster wheels in an echoing warehouse outside of Copenhagen. His collection was called Human Laundry. "He is an interdisciplinarian and renaissance man in the truest sense," Hanratty says. Vibskov also drums for the Danish electro outfit Trentemoller. His new unisex fragrance line, which will be introduced during New York Fashion Week, is called Type. "It reflects geographical locale rather than specific mood," says Hanratty of the three scents, each called Type A, B and C. "I knew, given his varied interests, that I would get a very atypical selection."

Consistent with the predictions of climate science, we seem to have entered an era of erratic weather and rising weather extremes. We are only halfway through 2011 and it's already been a crazy weather year - the third such year in a row. The science offers us no reason to believe this situation is going to get better, so it is time to start thinking about ways to cope.

In this week's Your Money column, I took the best shot I could in 1,400 words or so at helping widows avoid the financial pitfalls that so many of them fall into. They need not rush into making financial decisions, they should think hard about housing, they should not be a "purse" for anyone and they should be wary of blindly following financial orders left by their dead husbands.

Allen Fox coaches Igor Kunitsyn, a Russian journeyman who came back from two sets down to defeat Germany's Matthias Bachinger on Tuesday. (Kunitsyn plays Jurgen Melzer of Austria on Friday.) HIRSCH--Gabriel Landay, died on August 27, 2011 at age 22. Beloved son of Janet Landay and Edward Hirsch, he will be remembered by all who loved him for his humor and sweet soul. Services at 11:30am Friday, September 2nd at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Remembrances to a charity of your choice.

It's an event that seems to happen in the ''Star Wars'' world about as often as Wookiees celebrate Life Day, and which fans await with just as much dread. New versions of George Lucas's space-fantasy films are released, and with them come changes to the movies - alterations to audio and video, characters' actions and even dialogue that is very different from what fans remember seeing in theaters a long time ago and far, far away. So it goes for the latest editions of the six ''Star Wars'' live-action features that are being prepared for a Blu-ray home video release on Sept. 16. Previously, it was reported that the version of ''Star Wars - Episode I: The Phantom Menace'' included in this release would replace the puppet version of the Yoda character with a computer-generated creation. Then on Tuesday, an online report by Devin Faraci suggested a revelation almost as troubling as the news that Luke and Leia had been brother and sister all along: in a climactic scene from ''Return of the Jedi,'' when Darth Vader hurls the evil Emperor to his demise on the Death Star, he would now shout ''No!'' (In all previous versions of ''Jedi,'' Vader has committed this crucial deed in silence.)

Dedicated writer, author, editor, she used these talents in tireless pro-life efforts. Viewing Thursday, September 1, 2-4 and 7-10, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. Funeral Friday, September 2, 10:00am, Church of St. Agnes, 143 E. 43rd.

The video appeared to depict a Muslim woman -- not several -- being raped by men in American military uniforms.

WALLICK--Gloria, on August 31 after a determined battle with Alzheimer's. Beloved mother of Michael (Gayle), Claire (Kai Moy), Larry (Carolyn Horn) and Jim (Cathy). Proud grandmother to Brian, Carrie, Jessie, Karina, Russell, Daniel, Sophia and Eric. Devoted sister of Suzi (Martin) Oppenheimer. Loving wife and partner to the late Mel; who we miss greatly. Graduate of Brown. University, with a masters in policy analysis from the New School University, her life was devoted to bettering the lives of children and families. In the 1960s, she worked on Head Start programs, and in 1971 she helped found one of the first child care centers on Long Island, the Rosa Lee Young Childhood Center in Rockville Centre. In 1978 she became the first director of the fledgling Child Care Council of Nassau, where she served for 23 years. Her spirit of commitment, intelligence, and, warmth infused everything she did and all people she touched. She has inspired many people, most of all, her loving family. Services to be held at 11am on Monday, September 5 at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Child Care Council, of Nassau or the Rosa Lee Young Childhood Center in Rockville Centre, NY.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the Albany Park Workers' Center, which was set up in an effort to reform the day-labor industry, overstated what was known about the immigration status of one of the workers there. His surname was withheld because he might be an illegal immigrant, not because he is indeed here illegally.

An article on Wednesday about young reporters who are learning the basics of the campaign trail, including separating personal commentary from news coverage, referred imprecisely to a Muslim cleric whose death prompted an experienced journalist, Octavia Nasr, CNN's senior editor for Middle East affairs, to express her sadness on Twitter, which led to her firing. While the cleric, Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, was often identified by Western governments as the spiritual mentor of Hezbollah, his direct link to the militant Islamist organization was never determined, and therefore he was not necessarily ''a Hezbollah leader.'' (Ms. Nasr called him ''one of Hezbollah's giants,'' but he always denied having any authority over the group.)

The 7,203-square-foot sloping Laurie M. Tisch Illumination Lawn that tops the Lincoln restaurant at Lincoln Center is open for business this holiday weekend, a slow one for the arts complex. The lawn, on the north plaza along 65th Street, first opened last summer, was briefly closed because of brown spots caused by dehydration. It stayed open till last November and opened again in the spring, as Lincoln Center mastered the art of groundskeeping. The blades of this lawn are held in place by roots and by a geoweb, a type of polyethylene cellular mat. The hardy varieties of grass (tall fescue mixed with Kentucky bluegrass) were chosen to withstand all the walking the green space would see.

Semenya was barred from competing for 11 months, returning in 2010, after questions arose about her gender.

An obituary on Thursday about Bernard Wolfman, a leading critic of the United States tax system, misidentified his first wife. She was the former Zelda Bernstein -- not the former Elizabeth Coff, who was Mr. Wolfman's mother.

GINSBURG--Abe, passed away peacefully at home on September 1, 2011, at the age of 94. Abe is survived by his loving wife Sylvia; his devoted children Bernice Gailing, Howard Ginsburg, and Jaclyn Hartstein; his adoring grandchildren Stephanie, Aimee, Eric, Scott, Joshua, Zachary, and Alexa; his precious great-grandchildren Sophie, Maeve and Ari; and his admiring children-in-laws David Harstein, Randi Zinz Ginsburg, and Marvin Schwartz. Abe was a devoted family man with a brilliant mind, huge heart, beaming smile, and knowing eyes. He was the definition of a gentleman; he cared deeply for other people, priding himself on doing right by others. His generosity was extensive and beyond definition -- and was among the many ways he inspired so many lives. Abe was the founder of and driving force behind Jaclyn, Inc., a handbag, apparel, and accessory company. Abe was loved and respected by all. While his survivors will always hold him in their hearts where he will serve to inspire them throughout their lives, he will be sorely missed. A private funeral service will be held on Sunday, September 4.

While many residents in the New York region grabbed shovels, chain saws and dehumidifiers in the wake of Tropical Storm Irene, another breed of New Yorker reflexively - and joyfully - reached for binoculars. They are the serious birders, men and women who will go to unusual lengths to see pelagic birds, which spend most of their lives on the ocean, as well as little-known songbirds and rare shorebirds. Serious birders know that hurricanes and tropical storms bring not only flooding and heartache, but treasures in the form of once-in-a-lifetime bird sightings.

The worlds of Sting, the lute-wielding pop-rock Renaissance man, and Brian Yorkey, the Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning book writer and lyricist of ''Next to Normal,'' are coming together with increasing synchronicity in a new musical that is being prepared for readings in October. According to a casting breakdown that was circulated for the project, the musical is titled ''The Last Ship,'' and features music and lyrics by Sting and a book by Mr. Yorkey, who is directing. Though a plot summary is not provided, descriptions of the musical's characters suggest a story that is set in the 1980s in Newcastle, the northern British city where Sting was born and raised before joining his band the Police. The lead character, Gideon, is described as a man in his 30s: ''Charismatic, charming, cynical, worldly-wise; quick to buy a round or throw a fist, slow to open his heart. Grew up around the shipyards of Newcastle, got out as soon as he could, coming home to come to terms with his family, his history, and his future.'' (At least some of those qualities sound like they could also apply to one Gordon Sumner, a k a Sting.)

An article on Wednesday about farms in the Catskills that were crippled by flooding caused by Tropical Storm Irene misidentified the waterway that runs through the Lawrence and Tompkins farms in Ashland, N.Y. It is Batavia Kill, not Schoharie Creek. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

The Trade column on Thursday, about Warren E. Buffett's $5 billion investment in Bank of America, referred incorrectly to the investment's impact on the bank's capital position. Of the $5 billion, $2 billion will count in the measure of capital called Tier 1 under the current capital standard, known as Basel I. It is not the case that none of the $5 billion will count as Tier 1 capital.

Married 59 and half years to Tang, Yu-Jung. Beloved father of Deborah Wen Alt and William Wen. Grandfather of Jenna Liang, Joely, Nicholas, Michael, Jillian and Brandon Peter. Service are being handled by the Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home, Ramsey, NJ.

Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Jennifer and Alex, Heather and Isabella. Great-grandmother of Jack, Theo, Kate and Phoebe. She will live forever in our hearts.

More than 100 artworks that were held in buildings damaged in July's terrorist attack in Oslo are missing, including more than 40 that were on loan from Norway's National Museum of Art, The Art Newspaper reported on Wednesday. In addition to National Museum-owned works by artists including Christian Krohg, Anne Katrine Dolven and Jakob Weidemann, other missing art is owned by government ministries or on loan from Public Art Norway, the government agency for art in public spaces.

One of the most famous unfinished recordings in the history of popular music --The Beach Boys' ''Smile'' sessions -- will be released in November, 44 years after it was scheduled to come out, Capitol/EMI records has announced. The recordings were made in 1966 and 1967 and were intended to follow on the band's critically acclaimed album ''Pet Sounds.'' But ''Smile'' was left unfinished and shelved after the group's co-founder, Brian Wilson, suffered an emotional breakdown and the group's legal dispute with Capitol Records over the formation of the band's label.
BANTA--Melissa Wickser, a long-time contributor to the State University of New York at Buffalo and the local Buffalo arts scene, died on August 18th, her 86th birthday.

9 P.M. (Discovery) MAN, WOMAN, WILD Mykel Hawke, a wilderness expert and former Green Beret, and his wife, Ruth England (above left, with Mr. Hawke), a city girl and television journalist, embark on a second season of roughing it in some of the world's most dangerous locations. The adventure begins as they await rescue after their rented boat breaks down 20 miles off the coast of the Bahamas. They use raisins and the sun's heat to turn salt water into fresh, and Ms. England treats her seasick and dehydrated husband by administering an enema to him at sea. 7:35 A.M. (TMC) CHILDREN ON THEIR BIRTHDAYS (2002) In this adaptation of a Truman Capote short story, the new girl (Tania Raymonde) in an Alabama town makes a big impression, especially on a couple of boys (Joe Pichler and Jesse Plemons). Tom Arnold, above, also stars, and Mark Medoff, who wrote the play ''Children of a Lesser God,'' directed.

An article on Wednesday about President Obama's speech to the American Legion on Tuesday paraphrased incorrectly from comments he made about hiring veterans. He said he had told federal agencies to hire more veterans and that they had in fact hired more than 100,000 in the past 18 months. He did not say that he is currently ordering the federal government to hire 100,000 more veterans.

CULLMAN--Edgar M. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the loss of Edgar Cullman, husband of Life Trustee, Louise Cullman. Mr. Cullman was a dear friend and benefactor of WCS and the Bronx Zoo. His devotion to animals and to the conservation of wildlife inspired us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife and to his entire family. Ward W. Woods, Chair, Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society

NORTON, Mass. - Spectators on Friday afternoon at the first round of the Deutsche Bank Championship, the second of four events in the FedEx Cup playoffs, will get a chance to see at least one thing they have not seen before: Phil Mickelson using a belly putter. Mickelson, who will go off the first tee at 12:38 p.m., will be wielding an Odyssey belly putter for the first time in competition. It was made to mirror the specs of the one Keegan Bradley has used all year, most recently in his victory at the P.G.A. Championship.

CHRISTINA MCHALE VS. MARIA KIRILENKO On Wednesday, McHale scored one of the biggest upsets of the tournament, ousting the No. 8 seed, Marion Bartoli, in straight sets. Things don't get any easier as the 19-year-old McHale steps on court Thursday against the 25th-seeded Kirilenko. McHale's game is a bit of a throwback. She does not have the power of many of her peers, but she is a solid defender who can keep opponents off balance by constantly changing the angle, pace and trajectory of her shots. Although her ranking isn't as high as Bartoli's, Kirilenko, a Russian veteran, is in some ways a tougher matchup for McHale. She plays a similar baseline game but is much quicker around the court and will be less bothered by McHale's looping shots. ERNESTS GULBIS VS. GILLES MüLLER Gulbis, a 23-year-old Latvian, is another of those players whose results have not matched their talent. He has the kind of strokes that make you wonder how he ever loses -- a monster forehand, a laser beam of a backhand and a serve that rivals anyone's. Müller is the sort of steady veteran who should not give a player like Gulbis much trouble. But it is precisely situations like this where Gulbis has disappointed in the past.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE -There's an old story that goes something like this: When Carl Gauss, a German mathematician, was still a child prodigy blazing his way through school, his teacher assigned the class the tedious task of counting up all the numbers from 1 to 100. While his classmates began the timely process of adding up the numbers sequentially, the young wunderkind thought of a shortcut and arrived at the answer in a snap. What the young Gauss did was work from the outside in: he knew there were 50 pairs of numbers that added up to 100 (0+100, 1+99 etc. through 49+51), and that 50 times 100 is 5,000. Then he simply tacked on the middle 50 and announced to the class that the grand total was 5,050 -- astounding his teacher and probably making him the target of more than a few wet-Wilhelms.

CLAREMAN--Jack, 95 years old, died peacefully on September 2, 2011. He was the completely devoted husband of the late Rhoda Clareman; the loving and generous father of Lloyd Clareman, Pauli Wertheim, and the late Susan Clareman Emden; a kind and caring father-in-law to Patrice Clareman, David Wertheim, and Robert Emden; the doting grandfather of Billy (and wife Emily), Rebecca and Bart Clareman, and Robert, Julia and Samuel Wertheim; and, in his final months, the proud great-grandfather of the next Jack Clareman, son of Billy and Emily. The memory of his extraordinary goodness and generosity will be cherished by everyone who knew him. Services will be held Sunday, September 4, at 1:00pm, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Writers have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in ''Funny Girl''; unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings; the buzzkill of pre-show announcements; the etiquette of booing at the theater; and the good that can come from bad reviews. This week, Jack Viertel, the senior vice president of Jujamcyn Theaters, remembers the late songwriter Jerry Leiber and his role in creating a durable if highly debated stage genre, the jukebox musical. Jerry Leiber, who died on Aug. 22, has been justly celebrated in the last week as one of the fathers of rock 'n' roll. Indeed, with his writing and business partner Mike Stoller, he was a force to be reckoned with, turning out hits for Elvis, the Drifters and the Coasters, among others, and building a music publishing empire. What's been less noted is the strange and wonderful way he straddled many worlds - artist and tycoon, comedian and rock rebel, hipster, vulgarian and aesthete.

The field of Democrats planning to run against Senator Scott Brown in Massachusetts next year just got smaller. Representative Michael E. Capuano, a seven-term Democrat, announced on Friday that he would not run for the Senate. His decision lessened the chances of a competitive primary for Elizabeth Warren, the consumer advocate and Harvard law professor who shook up the race last month when she said she might run.

It may not be the most well-known aspect of the New York Fire Department, but there is a large subset of firefighters who surf. Many of them hail from the Rockaways and the south shore of Long Island, and many manage to work in firehouses in southern Brooklyn and Queens, which makes it easier to catch a few waves before or after work. The prevalence of wave-riding firefighters was visible at the surfing competition offered as part of the World Police and Fire Games being held this week in New York City to help commemorate the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

Hurricane Irene has many people thinking about flood insurance. Loretta Worters, vice president of the Insurance Information Institute, answered inquiries about flood protection policies. Q.Does homeowners' insurance typically cover damage from basement flooding arising from a loss of power to the sump pumps?

Signaling its commitment to tackling the social issues that affect childhood obesity, the White House announced on Friday that Dr. Judith S. Palfrey will head Michelle Obama's ''Let's Move'' campaign to fight childhood oebsity. A pediatrician for more than 30 years, Dr. Palfrey recently served as president of the American Academy of Pediatrics and director of the Children's Hospital of Boston's global health efforts. But Dr. Palfrey, who will start as executive director of ''Let's Move'' on Tuesday, has also made a name for herself as a child advocate.

On a sweltering night in Waco, Tex., Baylor quarterback Robert Griffin's five touchdown passes and fourth-quarter mettle led the Bears to a 50-48 victory over No. 14 Texas Christian, ending T.C.U.'s 25-game regular-season winning streak. Baylor led by 24 points at the start of the fourth quarter but trailed in the waning minutes after Casey Pachall threw three touchdown passes to lead a wild T.C.U. comeback. A 27-yard field goal by Ross Evans with 4 minutes 31 seconds remaining capped 25 unanswered points by the Horned Frogs, putting them ahead, 48-47.

Ten years after they watched and felt the World Trade Center towers crumble from their classroom windows, alumni from Stuyvesant High School have been trying to organize a vigil to commemorate that day. There's only one problem: No one will let them back in or near their school on Sept. 11, 2011. After a month of phone calls and e-mails failed to secure a space for the vigil, the alumni are appealing to elected officials for help.

Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona said Friday that she would not move up the state's Republican presidential primary to Jan. 31, a carefully watched decision that would have led Iowa to move its caucuses and New Hampshire its primary to immediately after New Year's Day. The Republican National Committee, which is trying to bring order to the chaotic calendar of the party's nominating contest, has offered to hold a presidential debate in Arizona in exchange for the governor agreeing not to move the state's primary, which is scheduled for Feb. 28.

The University of Oklahoma will decide whether to leave the Big 12 within the next three weeks, its president, David Boren, said Friday. Oklahoma's departure could further weaken a league already shaken by the losses of Nebraska and Colorado and Texas A&M's seemingly inevitable move to the Southeastern Conference next week. ''I hoped we had stability; I guess I'm just disappointed that the original Big 12 is not the same Big 12,'' Boren told The Oklahoman newspaper.

The Dominique Strauss-Kahn case has inspired exhaustive and perhaps exhausting public venting. But some have wondered why one person who would normally be expected to weigh in on such a controversial episode had been notably silent: the Rev. Al Sharpton. Now Mr. Sharpton has spoken up. The reason he had said nothing was that he had never met with the woman who accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her and that he had not been briefed on what she and her supporters were advocating.

An obituary on Friday about Ronald Fernandez, a sociology professor who wrote about the history of American colonialism in Puerto Rico, referred imprecisely to the federal tax obligations of residents of the island. While they pay Social Security and Medicare taxes, they do not pay federal income tax on income from Puerto Rican sources. (Federal government employees there do pay federal income tax.) And a subheading with the obituary described incorrectly the $7 million robbery by a Puerto Rican independence group that inspired Dr. Fernandez's interest in Puerto Rican nationalism. As the obituary correctly noted, it involved an armored car depot, not a bank.

The Venice Film Festival started on Wednesday, at or below sea level. I headed in the other direction, to Telluride, the former mining town in Colorado whose high-altitude festival occurs every year on Labor Day. Some people -- and a handful of movies -- manage to be in both places at once. George Clooney, for example. Mr. Clooney, after premiering ''The Ides of March'' -- of which he is director and star -- on the Lido, will come up to the San Juan mountains to receive a tribute. (Tilda Swinton will too.) Mr. Clooney stars in ''The Descendants,'' the new film from Alexander Payne, his first since ''Sideways,'' which will be shown here. So will ''George Harrison: Living in the Material World,'' Martin Scorsese's new documentary.

An article on Thursday about new laws in Florida that are helping to curb illegal sales of prescription drugs misstated the amount of oxycodone purchased by doctors in Florida in the first six months of last year. Doctors in the state purchased 89 percent of the oxycodone sold to practitioners nationwide during that period. They did not buy 89 percent of all the oxycodone sold in the country last year. The article also referred imprecisely to the lethal effect of oxycodone. While it is a lethal drug and indeed caused the most deaths by drug overdose in Florida last year, it is not necessarily the most lethal of all narcotics in the sense of being the most potent. (More often than not, medical experts cite heroin as the most potent.)

JUAN MONACO Haas may be 33 -- the oldest player left in the draw -- and ranked 400-something in the world, but when healthy, he can still play, as he demonstrated by ousting Alejandro Falla in straight sets Thursday. His next opponent, Juan Monaco of Argentina, is another clay-court specialist, but is a tad more dangerous on hardcourts than Falla.

RYAN--Mary Elizabeth, died peacefully on September 1, 2011 at age 93. Betty was joyously married to the late Bernard J. Ryan, MD. A beloved lady, mother and grandmother, she is survived by her devoted children Kathleen Ryan Gerard, Christopher Ryan, Elizabeth Ryan and Elaine Ryan Ittleman and grandchildren Rupert Gerard, John Gerard, Luke Ryan, Julia Ryan, Ryan Pepper, Mercedes Pepper, Kate Ittleman Foster, Benjamin Ittleman and Patrick Ittleman. Betty inspired all with her kindness and courage and it is with a heavy heart that her family bids her farewell. A funeral mass will be held at Our Lady of the Isle Church, Shelter Island, NY at 1030am, Monday, September 5. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Shelter Island Library or the Sylvester Manor Educational Farm is appreciated.

An article on Friday about the new challenges facing Gov. Peter Shumlin of Vermont in the aftermath of Hurricane Irene described incorrectly the location of Vermont Yankee, a nuclear power plant that Mr. Shumlin wants shut down. It is in the southeast corner of the state, not the southwest.

7:24 p.m. | Updated The News Corporation's board of directors underwent significant reshuffling on Friday with the departure of two long-serving members and the nomination of a new independent voice. James W. Breyer, a prominent venture capitalist and member of Facebook's board, will be nominated for election to the board when shareholders gather for their annual meeting in October. He is expected to lend an outside perspective to a body that is viewed as highly deferential to its chairman, Rupert Murdoch.

8 P.M. (HBO) MEGAMIND (2010) Will Ferrell lends his voice to this movie's blue-tinted, egg-headed title character, above, a hypersensitive brainiac who faces an existential crisis after one of his grandiose, evil schemes to vanquish his nemesis, the Elvis-coiffed Metro Man (Brad Pitt), actually works. Jonah Hill is Hal, the nerdy redheaded cameraman for the local television station, whom a disconsolate Megamind transforms into Tighten, a Metro Man replacement. And Tina Fey is Roxanne Ritchie, the beautiful and fearless news reporter coveted by all three, er, men. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said, ''Typical of DreamWorks Animation toons, 'Megamind' is crammed with pop culture references and jokes invented to show how up-to-the-minute it is in its slang and encyclopedic comic-book know-how.'' He added that visually the film ''is immaculately sleek and gracefully enhanced by 3-D,'' and that ''the opposite of the dark, murky Gotham City of 'Batman,' Metro City is a gleaming hub of institutional architecture, spacious promenades and jutting spires.'' By the time Michael Jackson's ''Bad'' plays near the end of the movie, ''Megamind's nature has largely triumphed over his nurture; heroism becomes him, and Roxanne's love looms as real possibility,'' Mr. Holden said. NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Norman Lear celebrates the 30th anniversary of People for the American Way, his civil liberties advocacy group, and discusses how his comedies ''All in the Family,'' ''Maude'' and ''The Jeffersons'' affected American behavior.

Last week, Ron Lieber wrote about character traits that doctors have that may lead them to financial harm. Here's a sampling of comments received in response: Most physicians I know and work with live ''within their means'' but as their income rises postresidency they live on their entire paycheck. This means that proportionately they are saving far less than many less-well-paid friends, relatives and neighbors. The sense of entitlement is very powerful, for luxury cars, beautiful homes, country club memberships, private schools for their kids. ...

When people talk about being a buy-and-hold investor these days, they are often confronted by others who declare that the last 10 years were a ''lost decade.'' When I wrote about the power of compound interest a few weeks ago, many of the comments focused on this idea that the decade ending on Dec. 31, 2010 was the decade of lost money for most investors. Not surprisingly, people then take the next step and say that it could continue, and the United States could end up looking like Japan - 25 years of negative or flat stock market performance.

ASCH--Hon. Sidney H.,92, died peacefully in North Carolina on September 1, 2011, after a long struggle with Parkinson's disease. Loving husband of the late Amy Cohen Asch. Devoted brother of the late Dr. Stuart S. Asch. Devoted father of Jane Asch, MD, and Nancy Asch (Beth Heinberg). Adoring grandfather of Emily Asch. Beloved as a professor of law, legislator, and judge, he had a creative and incisive mind. Everyone who came in contact with him responded to his enveloping warmth and interest. Throughout his long illness, the family was supported by many devoted friends and relatives. Funeral to be held Sunday, September 4 at 11am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York. Shiva calls Sunday, September 4 and Monday, September 5 from 6pm-9pm at the home of Jane Asch. Donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

After many months of behind-the-scenes drama on its costly scripted drama series, AMC, the cable home of ''Mad Men,'' ''Breaking Bad'' and ''The Walking Dead,'' said on Thursday that it was moving forward on two new reality programs - shows that will presumably be easier on the channel's pocketbook and won't result in as many backstage headaches. The first show, ''Secret Stash,'' comes from Kevin Smith (who earned his geek-culture bona fides with his films ''Clerks'' and ''Chasing Amy'') and is set in his Red Bank, N.J., comics shop, Jay and Silent Bob's Secret Stash. AMC said in a news release that the series would capture ''the world of the neighborhood comic-book store and fanboy culture'' and is planned for a first-quarter 2012 premiere. The ever-talkative Mr. Smith, who will be an executive producer of the show, said in a statement that he was ''ecstatic, proud, and extremely lucky to be in bed with a network I watch religiously anyway,'' adding: ''If they'd pushed just a little harder in the negotiations, I'd have done this show for no payment beyond early access to every episode of 'Mad Men,' 'Breaking Bad' and 'Walking Dead.' ''

Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, acknowledging widespread dissatisfaction with extended power failures on Long Island after Tropical Storm Irene, suggested on Friday that the Long Island Power Authority should consider replacing the energy company it pays to run its electric system, National Grid, when the contract expires. The power authority, known as LIPA, is close to awarding a new contract for the operation of its system beginning in 2014. Mr. Cuomo controls 9 of the 15 seats on its board of trustees, including the position of chairman, and the governor said on Friday that he would offer them some blunt advice.

The owners of a German art gallery say they have uncovered works by the Expressionist painter Otto Dix - three watercolors and a study for a portrait - at a Bavarian estate, Reuters reported. Two of the paintings are titled ''Naechtens'' and ''Soubrette'' while the third, ''Strich III,'' shows a street-scene with prostitutes; the fourth is a study for a 1926 portrait of the art dealer Alfred Flechtheim, Reuters said. The works date from 1922 to 1925. The gallery owners, Herbert Remmert and Peter Barth, identified the works at an estate owned by the daughter and granddaughter of Hans and Martha Koch, the news agency said. Hans Koch was a doctor and art collector; Martha Koch left him for Dix and later married the artist. The gallery has collaborated in the past with the family in searching for works at the estate, Reuters said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Lincoln Center Programming department mourns the passing of Mark Popkin, physicist and bassoonist, and founding member of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and North Carolina School of the Arts. Mark was truly a Renaissance man. As a performer and teacher through the years, he inspired countless musicians. We send our condolences to his wife, Elsie, and his family and friends. Jane Moss Ehrenkranz Artistic Director Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Well, hello there! I hope you all had a good week, and before we tear into another week's worth of crossword puzzles, I'd like to sincerely thank Thomas Gaffney for stepping up to the plate and batting them out of the park while I was off mopping my brow. Tom did an excellent job, as did the wonderful players in the dugout who helped support him, and they all deserve a round of applause from the fans in the stands. There just might be something left to Andy Roddick at this year's U.S. Open after all. Roddick roared back to life with a convincing 6-1, 6-4, 7-6 win over Julien Benneteau, mixing power with patience, serving with authority but also playing with a high shot tolerance. Compared with his first two rounds, in which he looked tentative and defensive, Roddick worked the point until he got a short ball then approached with a knifing backhand slice. His ground game and movement were visibly improved from his awkward win over Jack Sock on Friday night.

Many contemporary philosophers describe themselves as naturalists. They mean that they believe something like this: there is only the natural world, and the best way to find out about it is by the scientific method. I am sometimes described as a naturalist. Why do I resist the description? Not for any religious scruple: I am an atheist of the most straightforward kind. But accepting the naturalist slogan without looking beneath the slick packaging is an unscientific way to form one's beliefs about the world, not something naturalists should recommend.

As TNT approached the end of a summer that gave it two new hit shows, "Falling Skies" and "Franklin & Bash," the cable channel pulled the plug on an older show, "HawthoRNe." The channel said on Friday that it had elected not to order a fourth season of the show, which featured Jada Pinkett Smith as chief nursing officer at a hospital. "TNT truly appreciates the tremendous dedication of everyone involved," it said in a statement. TNT recently ordered a second season of "Falling Skies," which was the most popular new cable show of the summer with an average of 6.9 million viewers, and "Franklin & Bash," which averaged 3.9 million. The third season of "HawthoRNe" typically had about 3.3 million viewers. The cancellation may also make room for one of the shows that TNT is developing, like its remake of "Dallas" or its spin-off of "The Closer," "Major Crimes."

"The Help" officially achieved blockbuster status over the weekend by holding onto the No. 1 spot at North American multiplexes for a third consecutive week. That DreamWorks Studios movie, based on the best-selling novel about black maids in the 1960s and their white employers, took in an estimated $14.2 million for a new total of $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Second place went to "The Debt," a Focus Features espionage drama that sold a surprisingly robust $9.7 million in tickets for a total of about $14 million since opening on Wednesday; solid reviews and the potential thrill of seeing Helen Mirren as a retired but still derrière-kicking Mossad agent probably drove interest. The weekend's other two new releases came in neck and neck: "Apollo 18," a thriller from the Weinstein Company, was a limp third with an estimated $8.7 million in ticket sales, and "Shark Night 3-D" (Relativity Media) took in about $8.6 million for fourth place. Rounding out the top five was 20th Century Fox's "Rise of the Planet of the Apes," which sold $7.8 million in tickets for a five-week total of about $160 million.

PASSONNEAU--Joseph R.,architect, engineer, author and map maker, died Monday morning in DC. Born Pullman, Washington, January 19, 1921 to Sarah Anderson and Joseph Passonneau, Sr. Raised in Atwater, Minnesota, with sisters Caroline and Alice, his mother taught, his father farmed. In 1939, he went to Harvard University as a Conant National Scholar. Then to the South Pacific in WWII, code breaking for Naval Intell. After, return to graduate school on the GI bill, he obtained simultaneous Masters degrees in Architecture and Engineering from Harvard and MIT. While in graduate school, he married fellow Minnesotan Janet Vivian, a Ph.D candidate at Radcliffe College. He used her bicycle to make his way between the two universities. He was the author of the definitive work, Washington Through Two Centuries: A History of Maps and Images. JRP & Partners completed some of the most difficult transportation projects in the United States, including the Glenwood Canyon stretch of Interstate 40, solving a heated environmental and political dispute in Colorado, and which is lauded as both a work of beauty and a feat of civil engineering. He received numerous awards, including a Presidential citation. He was the Dean of the School of Architecture at Washington University in St. Louis from 1957 to 1967, taught at Harvard, Princeton, and the Universities of Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Southern California. He is survived by his wife Janet Vivian, his son Christopher Neal, three daughters, Rebecca Jane, Polly Nicole, and Sarah Michelle, Sarah's husband, Stanley Harpole, Rebecca's daughter, Vivian, and Sarah and Stanley's daughter, Ada Tea.

Once the province of home hobbyists and a few academics, vehicle-to-grid charging, or V2G, is gaining momentum. When appropriately equipped, a plug-in hybrid or purely electric vehicle can operate like a generator on wheels, powering a house in a blackout or feeding electricity to the grid. New devices that enable V2G are being developed for the Japanese market by Nissan, Mitsubishi and Toyota, with the first systems expected to reach customers within a year.

IN the traffic-clogged city of Amman, the Jordanian capital, pedestrians are a rare sight. Rainbow Street (bottom right) and the surrounding area, in the historic Jabal Amman neighborhood, is one of the few places where locals can park their cars and stroll, stopping at the many cafes, galleries and boutiques that have opened in the last few years. It's the culmination of equal parts urban planning (the city widened the sidewalks and converted the streets to cobblestone, so cars must slow down) and entrepreneurship (like the Friday flea market, organized by a neighborhood association). The area's renaissance also builds on one of its historic attractions: Rainbow Street was originally home to one of the city's first upscale movie theaters, the newly restored Rainbow Cinema, and farther down the street is Jordan's Royal Film Commission. ANNA LOUIE SUSSMAN

FREEDMAN--Frances, 83, passed away on September 1. She was a well respected and established real estate developer on the upper east side. Loving aunt and cousin, ardent swimmer and ballroom dancer, she loved to travel the world and spend time with her friends and family. Her quick whit, directness and generosity were appreciated by all who knew her. She will be dearly missed by her loved ones and friends. Graveside funeral service will be held on Monday, September 5 at 11:30am at Beth Olam Cemetery, Wyatt Road, Middletown, RI. Donations may be made in her honor to the Harlem Children's Society, 536 E. 86th St., Suite 5F, New York, NY.

WALLICK--Gloria. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the passing of our member Gloria Wallick, beloved wife of Melvin Wallick. Gloria was an integral part of a treasured 5th generation Rodeph Sholom family. We will always remember her love of family, commitment to her faith and community. We send our deepest condolences to her children, Michael, Claire, Larry and Jim, and all their dear ones. May her memory be a blessing. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

What does a doll-size Statue of Liberty, or a shot glass printed with the World Trade Center or, for that matter, a T-shirt printed in California on Chinese cotton have to do with the gritty, day-to-day city that New Yorkers live in? Nothing, says Rameses Crisi, 28, a resident of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Mr. Crisi has come up with what he calls a more ''authentic'' souvenir: a test-tube filled with muslin fabric stained with dirt, grass and dust from sites across Brooklyn. A dirt-level ode to the borough, it is offered at a price commensurate with Brooklyn's aspirational branding profile - $24 - and sealed with vegan-friendly, soy-based wax.

GINSBURG--Abe. The Chestnov family is deeply saddened by the passing of Abe Ginsburg, our beloved cousin, business partner, wise advisor, and role model. Abe, founder of Jaclyn Inc., along with his brother, Martin, and their cousin, Al Chestnov, formed a lifelong partnership that was an inspiration to us all. He was tremendously respected and admired for his business acumen, his foresight, his philanthropy, his great devotion to his entire family, and for always being a gentleman. Our love and condolences to his adoring wife, Sylvia, his loving children, Bernice and Marvin Schwartz, Howard and Randi Ginsburg, Jaclyn and David Hartstein, his grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Hannah, Bob, Sheila, Richard, Stephanie, and family

Josh Collmenter grew up in Homer, Mich., too young to see the champion Detroit Tigers of 1984. But he was raised on their stories, and now he pitches for the Arizona Diamondbacks, whose manager, Kirk Gibson, and bench coach, Alan Trammell, starred for that team. ''Everyone in Michigan knows who they are,'' Collmenter said. ''It's neat to look over in the dugout and see them sitting next to each other, and you're in the same dugout. It's kind of surreal in that regard, because you kind of looked up to them and now you're able to share a lot of experiences with them.''

FREEMAN--Claire, of Margate, FL and Scarsdale, NY on August 28, 2011, just shy of her 91st birthday. Loving wife of the late B. Walter; devoted mother of Debra (Barry) Goldman and Lynn (David) Pravda; dedicated grandmother of Lisa (Matthew), Heather, Jacqueline (David), William (Dana) and Douglas (Sarah); and fabulous great-grandmother of six. Her life was one of love and devotion to all her family and friends.
STAVROLAKES--Anne Hooper died peacefully in Nyack, New York on August 21, 2011. She was the beloved mother of Rena Stavrolakes.

They've become an unavoidable part of the back-to-school ritual: the long and confoundingly precise lists of supplies that schools ask students -- that is, parents -- to provide. This particular folder, that color pen, exactly this many boxes of tissues. This page shows all the items on a typical list: the one that Ellyn Agranoff drew up for the fifth-grade class she teaches at Public School 261 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. It includes an array of items each pupil will need -- eight notebooks, 12 folders, a pencil sharpener -- and others that each should share with the class: Post-it notes, paper towels, a bottle of hand sanitizer. For the parent who follows the list to the letter, filling the entire order can run about $125.

EFTIMIADI--Catharine Gibb Shaw Lewis, The daughter of Charles Elwin Lewis and Catharine Elizabeth Bayly Sharpley, Catharine was born at home on July 11th, 1921 in Greenbackville, VA in the bed of her ancestor General John Cropper of the American Revolution. She is survived by her son Peter Gibb Cropper Nemiroff, and his wife Diane McCormack Nemiroff, and her grandson William Alfred Cropper Nemiroff, all of New Canaan, CT, as well as by her sister Harriet Bayly Gibb Lewis DeMay of Charlotte, NC. Career highlights include: Department Head Textile Design, Moore Institute Art., Philadelphia, 1954--1960; President Kay Lewis Inc., New York City, 1959--1979; the first textile design instructor at the Arts Students League New York, 1959--1979; 1978 Recipient of the Distinguished Alumna award, Pennsylvania State University, speaker in the field for Tiffany, Ford and the Fulbright Foundations of New York City. Retiring in 1981 to her family home in Greenbackville, VA, she stayed active in the art world and served for many years as an Art show judge at the Art Institute and Gallery, Salisbury, MD, and at the Eastern Shore Art League, Onancock, VA, and in 1998 she had a one-woman show at the Eastern Shore Art League, Onancock, VA, of her Watercolors, Oil Paintings, and Textile Designs and Fabrics, 1944-2003.

WONG--Agnes H.,77, passed away August 28 following a long illness. Beloved wife of Ting C. Wong, she is survived by her son Richard and his wife Delphine Hu, her daughter Julia and her husband Eric Cortell; and her grandchildren Claudia, Andy, Vera and Charlie. Services. Saturday, September 10 at 11am at Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583. Memorial contributions to Scarsdale Congregational Church Music.

DETTMER--Robert G.,age 92, died peacefully at Kendal-on-Hudson on August 27, 2011. Beloved spouse for 63 years of Suzanne (nee Adler), father of Frederick, Peter, and Elizabeth, grandfather of William and Alexander Dettmer, father-in-law of Nancy Kraus. Sister Virginia predeceased him in 1989. Graduate of Columbia University and its Law School. Executive Vice President, General Counsel, Director of North American Philips Corp, 1946-1984. Army meteorologist in WWII. Valued member of Purchase Friends Meeting, where Memorial Service to be held Saturday September 10, 3pm.

Scott Hanson is in his sixth year as a reporter and host for NFL Network. But he is best known as the host of the addictive NFL RedZone channel, which whips from game to game on Sunday afternoons, excising the 1-yard runs and tedious timeouts and focusing only on the most jaw-dropping plays and touchdowns. Hanson, whose high-energy delivery is a perfect match for the snippets of action, said he had had only one cup of coffee in his life. A four-year walk-on at Syracuse, he earned scout-team player-of-the-year honors in 1992. RedZone broadcasts from Los Angeles, but Hanson was in New York recently to host an N.F.L. event for advertisers and, presumably, to limber up his vocal cords for the season.

PRITCHARD--Peter, 83, founder of Audio Dynamics Corporation and Sonic Research, Inc., passed away on August 23, 2011 in Austin, TX. Peter Pritchard was one of the pioneers of state of the art stereo systems in the 1960s and 1970s, his designs of phonograph cartridge styluses and "bookshelf" speakers were some of the most innovative of the time. He was preceded in death by his wife Patricia and is survived by his brother, John Pritchard of Milton-Keynes, England, his daughter, Sylvia McLeod and grandchildren Ian and Kylie Wilkinson of Albuquerque, NM and granddaughter Rosy Hanby of Austin, TX.

FOR its first retail endeavor, the Brooklyn design incubator 3rd Ward thought inside the box -- specifically, a salvaged shipping container. Shopbox, as they're calling it, opened Aug. 26 at the Dekalb Market in Downtown Brooklyn, where all of its neighbors are also housed in repurposed storage units. Painted a can't-miss green, with prominent window displays on two sides, Shopbox showcases (on spinning pedestals, no less) a rotating assortment of wares, including canvas backpacks, 3-D printers and this Mopha tool roll, $44, and floor lamp, $2,130. Shoppers can sign up on an on-site iPad, and purchase by text; 332 Flatbush Avenue. SARAH FONES

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Plenty of Good Seats Unavailable,'' Aug. 30: The great gate and related cash flow of the Boston franchise can be contrasted with the situation in Los Angeles, where the Dodgers, formerly attendance-record holders, now play day after day before only a few people.

CUSACK--John "Jack" Thomas (age 88), on Monday, August 29, 2011, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved husband of the late Mary Josephine Cusack. Loving father of Michael Kelly; brother of Jean M. Aratingi; devoted companion of Ginette Baum; also survived by many other loving family and friends. Friends will be received at Pumphrey's Bethesda Chevy Chase Funeral Home, 7557 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, MD 20814 on Wednesday, September 7, 2011 from 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Little Flower, 5607 Massachusetts Avenue, Bethesda, MD 20816 on Thursday, September 8, 2011 at 12:00pm. Interment Quantico National Cemetery, Triangle, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Alzheimer's Association, National Capital Area Chapter, 11240 Waples Mill Road, Suite #

CLAREMAN--Jack, 95 years old, died peacefully on September 2, 2011. He was the completely devoted husband of the late Rhoda Clareman; the loving and generous father of Lloyd Clareman, Pauli Wertheim, and the late Susan Clareman Emden; a kind and caring father-in-law to Patrice Clareman, David Wertheim, and Robert Emden; the doting grandfather of Billy (and wife Emily), Rebecca and Bart Clareman, and Robert, Julia and Samuel Wertheim; and, in his final months, the proud great-grandfather of the next Jack Clareman, son of Billy and Emily. The memory of his extraordinary goodness and generosity will be cherished by everyone who knew him. Services will be held Sunday, September 4, at 1:00pm, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

The ageless Jamie Moyer has started workouts at the Philadelphia Phillies' complex in Clearwater, Fla., hoping to come back from reconstructive surgery on his ancient left elbow. He continues to inspire a younger version with Kansas City. ''The guy's amazing - he's 48 and he still wants to pitch,'' Bruce Chen said by phone last week. ''That would be great to do that. If I can stay healthy, I could see myself pitching for a long time, because I don't rely on my velocity either. I rely on knowing how to pitch.''

An article last Sunday about efforts to establish a common standard for fast-charging electric cars' batteries misspelled the given name of a General Motors engineering specialist. He is Gery Kissel, not Gary.

ANNE HATHAWAY has been living la vida Tod's ever since she got her saddle-colored D bag. Now the actress, who is the face of the brand, can expect even more baggage as Tod's introduces its Signature collection built around the iconic pebble. There are eight different styles, including shoulder bags and envelope clutches. The Shopper ($2,165), an oversize bag with a drawstring closure, would appear to be ideal for Ms. Hathaway, but the actress seems preoccupied with her ''new envelope clutch and iPad case in black,'' she said. ''They're just so sleek.''

My son, who's in his early 30s and lives in Seattle, and I, in my mid-60s and living in New England, would like to escape to a warm, sunny and dry place for four to five days sometime in February or March. We'll be renting a car and think we would like to visit the Grand Canyon. Can you recommend something else that we could add to our itinerary without spending a lot of time driving? We like being outdoors; he loves hiking and I love walking, but not scaling great heights and rough terrain.Marianne Hessner, Brookline, Mass. In the late winter and early spring, the Grand Canyon is likely to fulfill your prerequisites of sunny and dry. It can, though, get chilly, especially at night. But stick to the South Rim, pack accordingly, and you'll have the benefit of fewer crowds, making it an optimal time to relax in the Grand Canyon's vast, quiet beauty.

ROSEN--Philip A.,87, on August 24, died suddenly surrounded by friends in Lauderhill, FL. He grew up in Bronx and raised a family in West Hempstead, NY and Franklin Lakes, NJ. He was a Veteran of World War II, serving in the 8th Air Force. The GI Bill helped him start a long successful career in the photo industry. As a partner of Keystone Camera Corporation he opened new markets around the world. He always put people before profits. He loved sports, was a loyal Red Sox fan, an avid tennis player and a high school football star. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Natalie. He was a devoted father and grandfather survived by his sons Joseph, Daniel, and Mark; grandchildren Lena, Gershon, Benjamin, Mathew, Jason, Sarah and Nathaniel. His wit, optimism and family loyalty will be greatly missed and always cherished.
DUMBO CONDO $1,400,000

9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS, SERIES IV: OLD, UNHAPPY, FAR OFF THINGS A new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' stalwart begins as Inspector Lewis, the long-suffering detective played by Kevin Whately (above left), and his erudite sidekick, Detective Sgt. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox, right), investigate the death of Poppy Toynton, a passive-aggressive -- and stunningly average -- graduate of Lady Matilda's, Oxford's last surviving all-female college, whose ''golden set'' has congregated on campus to honor its beloved professor Diana Ellerby (Juliet Stevenson) and perhaps to mourn the fact that the college has recently voted to admit men. But whodunit? Could it be the confident chief executive of a lingerie company (Stephanie Street)? The provocative newspaper columnist (Zoe Telford)? Lewis can't help but be reminded of the attack on 15-year-old Chloe Brooks at the college 10 years earlier, whose case was interrupted by the death of his wife, which obsesses him now more than ever. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, talks about the qualities in a presidential candidate that would win his endorsement as well as what he hopes to see in President Obama's proposed jobs plan.

GINSBURG--Abe. We are saddened by the passing of Abe Ginsburg. (Uncle Abe to most of us). He was a perfect gentleman who lived by the words "always do the right thing". He was the heart behind the growth of Jaclyn Inc, along with his brother Martin Ginsburg and cousin Alex Chestnov. His was a generous man, giving to many charities. However, most of all, he was a family man, always devoted to his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He will be sorely missed. Love forever & ever, Allan Ginsburg Family Bonnie Levy Family Bobbie Ginsburg

Thousands of people are still cleaning up from Tropical Storm Irene, but the residual impact may be felt by people who didn't see a drop of rain over the weekend. Damaged cars and trucks from cities and towns affected by the storm are likely to make their way to auto auctions across the country. Once on used-car lots, these vehicles may then be sold at deep discounts relative to the going rates of similar cars, but without any disclosure from sellers about the vehicles' exposure to the storm, echoing a common practice in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Fine Line on Foot Faults,'' Aug. 29: It's nice to see so many column inches quoting the rule and describing dated incidents with illustrative and memorable photographs devoted to a favorite subject of tennis fans, but nowhere did the article mention that the foot fault is cheating, whether flagrant or inadvertent, whether by a quarter-inch or by six inches over the white line.
Pop Jon Pareles

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Humility by the Pack,'' Sept. 1: I was dismayed by the article about rookie relief pitchers who are required to carry snacks to the bullpen in backpacks designed for little girls. What a terrible message the major leagues are sending to boys that it is all right to demean someone by association with girls.

DONALD YOUNG VS. JUAN IGNACIO CHELA Remember Donald Young, the onetime tennis prodigy who signed with an agent at 14? Donald Young, who was being praised by national magazines like Sports Illustrated as the ''next big thing'' before he was old enough to drive? On Friday, the now 22-year-old Young reminded everyone of those lofty expectations, ousting 14th-seeded Stanislas Wawrinka in a fifth-set tie breaker.

EKBLOM--Harry E. Banker, Attorney and Management Consultant, died on August 28 at his home in Osterville, Massachusetts. He was 83, and was the husband of Elizabeth H. (Betty) Ekblom for 61 years. Mr. Ekblom was born in New York City. He was a graduate of Columbia College and the New York University School of Law and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1957. He attended the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School in 1970. During his 33 year banking career Mr. Ekblom spent 20 years as a senior officer at The Chase Manhattan Bank, now known as JPMorgan Chase Bank. At Chase he was responsible for a number of diverse positions including General Manager, London Branches, Officer in Charge of Western Europe, as well as leading the bank's business in the Caribbean and Canada and head of the Commodities Lending Division. Following his career at Chase, Mr. Ekblom was elected Chairman, President and CEO of European American Bank in New York in 1970. Upon the bankruptcy of the former Franklin National Bank in 1974, EAB purchased the branches and other viable assets of Franklin from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and thereby became the largest bank on Long Island. EAB was later acquired by Citigroup. Mr. Ekblom retired from EAB in 1983 and became an Independent Contractor to A.T. Hudson, a management consulting firm in New Jersey where he spent 10 years as a non-executive advisor. He fought with the 40th Infantry Division in Korea during 1951-1952 and was awarded the Commendation Ribbon with Metal Pendant for meritorious service. In addition to his beloved wife Betty, he is survived by their three children: Harry E. Ekblom, Jr. of Wellesley, MA, Maryann E. Cudd of Scottsdale, AZ and Neil H. Ekblom of Ridgewood, NJ., eight grandchildren and one-great-grandchild. Visitation will be held at the Doane Beal & Ames Funeral Home, 160 West Main St., Hyannis on Friday, September 9, 2011 from 5:00pm to 7:00pm. His funeral mass will be held at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, 76 Wianno Ave., Osterville on Saturday, September 10, 2011 at 10:00am. Burial will follow at St. Francis Cemetery, Pine St., Centerville. No memorial donations are expected.

DRIVING to work in Southern California recently, Steven Tiller, a founder of SeaVees sneakers, heard on NPR that the Peace Corps was about to turn 50. Sensing an opportunity in line with the brand's philosophy and midcentury aesthetic, Mr. Tiller and his business partner, Derek Galkin, began sifting through old photos of Peace Corps volunteers. What was on their feet? Narrow plimsolls, a canvas and rubber sneaker commonly worn in the 1960s. ''The idea was to go back in time, reimagine these shoes, and hopefully make them cooler,'' Mr. Tiller said. The resulting sneaker, in salt-washed canvas, has a contrasting suede stripe around its rims and a vintage look. Donations to the Peace Corps will be made for each pair sold at seavees.com and jcrew.com. The Volunteer plimsoll is $78. BRUCE PASK

The third preseason game is often called a dress rehearsal for the regular season. Extending the live theater metaphor, the fourth preseason game is an afternoon performance at the Piscataway Summer Stock Playhouse to work out the kinks of the production and integrate the new songs Bono wrote. The N.F.L. knows better than to shine the footlights on the final exhibition games, in which starters parade the sidelines in baseball caps and coaches keep the real playbooks locked in the file cabinet. The whole final-week schedule was shunted onto Thursday and Friday night so Ryan Perrilloux would not have to match star power against Tim Lincecum or Serena Williams. With no national broadcasts, the regional Homer Sports Networks took center stage: the weekend late-night sports anchor got to be a sideline reporter, and Donny's Discount Drywall got to sponsor the extra points.

SHEFFIELD--Ludwig, at age 95. Mr. Sheffield was well known in Westchester musical circles, both vocal and instrumental, having conducted his own choruses and guest conducted others (including one from England) over a span of 60 plus years. He will be missed for his talent and his friendly mien. He is survived by his wife Evelyn, daughter Rosalie Johnston and her two sons, Jeremy and Chase.

After the economic meltdown and a couple of ash-spewing volcanoes, Iceland still has plenty to be optimistic about. For one: Harpa, the new abstract glass and steel edifice towering over Reykjavik's old harbor. Harpa (the name refers to the Icelandic word for harp) is the just-inaugurated conference center and concert hall that is home to the Iceland Symphony Orchestra and the Icelandic Opera.

HEINZERLING--Clifford, 86, of Shinnecock Hills, Long Island, NY, formerly of Lancaster, PA, passed away on August 23, 2011. He was preceded in death by his wife of 46 years, Barbara Wall Heinzerling. Born on March 22, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY, he attended Poly Preparatory Institute, sailed Snipe boats with his brother Ralph and won numerous races, including the 1942 International Snipe Championship. Cliff attended Bucknell University, where he enrolled in Officers Training School. During WWII, he served as an officer in the Navy. He married his college sweetheart Barbara Wall in August 1946. Clifford was a commercial artist in Manhattan, NY for over 40 years and enjoyed sailing catamarans and kayaking on the Great Peconic Bay in his summers. During retirement, he wrote short stories, several books, and was a prolific painter. He is survived by his brother, Ralph Heinzerling, of Port Washington, NY, and five daughters, Constance Heinzerling of Manhattan, NY, Gail Heinzerling of Hampton Bays, NY, Catherine Heinzerling of Hoover, AL, Joyce Heinzerling of Manhattan, NY, and Carol Heinzerling of Oyster Bay, NY. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Justin Beckert and David Heinzerling, both of Manhattan, NY. A Memorial Service will be held on September 17, 2011 at The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th St., in Manhattan, NY at 2pm.

A report last Sunday about the wedding of Julia Kiechel and Harold Birnbaum included an outdated reference to the date and location. Because of Hurricane Irene, they were married on Aug. 26 at the Modern, a restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art, not on Aug. 27 at the Battery Gardens restaurant in New York. (The Times learned of the change before the section was printed, but decided it was too late in the production process to revise the page.)

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the sports announcer Joe Buck's vocal problems misidentified the month during which Buck began to have trouble with his voice. It was February, not January.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel takes a fast train from Madrid to Segovia, where he figures out how to see a beautiful if overtouristed city for only 35 euros, including the train.

CHRIS RAINEY The Florida receiver scored three different ways in a victory over Florida Atlantic. Rainey touched the ball 18 times, scoring on a 14-yard reception and a 14-yard run. He also scooped up a blocked punt and sprinted 22 yards for a touchdown. ROBERT WOODS The Southern California receiver, right, caught a program-record 17 passes for 177 yards and 3 touchdowns in a win over Minnesota. Woods tied the team record first set by Johnnie Morton with his 15th catch late in the third quarter, and he surpassed it early in the fourth. The U.S.C. coaches mentioned the record to Woods this week. ''We said, 'It's time to break it,' '' Coach Lane Kiffin said.
Theater Patrick Healy

WAYNE--June. The Brodsky Center for Innovative Editions and the Mason Gross School of the Arts along with others at Rutgers University who came in contact with June Wayne during her years as a Distinguished Visiting Research Professor (2002-2007) join the art world in mourning her death. The Brodsky Center itself was established by Judith K. Brodsky with Wayne's Tamarind Lithography Workshop as a model. In a lifetime of successes and honors, her appointment at Rutgers was her first professorial appointment, and it was an honor to be able to pay homage to her. Her relationship with the Brodsky Center began long before her tenure at Rutgers. Brodsky had interviewed Wayne for an essay in the Art Journal in the 1970s. They became friends and Wayne became a heroine for Brodsky. In 1997, Brodsky invited Wayne to be an artist in residence at the Brodsky Center, then called the Rutgers Center for Innovative Print and Paper. During that residency, Wayne created a print in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the invention of lithography. The imagery included a litho stone and a whooping crane, Wayne's metaphor for her rescue of the vanishing breed of lithography printers in the United States. Along with her professorial appointment, the Brodsky Center established the June Wayne Archive and Study Room based on Wayne's gift of 3,321 prints (2,555 by Wayne herself) along with works by 128 artists whom she had published. The Brodsky Center donated a representative group of Wayne's prints to the Zimmerli Art Museum, which mounted a retrospective exhibition of Wayne's work to celebrate her appointment. The Brodsky Center also organized an exhibition of her lithographs in New York, as well as shows of her paintings, prints, and tapestries at the Mason Gross School of the Arts Galleries and the Brodsky Center Gallery at the Heldrich. The Brodsky Center was also responsible for the publication of her catalogue raisonne, June Wayne, The Art of Everything. That volume will ensure that a record exists of her lifetime achievement. Research on the book took place during her five years at Rutgers. In recognition of Wayne's contributions to the world of the visual arts, Rutgers University conferred an honorary degree on Wayne in 2005. We extend our sympathy to Wayne's daughter, Robin Claire Park and her granddaughters, Ariane Junah Claire and Jevon Claire. Thomas W. Lollar, Executive Director, Brodsky Center; Judith K. Brodsky, Founding Director, Brodsky Center; George B. Stauffer, Dean, Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

YESTERDAY, while riding the N train uptown, I started chatting with a young woman I knew to be a model. Of course she was: the elongated body, the strawberry-blond hair, the pale vague face. INDIANOLA, Iowa -- Sarah Palin did not say whether she would seek the Republican presidential nomination, but she made clear during a speech here on Saturday that she has no intentions of simply falling into line behind one of the party's leading candidates. At times she sounded like a candidate. At times she did not.

Republicans have to nominate someone better than the person they want to defeat. If they get so adamant that they will only support a candidate that believes everything on their checklist, they will re-elect Obama. Every detail of 5 Franklin Place was mapped out: Bosch washers and dryers, cantilevered staircases wrapping around cylindrical glass elevators and a facade with reflective black metal bands that would twist like ribbons and, just maybe, make Frank Gehry squirm. But the condominium planned for TriBeCa with the dizzyingly ambitious vision of a small development firm, and an exotic design by the Dutch architect Ben van Berkel, may stand out as one of the worst casualties of the city's banking and housing crises.

An article last Sunday about diversity recruitment in the New York Fire Department misstated, in some editions, a condition under which firefighter candidates can receive additional points. Candidates receive more points for having relatives who died in the line of duty while working for the department, not just for having relatives working in the department.

GINSBURG--Abe, passed away peacefully at home on September 1, 2011, at the age of 94. Abe is survived by his loving wife Sylvia; his devoted children Bernice Gailing Schwartz, Howard Ginsburg, and Jaclyn Hartstein; his adoring grandchildren Stephanie, Aimee, Eric, Scott, Joshua, Zachary, and Alexa; his precious great-grandchildren Sophie, Maeve and Ari; his admiring children-in-laws David Harstein, Randi Zinz Ginsburg, and Marvin Schwartz; and his caring grandchildren-in-laws Marc and Rachel. Abe was a devoted family man with a brilliant mind, huge heart, beaming smile, and knowing eyes. He was the definition of a gentleman; he cared deeply for other people, priding himself on doing right by others. His generosity was extensive and beyond definition -- and was among the many ways he inspired so many lives. Abe was the founder of and driving force behind Jaclyn, Inc., a handbag, apparel, and accessory company. Abe was loved and respected by all. While his survivors will always hold him in their hearts where he will serve to inspire them throughout their lives, he will be sorely missed. A private funeral service will be held on Sunday, September 4, 2011.

On Aug. 30, 1861, Maj. Gen. John C. Frémont, commander of the Union Western Department in St. Louis, issued a proclamation of martial law: ''All persons who shall be taken with arms in their hands shall be tried by court-martial, and if found guilty will be shot.'' This was harsh, but perhaps to be expected in the strife-torn region. But Frémont went further. ''The property, real and personal, of all persons in the State of Missouri, who shall take up arms against the United States, or who shall be directly proven to have taken an active part with their enemies in the field, is declared to be confiscated to their public use, and their slaves, if any they have, are hereby declared freemen.''

BAGEL or baguette? JFK or CDG? Pigeons or rats? These abiding questions are the central conceit of Paris Versus New York: A Tally of Two Cities, the witty Web site by the Parisian graphic designer Vahram Muratyan. With color-block graphics, Mr. Muratyan presents the iconography of each city in dueling juxtaposition. The diptychs can be so sly that the mere upward slope of a line (as in the case of Jean-Luc Godard's square eyeglasses beside Woody Allen's arched, angst-ridden pair) is enough to set the two greats apart. The popular site has produced an exhibition and sale of the most coveted images in limited-edition prints at Colette, in Paris, including macarons versus cupcakes and the dueling hairdos of Sonia Rykiel and Anna Wintour. AMY M. THOMAS

Could Henry Ford have imagined Park Avenue as a bike path for every wheeled alternative to the car? Major city streets are being cleared for riders: in New York, for example, Broadway from Columbus Circle to 34th Street, and Park Avenue from 72nd Street to the Brooklyn Bridge (the big thrill: the elevated stretch at Grand Central). Bike fever has also hit rush hour: a North African in caftan and skullcap on Fifth Avenue was followed by a woman in pearls. This transit alternative is as old as the bike, yet the variety of paths keeps it feeling new.

SELLING for $36.5 million, the Harkness Mansion, the Upper East Side town house that broke records when it sold for $53 million in 2006, was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.The buyer of the mansion at 4 East 75th Street, which is 50 feet wide and has 21,700 square feet of space, was Larry Gagosian, whose contemporary and modern art galleries form an empire from Rome to Los Angeles. The seller was J. Christopher Flowers, a prominent New York private equity manager who had un- officially been looking for a buyer for several years but eventually sold through Brown Har- ris Stevens. The sale was recorded in city records on Monday.Mr. Flowers bought the town house in Octo- ber 2006, less than two months after it was list- ed for $55 million, and at the time the sale was the costliest for a single residence in Manhattan history. Brokers say the mansion is now in need of major renovations; Mr. Flowers had begun a gut renovation but then apparently abandoned the plans. The property sat vacant for a few years before it sold.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the pre- vious week, ending Wednesday. SARAH KERSHAW

Kisco, NY to Zilpha Spring and Theodore Carpenter Slosson. She graduated from The Northfield School for Girls and from Wheaton College in Norton, MA. For more than a century, Yaddo, the private artists' colony on 400 acres of woods in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been a haven for writers, painters and composers. In cozy studios there, Patricia Highsmith wrote ''Strangers on a Train,'' Aaron Copland created his ''Piano Variations,'' and authors like Eudora Welty, Truman Capote and Langston Hughes spent productive time. Now, for only the fifth time in its history, Yaddo is opening up to the public.

The Ford Evos concept car, which is scheduled to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month, represents a near-term design strategy, said J Mays, the company's design chief, in a telephone interview on Wednesday. ''This will appear on production cars not in four years but in four months,'' he said. ''We want to grease the skids in Frankfurt so that when the production versions come out people will say, 'Oh yes, that's what they were going for.'''

SOMALIA is now suffering its worst drought in 60 years. A quarter of the population has fled famine and conflict, heading west into Kenya. More than 1,300 people a day stream into the complex of refugee camps at Dadaab, Kenya, which is now housing more than 430,000 people in camps designed for 90,000. Many Somalis arrive near death after journeys of weeks with little food. Large numbers of them are children, often without parents. At Dadaab they receive food, medical care, basic shelter -- the emergency relief they need. But they will probably spend years in that desolate grid of white tents, eating gruel that gets thinner toward the end of the month. The camp lacks the money to provide even subsistence rations. In exchange, the refugees give up their rights to move freely and to work.
