SASS--Jennifer Bement September 4, 1942 -- August 28, 2011. Jennifer lived a charmed life of honesty and candor. She was born to Eleanor Allen Bement and Kenyon Theodore Bement at Deaconess Hospital in Spokane Washington. She spent her summers in Twisp and Loon Lake and grew to be a woman of great substance from her early childhood in Spokane, her teens in Detroit and her adult years in Deerfield, Illinois and now these last 36 years in Portland Oregon. She had the most wonderful sense of humor. She is survived by a grateful group of friends, colleagues, her three children, Gretchen, and her husband Will, Jeff and Leticia, Jason and his girlfriend Jenny, one grandchild Kennedy, three adopted grandchildren, Jonathan, Adriana and LaShawna and a great grandson Maddox. As her loving husband of 47 years, I celebrate and treasure the ups and downs of a relationship that remains a truly great partnership. Also celebrating Jennifer are her siblings, Judy Kaiser, Jill McFarlane, Jane Geesman and Jeff Bement and their children, loving spouses and families. I marvel at the extended family we have all become. I include in the extended family her wonderful loving girl scout and grade school friends of 60 years, her old boyfriend Dick, her dear friends Joanne, Diane, Jackie and Bill, Ed, Maria, Elfie and Gary, Dianne, Jane O, Louisa, Cathy and Ernie, Carolyn, Tommy, Natasha, Linda, Susan and Chris Marie, Ben and Jock and those of us she called her "teachers". She enjoyed the company and companionship of Mark, Audrey, Kathy, Kevin, Rita, Laurel, Julie, Peggy, Georgia, Sarah, Jean, Sharon, Rachel, Rebekah and Lyle, Beatrice, Bob, John, Jonell , Mary Lou, Penelope, Ron and Sheila, Ron and Michele and a host of others. As the Bement and Sass clans are spread far and wide, I can unequivocally state that Carol and Bob, Patty and Peggy, Marcia and Margie and Mike, Jan and Andy, Ron, Cindy and Kim, Julie and Pauline are all cheering her on much as we have bid goodbye to their loved ones. Special mention to her wonderful and caring crew on-board Eleanor Allen: Timo DeVries and Nathalie, Yasar, Karine, Shane, Julia and Elise and of course, her special friends Jane Conner that had oversight for all financial projects and Lisa Day for all documentary film projects. Among her many accomplishments are the documentary films; Letting Go, a film about death and dying and her dear friend Kay Straight; COUPLES, a documentary on couples in relationship; Women Seen on Television, and a soon to be released documentary called Shelf Life, that captures the intimate joy of reading and the human connection to books: shelflifedocumentary.com. What she was most proud of was her Dip-C and her ability to be there in service for "other". She is after all her mother and father's daughter. A defining element of Jennifer's character was her ability to connect to and hold her relationships honestly and forever close. When she entered a room, her presence was felt and a warmth radiated from the very source of her beingness. I will miss her energy but will hold her in my heart until I meet her one day again. A memorial celebration for a "Life Well Lived" is planned for Portland friends and family as well as a memorial celebration at The Haven and True North on Gabriola Island in British Columbia. A private celebration will occur on-board the Eleanor Allen at Cannes Film Festival in the New Year 2012. Jennifer and her legacy will live on forever...Godspeed and may the force be with you!! I love you!! We love you!! Charitable Contributions may be sent in her name to: Contact Wellness Foundation: www.contactwellness.org in support of Research and Outcome Studies related to Developmental Origins of Health and Disease DOHaD.

WALLICK--Gloria, on August 31 after a determined battle with Alzheimer's. Beloved mother of Michael (Gayle), Claire (Kai Moy), Larry (Carolyn Horn) and Jim (Cathy). Proud grandmother to Brian, Carrie, Jessie, Karina, Russell, Daniel, Sophia and Eric. Devoted sister of Suzi (Martin) Oppenheimer. Loving wife and partner to the late Mel; who we miss greatly. Graduate of Brown. University, with a masters in policy analysis from the New School University, her life was devoted to bettering the lives of children and families. In the 1960s, she worked on Head Start programs, and in 1971 she helped found one of the first child care centers on Long Island, the Rosa Lee Young Childhood Center in Rockville Centre. In 1978 she became the first director of the fledgling Child Care Council of Nassau, where she served for 23 years. Her spirit of commitment, intelligence, and, warmth infused everything she did and all people she touched. She has inspired many people, most of all, her loving family. Services to be held at 11am on Monday, September 5 at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Child Care Council, of Nassau or the Rosa Lee Young Childhood Center in Rockville Centre, NY.

ZALAR--Gregory L.,M.D., age 65, passed away on August 30 at his home in Logatec, Slovenia. Dr. Zalar was born in Paris, France, and raised in Washington, D.C. He was a graduate of The George Washington University and Georgetown University School of Medicine. After his residency in dermatology, Dr. Zalar's 35 year career included private practice in New York City and a Clinical Professorship at Columbia University. During retirement, he spent a significant amount of time in Slovenia where he had a home on his family's property restored. Dr. Zalar was a true gentleman and an avid athlete. His enthusiam for all facets of life will be remembered by his wife Pat, his son Andrej and his many friends, colleagues and patients. Services were held in Logatec, Slovenia on September 3.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments on A. O. Scott's column about the summer's most polarizing movies, focusing on ''The Tree of Life,'' ''The Help'' and ''The Future.'' ''If Tim Robbins pitched 'The Tree of Life' to his studio bosses in 'The Player' the log line would be 'Leave It to Beaver' on steroids meets 'The Flintstones' as drawn by William Blake. But I don't think it would have been green-lighted. Fortunately Terrence Malick doesn't do log lines, and this cinematic visionary was given free reign. Twenty-five years from now, I predict, 'The Help' and 'The Future' will be relegated to the dust heap, and 'The Tree of Life' will be required viewing for any true cinephile.''

An article last Sunday about Alloy Entertainment, creator of many television shows aimed at teenage girls, erroneously included one book among the once-dormant book titles Alloy has turned into TV series. While Alloy did so with ''The Nine Lives of Chloe King'' and ''The Secret Circle,'' ''The Lying Game'' was not a dormant title. The article also misstated the age of the younger son of Leslie Morgenstein, Alloy's chief executive. He is 12, not 11.

LA GARÇONNE is the minimalist's go-to for everything from straightforward trousers to streamlined satchels by Maison Martin Margiela. Now, after several years of offering other designers' basics, Kris Kim, the Web site's founder, is taking a stab at her own label. La Garçonne Moderne stocks luxurious staples like hand-knit boat-necks, men's inspired button-downs, sleek sheath dresses and pegged trousers. And for those e-commerce dabblers too nervous to buy a pair of pants without trying them on, La Garçonne offers five different product views, with so much descriptive detail that buying a pair of wide-leg trousers with just enough stretch to conform to your body is pretty much a cinch. Cashmere coat, $1,450. Wool trousers, $525. Go to lagarconne.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Tim Coppens's first complete men's collection is a wonder not just of technical proficiency - Coppens was formerly the design director of Ralph Lauren's futuristic sportswear line, RLX - but also of economy. Coppens, a Belgian-born Royal Academy of Fine Arts grad, has no office, no employees and he's financing his 45-piece collection by himself. The design references are varied. They include a spit and polish riff on the leather jackets and baggy sweats of the Paris banlieues and also a curious repurposing of a Persian Farahan rug, which Coppens chopped up to form the back of a leather-sleeved varsity jacket. Characteristically, that jacket is assembled with almost clinical precision, but the carpet segment is left frayed on the bottom - an inspired touch. "I don't want to be brand-marked as a technical designer," Coppens says. "I want to make beautiful collections with classic fabrics. But the technical aspect gives me a good starting point."

HECHT--Hubert, 93, died peacefully on Saturday, September 3, 2011 surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Myra (Mabel). Devoted father to Alice and Paul and loving grandfather of Lea, Sam, and Noah. A practicing urologist until last week, Dr. Hecht was born in New York City, the youngest of 12. A graduate of Boys High, CCNY, and NYU School of Medicine, he served as a US Naval Medical Officer in WWII in the Pacific theater. Hubert Hecht based his 60+ years practice in Greenwich Village, working at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was a beloved figure among the generations of physicians he trained. Hubie was a high-energy, magnetic, and charming individual whose selflessness was evident through his generosity to his family, patients, and numerous philanthropic causes. Services will be held Tuesday September 6, 2011, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Donations may be made to the CCNY Alumni Association.
NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed.

''The Help'' officially achieved blockbuster status over the weekend by holding onto the No. 1 spot at North American multiplexes for a third consecutive week. That DreamWorks Studios movie, based on the best-selling novel about black maids in the 1960s and their white employers, took in an estimated $14.2 million for a new total of $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Second place went to ''The Debt,'' a Focus Features espionage drama that sold a surprisingly robust $9.7 million in tickets for a total of about $14 million since opening on Wednesday; solid reviews and the potential thrill of seeing Helen Mirren as a retired but still derriere-kicking Mossad agent probably drove interest. The weekend's other two new releases came in neck and neck: ''Apollo 18,'' a thriller from the Weinstein Company, was a limp third with an estimated $8.7 million in ticket sales, and ''Shark Night 3-D'' (Relativity Media) took in about $8.6 million for fourth place. Rounding out the top five was 20th Century Fox's ''Rise of the Planet of the Apes,'' which sold $7.8 million in tickets for a five-week total of about $160 million. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Celebrated for his warm confidence, covert wit, stylish eye wear; homemade lasagna, joy of friends, family and in-laws (yes, in-laws); distaste for mustard, love for biking, bass fishing, guitar playing, cocktails in his garden and driving with the top down; his generous spirit and the fortitude to walk away from a lucrative career at Alliance Capital to follow his dream to teach. La MaMa Experimental Theater Club has announced that Sam Shepard will receive the first Ellen Stewart Award, created in honor of the founder of La MaMa, who died in January. The award, designed to recognize artists who embody the creative ideals that Ms. Stewart championed, is to be presented on Oct. 17 at the La MaMa 50 Gala. Mr. Shepard has written several plays since the 1960s that went on to become La MaMa productions, including ''The Tooth of Crime'' and ''The Unseen Hand.''

Cole Stryker, a freelance writer and media consultant living in New York, spent years digging into Internet culture and communities, both as a participant and as a blogger covering viral phenomena. He's the author of a new book called ''Epic Win for Anonymous: How 4chan's Army Conquered the Web.'' He discussed with me what it's like exploring the seedy underbelly of the Internet, the rise of Anonymous, and why it and 4chan, widely considered one of the darkest and most subversive corners of the Internet, may be one of the most important and influential creations to emerge from the modern Web. How did you decide to write about 4chan?

SPORTS An article on Friday about the Yankees' 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox on Thursday night misidentified the Yankees reliever who induced the fly that led to center fielder Curtis Granderson's diving catch to end the bottom of the sixth inning. The reliever was Cory Wade, not Boone Logan. The article also misstated the number of outs in the top of the seventh when the Yankees' Russell Martin hit a two-run double. It was one out, not two.

FREEDMAN--Frances, 83, passed away on September 1. She was a well respected and established real estate developer on the upper east side. Loving aunt and cousin, ardent swimmer and ballroom dancer, she loved to travel the world and spend time with her friends and family. Her quick whit, directness and generosity were appreciated by all who knew her. She will be dearly missed by her loved ones and friends. Graveside funeral service will be held on Monday, September 5 at 11:30am at Beth Olam Cemetery, Wyatt Road, Middletown, RI. Donations may be made in her honor to the Harlem Children's Society, 536 E. 86th St., Suite 5F, New York, NY.

In its suit to block AT&T's $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile, the Justice Department leans heavily on the argument that consolidated market power is bad for consumers. More companies in an industry mean more competition and all the benefits that flow from competition -- lower prices, more choices and more innovation. That is a basic principle of economics and antitrust - and it is seemingly irrefutable. The yardstick that the Justice Department applied to its merger analysis is a standard, if complex, tool to measure market concentration, the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index, or HHI for short. Markets with HHI readings above 2,500, the government's complaint states, are ''highly concentrated.''

Those for older students include Countries of the World, which ranks No. 11 (with a score of 84.20) and U.S. Presidents, above right, at No. 18 (82.46). SHELLY FREIERMAN

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the world track and field championships in Daegu, South Korea, misstated the relationship of Saint George's to Grenada, the home country of the men's 400-meter gold medal winner Kirani James. It is the capital of Grenada; it is not an island.

Principal's Office is a new feature that will run regularly on SchoolBook, a Web site of news, data and conversation that launches Sept. 7. Martha Polin ''wandered'' into education 24 years ago, and since 2002 has run one of the most challenging programs in the city: a transfer high school, for students who have struggled in or dropped out of traditional programs. Hers, the Lower East Side Preparatory High School, has 571 students, most of them recent Chinese immigrants. Ms. Polin, who is 60 and had a salary of $150,926 in 2010, sees her job as heading a large, striving family. (This interview has been edited and condensed.) MARIA NEWMAN

Greg McElroy's rookie season ended Sunday when the Jets placed him on injured reserve as part of a series of roster-sculpturing moves. They ostensibly kept McElroy, who underwent right thumb surgery Friday after dislocating it in the team's preseason finale, on their original 53-man roster to maintain flexibility if another quarterback who appealed to them became available.

INTERNATIONAL An article on Aug. 19 about the emotions expressed by Russians regarding the 20th anniversary of a confrontation between protesters and military forces in Moscow that signaled the fall of the Soviet Union misstated the given name of a man who was shot and wounded during the confrontation. He is Gennady Veretelny, not Sergei.

As TNT approached the end of a summer that gave it two new hit shows, ''Falling Skies'' and ''Franklin & Bash,'' the cable channel pulled the plug on an older show, ''HawthoRNe.'' The channel said on Friday that it had elected not to order a fourth season of the show, which featured Jada Pinkett Smith as chief nursing officer at a hospital. ''TNT truly appreciates the tremendous dedication of everyone involved,'' it said in a statement. TNT recently ordered a second season of ''Falling Skies,'' which was the most popular new cable show of the summer with an average of 6.9 million viewers, and ''Franklin & Bash,'' which averaged 3.9 million. The third season of ''HawthoRNe'' typically had about 3.3 million viewers. The cancellation may also make room for one of the shows that TNT is developing, like its remake of ''Dallas'' or its spin-off of ''The Closer,'' ''Major Crimes.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Playing Angry Birds the other day, I was struck by what I no longer play: Xbox and PlayStation. Having children has something to do with that. So does Steve Jobs. The explosive popularity of inexpensive and free games for smartphones has by all accounts taken no small toll on the traditional video game business. New video game sales in July were the lowest for any month since October 2006, according to NPD, a market research firm, though the drop is the product of a handful of factors, including the natural ebbs and flows of the video game market as well as competition from casual and phone-based games.

Mitt Romney's keynote speech Sunday night at a Tea Party Express rally in Concord, N.H., was perhaps more notable for what did not happen - there were no fiery clashes with Tea Party protesters, or angry hecklers - than for what did - Mr. Romney delivered a lively version of his standard stump speech. ''I love this great land, I know we face extraordinary challenges, and I happen to believe that career politicians got us into this mess, and the career politicians can't get us out of this mess,'' Mr. Romney said. ''It will take someone who understands how the private economy works because he's worked in the private economy, and I have. I'm a business guy.''

Cablevision and Verizon FiOS customers abruptly lost their access to Tennis Channel on Sunday midway through the United States Open. The dispute revolves around a new contract between Tennis Channel and the National Cable Television Cooperative, a consortium of cable operators that Cablevision and Verizon belong to. The deal, which went into effect after midnight, requires its members to place Tennis Channel on a broad digital basic level - or not at all.

Postponed last weekend because of inclement weather, the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival will be pared back to one day with a smaller lineup later this month, the City Parks Foundation said on Thursday. Hurricane Irene forced organizers to cancel the two-day SummerStage event last weekend, and the headliners for the show -- the harmonica player Toots Thielemans and the saxophonist Archie Shepp -- could not be booked for a make-up concert. ''They live in Europe,'' said Sin Hom, a spokeswoman for the foundation. ''We just couldn't get them back.''

In Friday's Fixes column, I wrote about alternatives to keeping refugees in camps for years. The hundreds of thousands of Somalis streaming today into the camps in Dadaab, Kenya, are getting lifesaving food, medical care and shelter.  Camps like Dadaab are designed for emergency care and do it well - but most refugee situations are long-term.   Camps condemn refugees to years, maybe decades, of dependency.  There are people in Dadaab who have not stepped outside the camp since it opened in 1991.

P.J. Harvey became the first singer on Tuesday to win the prestigious Mercury Prize twice, when she accepted the award for her album "Let England Shake." Adele, the young soul-singer who had dominated the charts for much of the summer with her hit record "21," was left in the also-ran category. It was the second time that Ms. Harvey, the 41-year-old singer-songwriter from Yeovil, England, had taken home the prize, which is given every year to the best album from an English or Irish act. She first won in 2001, when the ceremony was held on Sept. 11. She was on tour in the United States at the time and got caught up in the chaotic day of the terror attack.

Convenience is key when it comes to refueling during Fashion Week, and more often than not, quick, carry-in-your-pocketbook processed foods are what many models and editors resort to between shows. The model and activist Elettra Wiedemann has set forth to change that by opening Goodness, a pop-up restaurant installed at Ed's Chowder House just across Columbus Avenue from Lincoln Center. From Sunday through next Wednesday, Goodness will offer a healthy, locally sourced menu, with daily specials designed by some of the city's best-loved chefs, including Christopher Rendell, an "Iron Chef" winner; Nicholas Wilber from the Fat Radish; and Robert Newton of Seersucker restaurant in Brooklyn. "I wanted to be eco-conscious without forcing it too much and create a place where people can go to escape," says Wiedemann, who teamed with Ed Brown, the Chowder House's Michelin star-rated chef, to design an especially soothing atmosphere in which to enjoy things like duck confit salad, pan-seared bream mash with a truffle vinaigrette and a fried chicken that Wiedemann calls "goodness (with a little bit of badness)." Check, please!

Two new polls have found low levels of support for President Obama and his economic stewardship of the country, with an increasing number of Americans saying that Mr. Obama's policies are making the economy worse. Growing up in Norway, Stian Tolnaes and Cathrine Wessel had plenty of opportunities to wear wool - and lots of it. "It's a Norwegian tradition," Tolnaes says. "If you see Norwegian fishermen, who are exposed to cold weather all the time, they wear layers of wool because it keeps them warm even when it's wet. Wool is incredibly insulating." After observing that Greek fishermen toiling in the balmy Aegean also favored wool but for entirely the opposite reason - its insulating qualities keep warm air out, too - the couple had a light-bulb moment. "We wanted to develop a clothing line that was completely natural and eco-friendly," Tolnaes says. "And we wanted to take the layering tradition of our childhoods and make it fashionable."

A few days after alumni from Stuyvesant High School were told that they could not hold a vigil to commemorate Sept. 11 in their school, they are now getting their wish. All it took was a few phone calls and a three-day weekend.

For two rainy days last week, some 250 chefs, scientists, foragers and farmers gathered beneath a blue and red circus tent in Copenhagen's Harbor for the first annual MAD Food Camp Symposium. Entitled "Planting Thoughts," the symposium was organized by Claus Meyer and Rene Redzepi, the founders of the current "world's best restaurant," Noma, along with the newly formed Food Organisation of Denmark (FOOD). The mission was to ask the big questions about the role of chefs in society, touching on issues of urban farming, food microbiology and social responsibility. At the podium was a parade of acclaimed chefs, among them Inaki Aizpitarte, David Chang, Andoni Aduriz and Alex Atala.

Nubby yarns aren't the most obvious springtime players. But Lindsay Degen, the Brooklyn-based 23-year-old behind the new hand-knit sock and lingerie line Degen, is a different sort of designer. Growing up in the suburban Midwest, she dabbled in cheerleading and Girl Scouting before going on to study fine art at the Rhode Island School of Design, where she joined a performance group called Knitting Nation that practiced endurance-building marathon stitch training. Soon, Degen says, "a hobby turned into a job," and she started collaborating with brands like VPL, Cooperative Designs and Mischa Lampert. "Knitting for people who see fashion and art as equals bent my previous view that they had to be separate worlds," she says. Indeed, Degen the line, which makes its debut during Fashion Week, is a clever blend of the two; the stripy, woven lingerie and cheerful one-off socks featured are just conceptual enough. "I've never wanted to buy a matching pair of anything," Degen says about offering singles instead of matching socks. "Plus, when I spend eight hours knitting one, it's dreadful to think that I'd have to spend another eight hours making the exact same thing." Restless and inspired, she confesses she's already in need of a new hobby. Let's hope it's sweaters.

The photographer Paolo Ventura was raised on stories. His father was an author of children's books, who, as Ventura remembers it, was "always inventing stories for me and my brothers." Over the past five years, Ventura, a former fashion photographer, has established his own voice as a storyteller building highly detailed, miniature sets from found objects, and then shooting them to appear life size. The resulting images demand a closer look, drawing the viewer into Ventura's often haunting narrative worlds.

Four or five hours of tennis does not seem to faze players - although Donald Young looked a bit wobbly after his marathon last week - but it is tough on spectators. The heat, the sun and above all the surging crowds moving in a continual swarm induce the claustrophobic feel of a subway platform with no train in sight. Where to find respite? The United States Tennis Association bookstore. Outer-court geeks may remember it used to occupy two smallish booths near Court 10. But this year, it has been given a spacious new site inside Chase Center, across the walkway from Louis Armstrong Stadium.

8 P.M. (Ovation) AMÉLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amélie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. Writing in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell called this comedy from Jean-Pierre Jeunet, whose original title was ''Le Fabuleux Destin d'Amélie Poulain,'' ''a sugar-rush of a movie.'' It has, he said, ''a hypnotic sense of romance; it's a fable filled with longing, with a heroine who constantly flirts with failure.'' The film's ''fastidious complex of flesh and fantasy is a dazzling achievement,'' Mr. Mitchell added. There is no denying, he said ''that 'Amélie' is, to paraphrase its title, fabulous.'' 1 P.M. (Starz) THE LAST STATION (2009) Leo Tolstoy (Christopher Plummer) and his wife, Sofya (Helen Mirren), battle over his literary estate in this drama from Michael Hoffman, based on Jay Parini's novel about the end of Tolstoy's life. Paul Giamatti plays Vladimir Chertkov, a spiritual guru who Sofya is convinced is trying to marginalize her and manipulate her husband into changing his will. And James McAvoy is Valentin, the nervous young secretary who manages to gain the confidence of both Tolstoys. To say that the actors ''overdo it would be an understatement,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''I can't handicap their Oscar chances, but isn't there a scenery-eating contest every summer out on Coney Island?'' (Mr. Plummer and Ms. Mirren each earned Academy Award nominations.) Mr. Scott added that it's ''the kind of movie that gives literature a bad name.''

OHANNESSIAN--Griselda Jackson. Surrounded by family, former president and managing director of New Directions Publishing, died peacefully in Rhode Island, on August 26, after a long struggle with Parkinson's. She was 84. Born in New York City in 1927, she grew up in Bucks County, PA, attending Westover, Barnard and Columbia. In 1956, she began a lifelong career at New Directions re-tiring as President in 2005. A devout New Yorker, Griselda married the late Garo Ohannessian in 1955 in Beruit. She is survived by a brother, a sister, three daughters, four grandchildren, and many beloved nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Carter Foundation.

STEIN--David F.,71, passed away peacefully at home on September 5. David was the devoted husband of Ellen Cohen for 38 years and the loving father of their children Jeremy (Robin), Katharine (Michael) and Nicholas (Kathryn) and grandchildren T.J., Ella, Michael and Lucy. David was the son of Nobel Laureate William H. Stein and Phoebe L. Hockstader and brother of William H. and Robert J. Stein. David graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Business School. He had a 40 year career as an investment banker in New York City where he was a Partner at Kuhn Loeb and a Managing Director at Lehman Brothers. Prior to his retirement David was the Vice Chairman of J & W Seligman and Company. Throughout his life David devoted himself to many causes, serving on the boards of Montefiore Hospital, The Children's Aid Society, Blythdale Children's Hospital and the Riverdale Country School. He was also a Director of Griffin Land & Nurseries, Inc. David will be remembered by his family and his many friends and associates as a loving, kind man of intelligence and integrity. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Phoebe Stein Child Life Center at Montefiore Hospital or The Children's Aid Society in New York City. Visitation 5-8pm, September 6 and 7 at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street and 5-8pm, September 8 at the Stein residence. Details concerning a memorial service later in the week to follow.

KOZINN--Murray Stanford, 97, of Woodmere, NY and Aventura, FL, father of immediate past National President of Hadassah, Nancy Falchuk, peacefully passed away at his home Friday. He is survived by his beloved family, including his wife of 68 years, Mildred, his three children, Nancy Falchuk of Newton, MA, Dr. Wesley Kozinn of Allentown, PA, and Andrew Kozinn of New York, NY, and by eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held in Florida Sunday. Donations may be made to the Turnberry Chapter of Hadassah, c/o Lucille Binderman, 3731 N. Country Club Drive, PH EF, Aventura, FL, 33180. May the memory of Murray Kozinn serve as a blessing to all who knew him. Marcie Natan, Hadassah National President

A United States District Court in Washington has rejected the Hungarian government's motion to dismiss a lawsuit filed against it and its museums and a university for artworks claimed by heirs of the Jewish banker and renowned collector Baron Mor Lipot Herzog. For more than two decades Herzog's heirs have been petitioning the Hungarian government to return more than $100 million worth of art, most of which has been hanging in Hungarian museums, where it was left for safekeeping during World War II or was placed after it was recovered from the Nazis and brought back to Hungary. Baron Herzog died in 1934. Years of requests have been rebuffed, and in July 2010 the Herzog family filed a lawsuit asking not only for the return of more than 40 artworks including paintings, sculptures and other works by El Greco, Lucas Cranach the Elder, Zubarán, Van Dyck, Velázquez and Monet, but also asking the Hungarian government for an accounting of all art from the Herzog family in its possession. Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle ruled late Thursday against Hungary's argument that its state-owned museums and university are immune from jurisdiction of the United States courts under the United States Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. She did dismiss the heirs' claims regarding 11 works, citing Hungarian judicial proceedings that she declined to revisit. Judge Huvelle's ruling will require Hungary to open government and museum records, allowing scrutiny of its Holocaust-era actions regarding looted artworks. Michael S. Shuster, the Herzog family's lawyer, said in a statement, ''We look forward to proceeding with discovery of the Hungarian government's shameful conduct in taking and refusing to return the family's artworks.''

THE FACTS Most people who get nighttime heartburn have heard the rule about eating before going to sleep: Avoid it. The kitchen cut-off time, doctors say, should be three to four hours before bed.

American Express, one of the event's corporate sponsors, offers card-carrying members a free radio headset for live commentary from CBS, Tennis Channel or ESPN. The gadget, available at the company's booths and called American Express Radio Live at the Open, has become a mainstay since it was introduced seven years ago. The company estimates it will hand out more than 140,000 headsets during the tournament this year. American Express has its own private radio station with a production team that pulls the broadcast feeds.

MOROT-SIR--Jacqueline, died August 3. Born in Marseille on December 15, 1914, she was the daughter of Cecile and Rene Le Senne, professor at the Sorbonne and a member of the Academie des Sciences Morales et Politiques. In 1935 she married Edouard Morot-Sir, professor de L'Etat, Cultural Counselor at the French Embassy in New York, 1957-1969, and subsequently professor at the University of Arizona and William Rand Kenan, Jr., Professor at the University of North Carolina, who died in 1993. A loving wife, mother and grandmother, an intellectual and a talented artist, she lived a full life in many places and enriched the lives of those around her with her support. She is survived by her daughter, Catherine Henriette Gordan, her granddaughter, Dr. Elizabeth L. Ellis of Palo Alto, her grandson, Dr. John D. Gordan of San Francisco, and her great-grandsons, Matthew and Owen Ellis. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 15, at 10:30am at the Dana Chapel, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations to: La Maison Francaise NYU, 16 Washington Mews, New York, NY 10003. Attention Francine Goldenhar.

CULLMAN--Edgar M.,of the Restigouche, Upsalquitch and Kedgwick Rivers, New Brunswick, Canada. All of us who knew you on these waters mourn the parting of the backing from your reel. Yours was a particularly honed reel. Being with you "in camp" was always a delight for the twinkle of your eye as you tightened the drag stimulating your chosen topic of conversation. You embraced many on these rivers as "family," particularly those from Runnymede and Two Brooks camps. Along the rivers, there is no finer accolade. Your decades long support for the conservation of wild Atlantic salmon makes a long cast for those of us following your drop. All members, directors and staff of The Atlantic Salmon Federation extend both our appreciation for your friendship and support and our condolences to the entire Cullman family. Richard J. Warren, U.S. Chairman Hon. Michael A. Meighen, Canadian Chairman William Taylor, President The Atlantic Salmon Federation

For a moment on Monday, it looked as if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would escape a second round of questions over his decision to conceal the domestic violence arrest that prompted the resignation of former Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith. Before the West Indian Day Parade in Brooklyn, he fielded several questions from reporters about the weekend's spate of violence, and spent roughly three minutes talking about it and its link to the proliferation of illegal guns circulating on city streets.

GREISMAN--Murray, 88, died gracefully in his sleep on Sunday, September 4th. He was the beloved husband of the late Beverly Greisman, and is survived by his sons Alan, Gordon, and Harold, his brother Jerome, and his grandchildren Sam, Chloe, Nicholas and Michael. He was a kind, loving and deeply thoughtful man. More than that, he was courageous. Serving in the Pacific during World War II, he was awarded the bronze star, and earned 10 battle stars signifying combat in 10 major naval engagements. He faced the end of his life with similar bravery. He lived with a quiet dignity, and died with an equal measure of it. The family wishes to express its profound gratitude to the Veteran's Administration Hospital in West Los Angeles, and the V.A. hospice facility in North Hills, California.

Conway; loving father of Jennifer Schott of San Pedro, CA, John W. Wingate of Cumming, GA, Jeffrey B. Wingate of Chatham, NJ; Proud grandfather of Julie and Janey Scott and Emily and Jake Wingate. -He donated a plot from his backyard garden for New York's original City Hall, where George Washington would be inaugurated as president. He presided as mayor over a government that assumed responsibility for paupers and banned slaughterhouses within the city limits. He even covered municipal deficits out of his own pocket. Nonetheless, the crated, larger-than-life bronze likeness of Abraham De Peyster remains in a parks department warehouse on Randalls Island - arguably, another unsung casualty of Sept. 11. The statue was removed from Hanover Square in the financial district seven years ago to make room for a memorial to British victims of the attack.

Citing ''the extremes of an anti-union attitude,'' workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have announced a strike that will cause the cancellation of a performance of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' by the Vienna Staatsoper this week, Agence France-Presse reported. The performance, scheduled for Friday, was to have revived a tradition of cultural exchanges between La Scala and the Staatsoper, with an Italian production - Verdi's Requiem - to be performed in Vienna on the same day and the same time the Austrian production was to have been staged in Milan.

Lawyers for Michael Jackson's doctor are trying to overturn a judge's refusal to sequester jurors for the doctor's manslaughter trial, saying they will be ''poisoned'' by the media frenzy surrounding the trial unless they are kept in isolation. Dr. Conrad Murray is accused of giving Jackson an overdose of the powerful anesthetic propofol just before the singer's death at his California home in 2009. Jackson, who was suffering from insomnia, was said to have used the drug to help him sleep. Dr. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter; if convicted he could face up to four years in prison.

RUGGIERO--Elaine Marie, of Greenwich, CT, died on August 31, 2011. She was 68 years old. She is survived by her husband Anthony W. Ruggiero, two daughters, Alicia Ruggiero and Audrey Kallassy and four grandchildren. A private family service was held on Saturday September 3, 2011.

The Moro Fountain on the southern end of the Piazza Navona in Rome was drained on Monday as restorers began reattaching two chunks of marble that were knocked off by a vandal. On Saturday a man wearing white sneakers climbed in the fountain, repeatedly attacked one of four large faces at the edge of it with a cobblestone, then walked away, according to The Associated Press. The man, who was caught on security cameras, was later picked up by the police, who noticed his sneakers matched those of the vandal caught on camera. He confessed to the crime, the police said, and also to throwing a rock at the nearby Trevi Fountain a few hours later, which he missed.

WASHINGTON -- When Shamai K. Leibowitz, an F.B.I. translator, was sentenced to 20 months in prison last year for leaking classified information to a blogger, prosecutors revealed little about the case. They identified the blogger in court papers only as ''Recipient A.'' After Mr. Leibowitz pleaded guilty, even the judge said he did not know exactly what Mr. Leibowitz had disclosed. ''All I know is that it's a serious case,'' Judge Alexander Williams Jr., of United States District Court in Maryland, said at the sentencing in May 2010. ''I don't know what was divulged other than some documents, and how it compromised things, I have no idea.''

LIMAN--Paula, age 100, on September 2, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Henry Liman. Survived by devoted children Bonnie Semon (Sig) and Lawrence Liman (Joan); adoring grandchildren Jerilyn, Jonathan, Matthew and Melanie; precious great-grandchildren Haley, Jessica, Alexa, Skylar, Harley, Ariela, Jared, Ryan and Marissa. "GiGi" (as she was dubbed after the birth of her first great-grandchild) was well-loved by everyone who came in contact with her. Her kindness and generosity knew no bounds. A born optimist, she was quick to say, "This too shall pass" whenever hard times befell her. GiGi, you have passed from our lives but you will never pass from our hearts and minds.

3:05 p.m. | Updated Buddy Ryan will not miss the latest edition of his twin sons' football rivalry - not even after being diagnosed with cancer for a fourth time. Rob Ryan, the Cowboys' new defensive coordinator, said Monday in Irving, Tex., that his father plans to delay surgery until after Dallas faces the Jets, coached by Rex, on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium. Rob Ryan said his father learned last week that he had cancer in his glands. It also spread to his neck, Rob said. ''This game's important to him,'' Rob Ryan said. ''He's going to get operated on after the game. He just wants to see these two rams bat heads and we're going to get after it.'' He added, ''It's a big thing for him, a big thing for the Ryans.''

This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Writers have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in ''Funny Girl''; unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings; the buzzkill of pre-show announcements; and the etiquette of booing at the theater. This week, Jason Zinoman, a New York Times freelancer and the author of ''Shock Value,'' a book about horror-movie directors, explores the meaning and purpose of bad reviews.

REED--Curt, age 92, of Massachusetts, formerly of Boynton Beach and New York. For 51 years, the beloved husband of the late Sonia Reed. Adored by his children, Deborah, David and Stacey, Shelley and Peter and grandchildren Jason, Julie, Alison, Kate and Nicky. Remembrances may be made to the U.S. Holocaust Museum.

The New Jersey-based band My Chemical Romance has fired its drummer, Michael Pedicone, just a year after he joined the group and replaced him with Jarrod Alexander of Dead Country. According to a statement posted on the band's Web site by the guitarist Frank Iero on Friday, Mr. Pedicone ''was caught red handed stealing from the band and confessed to the police after our show last night in Auburn, Washington.'' (Neither the Web site nor reports that followed have said what Mr. Pedicone is accused of having stolen.) Mr. Pedicone responded on Twitter that ''What happened is more complicated than it sounds but I did make a mistake,'' adding that ''it was an error in judgment based on a whole other situation that's way deeper, but this does not define me.'' The band, which is on national tour through Oct. 8, has decided not to press charges. ''We just want him out of our lives,'' Mr. Iero said on the Web site.

BROWNELL--Barbara G. Our guiding light of goodness, who touched our hearts and those of the children she taught. Made us laugh with tears at her unexpected funny, quirky insights. Taught us about fierce loyalty, compassion and to love without judgment. We will miss her and keep her within us, always. Her loving circle of friends.

In his recent Theater Talkback on the ArtsBeat blog, Jason Zinoman asked readers whether they agreed that giving harsh reviews was a necessary -- even sometimes useful -- aspect of a critic's job. Some of their responses follow: As an actor in community theater, where the criticism is so unprofessional (on every level) as to be laughable, I can say that it's very disappointing to read either a ''This is the best show ever'' or a ''This is the worst show ever'' review. Can we get a little information here? I learn nothing that might help my performance, and if I'm going to see another company's show, I learn nothing that will tell me what to expect. All of that said, this is also a product of our society -- it's perfectly fine to eviscerate or deep-fry anyone or anything. It's not. Harsh criticism can still be polite. If you don't have a strong enough command of vocabulary to get your point across without being mean, you should find another job.

Twelve jurors will decide the fate of Jeffrey E. Gundlach, the star fixed-income manager, in the civil trial pitting him against his former employer, Trust Company of the West. But investors in Mr. Gundlach's new firm seem to have already returned a verdict.

As President Obama confronts the nation's dismal unemployment problem - stubbornly stuck at 9.1 percent with, shockingly, zero net jobs created in August - Wall Street and corporate America are working behind the scenes in Washington to push for a series of temporary tax breaks, which they insist will help create jobs. Of course, businesses want an overhaul of the corporate tax code that would reduce rates for the long term. But for now they are seeking a series of tax holidays, including a payroll tax break for employers, not just employees, and a tax break to let companies repatriate about $1 trillion that is sitting overseas. In turn, they say, they will spend it on new recruits, perhaps as many as 2.9 million of them, according to a letter the United States Chamber of Commerce sent to the president on Monday.

KELMENSON--Leo-Arthur, of New York City and Remsenburg, died peacefully at his Remsenburg home, Land's End, on August 30, at the age of 84. Leo was a visionary in the world of advertising and marketing. He was Chairman of the Executive Committee of Bozell Worldwide (Advertising), Inc. and, previously, was Chairman and CEO of Kenyon & Eckhardt, Inc. (K&E). He also held senior management positions at Norman, Craig & Kummel and Lennen & Newell, where he began his career in the mailroom. In addition, he served as Chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide and, until recently, was executive advisor to David Bell, then Chairman and CEO of Interpublic Group of Companies (IPG). As CEO of K&E, and as an advisor to Lee Iacocca, Leo contributed significantly to the turnaround of Chrysler Corporation in 1979, by creating the ad campaign that helped to revive the ailing company and reshape its image. He was credited for restoring Chrysler's reputation in the eyes of the industry and the car-buying public. In his illustrious career, he also created highly successful ad campaigns for other leading automotive companies, such as Ford, General Motors, Daimler-Chrysler and Mitsubishi. Additionally, Leo served on the boards of many public companies, including Lorimar Telepictures, Online Software, and True North Communications. He also received numerous honors and awards for his service outside of the advertising industry, including the Guggenheim World Peace Award (1951), the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Award as The Outstanding Young Man of 1955 in charity, art, athletics and business thus upholding Theodore Roosevelt's belief that, "No man be dedicated to one venture or activity but to maintain a multitude of endeavors which each in its own way leads to the enrichment of human life." Mr. Kelmenson was awarded the Silver Quill Poetry Award in 1955 for "Epilogue", a book of poetry, reflecting his wartime experiences, the American Jewish Committee's Human Relations Award, the Catholic Charities Humanitarian Award (1989) and the Reserve Officers Association Award (1963). In the early 60's, he served in the White House as the Special Project Officer for the U.S. Department of State under President John F. Kennedy and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy. And, in the 1990's, he served as Chairman of the Board of the Development Committee at New York University's Tisch School of Arts. Born in New York City, Leo served with the U.S. Marine Corps in World War II First Parachute Division in the Pacific Theatre, South Pacific operations. He was awarded the Navy and Marine medal, the Bronze Star, two purple hearts, a Meritorious Unit Citation for bravery on the battlefield and was a Reserve Lieutenant Colonel. He graduated from Columbia University and studied at the Career Diplomat School of the University of Geneva. Leo was also a noted philanthropist, having supported numerous charities and causes. He served on the Boards of Directors of the Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island Foundation, the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, the President's Council of the American Diabetes Association, the National Cancer Foundation, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation, the Theodore Roosevelt Foundation, the United States Olympic Committee, and the Advertising Club of New York. He was a founding member of the African Medical & Research Foundation and Dr. Armand Hammer's Stop Cancer Foundation. Leo was also a member of the Sands Point Yacht Club and the United States Yacht Racing Association. He is survived by his beloved wife Gayle, their daughter, Philippa, his sons, Todd and Joel, and two grandchildren, Lana and Kyle. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation (www.mcsf.org. please specify The Kelmenson Memorial Scholarship) or by contacting: Marine Corps. Now that children are back in the classroom, are they really learning the lessons that will help them succeed? Many child development experts worry that the answer may be no. They say the ever-growing emphasis on academic performance and test scores means many children aren't developing life skills like self-control, motivation, focus and resilience, which are far better predictors of long-term success than high grades. And it may be distorting their and their parents' values.

Among many other things, the Civil War marked the first significant use of the railroad as a military tool. Between the opening of the first European and American railroads in 1830 and the outbreak of the war in 1861, there had been a few short wars in which railways had played a supporting role in moving troops and supplying armies with ammunition. Never before, however, did it play such a central role in the strategic and tactical planning of both sides.

Mitt Romney's 159-page jobs plan, which his campaign released in advance of tonight's Republican debate, is getting dismissed as "standard Republican fare," but its contents are more interesting than that. Romney spent most of his 2008 campaign for the presidency in full-on pander mode, but this time around he's trying a more difficult two-step. With the exception of a semi-backpedaled comment on global warming, he's refraining from challenging any conservative shibboleths directly, and his rhetorical flourishes can still sound like the "let's double Gitmo!" Romney of 2008 infamy. But at the same time, he's going to great to lengths to leave himself more room to maneuver on policy than the current right-wing line would normally allow - more room for the general election, and presumably for his hoped-for presidency as well.

To kick off Fashion Week and celebrate the Quiksilver Pro New York Surf Competition, an 11-day surf extravaganza on Long Island with a $1 million prize purse, Rogan's Bowery Street store is showing a collaborative installation called Rogan vs. LOOMSTATE-SRF CTY. On display starting today: cool surf clothes and the artist Maria Moyer's exclusive "Blue" collection, which consists of a delightful, ocean-inspired mix of jewelry and homeware, all handcrafted and cautiously sanded to simulate the effects of spending years under the sea. Limited-edition ultramarine discs and unglazed porcelain objects evoke the work of the Austrian sculptor Carl Aubock and are gratifyingly minimal and calming. The collection is available at Rogan through late October, and 10 percent of all proceeds from the capsule will go to Waves for Water, a nonprofit that helps bring clean water to impoverished communities.

When I joined the Army almost 10 years ago, I was already an old man - by the measure of my fellow recruits anyway, most of them only 18 or 19. I was all of 25, but it was enough to make a difference. Even though I got used to how my sergeants and lieutenants were often younger than me, I never got used to how young some of my fellow privates and Pfc.'s seemed. They were hardly more than boys, some of them, with bright ruddy cheeks, and bright eyes that grew hard during our year in Iraq.

Fans of the FX drama "Sons of Anarchy" rose up in record numbers on Tuesday, giving the show its highest ratings ever, with 4.9 million total viewers and 3.2 million in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Last week, the show's creator and executive producer, Kurt Sutter, announced on his blog that if the Season 4 premiere was up more than 10 percent in both major ratings categories over last season's premiere, he would award one of his more than 54,000  Twitter followers and one reader of his blog with a trip to Los Angeles, where the two lucky scion anarchists will be invited to a viewing party at Mr. Sutter's home. With a gain of 19 percent in total viewers and 17 percent in the 18-to-49 category compared to the Season 3 debut episode, Mr. Sutter will have to make good on his offer. FX also expects that when the final numbers are in, it will be the most watched original series episode in the cable channel's history.

The unofficial mascot for Alexa Chung's second collection for Madewell has to be the palm tree print, a black-and-gold repeat that shows up mostly on pajama-inspired pieces and looks like a polka dot from a distance. Chung, who wears the print in the line's new ad and will effectively motivate girls all over the world to go online and buy bits of it - pants, shirt or jersey ice skater dress - by doing so, drew the palm by hand. "I sketch so much in meetings," she says. "The Madewell team insisted." In fact, Madewell loves Chung's scribbles so much that they published a zine called Magaxine full of them. (Copies will be given to the first who buy pieces from the collection, which lands in stores and online on September 22.) "You know me, I'm obsessed with polka dots and Peter pan collars - British things like that - so they're all in there, too," Chung says.

Among the subjects I wrote about Tuesday was a book, "Following Ezra: What One Father Learned About Gumby, Otters, Autism and Love from His Extraordinary Son." It is, as the title indicates, the story of one parent's journey -- and it brought a question in the comments from Mir Kamin, who also has a child with autism, and who wrote:

It took me a long time to realize that the things my parents did were not exactly normal. I was about 7 years old, and it was the tail end of the 1950s, when it started to dawn on me that they were . . . well, let's just say they were different. For instance: my friends and I got shots when we went to the doctor and we hated them. But my parents stabbed themselves with needles almost every day, and seemed to enjoy it. Weird.

Graphic designers are fickle consumers of typographic fashion, their preferences changing on a whim. Some popular typefaces symbolize the future, or something even more fleeting; others are classic and exude elegance. A passé font returns from the wilderness, while others are exiled until they are rehabilitated by younger generations because they really are too cool for words - or too cool not to be made into words. Nothing is neutral about type. Designers so love their pet typefaces, and argue their merits so vociferously, that declaring one's type preferences can be as risky as calling oneself a Republican at a Democratic fund-raiser.

"Neither of my parents ever threw anything away," says John Carter Cash, the only son of Johnny Cash and June Carter. So, by his parents' death in 2003, the family vault brimmed with photos and scattered ephemera. John Carter spent years cataloging everything, and the result is "House of Cash" (Insight Editions, $40), a deeply personal, often surprising scrapbook of his home life. (Now 41, he appears as a boy in many of the photos from the book.) Who doesn't love buying online? It offers a bigger selection for less money, ordered from the privacy of your home and delivered there too. But if e-commerce is great for consumers, it is more  problematic for citizens. The sales tax that people pay in physical stores helps pay for the upkeep of their communities. The physical stores also provide employment; these workers can afford in turn to buy things and thus keep the economy afloat. Few such benefits flow from e-commerce.

Deceptively diminutive, Archy Marshall fidgets onstage. He is 17, angsty and awkward. But he is no teeny-bopper. A pleasant dissonance arises when he opens his mouth, and from his slight body emerges a deep, rich sound. His barked out lyrics are first person and loop through cryptic, emotionally raw experiences. A dubstep influence is there, but mostly in his modern sensibility as his music is guitar-anchored. For the last year or two, Marshall has played around Britain under the name Zoo Kid, heading to gigs after school, on weekends and over holidays. This past July he played under his new moniker, King Krule, at a festival in Hyères, France. With his second release due out in October, his seriousness is a welcome counterweight to the YouTube-driven fame of his contemporaries like Justin Bieber and Cody Simpson. "Teenager" need not be pejorative when it comes to lyricism. After all, Arthur Rimbaud was one.

The other day, I was working on a budget for our current operations, part of which involved totaling up payroll costs per hour. Right now, the company employs 14 people, and the pay totals $337 per hour (assuming a 40-hour week, and pro-rating the salaried employees). With that number of workers, using our current manufacturing methods and equipment, we can produce $2 million a year worth of goods. The projected profit should be in the range of 10 percent, $200,000 or so.

On Sept. 7, 1940, Nazi bomber planes launched an attack on London, killing an estimated 450 people in day and night raids. James B. Reston reported for the Sept. 7 New York Times, "Bombs fell in a district of the London area this morning before the sirens sounded and most of the residents were caught unprepared. At least five persons were killed outright and several others were seriously injured or burned by the fire that broke out. Search parties worked through the early hours looking for victims under wrecked houses. Many who escaped with their lives lost all their belongings in the fire."

In what was a very low prime-time turnout for the Labor Day holiday, Univision was the highest-rated broadcast network in both total viewers and the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. The Spanish-language network averaged 5.6 million viewers Monday night, aided by the three-hour season finale of ''Pequenos Gigantes'' (''Small Giants''), a talent show where children compete for a cash prize and are judged in three categories: singing, dancing and charisma. Fox finished second among 18- to 49-year-olds as ''Hell's Kitchen'' fell 10 percent from last week's summer high in the category and attracted 5.8 million total viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. .

What's not to watch? Tuesday's matches were moved back because of the rainout, and assuming the weather cooperates, holders of day-session tickets for the United States Open on Wednesday are in for a smorgasbord of tennis. CAROLINE WOZNIACKI VS. ANDREA PETKOVIC For someone who has been dominating the women's game for the better part of the past two years, Wozniacki always looks so darn beatable on court. Without a dominant shot, Wozniacki, the world No. 1 and 2009 Open runner-up, wins by keeping balls in play and waiting for her opponents to beat themselves. She is virtually immune to pressure and seems to know exactly when her opponent is about to crack. The 10th-seeded Petkovic is having her best year as a professional and comes into this match knowing she can beat Wozniacki on hardcourts, having defeated her in Miami this summer. Does she have the mental game to overcome Wozniacki in a quarterfinal on one of the biggest stages in tennis? I want to say yes, but I feel Wozniacki is going to find a way to win this match.
POWELL--Maxwell M. So greatly missed. In my heart always. With love, Susan

SASSON--Dorothea (Perlman), 86, died September 6, 2011. Sister to Herbert, Robert and Ruth; mother of Lionel and Nathaniel, grandmother of Anna, Aaron, Esther, Gabriela, David and Alex, devoted aunt, cousin, sister-in-law; loyal friend. An extraordinary life well-lived. Funeral Wednesday, September 7, 10:45am at Bach Synagogue in Long Beach, contact family for shiva details.

While hundreds of thousands of fans attend the United States Open each year, millions more watch the country's only Grand Slam tennis event in their living rooms -- or from anywhere with an Internet connection. In 2009, usopen.org began live-streaming matches at no charge. Phil Green, the United States Tennis Association's senior director for advanced media, estimated there were a little less than three million live-stream sessions over the course of the tournament that year. In 2010, all televised matches on the five show courts were live-streamed for the first time. Over the event's two weeks, there were 4.6 million sessions, according to the U.S.T.A. There were 40 million visits to the site, 12.4 million unique users and 298 million page views -- 30 million of them on mobile devices.

David became a director very early in the development of the company and always greatly contributed by consistently providing us with thoughtful, sensible and imaginative insights and advice. We will miss his counsel and friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Ellen, his children, Jeremy (Robin), Katharine (Michael) and Nicholas (Kathryn) and his grandchildren. Michael Danziger, President Griffin Land & Nurseries, Inc.

FINCH--Edward Ridley, JR. on September 4, 2011, in his 92nd year, born Westhampton Beach, New York, August 31, 1919, the only son of Mary Livingston Delafield and Judge Edward R. Finch. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 26 years, Pauline Swayze Finch, and survived by his first wife, Elizabeth Johnson Finch. Beloved father of Dr. Elizabeth Lathrop Finch, Edward Ridley Finch III and Dr. Maturin Delafield Finch; beloved stepfather of Carolyn Swayze, and Boopa to seven grandchildren. A graduate of Princeton University with A. B. (thesis honors) in 1941 and New York University School of Law (1947). He was proud of his active military service in World War II, including work with General Hap Arnold's Pentagon Combined Chiefs of Staff. He served as a JAG (USAF, Reserve) retiring as a Colonel. He received many awards including the Commandeur of French Legion of Honor from President Chirac, the Order of the British Empire (OBE) and Knights of the Order of St. John. He also received the Oak Leaf Cluster with the US Legion of Merit. In 1972 he was a US Special Ambassador to Panama and a member of the US Delegation to UNISPACE in 1982. He authored "Astrobusiness", "Holes in Your Pockets" and "Judicial Politics". Partner of Finch and Schaefler law firm for many decades. On the Boards of Directors of the New York Institute for Special Education, Adams Memorial Fund, St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School (Founder), St. Giles Foundation, and St. Andrew's Dune Church. He was a Director of the National Space Society and was its Permanent NGO Representative to the UN Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space. He loved to hold court at the dinner table, and the family will miss hearing his stories and seeing the twinkle in his eye. A memorial service will be held at a date yet to be determined. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Chair Fund at St Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue, New York, NY at (212) 328-0222 or at http://www.stbarts.org/chairs/.

GOLDBERG--William Eric. Jan. 2, 1971 - Sept. 7, 2000. Billy, it has been 11 years since you left us. You are in our thoughts and hearts every day. You are our angel. Please watch over us! Love, Mom and Heather.

Mr. Pascal, who also portrayed Roger in the 2005 film version of ''Rent'' and again on national tour, was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor in a musical for the role; he also played leading parts in the Broadway musical ''Aida'' and the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Cabaret.''

SPORTS An article on Monday about the inaugural Baltimore Grand Prix, a three-day event featuring IndyCar and Le Mans-style street races, erroneously attributed a distinction to three North American cities that host IndyCar racing on city streets. While Baltimore is the newest site, its addition will not mean that it, Toronto and Long Beach, Calif., are ''the only'' North American host cities. The racing is also held in St. Petersburg, Fla.

The Beatles have taken one more baby step into the world of digital music. After having had all of their original albums put on sale through Apple's iTunes in November, the Beatles on Tuesday released a downloadable version of ''1,'' their 27-song greatest-hits album from 2000, again available only through iTunes. As its title suggests, ''1'' contains songs that reached No. 1 in the United States or Britain, like ''Love Me Do'' (released in 1962, reaching No. 1 in the United States in 1964) and ''The Long and Winding Road'' (released and reaching the top spot in 1970). The album has sold 30 million copies around the world since its release, and in the United States it was the best-selling album of the first decade of the 2000s. It may be hard to imagine that there are any Beatles fans left who have not already bought their music. But in addition to completists, the digital release of ''1'' may appeal to the thriftiest of the band's fans. The original Beatles albums sell for $12.99 each on iTunes, with individual songs going for $1.29. But ''1'' costs $9.99, and almost immediately after its release on Tuesday it shot to the top of iTunes's internal sales ranking. iTunes has an exclusive deal to sell Beatles downloads, but neither Apple nor the band's label, EMI, has revealed how long that deal will last.

SCIENCE TIMES A picture in some editions on Tuesday with an article about advances in psychoacoustics was published in error. It showed the Boston Symphony Orchestra performing at Carnegie Hall in Manhattan -- not at Symphony Hall in Boston, which is regarded by many critics as an acoustically perfect space.

Though it hasn't been a great year, economically, for almost anyone, Steve Martin continues to do what he can to spare bluegrass musicians the worst of the lingering downturn. On Tuesday Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian and cultural omnivore, announced that Sammy Shelor, the banjo player and leader of the Lonesome River Band, is the second winner of his Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass, which comes with $50,000. In a telephone interview Mr. Martin said that Mr. Shelor - who has been named the International Bluegrass Music Association's banjo player of the year four times - did not necessarily need further recognition from his musical peers. ''He already is somebody,'' Mr. Martin said.

An article on Tuesday about a leak prosecution involving the disclosure of transcripts of F.B.I. eavesdropping on the Israeli Embassy in Washington gave an outdated location for the secret court that approves such wiretaps. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court moved to the federal courthouse in Washington in 2009; it is no longer at the Justice Department.

LICITRA--Salvatore. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of Salvatore Licitra, a prodigiously talented tenor who has sung with our company since 2002. He made a sensational Met debut, replacing Luciano Pavarotti as Cavaradossi in Tosca at the eleventh hour, in a sold-out performance that was also transmitted live to an audience of more than 3,000 opera lovers on Lincoln Center Plaza. He won a standing ovation for the debut performance. Salvatore went on to give impressive portrayals at the Met of some of the most demanding Italian roles, including Radames in Aida, Don Alvaro in La Forza del Destino, Canio in Pagliacci, Riccardo in Un Ballo in Maschera, and Calaf in Turandot. In 2007, he sang Luigi in Il Tabarro in the new production of Il Trittico, a performance that was transmitted live around the world as part of the Met's Live in HD series. In March and April 2011, he returned to the role of Cavaradossi for what would become his final Met performances. We will remember him not only for his artistry but for his warm personality and easygoing collegiality, qualities that made him an immensely popular backstage presence at the Met. His tragic death has touched our company deeply, and we offer our sincere condolences to his family, friends, and many admirers. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

SAN FRANCISCO -- Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo's chief executive, was fired Tuesday, ending a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the online media company. She went out with the same outspoken style she used while running the company. In an e-mail she sent to employees from her iPad, titled ''Goodbye,'' Ms. Bartz wrote: ''I am very sad to tell you that I've just been fired over the phone by Yahoo's chairman of the board.'' Ms. Bartz was informed of the board's decision while she was traveling to New York from Maine, according to a person familiar with the board's action.

WEEKEND A picture caption on Friday with the Weekend Miser column misstated the name of a performer in the Wasabassco Burlesque Show who was scheduled to appear on Sunday at the ''Take This Job and Shove It'' party at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn. She is Medianoche, not Marlo Marquise Medianoche. (Another member of the company named Marlo Marquise.)

Regis Philbin has put a date on it: Nov. 18 will be his last day on ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' the daytime talk show he has co-hosted in syndication since 1988. Nine months ago Mr. Philbin, left, said he planned to depart ''Live,'' but he had not specified a date until Tuesday, when the show began its new season. Mr. Philbin's co-host, Kelly Ripa, will remain on the show. ''Kelly will be trying out new co-hosts, just like we did 11 years ago, when we found her,'' Mr. Philbin said on Tuesday. Back then there was a seven-month period between the exit of the previous co-host, Kathie Lee Gifford, and the entrance of Ms. Ripa. There will be an interim period this time, too, as tryouts won't start in earnest until Mr. Philbin departs. Mr. Philbin, 80, has said he intends to be back on television sometime next year, perhaps on a new daytime show.

Groupon is considering a delay to its long-awaited initial public offering amid turmoil in the stock market. While the online coupon giant had been hoping to go public by the end of this month, it is studying the market conditions and may push back the timing of the offering, said two people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly about internal discussions.

BUSINESS DAY The Common Sense column on Saturday, about criticism of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, misstated the effect of the Fed's recent interest rate guidance on Treasury note yields. It was the yield on the 10-year note -- not the two-year note -- that dipped below 2 percent for the first time in over half a century. (The yield on the two-year note is hovering around 0.2 percent.)

Mary Kocy's circumnavigation of Manhattan on water skis began with a wrong number. Lots of wrong numbers, actually. ''Back in the days when people used phone books,'' Ms. Kocy said, '''Rusk, John,' who is my husband, was listed immediately under Rusk Institute. And instead of just listing the number, it would say, 'Please see N.Y.U. School of Medicine - Rehabilitation.' Either people didn't read that or, wishful thinking, they'd just call our number. We'd come home to a phone machine with messages like, 'Yes, I'd like to talk to Dr. Howard' or 'Would somebody please call me back, my father has had a stroke.'''

STEIN--David F. The Trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society of New York mourn the passing of David F. Stein, dedicated Board member and longtime supporter. Since 2001, David was a caring and committed Trustee and an active member of several committees. David was elected Vice Chairman of the Board in 2010, was the former chair of the Audit Committee and also served on the Executive, Finance and Investment, and Health Services Committees. David contributed his wisdom, intellect and expertise and will be remembered for the vitality of his concern and his steadfast efforts on behalf of the fragile children and families of New York City. David was also a very generous supporter of many of Children's Aid programs and services and was a familiar face at Children's Aid events. Our hearts go out to his wife Ellen and the rest of his family--he will be sorely missed. Richard R. Buery, Jr., President and CEO, Mark M. Edmiston, Chairman, Edgar Koerner, Chairman Emeritus

Bank of America shook up its top management team on Tuesday, as the beleaguered financial firm contended with a flagging share price and mounting legal liabilities. As part of the reshuffling, the bank announced the departure of two senior executives, Sallie L. Krawcheck, one of the top women on Wall Street, and Joe Price, a Bank of America veteran.

New productions of ''Timon of Athens,'' starring Simon Russell Beale and directed by Nicholas Hytner, and ''King Lear,'' starring Jonathan Pryce and directed by Michael Attenborough, are among the many, many Shakespeare works that will be presented as part of the World Shakespeare Festival, a seven-month celebration of the playwright that is being planned in Britain for next year. On Monday, its organizers announced a program that will include 70 productions and exhibitions taking place primarily in London and Stratford-upon-Avon, and involving more than 50 arts groups from around the world, as part of the London 2012 festival, which is the culmination of London's Cultural Olympiad. Other planned productions include ''Romeo and Juliet in Baghdad,'' presented by the Iraqi Theater Company; ''Julius Caesar,'' directed by Gregory Doran and set in present-day Africa; ''Troilus and Cressida,'' directed by Elizabeth LeCompte and Rupert Goold and presented as a collaboration between the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Wooster Group; and ''Desdemona,'' which combines the efforts of Toni Morrison, Peter Sellars and the Malian singer-songwriter Rokia Traore.

The Findings column on Aug. 30, about the locavore food movement and the globalization process that began when Columbus landed in the New World, misattributed the notion that the first ''green revolution'' was brought about by the widespread use of fertilizer, made possible by the importing of guano from Peru. Edward D. Melillo, a history professor at Amherst College, put forth that idea, as noted in the book the column cited, ''1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created,'' by Charles C. Mann; Mr. Mann was not the originator of that idea.

8 P.M. (ESPNU) SEC: STORIED Four hourlong documentaries analyze the traditions and rivalries of Southeastern Conference football, starting with this look at Herschel Walker (above, in 1981), who won the Heisman Trophy at the University of Georgia before playing for the Dallas Cowboys, the Minnesota Vikings, the Philadelphia Eagles and the New York Giants. ''I used to pay kids money to talk to me or to be nice to me,'' says Mr. Walker, who was bullied as a child for being overweight and stuttering. ''There are so many kids out there that are suffering and hurting, that if I can speak out about it and touch someone's soul, that makes me feel better than winning the Heisman Trophy.'' The film includes interviews with his family, his former Georgia coaches Vince Dooley and Mike Cavan, and his teammates Frank Ros and Joe Happe, as well as his high school coach and his psychotherapist, who treated him for dissociative identity disorder (formerly known as multiple personality disorder). 7 A.M. (HBO Signature) STANLEY AND LIVINGSTONE (1939) Stanley (Spencer Tracy), a reporter for The New York Herald, travels to Zanzibar to search for the long-missing British missionary Dr. David Livingstone (Cedric Hardwicke) in this lavish production from Henry King. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film ''intelligent and restrained and dignified.''

INTERNATIONAL A news analysis article on Friday about the Green Party's recent surge in popularity in Germany misstated the year the Green Party of Australia won its first House seat. It was in 2002, not 2010. (The 2002 vote was a by-election. The party won its first House seat in a general election in 2010.)

HECHT--Hubert, MD. LOS ANGELES - One of the Walt Disney Company's most senior executives, Andrew P. Mooney, abruptly resigned Tuesday morning as chairman of the conglomerate's sprawling consumer products unit. Mr. Mooney, who has served as chairman of Disney Consumer Products since 2003, informed staff members of his decision in an e-mail. Mr. Mooney, who was in good standing with the company, said in the e-mail that he desired to move ''to a leadership role with another organization and corporate boards.''

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday hailed the revival of Lower Manhattan over the decade since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and said the rebuilding and growth of the area was a testament to American resilience. ''I believe the rebirth and revitalization of Lower Manhattan will be remembered as one of the greatest comeback stories in American history,'' he said. ''And I believe it will stand as our greatest monument to those we lost on 9/11 and to our unshakable faith in the moral imperative of protecting and preserving a free, open, democratic society.''

A few days after alumni from Stuyvesant High School were told that they could not hold a vigil to commemorate Sept. 11 in their school, they are now getting their wish. All it took was a few phone calls and a three-day weekend. In an agreement brokered by the Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, and the Battery Park City Authority's chairman William C. Thompson Jr., the alumni will have a two-hour permit to use their school's auditorium on Sunday. Mr. Thompson had the authority to issue a permit for use of the auditorium in the school building, which is on Battery Park City property.

MIND OF MADOFF Despite initial doubts about his claims, Bernard L. Madoff, below, the convicted swindler, is actually working with a faculty member at Harvard Business School on a case study about his career experiences, including his enormous Ponzi scheme. The research, according to a Harvard spokesman, is aimed at identifying the ''pressures, circumstances, emotions, etc.'' that prompted the felons to commit their crimes.
