LOS ANGELES - If the idea is to stage a goofy television show about a very serious bunch of movies, next year's Academy Awards are pointed in the right direction. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which presents the Oscars, on Tuesday said that Eddie Murphy - whose starring roles over the past the 20 years have come almost exclusively in lowbrow movies like ''Norbit'' -- had agreed to host its 84th annual awards ceremony. ABC will broadcast the show on Feb. 26.

In her first day as executive editor of The New York Times, Jill Abramson announced the appointment on Tuesday of two new assistant managing editors to help round out her senior management team. Susan Chira, the foreign editor since 2004, will help oversee the daily news departments of The Times.

GREISMAN--Murray, 88, died gracefully in his sleep on Sunday, September 4th. He was the beloved husband of the late Beverly Greisman, and is survived by his sons Alan, Gordon, and Harold, his brother Jerome, and his grandchildren Sam, Chloe, Nicholas and Michael. He was a kind, loving and deeply thoughtful man. More than that, he was courageous. Serving in the Pacific during World War II, he was awarded the bronze star, and earned 10 battle stars signifying combat in 10 major naval engagements. He faced the end of his life with similar bravery. He lived with a quiet dignity, and died with an equal measure of it. The family wishes to express its profound gratitude to the Veteran's Administration Hospital in West Los Angeles, and the V.A. hospice facility in North Hills, California.

FRONT PAGE An article on Aug. 15 about Representative Darrell Issa's business dealings, using incorrect information from the San Diego County assessor's office, misstated the purchase price for a medical office plaza Mr. Issa's company bought in Vista, Calif., in 2008. And because of an editing error, a correction in this space on Aug. 26 also misstated the price. It cost $16.6 million -- not $10.3 million or $16.3 million.

STEIN--David F.,71, passed away peacefully at home on September 5. David was the devoted husband of Ellen Cohen for 38 years and the loving father of their children Jeremy (Robin), Katharine (Michael) and Nicholas (Kathryn) and grandchildren T.J., Ella, Michael and Lucy. David was the son of Nobel Laureate William H. Stein and Phoebe L. Hockstader and brother of William H. and Robert J. Stein. David graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Business School. He had a 40 year career as an investment banker in New York City where he was a Partner at Kuhn Loeb and a Managing Director at Lehman Brothers. Prior to his retirement David was the Vice Chairman of J & W Seligman and Company. Throughout his life David devoted himself to many causes, serving on the boards of Montefiore Hospital, The Children's Aid Society, Blythdale Children's Hospital and the Riverdale Country School. He was also a Director of Griffin Land & Nurseries, Inc. David will be remembered by his family and his many friends and associates as a loving, kind man of intelligence and integrity. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Phoebe Stein Child Life Center at Montefiore Hospital or The Children's Aid Society in New York City. Visitation 5-8pm, September 6 and 7 at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Memorial Service 3pm, September 8 at Rockefeller University, Caspary Auditorium, 1230 York Avenue at 66th Street. Reception to follow immediately.

STEIN--David F. The Board of Trustees and staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of David F. Stein. Mr. Stein was devoted to children's causes, and followed in his mother Phoebe's footsteps by serving as a member of the Board of Trustees of Blythedale for many years. In 2001, he was named an Honorary Trustee of the Hospital. We are grateful for all that the Stein family has contributed to Blythedale over the years, and extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. GOLDENBERG--Jacob, 56, of Hollis Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Deborah Laurie Goldenberg, proud father of Monica and Michael, loving son of Paul and Vera Goldenberg, brother of Dan Goldenberg (Orna) and Judith Spira (Josef), cherished son-in-law of David and Arlene Lurie, passed away peacefully at his home following a long, fiercely-fought illness. He was a CPA and partner at NY accounting firm of Elsikovic & Kane LLP, esteemed executive board member of the Hollis Hills Jewish Center and treasured by his friends, family and community.

STEIN--David F. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the passing of David F. Stein, a long-time Board member. Since being elected to the Board of Trustees in 1990 David has carried on a long family tradition of support for Montefiore that began with his grandparents, Frederick and Beatrice Stein, in 1929. His father, Nobel Laureate Dr. William Stein, was a Board member for 25 years and his mother, Phoebe H. Stein, served as a Trustee on the Board and as President of the Auxiliary. She volunteered at Montefiore for 40 years and founded the Phoebe H. Stein Child Life Program which continues as a nationally known program. During his tenure on the Board, David was an ardent supporter of the Child Life Program and the creation of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore. He had a deep connection to Montefiore's unique commitment to its community and saw it as central to the medical center's strategic plan. He was also a member of the Board's Executive Committee. Our deepest and heartfelt condolences go out to David's wife Ellen, his sons, Jeremy Vail Stein and Nicholas David Stein, his daughter, Katharine Ellen Stein Fahey, and their entire families. Steven M. Safyer, MD, President and CEO David A. Tanner, Chairman, Board of Trustees

Maybe a year ago - or was it longer? - Prabal Gurung answered Demi Moore's Twitter post with his own. Until then, Mr. Gurung, an up-and-coming designer who started his company two years ago, had been on the Twitter fence. He really didn't know what it was and, as he said, "it seemed too much about yourself." But after replying to Ms. Moore, he quickly got 500 followers. Today he has 32,604 followers, and as he calculated the payoff from the social media network, says, "It's a business." It has helped him build his brand.

Brazil's most famous assets usually end up prancing down a Victoria's Secret runway, but with the publication of "Brazilian Style" ($65 at assouline.com), the country's more obscure offerings - pink dolphins, anyone? - join Carmen Miranda and the caipirinha in a colorful look at Brazil's cultural legacy. Armand Limnander, the book's author and a former T editor, says the tome grew out of a 10-year love affair with the country. "It's a very personal take on the people, places and things that resonate with me," he says (like the idyllic island of Fernando de Noronha, shown here.) He adds, "Brazil is already an economic superpower - it's hosting both the Olympics and the World Cup in the next few years - so the next logical step is for it to begin exporting its culture, which is rich, varied and above all, fun."

At New York Fashion Week, particularly with the September shows, there is always a slight back-to-school feeling whenever all the editors and retailers reconvene, as they did this morning in Lincoln Center, in all their latest finery. This morning also happened to be the first day of school for most New York City students, and at least in my neighborhood in Brooklyn, the students were better dressed than the fashionistas. A couple of weeks ago, the artist Hanna Liden forgot her backpack on a bench in the East Village. When she went back to look for it some 20 minutes later, it was still there. "That's scary!" Liden exclaimed the other morning, sitting at a table at Karma, Brendan Dugan's bookshop and design studio on Downing Street in the West Village. The New York Liden lays bare in her new book, "Out of My Mind ... Back in 5 Minutes," is not the sort of place you'd want to leave your personal belongings unattended. Trash bags pile up in the streets like body bags, a slick of dark liquid might be oil or it might be blood, even a rock in central park has the menacing look of a giant, gaunt-eyed skull. This is, of course, all a lot funnier than it sounds. The book is compiled from images swiped from the Internet, photos taken with a BlackBerry and installation shots from Liden's recent shows at Maccarone and Salon 94 including a series of self-portraits in which she wore various plastic deli shopping bags. A recurring chorus of slogans appropriated from souvenir T-shirts delivers the punchline. "Of all the things I've lost, I miss my mind the most."

The extensive collection is a peek into six decades of Mr. Raitt's life and includes scrapbooks, publicity photos, recordings, annotated scripts, musical scores, tapes he made of himself, and correspondence, said Denise Gallo, the head of acquisitions and processing at the library's music division.

From the rubble-filled streets of Rome to the sunny, aqua-blue skies of Mozambique, Bob Dylan has traveled the world in his music and his real-life exploits. Now a series of his drawings and paintings that chronicle his journeys in Asia will be coming to the Gagosian Gallery, the first time that Mr. Dylan's art will be exhibited in New York City, the gallery said. The exhibition, "The Asia Series," will run at the Gagosian on the Upper East Side from Sept. 20 through Oct. 22, and will include works that Mr. Dylan created on trips to Japan, China, Vietnam and South Korea. (Dylanologists will recall that the singer-songwriter played his first shows in China and in Vietnam last spring.)

Trying to capitalize on Booker buzz, Knopf has moved up the publication date of "The Sense of an Ending," a novel by Julian Barnes that was one of six books chosen for the shortlist of the 2011 Man Booker Prize for Fiction. Mr. Barnes has been widely cited as a favorite for the prize, which is the most celebrated literary award in Britain. "The Sense of an Ending," a slim volume of only 176 pages, will be released by Knopf, part of Random House, on Oct. 11, three months ahead of its scheduled U.S. publication date. Four of the other shortlisted books have already been published in the United States, and the remaining book, "Half Blood Blues" by Esi Edugyan, is not yet available in the United States, said a spokeswoman for its London-based publisher, Serpent's Tail. The winner of the Booker will be announced on Oct. 18.

Not many fashion labels can boast an in-house art curator, but for Jesse Finkelstein and Katie King, the designers behind the New York label JF & Son, Travis Boyer is an accessory they can't live without. Through my "My Favorite Things," JF & Son works on at least four collaborative collections per year as well as various one-off collaborations. Last year, for example, the artist Ulrike Müller translated her 8.5-by-11-inch pencil drawings into quilts; a version of this project was part of the 2010 Cairo Biennial. "We're trying to be a little more spontaneous," Finkelstein explains. "It's not about creating a lifestyle for our customer. Adds King: "It's more about creating a vision that appeals to the community."

Under the traditional rules of American politics, last night was a very bad night for Texas Governor Rick Perry. In his debut debate, his first introduction to a national audience, he found himself first explaining and then doubling down on his description of  Social Security as a "Ponzi scheme," with a few references to the "monstrous lie" of its long-term promises thrown in for good measure. It was precisely the kind of moment that the Romney campaign must have been hoping for, and thanks to the moderators' questions and Perry's answers, it fell into Romney's lap without him having to even raise the issue. As soon as the exchange happened, a Romney adviser e-mailed Politico's Ben Smith: "[Perry] has lost. No federal candidate has ever won on the Perry program to kill Social Security. Never has. never will." That's spin, yes, but I'm sure the Romney people believe the basic premise. As well they should. Everything we know about American voters - and yes, Republican primary voters very much included - suggests that Perry's comments will eventually be deadly to his electoral prospects.

It turns out a Tony Award really can get you in anywhere. Having run the table at the Tonys in June with their hit musical, "The Book of Mormon," the "South Park" co-creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker were back in New York on Tuesday, where they showed up as instructors at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. Approximately 25 freshmen who perhaps expected to doze their way through the first day of a "Storytelling Strategies" course were instead treated to a surprise visit by Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker, who discussed the creation of projects including "South Park," "Team America: World Police" and "The Book of Mormon." (Among the nuggets of wisdom offered by Mr. Parker, a self-confessed addict of the Food Network, was to not use too many ingredients in your writing: "Get one piece of salmon and cook it just right," he said. "Boil it down to one thing.")

"I love brands that have a niche, something that they do incredibly well time and time again," says the designer Wes Gordon. For Gordon, few fit this description better than Manolo Blahnik. "What I love about Manolo is that they've been making the same consistently beautiful shoes for as long as they've been in business," says Gordon. "No one nails the timeless, forever-feminine aesthetic quite like them. This praise explains his excitement about collaborating with the Italian shoe company for his spring presentation, taking place on Thursday at the Hosfelt Gallery in Chelsea. Using elements of Manolo's existing vocabulary  -- a heel here, a strap there -- Gordon designed two different shoes for the show, an updated Mary Jane for day and a streamlined, stacked-heel sandal for night. "It was something of Manolo Legos," the designer says of the process. "The look is very Gwyneth from 'Great Expectations.' Clean '90s minimalism done in a very luxe way." Expect timeless silhouettes done in surprising fabrications, like Lurex and stretch tulle. "So many shoes out there are very aggressive or very cool, and make a statement. But I think at the end of the day what a woman wants is something really sexy, beautiful and clean."

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the dismissal of Carol A. Bartz as chief executive of Yahoo misstated the company's share of online display advertising in the United States as estimated by the digital marketing research firm eMarketer. Yahoo's share is expected to decline to 13.1 percent this year from 14.4 percent last year, according to the firm; it is not expected to decline 13.1 percent this year after falling 14.4 percent last year.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about Michael Arrington, the founder of the technology blog TechCrunch, using information from the blog's database, misstated the date of Mr. Arrington's investment in Milk, a mobile development lab. Mr. Arrington said he invested in Milk several days before its funding round closed on April 26, not on April 1 as indicated in the database at Crunchbase.com. On the basis of that incorrect date, the column erroneously faulted the site for not disclosing Mr. Arrington's investment in a positive TechCrunch article about Milk on April 4. That article did not disclose Mr. Arrington's investment because it had not yet been made. TechCrunch disclosed the investment in an article on April 26; it was not the case that TechCrunch failed to disclose that Mr. Arrington was an investor. The column also misidentified the profession of Robert Scoble, who was cited as another venture capitalist who both published and traded on information. He is a blogger and technologist, not a venture capitalist.

CARROLL--Sidney Burke, 87, passed away June 9 surrounded by her four sons. Born August 15, 1923 in Rutland, VT, she was the daughter of the late J. Frank and Mary Barnett Burke. Sidney and her three younger siblings spent their youth in Slingerlands, NY. She graduated cum laude from The Albany Academy for Girls in 1941 and graduated as a Wellesley College Scholar in 1945 with a B.A. in Political Science. From 1946-48 she served as special assistant to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, in charge of speechwriting and press relations. Sidney and Thomas Sylvester Carroll were wed in 1947 and together raised five sons in New Canaan, CT. Sidney was known for her organic gardens, ardent support of Montessori education, and love of Vermont. Among other civic activities, she was a director of the League of Voters in New Canaan and Children's Services of Stamford, CT. In 1969, Sidney earned her Juris Doctorate from NYU School of Law and served as a staff attorney for the Juvenile Relations Division of The Legal Aid Society in New York from 1971-1981. Inspired by conversations with children from The Whitby School carpool, Sidney authored the children's book You Be The Judge. The book challenges the reader for decisions in legal cases and their precedents, and was intended to give children a better understanding of the law and its role in society. Residing in Manhattan for the past three decades, Sidney was a longstanding volunteer at the Guggenheim Museum, The Asia Society, and the English Speaking Union. Sidney's family is graced with her many original watercolor paintings and collections of "Easy Thoughts." She leaves behind her three siblings, James Burke, Daniel Burke, and Phyllis Burke Davis and their families; four of her sons, Jeffrey Burke Carroll, James Francis Carroll, Matthew Carroll, and Charles Laurence Carroll, her daughters in law, nine grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and her cherished caregivers. Her fifth son, Thomas Jeremiah Carroll, predeceased her; their remains rest together in Eden, VT. A celebration of Sidney's life will take place at The Whitby School, Greenwich, CT at 3pm on September 17th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Whitby School Annual Fund, 969 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831.

FROST--William Lee. William Lee Frost (84 years old), Chairman of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation, passed away on September 7th, 2011. Born in Larchmont, New York to Charles and Eva Frost, he graduated Bayside High School and served in the Navy during World War II before attending Harvard College (1947), Yale Law School (1951), and the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration (1958). He entered the State Department in 1952 and served as a Foreign Service Officer in Belgrade, Salzburg, and Bad Godesberg. Returning to New York City in 1959 due to the illness of his first wife, Judith, daughter of Charlotte and Lawrence E. Spivak, he re-entered legal practice specializing in management and investments until later becoming President of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation. Always interested in health, he served as a member of the Public Health Council of New York State's Department of Health under Governor Carey, and as Chairman (1985-87), Treasurer, and Director of the New York Heart Association. He was also a Trustee of the Brearley School, the Collegiate School, Marlboro College, and Radcliffe College. As a student at Harvard, he was the founding President of Hillel and later, as a graduate, became a member of the Visiting Committee, Honorary Curator, and President of Judaica at Harvard University Library. He also served as a member of the Visiting Committee to the Harvard Divinity School. He was Chair of the New York State Archives Partnership Trust (1994-97) and on the Board of the Croton Aqueduct. He was also the President and a Director of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, and a Trustee of the P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, Inc. His hobbies including rambling, whether around Manhattan, the Rockies, or Scotland, and often singing as he strolled along to whomever crossed his path. Predeceased by his first wife, Judith, he is survived by their daughters Rebecca (Mohammed) and Hannah, as well as by his wife Susan and their children Abigail (John) and Robert (Navah) and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Aviva, Cipa, Zamira and Ivry. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street on Friday, September 9th, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to one of the institutions mentioned above.

WASHINGTON -When the actress Meryl Streep learned that she would be among the five performers to receive this year's John F. Kennedy Center Honors, the moment was bittersweet. ''I am deeply honored by this news, and wish my mother and father were alive to hear it!'' she said in a statement Tuesday sent from Connecticut, where she is filming the romantic comedy ''Great Hope Springs.'' ''All that education, allowance, tuition, voice lessons, summer jobs, scholarship application deadlines and loving care and discipline - all that they gave me, bore fruit in a way they never dreamed. I am so grateful!''

The Home Tech column last week, about security devices for vacation homes, referred imprecisely to a feature of the LiNK Wireless Keypad Deadbolt by Schlage. A code that allows the deadbolt to be opened can be set and changed remotely with a computer or cellphone, but the deadbolt itself must be opened and closed manually.

An article on Wednesday about performances in which the New York Philharmonic is playing the score to the film ''West Side Story'' during screenings of the movie misidentified the Academy Award won by the orchestrators of the film's music. It was for scoring of a musical picture, not best original score. The article, using information from the Philharmonic, also misspelled the given name of a researcher at the Leonard Bernstein Office who worked on the project. She is Eleonor Sandresky, not Eleanor. And the article misidentified the studio that made the film. It was United Artists, not MGM. (MGM Holdings Inc. now owns United Artists.)

To paraphrase a famous saying, a camera can never be too (feature) rich or too thin. Two new cameras bring that aphorism to mind, the Canon PowerShot Elph 510 HS and the Nikon Coolpix S8200, both small, slim point-and-shoot cameras packing oversize zoom lenses.

Among basic cable channels FX is behind perhaps only AMC in terms of program prestige, but FX's highest-rated show isn't the Emmy-nominated comedy ''Louie'' or the Emmy-nominated drama ''Justified,'' or even the previously Emmy-nominated ''Rescue Me.'' It's the network's Hamlet-on-Harleys outlaw drama ''Sons of Anarchy,'' which returned for its fourth season on Tuesday. The new season finds the motorcycle club's leaders recently released from prison to face new threats from law enforcement types, Russian gun dealers and real estate developers. Meanwhile the dynastic intrigue thickens around the melancholy young Jax (Charlie Hunnam) and the club's king and queen, his stepfather, Clay (Ron Perlman), and mother, Gemma (Katey Sagal). (Claudius and Gertrude, get it?)

TAFFNER--Donald. The St. John's University family mourns the passing and celebrates the life of Donald Taffner, 53C, 89HON, illustrious and accomplished alumnus, extraordinarily generous benefactor, and loyal, cherished friend. For more than half a century, he blessed us with his love, dedication, and support and shared with us his remarkable creativity and business acumen. An inveterate sports fan, he inspired our student athletes, in particular, to pursue and achieve excellence in every facet of their lives. His legacy to them and to the entire University includes the Taffner Field House, a gift from him and his beloved wife, the late Eleanor Taffner, trustee emerita. St. John's has been immeasurably strengthened by his service, humbly given and most gratefully received. We shall remember him with admiration and affection always. Our thoughts and prayers go to his children and grandchildren in this time of sorrow. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chair, Board of Trustees Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

SIMI VALLEY, Calif. -- The fight for the Republican presidential nomination began narrowing into an intense and ideological battle at a debate here Wednesday night, with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Mitt Romney sharply clashing over Social Security, health care and each other's long-term prospect against President Obama. A series of spirited exchanges between the two men, which revealed differences in substance and style, offered the first extensive look into the months-long contest ahead. They traded attacks on each other's job creation records and qualifications to be president, overshadowing their opponents in the crowded Republican field.

Wednesday was a virtual repeat of Tuesday, as far as the weather. Sure, there were a few balls struck in the morning, but the rains came soon after those matches got under way and never let up. Thinking optimistically about the forecast, here are the top matches on tap for Thursday: CAROLINE WOZNIACKI VS. ANDREA PETKOVIC For someone who has been all but dominating the women's game for the better part of the past two years, Wozniacki always looks so darn beatable on court. Without a dominant shot, she wins by keeping balls in play and waiting for her opponents to beat themselves. The 10th-seeded Petkovic is having her best year as a professional. She defeated Wozniacki on hardcourts in Miami this summer. Does she have the mental game to overcome Wozniacki in a quarterfinal on one of the biggest stages in tennis? I want to say yes, but I feel Wozniacki is going to find a way to win this match.

8 P.M. (TCM) 50 YEARS OF MERCHANT IVORY In 1961 the producer Ismail Merchant and the director James Ivory formed Merchant Ivory Productions with the intention of making English-language films in India for an international market. Soon the company was generating acclaim for elegant adaptations of works by Henry James and E. M. Forster created on modest budgets, often with scripts by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. ''It is a strange marriage we have at Merchant Ivory,'' Mr. Merchant (above left with Mr. Ivory) once said. ''I am an Indian Muslim, Ruth is a German Jew, and Jim is a Protestant American.'' This monthlong tribute, with 21 feature films and 5 shorts shown across 5 Thursdays, picks up with ''The Europeans'' (1979), about a New England household upset by the arrival of two cousins (Lee Remick and Tim Woodward) , followed at 9:45 by ''The Bostonians'' (1984), about a Mississippi lawyer (Christopher Reeve) and a suffragist (Vanessa Redgrave) who compete for the attentions of a faith healer's charismatic daughter (Madeleine Potter), and at midnight by ''Roseland'' (1977), three stories set in the Roseland ballroom in Manhattan in the 1970s and featuring Teresa Wright, Lou Jacobi and Christopher Walken. The program ends with ''Quartet'' (1981), starring Isabelle Adjani as a vulnerable foreigner in post-World War I Paris who moves into the home of a hedonistic English couple (Alan Bates and Maggie Smith) after her husband's arrest leaves her penniless, at 2 a.m.; and ''Savages'' (1972), about tribal people who move into a Long Island estate and transform themselves into social lions, at 4. 6 A.M. (Oxygen) THE DUCHESS (2008) No bodices rip in this historical drama from Saul Dibb, but Ralph Fiennes, as the Duke of Devonshire, does takes scissors to the unmentionables of Georgiana Spencer, the Duchess of Devonshire, played by Keira Knightley, right, in this adaptation of a biography by Amanda Foreman. Charlotte Rampling plays Georgiana's mother, all too eager to pimp out her teenage daughter to the wealthy older man. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this film, with screenplay by Mr. Dibb, Jeffrey Hatcher and Anders Thomas Jensen, ''an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.'' In ''Atonement'' (2007), at 11, Joe Wright and Christopher Hampton's adaptation of the Ian McEwan novel, Saoirse Ronan plays Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses Robbie (James McAvoy) , the son of a family servant -- and the lover of her older sister, Cecelia (Ms. Knightley) -- of a crime. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave are Briony as a young woman and as an older writer.

MORFOGEN--Marilyn M. 82, of Palm Beach, FL died Tuesday, September 6, 2011. She was the daughter of the late Albert and Helen (Glennon) McCormick. Marilyn was born in Boonton, New Jersey July 18, 1929, graduated from Boonton High School, attended the University of South Carolina and received her Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Nebraska in 1950. She married her Boonton High School classmate, Zachary Morfogen in 1956, and they had two children, Ann and Paul, and lived in Den Haag, The Netherlands before moving to Palm Beach, Florida in 1998. When he retired from Time Inc. in 1987, they formed Morfogen Associates, a consulting company for corporations and cultural institutions and launched "NEWS" with she, the Publisher, and he, the Editor of the popular newsletter that celebrates the Arts---The Four Freedoms---Hospice Care--- with exhibitions, books, television and educational programming for these centerpieces of their life together as expressed by Donald Schumacher--- "As President and CEO of the National Hospice Foundation, we honor Marilyn for the inspiration and passion to get the Morfogens involved in hospice many years ago when the hospice movement was getting started in the United States. We were especially honored to have Marilyn participate in the HBO reception where NHF announced the Zachary Morfogen Art of Caring Award on June 23, 2011, in New York. Marilyn has so many friends and admirers in the hospice family to remember her and the legacy she has inspired." That legacy has inspired their seven grandchildren and a broad circle of associates to celebrate her spirit by contributions to the Morfogen Arts and Education Fund for the National Center for Care at the End of Life, 1731 King Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22341 where a sculpture on "Freedom from Fear" by artist/friend Henry Loustau will be permanently installed in memory of Marilyn who embraced hospice care for othersand herselffree from fear. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 9:30am on Friday, September 9, 2011 at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Catholic Church, 910 Birch Street, Boonton, NJ 07005. There will be a viewing on Thursday, September 8, 2011 from 6-8pm at Lewis & Carey Funeral Home, 312 West Main Street, Boonton, NJ 07005. Following the Mass, interment will be at St. Mary's Cemetery. Lewis & Carey Directors of Funerals (973) 334-0842

An article on Tuesday about a Food and Drug Administration review of the safety of bisphosphonate drugs to build bone mass, misattributed remarks of a member of one of two advisory panels considering the issue. It was Dr. Richard S. Bockman, a professor at the Joan and Sanford Weill Medical College of Cornell University, who said a proposed ''drug holiday'' for longer-term users of the drugs was not warranted by current scientific evidence. The point was not made by Dr. Paul D. Blumenthal, a Stanford University professor and another member of the same panel.

The New York Times named a new foreign editor on Wednesday, the latest in a series of high-level appointments by Jill Abramson, who became executive editor this week. The appointment of Joseph Kahn, a Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent who served in various foreign and domestic postings for The Times before he was promoted to deputy foreign editor, was announced in a memo to the staff.

FROST--William L. The Board of Directors of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation mourns the passing of William L. Frost, our Chairman of the Board and long serving past President. Bill's stewardship of the Foundation for more than three decades enabled it to make a positive impact on literally hundreds of worthy Jewish, educational and civic causes throughout the world. We will miss Bill's leadership, counsel and, most importantly, his friendship. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife, Susan; daughters, Hannah, Rebecca and Abigail; son and fellow board member, Robert; and to his many grandchildren, of whom he was so proud.

Adding to its stable of crime programming, the Lifetime cable channel said Tuesday that it had picked up ''America's Most Wanted,'' the crime-fighting show that was dropped by Fox earlier this year. Lifetime said that new episodes of the show, hosted by John Walsh, would start later this year. It did not specify a premiere date. ''It's an honor to partner with him on bringing back this important show,'' said Nancy Dubuc, the president and general manager of Lifetime Networks.

It's 2011 -- television is everywhere, and cable runs on a 24-hour news cycle. But the start of the fall season on broadcast television still captures the imagination of viewers and causes network executives to grip their armrests a little tighter. There are 25 new scripted shows -- sitcoms and dramas -- on ABC, CBS, FOX, NBC and CW. Which show will be the breakout hit of the year? Is ''Terra Nova,'' a family-focused action-adventure series on Fox that is set in both the future and the prehistoric past, this season's ''Lost?'' Will NBC's ''Prime Suspect,'' a remake of a British police procedural, find success on this side of the Atlantic, and is the CW show ''Ringer,'' starring Sarah Michelle Gellar, the second coming of ''Buffy?''

It is a time of rapid-fire earthquakes and hurricanes. Wouldn't you like a panic button in your pocket? A newly free app can make your BlackBerry just that, letting you summon help with the press of a button in an emergency. The app, Personal Guardian from mobile security start-up SmrtGuard, lets users send an all-points S O S by triggering a silent alarm to call to 911, or any other number, as well as sending an e-mail, text message or Twitter post with your location.

The woman climbs the stairs in the shabby East Village tenement and enters while Larry Fagin is finishing a call with another poetry student. ''How's Aiden? Is he old enough to go to college yet?'' Mr. Fagin asks the man on the phone, making small talk. He motions for the woman to take a seat at the dining table, where her most recent poem is up on his computer screen. ''O.K. Send money,'' he barks and hangs up.

A Gish for Trisha: the modern dance choreographer Trisha Brown has won this year's Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, an award worth about $300,000 that was named after the silent film actresses. The trust that administers the award, given to artists for ''groundbreaking impact in their chosen fields,'' said Ms. Brown had ''transformed'' modern dance ''with new vocabularies of movement.'' The prize, now in its 18th year, will be given at an event in New York on Nov. 2. Past winners have included Chinua Achebe, Robert Redford, Pete Seeger, Laurie Anderson, Peter Sellers, Ornette Coleman, Bill T. Jones, Bob Dylan and Frank Gehry.

Years before he was a teen pop heartthrob, Nick Jonas made his Broadway debut as the youngsters Little Jake in ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' Chip in ''Beauty and the Beast,'' and Gavroche in ''Les Miserables'' - three roles he credited for developing his voice for his band, the Jonas Brothers. The acting bug stayed with him, though, and he took the supporting role of the love-smitten revolutionary Marius in the London production of ''Les Miserables'' last year. Now Mr. Jonas, who turns 19 next week, is stepping up to a leading role for his return to Broadway: beginning Jan. 24 he will play the rascally executive J. Pierrepont Finch in the Broadway revival of ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' succeeding the television actor Darren Criss (''Glee'') in the role. (Mr. Criss is performing as Finch for just three weeks in January after the musical's current star, Daniel Radcliffe, departs the production.) Mr. Jonas and the revival's director, Rob Ashford, announced the news at an event at Sardi's on Wednesday afternoon. A spokesman for the production said that Mr. Jonas's contract runs through July 1.

1:04 p.m. | Updated Lil Wayne is back on top. The rapper's latest album, ''Tha Carter IV'' (Cash Money/Universal Republic), had huge sales in its first week out, exceeding most industry estimates. Released at midnight on Aug. 29 -- shortly after Lil Wayne gave the closing performance on MTV's Video Music Awards -- the album sold 964,000 copies through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and it broke iTunes's record for the most album downloads in a week.

If that Web page you are looking at in Internet Explorer 9 does not look quite right with menus and other elements out of place, it may be because the site was created before this latest version of Microsoft's browser was released. Luckily, IE9 includes a Compatibility View feature that can help the page appear as it was intended for an earlier version of Internet Explorer. To use it, click the Compatibility View icon in the browser's address bar; the icon looks like page broken in two. Microsoft has a picture of the icon, as well as more information about Compatibility View, here.

An article on Friday about the founding of a technology-focused venture capital fund by Michael Arrington, editor of the technology blog TechCrunch, referred incompletely to the policy of another tech blog, GigaOm. While the blog does not prohibit its writers from investing in companies covered on the blog, it does prohibit them from covering any companies in which they are personally invested and any companies in which Om Malik, the site's founder, who is also a partner at the venture capital fund True, is invested.

Skype, best known for providing phone calls over the Internet via PCs and the smartphones, now wants your landline too. The company has released two new products: A minirouter along the lines of a MagicJack or netTalk Duo, that lets you plug a landline into your router to make calls even when your computer is off. The second is a cordless G.E. phone that makes calls over your regular line or Skype.
8:08 p.m. | Updated Guy Hands is back.

P.J. Harvey became the first singer on Tuesday to win the prestigious Mercury Prize twice, when she accepted the award for her album ''Let England Shake.'' Adele, the young soul-singer who had dominated the charts for much of the summer with her hit record ''21,'' was left in the also-ran category. It was the second time that Ms. Harvey, the 41-year-old singer-songwriter from Yeovil, England, had taken home the prize, which is given every year to the best album from an English or Irish act. She first won in 2001, when the ceremony was held on Sept. 11. She was on tour in the United States at the time and got caught up in the chaotic day of the terror attack. ''I was in Washington, D.C., watching the Pentagon burning from my bedroom window,'' she recalled as she took the microphone to thank her managers and her record label, Island Records, for helping her deserve this year's prize.

WHERE ARE THE WOMEN? Women -- always a rare breed in the upper echelons of Wall Street -- are looking like an endangered species in the executive suite of big banks. With the departure of Sallie Krawcheck, left, from Bank of America, only a handful of women still report directly to the bank's chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan. It is a long-running theme across Wall Street, with the plum spots in investment banking and brokerage firms typically held by men. All told, women account for just 2.7 percent of the chief executives in the financial industry and 16.8 percent of the executive officers, according to a study by Catalyst.

When Brady Hoke was hired as Michigan's coach, his first three congratulatory phone calls were from Tom Brady, Charles Woodson and Steve Hutchinson. Hoke has returned some swagger and bravado to the Wolverines after Rich Rodriguez's inglorious three-year stay in Ann Arbor. Hoke has talked big in promising that in Year 132 of Michigan football that everyone will be accountable, right down to the managers and grounds crew. "There's consequences for losing," he said, flatly. So who is Brady Hoke? He sat down for an extended interview during training camp about everything from his desire to work in the Secret Service, to marrying his junior high sweetheart and whether he would make Denard Robinson tie his shoes.

This weekend's issue of T: The New York Times Style Magazine includes something for soccer fans, as Tim Adams looks at Alex Ferguson, the man who built the team by which most of the rest are measured, and the photographer Max Vadukul makes him and some of his current and former players look like the sexiest team on earth. Desmond Howard, who was inducted to the College Football Hall of Fame in July, is one of four Heisman Trophy winners who were also named most valuable player in a Super Bowl. Howard, 41, played for five teams in 11 N.F.L. seasons, winning the Super Bowl with the 1996 Green Bay Packers. He holds the N.F.L. record for most punt return yards in a season (875) and the longest kickoff return in Super Bowl history (99 yards). Now a college football analyst for ESPN, Howard has chronicled his Michigan career in the book "I Wore 21: The Legend of Desmond Howard," which will be released Saturday.

While the final outcome of the National Football League season opener on Thursday between the Green Bay Packers and the New Orleans Saints was in doubt until the end, what was never in doubt was the ratings dominance the N.F.L. would give NBC. (The Packers ultimately won the game, 42-34.) According to Nielsen estimates, an average of 27.2 million total viewers tuned in for the game. It was the second-most-watched N.F.L. opener of all time, trailing only last season's Brett Favre-enhanced contest between the Minnesota Vikings and The Saints.  CBS, which was led by "Big Brother" at 9 p.m. with 6.5 million viewers, came in far behind NBC for second place among the broadcast networks.

For the Bulgarian-born shoe designer Gio Metodiev of Gio Diev, seven-inch heels aren't always a prerequisite for seductive footwear. "It's really not about height anymore," he says. "You can make a statement without having to be sky high." The 30-piece offering, which Metodiev will introduce at Premiere Classe in Paris later this month, includes color-blocked heels with ankle cuffs inspired by armor and flats strapped with leather "wire." Diev's meticulous construction - he shares a factory in northern Italy with Manolo Blahnik; he has his mother wear and test every new style - and intuitive sense of what strong women want have already made him a favorite of actresses like Emmy Rossum and Rose Byrne. His dream feet, though? Gwyneth Paltrow's. "She's so beautiful and she does it all," Metodiev says, going on to explain that at the end of the day it's all about taking chances. "Who wants to wear the same old safe thing?" Not we, says T.

The founder and owner of Lit Lounge, a singular source of some of the most embarrassing "I blacked out" moments in New York, the almost legendary Erik Foss also devotes a fair amount of his time and energy to supporting and creating art. His gallery, Fuse, has given an invaluable vote of confidence to countless young New York artists (including me a year ago), by showing their work before anyone else would so much as bat an eyelash at them. Over the last few years, Foss's own cheeky (and often pornographic) paintings have appeared in numerous group shows internationally, and he's had two solo gigs at White Walls Gallery in San Francisco. I caught up with Foss on the eve of his first solo show in New York, the town he has called home for almost two decades. Catch the artist's reception for "Avarice" at Malick Williams and Co. (150 11th Avenue), on Sept. 11 from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.

Almost 10 years ago, on New Year's Day 2002, Sir Alex Ferguson believed he had finally retired from the greatest job in English soccer: manager of the most legendary sporting club of all, Manchester United. Ferguson, who had already achieved everything he could in the game he lived for, had celebrated his 60th birthday the day before. Now he was at home, taking a nap after a long lunch, when his wife, Cathy, kicked his foot to wake him up. When he opened his eyes, Cathy was standing in front of him backed by his three adult sons. "We've decided you're not retiring," she said. And that was that.

Back in 1993, long before the fashion photographer Craig McDean started shooting waifish models for the likes of Vogue and Another Magazine, he spent a year in Japan, where he documented sumo wrestlers with an almost ritualistic devotion. The more time he spent with them, the closer he was able to get until, he recalls, "Eventually, they scarcely noticed I was there." McDean wasn't shooting with any particular end in mind, except perhaps to fill the hours of the day and to feed his childhood obsession with martial arts. A few of the photos were published in The Face. The rest sat in a drawer. "At the time I dismissed a lot of photos because I was trying to get everything sharp," says McDean, who reedited them with a fresh eye. In "Sumo," an intimate hand-bound volume from Mörel books, and in an accompanying show at the Half Gallery, McDean captures a sport akin to mountain moving in moments of unexpected fluidity and grace with Baconesque piles of flesh coming together as if in a dance. The book is punctuated with moments of stillness, like a portrait of a young wrestler whose hair is being pulled up into a knot. "Their hair is done, they are dressed, they are taken care of," McDean says, realizing that perhaps the world of sumo wasn't so far from the world of fashion as he might originally have thought. "He's like a model sitting in a chair."

I've developed a habit - it's probably a bad habit - of assigning letter grades to the Republican candidates based on my initial reaction to their performance in debates. After Wednesday night's debate in Simi Valley, I gave Rick Perry a B-minus, meaning an average performance. Meanwhile, I gave Mitt Romney, his primary rival for the Republican nomination, a higher grade of A-minus. The grades are based on neither style nor substance per se, but instead mostly on strategy: how much each candidate did to improve his chances of winning the nomination. Newt Gingrich, for example, got in some good one-liners and seemed more poised than he had in past debates. But in deliberately avoiding contrasts between himself and the other candidates, he did little to give Republican voters a reason to pick him - something he needs to do, since he's standing at about 4 percent in the polls.

FROST--William Lee. William Lee Frost (84 years old), Chairman of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation, passed away on September 7th, 2011. Born in Larchmont, New York to Charles and Eva Frost, he graduated Bayside High School and served in the Navy during World War II before attending Harvard College (1947), Yale Law School (1951), and the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration (1958). He entered the State Department in 1952 and served as a Foreign Service Officer in Belgrade, Salzburg, and Bad Godesberg. Returning to New York City in 1959 due to the illness of his first wife, Judith, daughter of Charlotte and Lawrence E. Spivak, he re-entered legal practice specializing in management and investments until later becoming President of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation. Always interested in health, he served as a member of the Public Health Council of New York State's Department of Health under Governor Carey, and as Chairman (1985-87), Treasurer, and Director of the New York Heart Association. He was also a Trustee of the Brearley School, the Collegiate School, Marlboro College, and Radcliffe College. As a student at Harvard, he was the founding President of Hillel and later, as a graduate, became a member of the Visiting Committee, Honorary Curator, and President of Judaica at Harvard University Library. He also served as a member of the Visiting Committee to the Harvard Divinity School. He was Chair of the New York State Archives Partnership Trust (1994-97) and on the Board of the Croton Aqueduct. He was also the President and a Director of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, and a Trustee of the P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, Inc. His hobbies including rambling, whether around Manhattan, the Rockies, or Scotland, and often singing as he strolled along to whomever crossed his path. Predeceased by his first wife, Judith, he is survived by their daughters Rebecca (Mohammed) and Hannah, as well as by his wife Susan and their children Abigail (John) and Robert (Navah) and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Aviva, Cipa, Zamira and Ivry. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street on Friday, September 9th, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to one of the institutions mentioned above.

The southernmost entrance to Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, seemed like the gate to a soccer stadium on the day of a championship match: frenzied, loud and absolutely jammed. This is not your entrance.''

A federal judge has greatly expanded the scope of an antitrust lawsuit against the world's largest private equity firms, broadening the case to include some of the largest leveraged buyouts in history. The four-year-old suit accuses 11 firms, including Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, of a huge, overarching conspiracy to rig the market for multibillion-dollar takeovers.

9 P.M. (Sundance) UNLEASHED BY GARO Garo Sparo (above, with Claudia McLain and her daughter Alicia), who calls himself a ''countercouture designer,'' has created garments for Madonna, Lady Miss Kier and Daphne Guinness. ''Fashion gives you a choice,'' he says. ''You can hide behind it or use it to express yourself. I can use fashion and design to transform anyone that walks through the door. It's all about finding that thing in a person that ignites change.'' In this new makeover series, part of ''Full Frontal Fashion,'' the channel's annual programming tribute to New York Fashion Week, Mr. Sparo offers some sartorially lost souls ''design therapy'' in his East Village studio, where he helps his clients battle their inhibitions. His first subjects include Jennifer, a new mother who finds her postbaby curves too matronly; the six-foot-tall Nefe, who is sometimes mistaken for a man; and Tali, a showgirl and Mr. Sparo's secret crush, who needs a 10-piece ensemble for her Las Vegas act. 2 P.M. (E!) KNOCKED UP (2007) A one-night stand has an unforeseen consequence in this commentary from Judd Apatow on sex, love, gender differences and the meaning of family. Katherine Heigl plays Alison, who celebrates a promotion with a little nightclubbing; Seth Rogen is Ben, the stoner she takes to the dance floor, and then to bed, before her beer goggles wear off. Voilà! Cue baby bump. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film ''an instant classic, a comedy that captures the sexual confusion and moral ambivalence of our moment without straining, pandering or preaching.'' Also shown at 4:30.

SLATER--John Edmund, 89, passed away, September 4, 2011. He was the only child of Margaret and John Edmund Slater Sr of Yonkers NY. He retired from McGraw Hill in 1995 as Senior Vice President of the Energy Information Services Group, and Publisher of "Power" and "Electrical World." During the 1970's, he pioneered business talks with China establishing an early foothold for the company in that expanding market. In WWII John was a forward observer with the 34th Field Artillery Battalion (9th Infantry Division) where he courageously defended the Elsenborn Ridge during the Battle of the Bulge. He was president of the U.S. Court Tennis Association from 1971 to 1988. In 2008 they honored his lifelong contribution by inducting John into their Hall of Fame. John is survived by his wife Kate, of Fayetteville, NC. He is also survived by his three children, Nathanael Slater, Sarah Slater, Gifford Slater; five step children, Wendell Holmes, Walker Holmes Haigh, John Holmes, Charles Holmes and Kate Holmes; 17 grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Memorials may be made to John E Slater Ezra Cornell Scholarship Fund in Ithaca, NY.

At the Harlem Tennis Center, the Hall of Fame tennis player Steffi Graf was trading shots Thursday morning with a scrawny boy using a scaled-down racket. They were playing on the backcourt of a regulation-size court, with a net stretched from the service line to the baseline, and using oversize foam balls. The tennis clinic, sponsored by the watchmaker Longines, was part of the QuickStart program, a United States Tennis Association initiative to introduce the game to children 10 and younger. Graf, 42, and her husband, Andre Agassi, also a Hall of Famer, are spokespersons for QuickStart, which is based on the premise that the effort required to hit a ball over the net shouldn't outweigh the fun of it.

From the rubble-filled streets of Rome to the sunny, aqua-blue skies of Mozambique, Bob Dylan has traveled the world in his music and his real-life exploits. Now a series of his drawings and paintings that chronicle his journeys in Asia will be coming to the Gagosian Gallery, the first time that Mr. Dylan's art will be exhibited in New York City, the gallery said. The exhibition, ''The Asia Series,'' will run at the Gagosian on the Upper East Side from Sept. 20 through Oct. 22, and will include works that Mr. Dylan created on trips to Japan, China, Vietnam and South Korea. (Dylanologists will recall that the singer-songwriter played his first shows in China and in Vietnam last spring.) The gallery said in a news release that Mr. Dylan's works would offer ''firsthand depictions of people, street scenes, architecture and landscape'' with evocative titles like ''Mae Ling,'' ''Cockfight,'' ''The Bridge'' and ''Hunan Province.'' The release added: ''Conversely, there are more cryptic paintings often of personalities and situations, such as 'Big Brother' and 'Opium,' or 'LeBelle Cascade,' which looks like a riff on Manet's 'Le De jeuner sur l'Herbe' but which is, in fact, a scenographic tourist photo-opportunity in a Tokyo amusement arcade.'' Mr. Dylan's paintings have previously been shown in Chemnitz, Germany (where the exhibition ''The Drawn Blank Series'' opened in 2007), the Statens Museum in Copenhagen (where his ''Brazil Series'' was shown in 2008) and any rec room where the cover of his ''Self Portrait'' album has been prominently displayed.

Regulators are nearing a settlement with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over whether the mortgage finance giants adequately disclosed their exposure to risky subprime loans, bringing to a close a three-year investigation. The proposed agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the terms being discussed, would include no monetary penalty or admission of fraud, according to several people briefed on the case. But a settlement would represent the most significant acknowledgement yet by the mortgage companies that they played a central role in the housing boom and bust.

MULLIGAN--Tim, Died peacefully at home, age 73, surrounded by the art he loved and the lifetime partner he adored, on September 7, 2011, after a brave and uncomplaining battle with cancer. Brilliantly educated at Philips Andover, Yale, and The University of Paris, he spent the first 22 years of his career from 1963 as an editor at the magazines "This Week," "Good Housekeeping," and "Family Weekly." In 1985 he began 10 years of memorable service as head of public affairs for the New York State Council on the Arts, supporting Kitty Carlisle Hart's vision and reflecting her ebullience in venues throughout the state. Since 1995 he has been the respected director of external affairs for the Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture, working to expand international coverage and initiating the Center's global travel program and its annual Iris Awards for outstanding contributions to decorative arts under founder Susan Weber. As a public affairs consultant, he advised The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Mariners' Museum, and a host of corporate clients, while his amusing and insightful freelance pieces appeared in such national magazines as "Omni," "Conde Nast Traveler," and "Travel & Leisure." One of the most original, cultured, and highly praised travel writers of the 1980s and 90s, his books included "The Traveler's Guide to the Hudson River Valley," in its fifth edition and still considered the best in its field, along with: "The Traveler's Guide to Western New England and the Connecticut River Valley," and "Virginia: A History and Guide." He also co-edited the 2006 collection, "The Battle of Hampton Roads: New Perspectives on the USS Monitor and CSS Virginia." But even these accomplishments hardly begin to convey his infectious wit, his incomparable elegance, his peerless taste, and his innate modesty. He was a scholar, a gentleman, an arts champion, and a loving and endlessly delightful friend. He is survived by his partner of 46 years, and spouse of three heroic weeks, John O'Keefe.

Aaron Sorkin is a man who likes getting deep inside high-pressure work environments - see his resume, which includes the television series ''Sports Night'' and ''The West Wing,'' and his Academy Award-winning screenplay for ''The Social Network.'' And his latest project should offer plenty of opportunities for the verbal fireworks and walk-and-talk tracking shots he favors. HBO said on Thursday that it had picked up a new series from Mr. Sorkin set in the competitive world of cable-television news. In a news release the show (which does not yet have a title or a premiere date) is described as chronicling a television anchor and his staff as ''they set out on a patriotic and quixotic mission to do the news well in the face of corporate and commercial obstacles and their own personal entanglements.'' Jeff Daniels (whose films include ''The Squid and the Whale'' and ''Good Night, and Good Luck'') will play the fictional news anchor Will McAllister; Emily Mortimer (''Our Idiot Brother'') will play his executive producer, MacKenzie; and Sam Waterston (''Law & Order'') will play their boss, Charlie.

An article on Thursday about the spirited exchanges between Mitt Romney and Gov. ALLEN--Richard Arthur, 87, of Taylor Drive, Laconia and Sandwich, NH, died suddenly September 2, 2011 at his summer home on Squam Lake. Born in Manchester, NH on April 12, 1924, he was the son of Chris and Margaret (Walker) Allen. He grew up in Manchester and graduated from Kimball Union Academy, Meriden, NH. Richard also graduated from Dartmouth College, class of 1946, and from Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth, class of 1950, with a Master's in Business Administration. He resided in Darien, CT for thirty-five years and summered on Squam Lake. He and his wife Marcia moved to Sandwich permanently in 1991. They have has resided in Laconia for the past few years. Richard worked most all his life in the financial industry as an investment advisor, beginning with JP Morgan and for over thirty years for Swiss Reinsurance Company. He was also a co-founder of the Bank of Darien. He was a long-standing parishioner at St. Luke Church, Darien, where he served on the vestry. After moving to Sandwich, Dick was on the Board as the Treasurer of The Sandwich Children's Center. He was also a permanent Trustee of Chocorua (Church) Island, on Squam Lake. Richard was a US Army officer and a veteran of both World War II and the Korean Conflict. Dick is survived by his wife of sixty years, Marcia (Boulton) Allen of Laconia, daughters, Rebecca Allen Barlow and husband Steven of New Canaan, CT; Margaret W. Nelson and husband Eric of North Wales, PA; Louise A. Coughlan and husband David of Winchester, MA. He is also survived by granddaughters, Calista, Sarah, Emily, Betsy and Tory and by his sisters, Elizabeth Swim of Burlington, VT and Kathryn Pfaff of Stamford, CT and their children. A Memorial service was held at Church Island on Squam Lake, Wednesday, September 7th at 11am. In the event of rain, the service will be held in the Playhouse at Rockywold-Deephaven, NH on Route 113, Holderness. A boat to the island will be leaving Rockywold-Deephaven at 10:15am. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either The Sandwich Children's Center, 54 Maple St., Sandwich, NH 03227 or the Chocorua Island Chapel Association, PO Box 356, Holderness, NH 03245. The Mayhew Funeral Homes, in Meredith is assisting the family with the services.

Trying to capitalize on Booker Prize buzz, Knopf has moved up the publication date of ''The Sense of an Ending,'' a novel by Julian Barnes that was among the six books chosen for the shortlist of the 2011 Man Booker Prize for Fiction this week. Mr. Barnes has been widely cited as a favorite for the prize, which is the most celebrated literary award in Britain. ''The Sense of an Ending,'' a slim volume of 176 pages, will be released by Knopf, part of Random House, on Oct. 11, three months ahead of its scheduled United States publication date.

The rain cleared, and the sidewalks of New York filled with all the familiar sights and sounds: the Cinderella backpacks, the complaints about school uniforms, the comparing of schedules, the shrieks and giggles. As 1.1 million students and 77,000 teachers returned to school Thursday, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott made the traditional five-borough tour, saying his ''goal is to set a high bar for our parents, our teachers, to aspire to.'' At Public School 295 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, third graders peppered Mr. Walcott with questions about his reading habits. The chancellor said that he liked to read about ''people and history,'' and that his wife had given him a book about Frederick Douglass for his 60th birthday on Wednesday. The students, for their part, said they liked reading ''Diary of a Wimpy Kid,'' and books about animals and mysteries. One girl said she liked reading books about New York.

Just as he did on the first day of school last year -- and on the second day and on the last day, for that matter -- Gregg Breinberg started his morning Thursday with a trip to Dunkin' Donuts on Forest Avenue, in Graniteville on Staten Island. As usual, Mr. Breinberg ordered a large decaffeinated French vanilla coffee, then got back behind the wheel of his Honda Accord for the short drive toward Public School 22, for what would be his 13th ''first day'' there. Mr. Breinberg, 38, is no ordinary teacher -- for one thing, he had a documentary film crew recording his every interaction. There were the giddy students remarking about his freshly buzzed head -- no more ponytail and corn rows this year! -- and the questions from parents eager for their children to land in his classroom, all of which could be summed up as the ''Oscar effect.''

DJANDJI--Nicolas. Dia Art Foundation mourns the untimely loss of Nicolas Djandji, beloved colleague and friend, and extends its heartfelt condolences to the Djandji family. Nick's presence was a positive force at Dia where he applied keen intelligence and good spirit to his work with artists. He will be profoundly missed.

The Broadway and personal memorabilia of John Raitt, the dynamic baritone and Broadway leading man who played Billy Bigelow in the original 1945 production of ''Carousel'' and Sid Sorkin in ''The Pajama Game'' a decade later, has gone to the music division of the Library of Congress. The extensive collection is a peek into six decades of Mr. Raitt's life and includes scrapbooks, publicity photos, recordings, annotated scripts, musical scores, tapes he made of himself, and correspondence, said Denise Gallo, the head of acquisitions and processing at the library's music division. ''We haven't inventoried it yet but it's of such import to us that we'll get to it quickly,'' Dr. Gallo said on Thursday, when the acquisition was announced. ''He's one of the iconic singers of the 1940s. For many years he was the leading man on Broadway.'' Mr. Raitt, who died at age 88 in 2005, was the father of the singer Bonnie Raitt. He retained his voice into his 80s and collaborated with his daughter on the road and in television specials.

An article on Tuesday about Webb Simpson's victory in the Deutsche Bank Championship misidentified the city in North Carolina where he won the Wyndham Championship three weeks earlier. It was in Greensboro, not Charlotte.

MILLIKEN--Gloria W.,Housing Advocate, Philanthropist, a New Yorker for 50 years, worked tirelessly to prevent homelessness and injustice. With her late husband, Seth M. Milliken, she co-founded, Housing Conservation Coordinators in 1969 to serve the Clinton neighborhood. Gloria established Eviction Intervention Services in 1984 to serve Manhattan's Eastside. In 1986, she founded the New York Women's Foundation to support programs for women and girls. Born in 1922, in Trinidad, W.I., Gloria W. Milliken died of natural causes in Seattle on September 4. She is survived by her sons, Arthur Knapp, in Redmond, WA., and Ashly Knapp in Seattle, WA., their wives, four grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to New York Women's Foundation, Eviction Intervention Services, or Housing Conservation Coordinators. Memorial services are not yet scheduled and will be held in Seattle and New York City.

SACKS--Dr. Herbert S, a clinical professor of child and adolescent psychiatry at Yale School of Medicine, a past president of the American Psychiatric Association, and an international medical consultant died on August 30, 2011 in New Haven, Connecticut. He was 84 years old. Dr. Sacks was a longtime leader of professional psychiatric organizations, first in Connecticut, and then nationally. In this capacity, his broad concern was how modern psychiatry is represented in society. His contributions to the understanding of such issues as patient advocacy and confidentiality have informed social policy. As president of the Connecticut Psychiatric Association, Dr. Sacks led a successful campaign to mandate group insurance coverage for outpatient psychiatric treatment, the first such state legislation in the country. In 1997, as the president of the American Psychiatric Association (APA), he spearheaded a national initiative for mental health parity in insurance coverage as part of a policy of universal access to mental health care, testifying before a Presidential advisory commission, collaborating with national legislators, and making the case against the "industrialization of American medicine", as capitated managed care threatened the survival of individualized psychotherapy by psychiatrists. As a member on the National Commission on the Confidentiality of Health Records, Dr. Sacks was a forceful proponent for the maintenance of confidentiality of medical records, both to protect the integrity of the physician-patient relationship, and to safeguard against discrimination based on public disclosures of treatment. He strongly supported the "Goldwater Rule" promulgated in the APA's Principles of Medical Ethics, barring psychiatrists from offering professional opinions regarding anyone they have not personally examined. This guidance developed after Barry Goldwater was subjected to public statements questioning his mental fitness for office by physicians who had not examined him, prior to the 1964 Presidential election. During the 1960's, Dr. Sacks consulted to the U.S. Peace Corps, preparing young volunteers for their service overseas and acclimation upon their return. An advocate for culturally sensitive health care development, he continued his work as an international health consultant, focusing on the psychological impact of population dislocations caused by natural disasters and water development projects. He undertook these efforts in association with numerous medical schools, development assistance organizations and the U. S. Agency for International Development. Dr. Sacks was an early advocate for the integration of traditional healing into structured public health programs, in conjunction with village leaders and traditional healers. Dr. Sacks remained active as a founding member of Yale School of Medicine's Committee on International Health for more than 40 years. He was enthusiastic about his service on the Downs Fellowship Committee, which awards international student travel grants to Yale medical, nursing and physician assistant students pursuing scientific research and cultural exchange in developing countries. He was also a consultant to the Yale Five Year B.A. Program, which encouraged undergraduates to take a year away from college to work in developing countries, when such interruptions of college careers were uncommon. Dr. Sacks had recently been elected to a term on the Board of the Association of Yale Alumni in Medicine. Amongst his publications, Dr. Sacks was most enthusiastic about his book, Hurdles: The Admissions Dilemma in American Higher Education, (Atheneum 1978), which continues to be relevant today. Dr. Sacks was born in New York City in 1926, the son of Rabbi Maxwell and Mrs. Anna Sacks. He grew up in Brooklyn and enlisted as an ensign in the U.S. Navy at 17, serving in the South Pacific. He was a graduate of Dickinson College, where he later became a member of the Board of Alumni Advisors, and a graduate of Cornell School of Medicine. Dr. Sacks trained in pediatrics and child psychiatry at Yale School of Medicine, and joined the faculty of the Yale Child Study Center more than 50 years ago. Up until the time of his death, he maintained a private practice in Westport, Connecticut. In 1948, Dr. Sacks married Helen Margery Levin. They enjoyed a 63 year marriage. Mrs. Sacks, who retired as an assistant clinical professor of social work at the Yale Child Study Center, was always her husband's chief advisor and critic. She co-founded and directed a psychiatric clinic for the assessment of serious offenders in New Haven Juvenile Court, and shared many research interests with her husband. Dr. Sacks enjoyed private family time on his farm in Southern Vermont, the company of good friends, the glorious music of the Marlboro Music Festival, eclectic Vermont hardware stores, and late nights reading scores of police procedural novels set in his favorite foreign locales. He is survived by his wife; four children, Eric and Douglas of New York City, Russell of Albuquerque, NM, and Kate of New Haven; and seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to Marlboro Music (http://www.marlboromusic.org) or to the Yale School of Public Health, Downs Fellowship (http://publichealth.yale.edu/giving/gift). A memorial service will be scheduled in the coming months

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with the TV Watch column, about ''The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,'' reversed the identities of two of the housewives. Kyle Richards was at the right; Kim Richards was the second from the right. Lisa Vanderpump and Camille Grammer were also pictured.)

Consider Friday a sort of appetizer for what should be a spectacular Saturday, which will feature both the men's and women's semifinals. But that does not make Friday's offerings any less appealing. ANDY RODDICK VS. RAFAEL NADAL Not only did Roddick beat fifth-seeded David Ferrer on Thursday, but he also did so looking like a serious threat to be one of the two men in the rain-delayed final Monday.

An article on Wednesday about a poll that found broad dissatisfaction among New Yorkers over the quality of the city's public schools credited the poll incorrectly in some editions. It was conducted by The New York Times; it was not a New York Times/CBS News poll. And the article misstated the middle initial of a political consultant who said education may not turn out to be as strong a legacy as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had hoped to leave. The consultant is Bruce N. Gyory, not Bruce M.

Conference realignment, which once appeared to be an inevitability, has reached a holding pattern. The threat of legal action by Baylor and other Big 12 universities has stymied Texas A&M's move to the Southeastern Conference, reviving the chance that the Big 12 can save itself. The SEC has adopted a wait-and-see attitude on Texas A&M, as the league has staunchly maintained that it wants to avoid any legal fights during expansion. The Big 12 presidents are expected to meet again in the next 10 days. ''The general feeling right now is we want to do everything that we can to keep the Big 12 together in as close a form as we can to the current configuration,'' a high-ranking official at a Big 12 university said. ''We need stability and a longer-term commitment from the big guys so we can become 12 again down the road.''

An article on Wednesday about management changes at Bank of America referred incompletely in some editions to a job change involving Charles Noski, a former chief financial officer. Mr. Noski gave up that position in April because of the serious illness of a close family member; he did not leave the bank, and remains a vice chairman.

Workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have rescinded a strike threat, meaning a concert performance of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' there on Friday by the Vienna Staatsoper will go on, a spokesman for the company said on Thursday. ''Everything is O.K.,'' the spokesman, Carlo Maria Cella, said. The performance is part of a rare simultaneous exchange in which La Scala forces will perform Verdi's Requiem in Vienna on the same day.

SOMERS--Lewis III and Elizabeth. The Board of Directors and staff of the Monell Chemical Senses Center mourn the deaths of Lewis Somers, III and Elizabeth Somers. They will be greatly missed. Mr. Somers was a valued and insightful member of Monell's International Advisory Council for more than 30 years; together, they were enthusiastic supporters and advocates for Monell's mission of basic and clinical research benefiting health and well-being. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Somers family. Monell Chemical Senses Center

Sony's arthouse unit and its two co-presidents, Michael Barker and Tom Bernard, have been celebrating the company's 20th anniversary with a series of parties that just keeps getting longer.

Shrugging off the effect of a bandaged right foot layered with adhesive, Serena Williams of the United States bounded into the U.S. Open women's final with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, the world's top ranked and top seeded player.

Mesh was a strong look at Alexander Wang's show this afternoon, held in his usual space on a pier on the West Side Highway, seen in the loose-fitting parkas, bombers and anoraks that opened the collection in an inky color he called "petrol." They were shown over bright blue and orange polo shirts in technical fabrics that constituted Mr. Wang's nod to the color trend of the season. It's nice to see several designers continuing to show sporty jackets for spring, reprising a dominant look from the fall collections. Fashion has been moving so fast these days, I was half afraid they would have already moved on to something else.
Americans took part in ceremonies and other events commemorating the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

ANAHEIM - With his sprained left thumb not completely healed, Alex Rodriguez was kept out of the lineup for Saturday night's game against the Los Angeles Angels. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Rodriguez would be shelved for the next three to four days.
The New York Times asked readers to share stories, emotions and memories — tens of thousands responded on a map of the world. Browse and filter by most frequently used words and locations.

"The timing just feels right," said Helmut Lang's creative directors, Michael and Nicole Colovos, days before the label's first runway show in more than five years at the cavernous Pier 57 warehouse on Manhattan's Far West Side. With the help of the stylist Alastair McKimm and the producer and set designer Alexandre de Betak, the duo achieved exactly the effect they were going for: a dramatic show referencing 90s minimalism (a nod to the original Helmut Lang look) set against a backdrop so raw it magnified the collection's softness, something that the Colovoses have bestowed upon the label since taking over in 2007. "We've always explored contrasts in texture and fabric," Ms. Colovos said. And there were billowy silk trousers, asymmetrical handkerchief dresses and washed leather jackets paired back to single-shoulder-strap sports bras and made-for-stomping platforms designed by Alejandro Ingelmo to prove that. For McKimm, who created the look, the biggest challenge was editing the collection, and he did so by forgoing a pink story and a print, using only a selection of canary-yellow pieces to pop amongst all the black and white. As for the venue, de Betak was dead set on using an open space that had not been touched too much; the less pomp and circumstance, the better. The final stage, a square platform perched high above the ground, lent gravitas to the exceptionally strong clothes it carried.

As the agent for Matt Kemp, Dave Stewart has an obvious bias in the National League Most Valuable Player Award discussion. But Stewart, the former star pitcher, looks at the recent trend in awards voting and feels good about the chances of his client, who is profiled in the Sunday New York Times.

The commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks began in earnest on Saturday, with major ceremonies not only in Shanksville, Pa., but also New Jersey, Lower Manhattan and Midtown Manhattan. Most, if not all, were somber events.

T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.Tiffany Tuttle of LD Tuttle has been making innovative anti-trend shoes for the VPL show for more than a few seasons now. Here, a typical LD Tuttle silhouette - triangle heel, ankle-height cuff - done in neoprene to match that which Victoria Bartlett used in the collection on everything from swimsuits to jackets.

No. 9 seed Samantha Stosur toughed out a 6-3, 2-6, 6-2 over 92nd-ranked German Angelique Kerber, becoming the first Australian woman to reach the U.S. Open final since Wendy Turnbull in 1977. It will be Stosur's first career U.S. Open final and second career Grand Slam final.
