Rafael Nadal of Spain applied relentless pressure on Andy Murray of Britain to win a place in the U.S. Open men's final for the second successive year with a 6-4, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2 victory on Saturday night.

The obstacles male players face when transitioning from A.T.P. Tour events to the Grand Slams are well-documented. Best-of-three matches are traded in for best-of-five, increasing the physical and mental difficulty of winning significantly.

TORONTO - Parenting has rarely looked as painful and difficult onscreen as it does in Lynne Ramsay's drama "We Need to Talk About Kevin," which screened last night at the Toronto International Film Festival. The film focuses on the experience one woman (Tilda Swinton) has raising a son (Ezra Miller) who turns out to be a very, very bad seed.

Unlike some creatives who choke under pressure, the menswear designer Antonio Azzuolo, a finalist for this year's CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, gracefully eased the reins and took a more relaxed approach to his Spring/Summer collection. Mr. Azzuolo explained backstage, "My first collection was very formal, all about suits. This season I designed more liberally, drawing inspiration from Les Minets, a French/British hybrid movement of mod culture. These young men shunned bourgeois culture, but still dressed up. They were rough and rebellious, but chic and sophisticated as well." Noting the designer's departure from his norm of neat, the hairstylist Andre Rodman casually styled models' hair with his hands and a healthy dollop of Shu Uemura Shape Paste, to enhance each guy's individual hair texture. Mr. Rodman completed looks with a brisk shake of the dryer, along with "lots of Oribe Dry Texturizing Spray, for a subtly messy, matte look." The makeup artist Gregory Arlt paired hair and clothes with M.A.C. products that conveyed, "Healthy tired. It might sound strange, but we imagined the guys looking warm and attractive, despite their penchant for partying." Using just moisturizer (as opposed to foundation) for a base, Arlt slathered onto the models' faces a yet to be released product from M.A.C.- Mineralize Charged Water Moisture Gel (hitting shelves this December). Brows were then defined and filled in with Kid eyeshadow, while lips were smoothed with lip conditioner. Lastly, he dotted on Select Moisturecover Concealer as necessary, so models looked "handsome, even after that long night out."

My favorite vacation involves backpacking in the mountains with my family - unplugged, out of contact and engaging with the most beautiful scenery in America. And that's what inspired my Sunday column: If America's "best idea" is its public lands, then it's an idea under assault. But while environmentalists focus on Republican efforts to reduce protections of those lands, it seems to me that an equal challenge is the way the public is withdrawing from nature. Conservation should be about preserving nature, yes, but also about giving people a chance to experience it.

Because its equitable playing surface and place in the calendar present most top players with ample opportunity to succeed, the U.S. Open historically has had fewer unknowns scuttling through the draw than the other three Grand Slams.

The Indo-Pak Express made its last stop at the United States Open on Friday. Rohan Bopanna of India and Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan, the No. 5 doubles team, fell in the semifinals to the sixth-seeded team from Poland, Mariusz Fyrstenberg and Marcin Matkowski, 6-2, 7-6 (4).
In this Fashion Week exclusive, T documents the making of a collection-defining dress.

Felipe Oliveira Baptista had a nice debut at Lacoste this morning with a collection that featured women's looks largely based on rugby shirts, some cool outerwear pieces and, for men, a larger-than-usual piqué used on blazers and polo shirts that looked nice and breathable. Mr. Baptista, who is Portuguese by birth, shows his own line in Paris and took over Lacoste this season from Chistophe Lemaire, who scooted over to Hermès.

Here is something you do not expect to see at a Prabal Gurung fashion show: Nicki Minaj, the colorful hip-hop star who gives Lady Gaga a run for her money in the outrageous attire department, making a slow entrance with John Demsey, the carefully groomed, straight-faced Estée Lauder executive, and followed by an entourage of men wearing black T-shirts that said "$WAG." Ms. Minaj, who will appear in a new MAC Viva Glam campaign, wore a bikini top that was half hot pink and half purple, some crazy graffiti-covered tights, a silver ballerina skirt and, in her big curly blonde hair, an iridescent pink bow that matched the chain of her necklace that had attached to it a hot pink pendant in the shape of a pretzel.
Ferry
Nearly 200 people drowned when an overloaded ferry capsized off east Africa as it sailed from Zanzibar to Pemba island, police said on Saturday.

Corporations are hiring popular students to promote their brand on campus. At the University of North Carolina, American Eagle helps first-year students move-in, while Target hosts the inaugural party

"We usually have a strong beauty concept," said the stylist Natasha Royt backstage at Mandy Coon. "This time it's modern, approachable, realistic, low maintenance-- cool. We want to let the graphic, modern clothes speak for themselves." Last season's wig-wrapped hair and black, fringed, pastel falls turned into "effortless glamour" this season, according to Rolando Beauchamp. Loose waves came by way of Bumble + Bumble Gel, a blow dry, and then a one-inch curling iron wrapped at the shaft of the hair, all set with Bumble + Bumble Grooming Creme and roughed up with BB Texture for a messy, matte finish. The last step ensured that nothing was "too pretty or too shiny." Coon's color-blocked looks were translated into Mark Rothko-inspired, multi-step eyes at the hands of the makeup artist Francelle Daly for NARS. Lavender-grey Lhasa was the primary shadow. "I'm obsessed with this shade," Daly said. "It's rarely used for spring/summer collections." She also added a trio of pinks with an icy tone at both corners of the eye. The Rue Bonaparte Larger Than Life Eyeliner pencil, a natural beige, was used to neutralize under the eye while white Santa Monica Boulevard lined inside. Madison Avenue grey was drawn as triangles on the outer edge of the lid. Without mascara on the bottom lashes, this all contributed to a "special effect" accompanied by a raspberry lip. An effect that caused one model to comment, "I look like I've been crying." Her friend countered, "No, you look beautiful."

If only it had started raining an hour earlier, as the look for both hair and makeup at Helmut Lang's first runway show - with Nicole and Michael Colovos at the helm - was described in one word: "wet." Lisa Butler explained the effect created with Temptu Airpod shadow to the brow and Champagne airbrush gloss at the lash as "jump out of shower" makeup. It follows that nails were simply Priti's pink Coronation. The theme was carried over with Paul Hanlon for Catwalk by TIGI's undone knots. Hair at the lower half of the head was left long and loose with a final shot of Your Highness Weightless Shine Spray. "It's a morning show, so everyone comes with clean hair," Mr. Hanlon said. "That's the opposite of what we're doing." Let the rain begin.
Homes in and around Binghamton, N.Y. were devastated by the record-high floodwaters of local rivers.
The architect Daniel Libeskind reflects on his Op-Ed from June 23, 2005, about his embattled master plan for rebuilding ground zero.
Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Rohan Bopanna of India discuss how friendship helps them succeed as a doubles team.

"It was really embarrassing," said Revlon's Global Artistic Director, Gucci Westman, dressed in a tweed aqua blazer, baggy white pants and leopard slippers backstage at Rag & Bone. "My husband (Rag & Bone designer David Neville) called and said, 'Where are you? We need the turquoise trousers for the show.'" By accident, Westman had selected a look that made it into the final collection, instead of an edit, to wear today, a mistake that was quickly corrected. "It's the strongest Spring, yet," she said explaining her excitement at the '70s surf vacation and 90s rave culture-inspired pieces. She chose a minimal makeup look, so as not to compete with the bright colors of the clothes. Eyes were simply taupe Revlon 16H shadow in Addictive with a touch of Sueded Brow liner. Cheeks were tinted with a light bronzer and blush in Tawny Peach while lips were pale pink, coated with shine and patted with powder. "Personally, I don't think lip gloss is cool." What is cool-- and consistently Rag & Bone-- appears to be grey nails. Jin Soon Choi took last season's slate to a lighter shade of concrete- Revlon's Smoky Canvas or Hazy. As for hair, Guido Palau admitted the idea was "effortless," though the process was anything but. "Eighty percent of the New York designers want ease. It always looks glamorous," he said. To achieve this, Palau tightly braided the underside of the models' hair and then added extensions for length to create the illusion of fineness. He then used Redken Satinwear all over damp hair which he dried with a Mason Pearson brush and Sultra tools. The hair was then clamped at the neck with a Velcro strap to create a bob-like effect. Ah, this explains the rave reference.

Friday night, after checking out a cheeky and borderline shameful Parke & Ronen runway show that suggested the male modeling industry may soon be facing its own steroid scandal, I popped over to Jason Wu's afterparty at Adour in the St. Regis Hotel. After muscle-bound mutants in skimpy swimwear, it was a pleasure to see some grown-ups in evening attire. Nacho Figueras and Delfina Blaquier looked smashing, he in a sharp black suit, she in a one-shouldered black dress, standing next to a D.J. booth that was covered over with hydrangea blossoms. I almost had my appetite back when I picked up what appeared to be a mint-colored petit four, only to bite into a watercress-wrapped piece of salmon.

Google took the unusual step of warning Gmail users in Iran to "secure their accounts," a week after an unidentified hacker generated fake Web site verification certificates that may have allowed the Iranian state to monitor communications by its citizens, including dissidents.

Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Bull tells T about the struggles of staying in shape during Fashion Week. "I really do try my hardest to eat as healthily aspossible," Bull says. "It gets really hard when you're flying two nights a week and staying in hotels." Sigh.

In the category of unexpected Grand Slam champions, it would be hard to top the fresh-faced pair that captured the 2011 mixed doubles trophy at the U.S. Open. Nineteen-year-old Melanie Oudin and 18-year-old Jack Sock, a wild card entry playing together for the first time, beat No. 8 seeds Gisela Dulko and Eduardo Schwank of Argentina 7-6(4), 4-6, 10-8 Friday evening to give the United States its first championship of the tournament.

Following a script eerily similar to that of the U.S. Open semifinal the two played last year, Novak Djokovic saved two set points to defeat Roger Federer, 6-7(7), 4-6, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, booking a spot in his second consecutive Open final.

KANSAS CITY, Kan. -- It has been lauded as perhaps the best soccer stadium in the country, but Sporting Kansas City's Livestrong Sporting Park has received some negative attention recently for one of its most integral parts: the grass playing surface.

After a summer of dispiriting headlines, one piece of news made me yelp with joy: Philip Levine was named poet laureate of the United States. I was happy because I have loved his sublime, subversive poems for years; now, more people would read his work. And I was happy because the new poet laureate loves tennis, and was a pretty good player.

Every country in which Formula One has a race attracts a certain number of local residents who are not seen at other races. Phil Hill would often come all the way from the United States to visit the race at Monza, where he won the world title - as I mention in today's F1 preview. Monza also tends to attract Luca di Montezemolo, the Ferrari president who occasionally visits other races.

President Obama, in his speech on Thursday before a joint session of Congress, promised to deploy the power of the federal government to induce small businesses to hire out-of-work Americans. But even some of the small-business owners who watched the speech live in the House chamber at the White House's invitation said they would not be swayed by the carrots the president proposed to dangle.

I was recently in Copenhagen, where I took a sneak peek at the Coffee Collective's new coffee bar in Torvehallerne, a gastro-complex of modernist glass sheds that opened last week. Copenhagen's amenities might be the envy of the civilized world - that airport, those parks, a network of bike paths so comprehensive and easy to use that cars are almost pointless - but until Torvehallerne, the city didn't have a central food hall.

I was walking recently with a friend near Stuyvesant Town, on the East Side of Manhattan, when we spied a low-lying plant, about knee-high, growing just outside an apartment building. The leaves gave off the unmistakable scent of gasoline that is characteristic of epazote. I immediately considered the culinary possibilities: guacamole, quesadillas or black-bean dip?

Zalmai Ahad, known professionally as Zalmai, is an Afghan photographer. Now 47, he moved to Switzerland when he was 15. He has been photographing Afghanistan for almost 10 years.
